description: The Cisco Certified Network Associate (CCNA) is the most well known Cisco certification path. It takes the general networking theory from the CCENT certification and applies it in real world scenarios. It moves beyond configuring individual devices into more complex territory often requiring the configuration of numerous devices to create a robust and optimized network. While studying for this certification, you will revisit the routing and switching topics from the CCENT in more depth as you learn about and implement the advanced features of each technology.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review the vlan fundamentals and vlan configuration.  They show the requirements in configuring in the extended vlan requirement. Lastly, they show how to configure vlans in the lab environment.
episodes.title: Configure VLANs

That there is gonna be a default VLAN

When you actually have that default VLAN,

Okay, so when we see something like this,

First, you'll actually see VLAN 1,

00:04:38.440 --> 00:04:41.560

And then 1002 through 1005,
they're actually gonna

81
00:04:45.770 --> 00:04:49.520
be these VLANs that

00:04:49.520 --> 00:04:53.960
But the other ones,

the 2 through 1001, those are not created.

And the 1006 through 4094,

But the switches will

So those are the default configurations

of the box in terms of configuration and

122
00:07:06.190 --> 00:07:08.340
Now, when we do something like this, and

123
00:07:08.340 --> 00:07:12.975
once we get that, what you're gonna see
and I mention this right out of the box

124
00:07:12.975 --> 00:07:18.190
before is that every single port, physical

125
00:07:18.190 --> 00:07:22.120
So that means once you plug in the switch

126
00:07:22.120 --> 00:07:26.420

127
00:07:26.420 --> 00:07:29.890
Once the light settle down on everything,

00:07:29.890 --> 00:07:34.390
and Ethernet cable and plug it to

129
00:07:34.390 --> 00:07:37.620
And it will begin switching

00:07:38.650 --> 00:07:42.540
So that's the goal and
the idea when you start seeing that.

131
00:07:42.540 --> 00:07:43.870
So it is there.

132
00:07:43.870 --> 00:07:48.760
But there are also virtual ports
that exist on the machine and

00:07:48.760 --> 00:07:50.790
they are normally shut down by default.

134
00:07:50.790 --> 00:07:54.353
Now, not every switch does this and

135
00:07:54.353 --> 00:07:57.179
So let me show you what
I'm talking about there.

136
00:07:57.179 --> 00:08:02.594
If we got back to our practice labs
here Let me kind of move this dow,

137
00:08:02.594 --> 00:08:06.680
just a little bit and
we'll zoom in to help us out.

138
00:08:06.680 --> 00:08:15.340
Now we go back here and now I can type
in show If I could spell interface.

139
00:08:15.340 --> 00:08:19.226
Show interface,
I need another option here.

140
00:08:19.226 --> 00:08:24.740
Show ip interface brief,

141
00:08:24.740 --> 00:08:29.100
I can now take a look at the idea of
some of these different ones here, okay?

142
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:31.620
Normally when you see
something like Vlan1,

143
00:08:31.620 --> 00:08:35.860
that is considered a virtual interface for
us.

144
00:08:35.860 --> 00:08:40.790
And these ports normally out of the box
by the older switches that I know about,

145
00:08:40.790 --> 00:08:42.830
they're normally shut off by default.

00:08:42.830 --> 00:08:45.070
But notice,
this one's actually already up.

147
00:08:45.070 --> 00:08:48.770
So in this case on this particular

00:08:48.770 --> 00:08:51.980
it is up by default instead.

149
00:08:51.980 --> 00:08:55.777
So normally when you see like VLAN1,
VLAN2, VLAN3, etc as you go on,

150
00:08:55.777 --> 00:08:58.800
they are normally shut down on
some of the older switches.

151
00:08:58.800 --> 00:09:01.030
But here you may do that.

152
00:09:01.030 --> 00:09:05.544
And even if you do configure IP addresses
on these virtual interfaces here,

153
00:09:05.544 --> 00:09:07.588
normally you also just go ahead and

154
00:09:07.588 --> 00:09:11.833
issue a no shut down command to
ensure that they're up anyways, okay?

155
00:09:11.833 --> 00:09:15.875
So that's normally what you end up
do seeing when you have to configure

156
00:09:15.875 --> 00:09:17.606
something like that as well.

157
00:09:17.606 --> 00:09:20.600
And we just wanna make sure that we
understand the defaults that come out of

158
00:09:20.600 --> 00:09:22.450
the box when this is happening.

159
00:09:22.450 --> 00:09:25.740
Also, there's another concept
that we need to make sure of.

160
00:09:25.740 --> 00:09:28.710
Even though we've reviewed
it inside of the Cisco CCENT

161
00:09:28.710 --> 00:09:30.560
we're again reviewing it now.

162
00:09:30.560 --> 00:09:34.520
There is the default VLAN which we already
told you about at the very beginning which

163
00:09:34.520 --> 00:09:35.640
is VLAN1, okay?

164
00:09:36.680 --> 00:09:42.110
Now when we start putting data onto
VLAN1 as we plug information in,

165
00:09:42.110 --> 00:09:45.060
we're not really thinking
about configuring other VLANs.

166
00:09:45.060 --> 00:09:49.550
So in that sense, there is no,
what we call, VLAN tagging going on.

167
00:09:49.550 --> 00:09:53.180
So we don't send information
out that's tagged with VLAN1.

168
00:09:53.180 --> 00:09:55.700
It just has no tagging information.

169
00:09:55.700 --> 00:09:58.490
So therefore, it can go across
the link to another switch.

170
00:09:58.490 --> 00:10:02.400
And there's no tagging information on
the other side that it has to read.

171
00:10:02.400 --> 00:10:07.220
But technically, that is because
it is also, at the same time,

172
00:10:07.220 --> 00:10:11.980
from right out of the factory
itself the native VLAN.

173
00:10:11.980 --> 00:10:16.940
The native VLAN is the reason
that there is no tagging.

174
00:10:16.940 --> 00:10:19.928
In 802.1q, that type of encapsulation,

175
00:10:19.928 --> 00:10:23.670
technically it's not
encapsulation it's VLAN tagging.

176
00:10:23.670 --> 00:10:28.603
In 802.1q, They used a concept of a native
VLAN which is a VLAN that doesn't

177
00:10:28.603 --> 00:10:32.580
allow for tagging information
if you're in that VLAN.

178
00:10:32.580 --> 00:10:36.090
So because there's only one VLAN,
default VLAN,

179
00:10:36.090 --> 00:10:41.140
VLAN 1 on the switch at the beginning,
it also has to be

180
00:10:41.140 --> 00:10:45.990
the native VLAN but it doesn't mean that
it always has to be the native VLAN.

181
00:10:45.990 --> 00:10:49.010
In other words, we can switch this and

182
00:10:49.010 --> 00:10:52.990
choose a different VLAN to
be a native VLAN so that

183
00:10:52.990 --> 00:10:57.986
one day you may see on a different switch,
where the native VLAN is not VLAN1.

184
00:10:57.986 --> 00:11:00.500
It may be VLAN93 or 37 or

185
00:11:00.500 --> 00:11:05.250
45 who cares, whatever the number is,
it doesn't really matter.

186
00:11:05.250 --> 00:11:08.855
And that means that traffic going
across that once we assign a trunk,

187
00:11:08.855 --> 00:11:13.400
and we start doing that, we can use
that as actually saying no VLAN or

188
00:11:13.400 --> 00:11:16.820
no tabs are gonna be on that particular
VLAN, that's also gonna happen.

189
00:11:17.970 --> 00:11:22.030
Once everything is configured and
you start configuring VLANs,

190
00:11:22.030 --> 00:11:27.360
the information though is generally gonna
be stored in Flash, in the VLAN database.

191
00:11:27.360 --> 00:11:31.847
The VLAN database is stored in
a file here called vlan.dat and

192
00:11:31.847 --> 00:11:37.960
this is very important for something
that you have to remember for a switch.

193
00:11:37.960 --> 00:11:39.830
We tend to buy switches,

194
00:11:39.830 --> 00:11:42.540
if they're brand new of course we
don't expect anything to be on them.

195
00:11:42.540 --> 00:11:47.950
But if we happen to buy let’s say used
equipment which is a very popular market,

196
00:11:47.950 --> 00:11:49.150
reselling market today.

197
00:11:50.320 --> 00:11:54.510
Sometimes you'll end up getting a switch,
in which well, it's been used and

198
00:11:54.510 --> 00:11:58.460
the only thing that they verified is that
it turned, and they could get access, so

199
00:11:58.460 --> 00:11:59.860
it's fully functional.

200
00:11:59.860 --> 00:12:03.950
But it could be that there's still
VLAN information on that switch.

201
00:12:03.950 --> 00:12:08.050
So one of the things that you want to make
sure of before you start configuring it,

202
00:12:08.050 --> 00:12:10.540
is you wanna wipe it all the way
back to the factory default.

203
00:12:10.540 --> 00:12:12.860
In other words get rid
of the startup-config.

204
00:12:12.860 --> 00:12:14.570
Get rid of all that stuff.

205
00:12:14.570 --> 00:12:19.430
But that doesn't necessarily get rid of
the vlan.dat and the reason why is that,

206
00:12:19.430 --> 00:12:22.250
this is stored in flash.

207
00:12:22.250 --> 00:12:23.460
So you have to go in and

208
00:12:23.460 --> 00:12:28.370
manually also delete the vlan.dat out if
you actually reboot and you actually still

209
00:12:28.370 --> 00:12:31.610
see other VLANs that are there,
it's because you didn't get rid of that.

210
00:12:31.610 --> 00:12:35.110
And that means that's not reset
to factory default anymore.

211
00:12:35.110 --> 00:12:39.971
So make sure you pay attention to some
of these subtle details that we did

212
00:12:39.971 --> 00:12:44.070
mention during the Cisco CCENT
exam show as we did this.

213
00:12:44.070 --> 00:12:46.440

00:12:57.982 --> 00:13:01.850
sure that you're focusing on just

00:13:01.850 --> 00:13:05.106
Because this is what helped you to
kind of get everything settled in.

00:13:05.106 --> 00:13:09.841
Cuz without these foundations it's really
hard for you to pedal to the next level

222
00:13:09.841 --> 00:13:14.690
which is where the CC&A routing and
switching show is taking us, all right?

223
00:13:14.690 --> 00:13:17.430
So now that we understand
that default configuration,

224
00:13:17.430 --> 00:13:21.660
okay, let's go over to the idea of
what a user configuration means, okay?

225
00:13:21.660 --> 00:13:22.220
So this means what?

226
00:13:22.220 --> 00:13:25.500
We're no longer just following what's
out of the box, this is now you and

227
00:13:25.500 --> 00:13:29.020
me getting into the command line,
just like I showed you, and

228
00:13:29.020 --> 00:13:33.060
now configuring it or manipulating it or
administratively changing it.

229
00:13:33.060 --> 00:13:35.040
Whatever you wanna call it, okay,

230
00:13:35.040 --> 00:13:39.050
to configure it the way that I need
it inside of my network, okay?

231
00:13:39.050 --> 00:13:42.360
So when I do something like that,
here's the way it ends up changing.

232
00:13:42.360 --> 00:13:44.760
Oops, don't let me tell
you the wrong way here.

233
00:13:44.760 --> 00:13:47.080
Let me zoom in [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

234
00:13:47.080 --> 00:13:49.260
>> I zoomed out completely, okay?

235
00:13:49.260 --> 00:13:54.270
So instead of maybe perhaps one VLAN
that I might have, I may go ahead and

236
00:13:54.270 --> 00:13:59.690
configure it to where I have
additional VLANs besides VLAN1, okay?

237
00:13:59.690 --> 00:14:04.420
So when I do something like that, now
every port that's in there, even though

238
00:14:04.420 --> 00:14:10.620
it's by default inside of VLAN1,
I can reassign ports to specific VLANs.

239
00:14:10.620 --> 00:14:13.830
So I can take it out of that
general pool in VLAN1 and

240
00:14:13.830 --> 00:14:18.210
assign it to where I want to inside
of those individual VLANs as well.

241
00:14:18.210 --> 00:14:21.360
Now, when something like that
ends up happening, right?

242
00:14:21.360 --> 00:14:23.500
Now we have a single switch,

243
00:14:23.500 --> 00:14:26.430
single physical switch like
you see up here at the top.

244
00:14:26.430 --> 00:14:31.040
But now each one of these is
functioning as if on their own smaller

245
00:14:31.040 --> 00:14:35.140
owned the multiple switches, even though
they're on the same physical switch.

246
00:14:35.140 --> 00:14:37.230
So and that's why they
actually do function that way.

247
00:14:37.230 --> 00:14:40.370
We can treat them as if they're
actually different switches.

248
00:14:40.370 --> 00:14:43.730
And we also wanna remember that generally,
and I'm saying this,

249
00:14:43.730 --> 00:14:45.520
cuz we'll see this in the exam.

250
00:14:45.520 --> 00:14:49.360
Each VLAN is actually its
own broadcast domain.

251
00:14:49.360 --> 00:14:53.800
So that should actually indicate to you
that the endpoint addresses should have

252
00:14:53.800 --> 00:14:58.610
their own subnet as you start plugging
those devices into those VLANs as well.

253
00:14:58.610 --> 00:15:04.455
All right, now the other thing that we
also want to do in terms of review,

254
00:15:04.455 --> 00:15:07.870
right, is to remember that
multiple VLANs on the same switch,

255
00:15:07.870 --> 00:15:11.520
they cannot directly
communicate between VLANs.

256
00:15:11.520 --> 00:15:15.930
So even if you have port
FA0/1 in VLAN 100, and

257
00:15:15.930 --> 00:15:21.770
you have FA0/2, the one that's
directly under it in VLAN 200,

258
00:15:21.770 --> 00:15:26.360
they do not just get to communicate
directly on the switch itself,

259
00:15:26.360 --> 00:15:29.660
even though it's actually one
port on top of the other.

260
00:15:29.660 --> 00:15:31.790
That have to,
if you're gonna do something like that,

261
00:15:31.790 --> 00:15:33.180
if they're in two different VLANs.

262
00:15:33.180 --> 00:15:37.840
You need to go through a layer three
device such as of course a router or

263
00:15:37.840 --> 00:15:42.320
a Layer 3 switch to be able to
have them communicate, okay?

264
00:15:42.320 --> 00:15:45.780
So, you have to remember that
if that's what you want to do.

265
00:15:45.780 --> 00:15:48.180
Now, is there any other way around this?

266
00:15:48.180 --> 00:15:49.946
Well, technically yes.

267
00:15:49.946 --> 00:15:51.885
If you directly plug,

268
00:15:51.885 --> 00:15:57.706
in other words take that cable
going from fa01 going into fa02,

269
00:15:57.706 --> 00:16:02.623
and you have another port
on that's saying VLAN 200.

270
00:16:02.623 --> 00:16:07.344
Well yes, you now broken the boundary of
the VLANs itself and you can do that.

271
00:16:07.344 --> 00:16:11.301
But you wouldn't wanna do that, that's why
you configure it the way that you wanted

272
00:16:11.301 --> 00:16:13.603
to, so
you don't do things like that to do that.

273
00:16:13.603 --> 00:16:15.530
So, that's the other thing.

274
00:16:15.530 --> 00:16:19.308
When we also start configuring

which is right here available
to you as an ITProTV subscriber.

494
00:29:51.870 --> 00:29:55.490
Make sure you review those if you're now
still having problems remembering some of

495
00:29:55.490 --> 00:29:59.285
those concepts, cuz the only thing that's
gonna do is help you out as you do it now.

496
00:29:59.285 --> 00:30:00.785
Don't wait until the day
before the exam and

497
00:30:00.785 --> 00:30:04.865
go, I don't remember how to
actually create that extended VLAN.

498
00:30:04.865 --> 00:30:06.525
That's not the day to practice it,

499
00:30:06.525 --> 00:30:09.235
so just continue to do the practice
that you've been doing.

500
00:30:09.235 --> 00:30:12.585
Review these concepts, write down these
key notes that we're talking about,

501
00:30:12.585 --> 00:30:15.505
cuz these are good points that
you're gonna have to remember for

502
00:30:15.505 --> 00:30:18.047
the day of the exam.
>> As always, great advice,

503
00:30:18.047 --> 00:30:21.610
CCNA routing and switching exam 200-105.

504
00:30:21.610 --> 00:30:24.200
Gonna be a great series,
cuz this is the first one, and

505
00:30:24.200 --> 00:30:27.790
make sure your watch every single episode,
you're gonna be glad that you did.

506
00:30:27.790 --> 00:30:29.360
And by the way you'll be
in the course library,

507
00:30:29.360 --> 00:30:31.050
there's thousands of other videos there.

508
00:30:31.050 --> 00:30:34.136
And they are there to help you go further,
so check those out too.

509
00:30:34.136 --> 00:30:38.079
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
ITProTV is bingeworthy.

510
00:30:38.079 --> 00:30:40.509
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

511
00:30:40.509 --> 00:30:42.578
>> We will see you again soon.

512
00:30:42.578 --> 00:30:48.682
[MUSIC]

513
00:30:48.682 --> 00:30:50.700
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with configuring vlans.  Previously, they defined vlans on a switch.  Here they assign ports to different vlans and verify their working.  They discuss the use of default vlans and best practice of moving ports to an unused vlan.
episodes.title: Configure VLANs Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:02.643
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.643 --> 00:00:06.272
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.272 --> 00:00:08.478
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.478 --> 00:00:11.990
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.990 --> 00:00:14.443
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching an ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.443 --> 00:00:16.290
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.290 --> 00:00:22.130
I'm your host, Zach Memos, for
CCNA routing and switching exam 200-105.

8
00:00:22.130 --> 00:00:25.600
And this is configure VLANs, episode two.

9
00:00:25.600 --> 00:00:27.370
You saw episode one, didn't you?

10
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:28.055
You better.

11
00:00:28.055 --> 00:00:30.560
[LAUGH] And of course,
Ronnie Wong is here to help us out.

12
00:00:30.560 --> 00:00:31.760
Ronnie, good to see you again, sir.

13
00:00:31.760 --> 00:00:32.630
>> Well, thank you, Zack, for

14
00:00:32.630 --> 00:00:36.770
having me back as we continue in our
CCNA Routing and Switching show.

15
00:00:36.770 --> 00:00:40.080
We are in the middle of configuring VLANs.

16
00:00:40.080 --> 00:00:44.280
And in the last episode, we left off where
we had talked about some of the details

17
00:00:44.280 --> 00:00:47.700
of things that are easily forgotten
when we start configuring VLANs and

18
00:00:47.700 --> 00:00:49.000
some of those things.

19
00:00:49.000 --> 00:00:52.420
And so, we reviewed those because you
need those when you get ready for

20
00:00:52.420 --> 00:00:55.140
the exam,
as well as started the configuration here.

21
00:00:55.140 --> 00:00:58.777
And reminded you the goal and
the idea is to move through this

22
00:00:58.777 --> 00:01:03.448
material as quickly as you can,
especially it's review material for you.

23
00:01:03.448 --> 00:01:05.350
So that's what we want to do.

24
00:01:05.350 --> 00:01:08.886
But at the same time, we're not rushing
it just for the sake of rushing.

25
00:01:08.886 --> 00:01:12.322
What we want you to do is build speed,
but understand that at the same time.

26
00:01:12.322 --> 00:01:16.310
So I'll be moving slower than
normal as we explain this.

27
00:01:16.310 --> 00:01:17.490
But hopefully, again,

28
00:01:17.490 --> 00:01:20.220
you actually should be able to do
this on your own as well, okay?

29
00:01:20.220 --> 00:01:24.420
So, Zach, in our last episode, we went
ahead and during our lab as we started

30
00:01:24.420 --> 00:01:26.810
doing this, we configured two VLANs
>> Right.

31
00:01:26.810 --> 00:01:29.650
>> One VLAN 100 that we called management,

32
00:01:29.650 --> 00:01:30.570
I believe
>> Yep.

33
00:01:30.570 --> 00:01:31.790
>> And then, VLAN 200 which we called

34
00:01:31.790 --> 00:01:32.580
sales
>> That's right.

35
00:01:32.580 --> 00:01:37.010
>> But I also showed you that there
was actually kind of a lack of

36
00:01:37.010 --> 00:01:38.370
interfaces in those VLANs.

37
00:01:38.370 --> 00:01:41.587
Let's take a look at the screen here.

38
00:01:41.587 --> 00:01:44.087
I couldn't remember what I was gonna call,
at at the screen, and

39
00:01:44.087 --> 00:01:45.505
show you what we're talking about.

40
00:01:45.505 --> 00:01:46.376
So here it is.

41
00:01:46.376 --> 00:01:49.630
VLANs 200 and 100 are here, but
notice there are no interfaces.

42
00:01:49.630 --> 00:01:53.950
So even though VLAN creation is done, it
doesn't mean it's gonna effectively work

43
00:01:53.950 --> 00:01:57.020
if you do not have VLAN
interfaces assigned to them.

44
00:01:57.020 --> 00:01:59.580
And that's what we have to do now,
is make sure we get them assigned.

45
00:01:59.580 --> 00:02:01.870
>> And by interfaces, you're talking
about the physical ports, right?

46
00:02:01.870 --> 00:02:04.320
>> Right, so
right here where they're listed as ports,

47
00:02:04.320 --> 00:02:09.140
we're essentially gonna move some of
these down here to VLAN 100 and 200, and

48
00:02:09.140 --> 00:02:12.270
make sure that we understand
how that is going to be done.

49
00:02:12.270 --> 00:02:16.300
So let's go ahead and configure this,
which to do so, get access into our

50
00:02:16.300 --> 00:02:19.750
privilege exempt mode, and then into
our global configuration, as well.

51
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:24.230
So we'll do our configure terminal, too.

52
00:02:24.230 --> 00:02:29.086
And what we're going to do first is that

53
00:02:29.086 --> 00:02:33.795
we're gonna assign FA0/22, and

54
00:02:33.795 --> 00:02:37.925
FA0/24, into VLAN 200.

55
00:02:37.925 --> 00:02:41.098
Actually, we're going to do 1 and 2 first,
and we're going to sign that into 100.

56
00:02:41.098 --> 00:02:46.195
And then, FA0/22, and
0/24 into VLAN 200 here.

57
00:02:46.195 --> 00:02:47.348
That's what we're going to do.

58
00:02:47.348 --> 00:02:50.310
I kind of just read that a little bit
backward, make sure I get that right.

59
00:02:50.310 --> 00:02:56.289
Now, if I have FA0/1 and FA0/2, and
they're consecutive in that way,

60
00:02:56.289 --> 00:02:59.822
I can,
instead of doing each individual one,

61
00:02:59.822 --> 00:03:05.460
use a VLAN range command interface
range command, I should say.

62
00:03:05.460 --> 00:03:06.830
So what am I talking about?

63
00:03:06.830 --> 00:03:15.040
Well, interface range,
and then fast Ethernet.

64
00:03:15.040 --> 00:03:18.360
And we're gonna start off with 1/0/1.

65
00:03:18.360 --> 00:03:23.550
And you have to remember that you
have to do a space dash space 2.

66
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:26.710
And those spaces are important.

67
00:03:26.710 --> 00:03:31.310
I know it sounds silly, but it is a syntax
error if you don't do it correctly.

68
00:03:31.310 --> 00:03:32.660
So we'll go ahead and do that and

69
00:03:32.660 --> 00:03:37.230
watch and verify that you actually do
see the change here in the prompt.

70
00:03:37.230 --> 00:03:41.410
Notice it says config-if-range,
is what you begin to see.

71
00:03:41.410 --> 00:03:44.620
And this will now allow to be
configure what one time but

72
00:03:44.620 --> 00:03:46.610
affect both of these ports.

73
00:03:46.610 --> 00:03:47.950
So what do I want to do here?

74
00:03:47.950 --> 00:03:50.415
I want to change them
both to access ports.

75
00:03:50.415 --> 00:03:54.060
Its it's gonna to be
switchport mode access.

76
00:03:55.130 --> 00:03:57.890
When we start assigning
ports in the VLANs,

77
00:03:57.890 --> 00:04:00.780
we want them to be what
we call access ports.

78
00:04:00.780 --> 00:04:04.230
You do not want them to be trunk ports,
you want them to be access ports.

79
00:04:04.230 --> 00:04:07.510
And because we're actually
setting it as mode access,

80
00:04:07.510 --> 00:04:11.400
we're simply telling it don't
do anything that's dynamic.

81
00:04:11.400 --> 00:04:15.800
We're saying that we are now manually
configuring this to be an access port

82
00:04:15.800 --> 00:04:17.550
is what we are doing here, okay?

83
00:04:17.550 --> 00:04:21.730
Now, there is another command, we don't
tend to actually use it in this lab,

84
00:04:21.730 --> 00:04:24.990
I'm gonna add it in because I like to.

85
00:04:24.990 --> 00:04:26.392
You can also do switchport.

86
00:04:30.167 --> 00:04:30.921
No.

87
00:04:32.729 --> 00:04:35.620
Negotiate as well, okay.

88
00:04:35.620 --> 00:04:37.770
Now, we'll normally do that with trunks,
but

89
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:40.140
we can also do it with
interface ports here.

90
00:04:40.140 --> 00:04:44.630
When you manually set the access ports
here like this, you're essentially saying,

91
00:04:44.630 --> 00:04:48.270
don't do anything dynamic, don't try and
negotiate, don't do anything like that.

92
00:04:48.270 --> 00:04:51.460
Now, you're also telling it,
essentially on these ports,

93
00:04:51.460 --> 00:04:54.410
turn off any possible negotiation,
is what you're doing.

94
00:04:54.410 --> 00:04:55.770
It's perfectly fine.

95
00:04:55.770 --> 00:04:57.630
We can do that here, too.

96
00:04:57.630 --> 00:05:02.580
And because we've already created
the VLANs, then we can do the next demand

97
00:05:02.580 --> 00:05:08.760
which is gonna be switchport,
if I can spell it, switchport access.

98
00:05:08.760 --> 00:05:10.570
And this will be in VLAN100.

99
00:05:11.730 --> 00:05:15.280
So now, both of those ports
will be assigned to VLAN100.

100
00:05:15.280 --> 00:05:17.400
So we can do that.

101
00:05:17.400 --> 00:05:19.177
Now, let's try this again,

102
00:05:19.177 --> 00:05:24.120
but now, I have two other interfaces
which is gonna be FA0/22 a And 0/24.

103
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:28.060
Well, those are not in
a contiguous range together.

104
00:05:28.060 --> 00:05:31.593
So in that one I'd go ahead and
assign them individually instead.

105
00:05:31.593 --> 00:05:37.112
So here, Not range, but iInterface

106
00:05:37.112 --> 00:05:42.524
fastethernet 1/0/22.

107
00:05:44.450 --> 00:05:50.734
And then, switchport mode access,

108
00:05:50.734 --> 00:05:56.410
and switchport nonegotiate.

109
00:05:56.410 --> 00:05:58.960
Now, do you have to do the nonegotiate?

110
00:05:58.960 --> 00:06:00.020
Not really, okay?

111
00:06:00.020 --> 00:06:04.500
You really don't have to, but it's
always been a practice of mine because

112
00:06:04.500 --> 00:06:08.830
it really does at least gives me the sound
mind of being that it's not gonna try and

113
00:06:08.830 --> 00:06:09.710
negotiate with anything.

114
00:06:09.710 --> 00:06:11.720
Even if the other side
says let's negotiate,

115
00:06:11.720 --> 00:06:13.260
it's just gonna ignore it at this point.

116
00:06:13.260 --> 00:06:17.814
And we're gonna do switchport access

117
00:06:17.814 --> 00:06:23.910
VLAN200, is what we're gonna do.

118
00:06:23.910 --> 00:06:25.480
So just trying to show you this, right?

119
00:06:25.480 --> 00:06:29.660
As we start doing this individually, port
after port, you can see why the interface

120
00:06:29.660 --> 00:06:34.820
range command becomes a little bit more,
as much as you can, right?

121
00:06:34.820 --> 00:06:38.410
Quicker, because I've just created
the same configuration for

122
00:06:38.410 --> 00:06:40.590
two ports using one set of commands.

123
00:06:40.590 --> 00:06:45.020
And now, individually, I'm having to,
well, create two different sets here.

124
00:06:45.020 --> 00:06:48.697
So now, I'm gonna use the abbreviation
this time to help speed up our process.

125
00:06:52.854 --> 00:06:54.410
And then same thing, switchport,

126
00:06:57.803 --> 00:07:03.750
nonegotiate And then,
we'll do the same thing.

127
00:07:03.750 --> 00:07:07.430
Switchport access VLAN 200.

128
00:07:07.430 --> 00:07:10.080
All right, now,

129
00:07:10.080 --> 00:07:14.790
on a switch in which you're not limited to
the interface and that type commands here,

130
00:07:14.790 --> 00:07:18.910
okay, the great thing is we could've
been even faster at this, Zach.

131
00:07:18.910 --> 00:07:22.210
The reason why is that we would
have had access to shortcut keys

132
00:07:22.210 --> 00:07:23.470
that would have worked.

133
00:07:23.470 --> 00:07:27.040
So I could have actually just simply
hit the up arrow a couple of times,

134
00:07:27.040 --> 00:07:30.560
and that would have brought back
up the interface originally here.

135
00:07:30.560 --> 00:07:32.860
The interface fastethernet 22.

136
00:07:32.860 --> 00:07:37.080
And then, all I would had to do is
actually change the set of last number,

137
00:07:37.080 --> 00:07:40.120
and that would have changed it to the 24.

138
00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:44.880
Then, I could have used the up
arrows again and just scrolled to

139
00:07:44.880 --> 00:07:47.630
switchport mode access, pressed Enter,
and it would have accepted it.

140
00:07:47.630 --> 00:07:51.601
The same thing to switchport nonegotiate,
and press Enter.

141
00:07:51.601 --> 00:07:54.322
And the same thing with access VLAN200,
and

142
00:07:54.322 --> 00:07:56.781
it would have actually done that quicker.

143
00:07:56.781 --> 00:08:00.498
But because I'm limited to this box,
I had to individually type them in.

144
00:08:00.498 --> 00:08:03.319
And it makes sense in the practice
labs and what they've done.

145
00:08:03.319 --> 00:08:05.590
They want you to type in
the commands manually.

146
00:08:05.590 --> 00:08:08.850
They don't want you to use the shortcuts
because it's easy to get hooked on that

147
00:08:08.850 --> 00:08:13.490
and you're not guaranteed on the exam
whether or not shortcuts will work or not.

148
00:08:13.490 --> 00:08:16.370
So it's better if you can learn all these
and then use the shortcuts when you

149
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:20.200
actually know that you've got the commands
down the way that you want to.

150
00:08:20.200 --> 00:08:23.370
So that's what we want to be able to do.

151
00:08:23.370 --> 00:08:25.217
Now, once we're done with this,

152
00:08:25.217 --> 00:08:28.090
we wanna do the same
verification that we did before.

153
00:08:28.090 --> 00:08:30.701
So let's go ahead and do that and

154
00:08:30.701 --> 00:08:35.840
now see if we still have
connectivity from, well, NYEDGE1.

155
00:08:35.840 --> 00:08:40.930
Now, in theory, we should not have
connectivity to everything anymore, okay?

156
00:08:40.930 --> 00:08:44.980
So some of these now have actually
been moved to their own ports in

157
00:08:44.980 --> 00:08:47.935
different VLANs is what
we're trying to say.

158
00:08:47.935 --> 00:08:49.680
Okay?
Now, before I do that, right?

159
00:08:49.680 --> 00:08:53.818
I just realized I did not verify
that those actually did end up in

160
00:08:53.818 --> 00:08:55.480
the proper VLAN.

161
00:08:55.480 --> 00:09:00.220
So I am kind of being
counter productive here.

162
00:09:00.220 --> 00:09:01.329
Cuz I could try and ping and

163
00:09:01.329 --> 00:09:05.060
one of the things it might be is that
I just didn't configure anything.

164
00:09:05.060 --> 00:09:08.040
So let's go ahead and
do a show vlan brief here.

165
00:09:10.050 --> 00:09:11.500
And I'll hit that up.

166
00:09:11.500 --> 00:09:14.750
And I just wanna verify that
the ports that I meant to assign

167
00:09:14.750 --> 00:09:16.710
are in their proper VLANs.

168
00:09:16.710 --> 00:09:18.590
And that's what you're seeing right here,
okay?

169
00:09:18.590 --> 00:09:21.680
That's exactly the ports that I
meant to assign right here and

170
00:09:21.680 --> 00:09:22.730
that's perfectly fine.

171
00:09:22.730 --> 00:09:25.810
As long as I know what those ports are,
we are good and we are ready to go.

172
00:09:25.810 --> 00:09:28.150
All right.

173
00:09:28.150 --> 00:09:31.990
So let's try this from NYEDGE1,
just like I said, for verification.

174
00:09:33.531 --> 00:09:37.780
All right, let's see if I could,
can I move that down?

175
00:09:37.780 --> 00:09:39.036
Maybe, maybe not.

176
00:09:39.036 --> 00:09:42.630
All right,
well we'll zoom in that a bit, okay?

177
00:09:44.847 --> 00:09:52.379
Come on, not to jerk around too much here.

178
00:09:54.373 --> 00:09:57.060
So let's do it again.

179
00:09:57.060 --> 00:09:57.970
So ping 192.168.16.2.

180
00:09:57.970 --> 00:10:01.620
And that is successful when
we start pinging 16.2.

181
00:10:01.620 --> 00:10:05.293
And the reason why is that NYVAN1 and
the NYEDGE1,

182
00:10:05.293 --> 00:10:09.231
which is what we're on,
they're both on VLAN100.

183
00:10:09.231 --> 00:10:13.270
So that makes sense that it should ping.

184
00:10:13.270 --> 00:10:18.354
So now if I do ping 192.168.16.3 here,
well,

185
00:10:18.354 --> 00:10:23.438
16.3 which is NYACCESS1,
well, this one is actually

186
00:10:23.438 --> 00:10:28.127
in VLAN200 and so
this one should not succeed here.

187
00:10:28.127 --> 00:10:35.611
And ping 192.168.16.4.

188
00:10:35.611 --> 00:10:38.200
I can't remember my numbers anymore.

189
00:10:38.200 --> 00:10:43.161
That's a hard thing,
this one should also not be

190
00:10:43.161 --> 00:10:47.161
because those are also in VLAN200.

191
00:10:47.161 --> 00:10:52.020
So we are verifying now that the VLANs
are operating the way that they should be

192
00:10:52.020 --> 00:10:53.360
operating.

193
00:10:53.360 --> 00:10:55.200
But if you're not sure,

194
00:10:55.200 --> 00:11:00.230
you can always go then to the other
machine which is in the other VLAN.

195
00:11:00.230 --> 00:11:03.290
So we'll start here from NYACCESS1 and

196
00:11:03.290 --> 00:11:05.557
we'll do the same ping pattern,
that's what we'll do.

197
00:11:07.880 --> 00:11:12.837
So in NYACCESS1, if I now try and
ping 192.168.16.1,

198
00:11:12.837 --> 00:11:18.230
well, that's NYEDGE1,
which is in VLAN100, and I'm VLAN200.

199
00:11:18.230 --> 00:11:20.699
Well, now, I should be blocking that.

200
00:11:26.239 --> 00:11:28.720
And we'll just try and verify.

201
00:11:28.720 --> 00:11:30.530
And this one should also
end up being blocked.

202
00:11:38.040 --> 00:11:44.284
And then I have one more which
is gonna be NYCORE1 which is .4.

203
00:11:46.530 --> 00:11:49.860
This one, though, should be successful,
because that's in the same VLAN.

204
00:11:49.860 --> 00:11:52.260
So it allows us to go ahead and
configure this and

205
00:11:52.260 --> 00:11:54.520
verify that these VLANs are up and
working.

And normally when we do this
we assign the data vlan first.

433
00:25:45.910 --> 00:25:52.075
So switch port access vlan 60.

434
00:25:52.075 --> 00:25:56.486
And then switchport access,
or not access, voice,

435
00:25:56.486 --> 00:26:00.122
jimminey, I was about
to do that one wrong.

436
00:26:00.122 --> 00:26:05.411
>> [LAUGH]
>> vlan 50.

437
00:26:05.411 --> 00:26:10.073
All right, so now we have that one port,
actually in two different vlans,

438
00:26:10.073 --> 00:26:12.740
which I told you couldn't be done.

439
00:26:12.740 --> 00:26:17.548
But one is an access port, and one is
a voice port, or voice vlan instead.

440
00:26:21.343 --> 00:26:24.919
Show interface fa1/0/12 and

441
00:26:24.919 --> 00:26:29.572
we're gonna do
the switchport command here.

442
00:26:32.258 --> 00:26:33.590
If I typed it in correctly.

443
00:26:33.590 --> 00:26:35.552
All right, cool I did.

444
00:26:35.552 --> 00:26:37.103
That's kind of a first for me, okay?

445
00:26:37.103 --> 00:26:39.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> So with that particular, yeah,

446
00:26:39.830 --> 00:26:42.080
my tryping is atrocious.

447
00:26:42.080 --> 00:26:45.780
So this is where we can verify
something that we weren't

448
00:26:45.780 --> 00:26:48.260
actually thinking about being able to do.

449
00:26:48.260 --> 00:26:52.399
Notice that there are now actually
two vlans on this one port,

450
00:26:52.399 --> 00:26:54.958
which I told you, you can't do this.

451
00:26:54.958 --> 00:26:57.446
>> Right.
>> But there are times when you can and

452
00:26:57.446 --> 00:27:02.281
that's the time, is when you're gonna use
a voice vlan and a data vlan together,

453
00:27:02.281 --> 00:27:04.430
then you can do this, okay?

454
00:27:04.430 --> 00:27:13.048
So if we now show interface status.

455
00:27:18.549 --> 00:27:20.452
Now notice the way that it shows up,

456
00:27:20.452 --> 00:27:23.943
this one just shows 60 here okay,
but it doesn't seem to show,

457
00:27:23.943 --> 00:27:28.170
let's see it doesn't show the 50
down here a little bit more, nope.

458
00:27:28.170 --> 00:27:30.671
So you can even see that
on the interface itself,

459
00:27:30.671 --> 00:27:32.992
it actually does just
see the ID of vlan 60.

460
00:27:32.992 --> 00:27:36.090
I wasn't sure if it actually
showed vlan 50 and 60 here.

461
00:27:36.090 --> 00:27:40.230
But this one actually does show vlan 60,
but that doesn't mean that it's not there.

462
00:27:40.230 --> 00:27:41.050
So let's see.

463
00:27:41.050 --> 00:27:42.080
Let's do this.

464
00:27:42.080 --> 00:27:43.730
Show vlan brief now.

465
00:27:43.730 --> 00:27:47.800
Let's see what vlan brief
shows us about this, okay?

466
00:27:47.800 --> 00:27:48.480
There you go.

467
00:27:48.480 --> 00:27:51.820
Here's another way that you can
confirm that you've actually done this

468
00:27:51.820 --> 00:27:52.900
correctly as well.

469
00:27:52.900 --> 00:27:58.100
We notice that right there That is,
excuse me,

470
00:27:58.100 --> 00:28:02.913
fa1/0/12 in both vlan 50 and 60.

471
00:28:02.913 --> 00:28:03.426
>> Well done.

472
00:28:03.426 --> 00:28:05.550
>> Remember that this is actually key.

473
00:28:05.550 --> 00:28:09.975
I'm showing you this on purpose because
of what I told you at the beginning of

474
00:28:09.975 --> 00:28:10.607
part one.

475
00:28:10.607 --> 00:28:15.170
You can't assign a single port
to more than one vlan, right?

476
00:28:15.170 --> 00:28:18.990
Well, technically no,
not to access vlan, you can't.

477
00:28:18.990 --> 00:28:21.920
But the very fact is on a voice vlan and

478
00:28:21.920 --> 00:28:26.590
a data vlan, yes you can and
here is to prove that it works.

479
00:28:26.590 --> 00:28:30.330
So don't be surprised if you
see something like this.

480
00:28:30.330 --> 00:28:34.068
And you're actually wondering like,
that's impossible, I can't do that.

481
00:28:34.068 --> 00:28:36.990
Well check out and verify the name.

482
00:28:36.990 --> 00:28:40.790
Most of the time people name the vlans
'with something that is descriptive,

483
00:28:40.790 --> 00:28:41.470
that makes sense.

484
00:28:41.470 --> 00:28:43.220
They are not just going to say Data2,

485
00:28:43.220 --> 00:28:45.750
it's going to be something that
is going to be distinguishing.

486
00:28:45.750 --> 00:28:49.630
And that will help you to know
that this is a voice vlan as well.

487
00:28:49.630 --> 00:28:54.080
The great thing about this is that now you
don't need two separate cables, one for

488
00:28:54.080 --> 00:28:57.390
the phone, then taking up one
switch port and then one for

489
00:28:57.390 --> 00:28:59.950
your computer typing up the other
one on the switch itself,

490
00:28:59.950 --> 00:29:05.390
we're just taking up fa1/0/12 but
two devices are not plugged into it.

491
00:29:05.390 --> 00:29:09.620
So it conserves our port number in
terms of the density that we have.

492
00:29:09.620 --> 00:29:13.536
And that way we can use more devices
on that single switch to help us out as

493
00:29:13.536 --> 00:29:14.332
well, okay?

494
00:29:14.332 --> 00:29:19.953
So Zach at this point, this is really kind
of the end of our basic configuration and

495
00:29:19.953 --> 00:29:24.107
review of configuring vlans but
there's still a lot more for

496
00:29:24.107 --> 00:29:27.468
us to go in terms of LAN
switching technologies.

497
00:29:27.468 --> 00:29:30.696
We'll actually save that for
a different episode as well.

498
00:29:30.696 --> 00:29:34.900
But Zach, that's actually our review
here but it's good, but make sure those

499
00:29:34.900 --> 00:29:39.230
fundamentals that we've just went over in
these two episodes at this point are not

500
00:29:39.230 --> 00:29:43.680
lost on you, everybody always thinks
that I know that and I could do that.

501
00:29:43.680 --> 00:29:48.490
But make sure you review them and as long
as you have confidence in it then move on.

502
00:29:48.490 --> 00:29:52.900
If you don't, do it again and again and
again until you build the confidence

503
00:29:52.900 --> 00:29:55.470
in what we've just talked about and
knowledge as well as skill.

504
00:29:55.470 --> 00:29:56.572
>> Well done sir, well done.

505
00:29:56.572 --> 00:29:59.914
So this is configure vlans part two,
make sure you see part one.

506
00:29:59.914 --> 00:30:03.770
Configure trunking is gonna come up, too,
so make sure you stay with us for that.

507
00:30:03.770 --> 00:30:06.200
Before we move on, though, Ronnie,
anything else you'd like to say?

508
00:30:06.200 --> 00:30:11.103
>> Well, this is where you are going to be
practicing these commands as quickly as

509
00:30:11.103 --> 00:30:11.707
you can.

510
00:30:11.707 --> 00:30:16.650
So it's no longer just about getting them
down and making sure you understand,

511
00:30:16.650 --> 00:30:19.500
but you have to increase your speed.

512
00:30:19.500 --> 00:30:24.110
Try and think of not doing these certain
commands that we've turned to you.

513
00:30:24.110 --> 00:30:24.893
Try and time yourself.

514
00:30:24.893 --> 00:30:27.690
I know that sounds silly,
give yourself a minute and

515
00:30:27.690 --> 00:30:31.951
say, I'm gonna configure this interface
range or this default vlan and try and

516
00:30:31.951 --> 00:30:34.630
move through that as quickly as you can.

517
00:30:34.630 --> 00:30:38.250
It doesn't mean that if you can't get in
a minute, it's not going to help you out.

518
00:30:38.250 --> 00:30:41.540
But what it means is that you're
trying to give yourself a goal

519
00:30:41.540 --> 00:30:45.060
We're typing these things in and
you know what the commands are.

520
00:30:45.060 --> 00:30:47.090
When you actually look at
the instruction that's given,

521
00:30:47.090 --> 00:30:49.310
and you know how to get it set up.

522
00:30:49.310 --> 00:30:53.240
Pay attention to every show command
that we've also shown you as well during

523
00:30:53.240 --> 00:30:57.710
the show, because the show commands
are going to become even more important.

524
00:30:57.710 --> 00:31:01.070
As you'll actually see that you will
not be able to depend on the show run

525
00:31:01.070 --> 00:31:02.450
command as well.

526
00:31:02.450 --> 00:31:06.520
So make sure you take a look at all
these in terms of your review for

527
00:31:06.520 --> 00:31:08.000
just configuring vlan.

528
00:31:08.000 --> 00:31:09.210
>> Great advice, Ronnie.

529
00:31:09.210 --> 00:31:14.702
And make sure you watch every episode of
CCNA running and switching, exam 200-105.

530
00:31:14.702 --> 00:31:16.719
You're gonna be very glad you did.

531
00:31:16.719 --> 00:31:20.246
And by the way, you'll be in the course
library where there's thousands of other

532
00:31:20.246 --> 00:31:22.310
videos that are there
to help you go further.

533
00:31:22.310 --> 00:31:23.280
Check those out.

534
00:31:23.280 --> 00:31:25.250
Tell everybody you know about ITPro.TV.

535
00:31:25.250 --> 00:31:27.129
ITPro.TV is binge worthy.

536
00:31:27.129 --> 00:31:28.482
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

537
00:31:28.482 --> 00:31:29.338
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

538
00:31:29.338 --> 00:31:31.562
>> We will see you again soon.

539
00:31:31.562 --> 00:31:37.465
[MUSIC]

540
00:31:37.465 --> 00:31:40.882
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review the concept of trunking. They review configuration issues and details.  These details inlcude setting the mode and the different modes possible.  They discuss details of configuring the mode differently on each end.
episodes.title: Configure Trunking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.704
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:01.704 --> 00:00:03.893
I am your host Don Pezet.
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.893 --> 00:00:05.106
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

4
00:00:05.106 --> 00:00:08.228
California.
>> [CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:08.228 --> 00:00:11.873
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.873 --> 00:00:12.932
>> Hello and thank you for

7
00:00:12.932 --> 00:00:15.673
watching ITProTV,
helping you learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:15.673 --> 00:00:17.150
>> I'm your host Zack Memos.

9
00:00:17.150 --> 00:00:24.130
CCNA Routing and Switching (Exam 200-105)
This is Configure Trunking this episode,

10
00:00:24.130 --> 00:00:27.910
and perhaps there will be a couple more
episodes for Configure Trunking as well,

11
00:00:27.910 --> 00:00:29.640
but we'll find out as we go along.

12
00:00:29.640 --> 00:00:31.860
But the person bringing us all
the information we need is the one and

13
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:32.950
only Ronnie Wong.

14
00:00:32.950 --> 00:00:35.290
Ronnie, good to see you.
>> Zack, thank you again for

15
00:00:35.290 --> 00:00:38.280
having me back on our CCNA routing and
switching show as we

16
00:00:38.280 --> 00:00:40.840
continue to move forward
>> There's some of the different topics

17
00:00:40.840 --> 00:00:44.900
that we'll be covering for that CCNA
routing and switching exam as well.

18
00:00:44.900 --> 00:00:48.480
And today we're gonna be taking
a look at configuring trunking.

19
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:52.260
And this is an important part
of something that we have to do

20
00:00:52.260 --> 00:00:57.410
since we really did look at the idea here
of configuring vlans in previous episodes.

21
00:00:57.410 --> 00:01:00.985
Now we have to understand that when
we talked about it right, vlans that

22
00:01:00.985 --> 00:01:05.339
we've been doing is that, we've limited
everything to one switch essentially, and

23
00:01:05.339 --> 00:01:09.061
then from that point we allowed for
that to do the separation it wanted to.

24
00:01:09.061 --> 00:01:12.757
But most networks don't just stay at
one switch, even though they can,

25
00:01:12.757 --> 00:01:15.380
networks continue to grow and they change.

26
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:19.430
And when something like that happens,
we'll get inconsistent vlan data bases on

27
00:01:19.430 --> 00:01:23.880
each one of those if we
are not careful with vlans and

28
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:27.270
management and trunking here,
is a big part of

29
00:01:27.270 --> 00:01:29.450
helping us to manage these things better.
>> Right.

30
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:31.230
>> Now what I mean by that

31
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:32.630
is simple, okay.

32
00:01:32.630 --> 00:01:37.240
As we start configuring vlan on multiple
switches, well we have to be able to

33
00:01:37.240 --> 00:01:42.040
deal with the fact that we need for that
same vlan, essentially to be across two or

34
00:01:42.040 --> 00:01:45.740
three different switches, and
that's what we need to happen, okay?

35
00:01:45.740 --> 00:01:48.700
So, when we do something like
that we've got two choices.

36
00:01:48.700 --> 00:01:53.520
We can either do trunking or we don't
have to do trunking to make that happen.

37
00:01:53.520 --> 00:01:57.430
But let's talk about this idea first,
about not doing trunking and

38
00:01:57.430 --> 00:02:00.100
then we'll talk about the idea
of what trunking does for

39
00:02:00.100 --> 00:02:03.570
us to help us out so
that we can configure what we need to.

40
00:02:03.570 --> 00:02:06.460
So let's take a look at the screen
in front of me right now and

41
00:02:06.460 --> 00:02:08.290
this will help us out a little bit.

42
00:02:08.290 --> 00:02:11.880
Let me see if I can move up my diagram,
there we go.

43
00:02:11.880 --> 00:02:13.560
>> Perfect.

44
00:02:13.560 --> 00:02:14.900
>> Out from behind my head, and

45
00:02:14.900 --> 00:02:16.420
this will help us out.

46
00:02:16.420 --> 00:02:21.480
So I have two different switches
over here on the left-hand side.

47
00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:26.060
And remember this is the idea
without trunking here, okay?

48
00:02:26.060 --> 00:02:28.440
Without trunking,
I would have to configure vlan10,

49
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:34.090
vlan20, vlan30 on all of those switches,
both of those switches.

50
00:02:34.090 --> 00:02:38.560
I'd also have to configure and
assign different ports,

51
00:02:38.560 --> 00:02:42.530
okay, on each switch to each
of the vlans as well, okay?

52
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:47.560
So after a while it sounds monotonous,
okay, and tedious as you start doing this.

53
00:02:47.560 --> 00:02:50.105
The more switches that
you have to do this,

54
00:02:50.105 --> 00:02:53.151
the more you have to do
something like this as well.

55
00:02:53.151 --> 00:02:55.530
Now there's also another problem here.

56
00:02:55.530 --> 00:02:58.560
Not only is it administratively
boring to do that, but

57
00:02:58.560 --> 00:03:02.250
there also comes this point
when between those switches,

58
00:03:02.250 --> 00:03:06.890
that, if each of these vlans has
to be on those switches, okay?

59
00:03:06.890 --> 00:03:11.537
Because we have ports assigned in each
one of those account thing in sales and

60
00:03:11.537 --> 00:03:12.345
marketing.

61
00:03:12.345 --> 00:03:17.589
The other thing that ends up happening
is that we start using more and

62
00:03:17.589 --> 00:03:23.385
more of the switch ports on each switch
to just communicate with the other or

63
00:03:23.385 --> 00:03:28.170
with the same vlan number and
name on the other switch.

64
00:03:28.170 --> 00:03:29.820
So what does that actually mean?

65
00:03:29.820 --> 00:03:33.400
Well let's take for an example,
we have an 8 port switch, okay?

66
00:03:33.400 --> 00:03:36.766
So even in this very simple
example I know this says 5 ports,

67
00:03:36.766 --> 00:03:39.476
that's what the diagram
actually limits we do.

68
00:03:39.476 --> 00:03:42.480
Well let's say it's an 8
port switch here Zack, okay?

69
00:03:42.480 --> 00:03:45.196
With an 8 port switch,
if I were to do something,

70
00:03:45.196 --> 00:03:48.903
actually I guess I have to go up
to 12 since I have 10 ports other.

71
00:03:48.903 --> 00:03:50.280
Well let's do a 12 port switch.
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:03:50.280 --> 00:03:50.970
>> Because that makes more

73
00:03:50.970 --> 00:03:51.960
logical sense here.

74
00:03:51.960 --> 00:03:52.880
Okay, so yeah.

75
00:03:52.880 --> 00:03:56.360
Just one through ten, as you see those.

76
00:03:56.360 --> 00:03:58.870
So let's say I said 12 port switch.

77
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:04.440
Well if I do this and I start configuring
those vlans on each one of those,

78
00:04:04.440 --> 00:04:08.170
I really have to make sure that
I do something here, okay?

79
00:04:08.170 --> 00:04:12.580
For the vlan on this first switch to
communicate with the same vlan on this

80
00:04:12.580 --> 00:04:17.500
switch, I would also have to
take one of those ports and

81
00:04:17.500 --> 00:04:19.760
use a link in between them.

82
00:04:19.760 --> 00:04:25.510
So I'd physically have to
cable in vlan10 on one switch,

83
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:27.610
to vlan10 on the other switch.

84
00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:35.420
So that means I consume, well, two ports,
right here, just for vlan10, okay?

85
00:04:35.420 --> 00:04:38.090
So if those particular switches,
here, okay,

86
00:04:38.090 --> 00:04:42.260
were to do that, I'm essentially take up,
well, at least those two.

87
00:04:42.260 --> 00:04:45.400
But then when I add a second one,
I'd have to do the same thing.

88
00:04:45.400 --> 00:04:48.390
I'd have to connect
something in vlan20 over

89
00:04:48.390 --> 00:04:51.600
to something in vlan20
over here on this switch.

90
00:04:51.600 --> 00:04:55.920
Same thing for vlan30,
I'd have to connect something in vlan30

91
00:04:55.920 --> 00:04:59.550
over to vlan30 on this switch as well.
>> Mm-hm.

92
00:04:59.550 --> 00:05:01.820
>> So out of ten ports, and

93
00:05:01.820 --> 00:05:05.120
if I'm using three vlans,
>> you think about it,

94
00:05:05.120 --> 00:05:09.220
it's actually three separate links here,
okay?

95
00:05:09.220 --> 00:05:14.360
So about a third of my ports on each
of those 10 port switches or 12 port.

96
00:05:14.360 --> 00:05:18.700
So lets do a quarter, so
I said 10, 12 port switches, so

97
00:05:18.700 --> 00:05:22.830
a quarter of the actual
ports are just being used so

98
00:05:22.830 --> 00:05:27.420
that vlan10 can also just
communicate to vlan10 on this one.

99
00:05:27.420 --> 00:05:32.820
Vlan20 can communicate to vlan20 on
this one, vlan30 to vlan30 on this one.

100
00:05:32.820 --> 00:05:35.660
You add in another vlan,
well, that's now four,

101
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:40.170
so that means a third of those
12 ports would then be consumed.

102
00:05:40.170 --> 00:05:43.270
You add in a fifth vlan,
now you start eating into it,

103
00:05:43.270 --> 00:05:45.230
and then you start realizing something.

104
00:05:45.230 --> 00:05:50.220
Well I can't actually put as many devices
on those because I'm starting to eat up

105
00:05:50.220 --> 00:05:53.040
what more ports on each
one of these switches.

106
00:05:53.040 --> 00:05:56.350
So all of a sudden now that's
what's starting to happen.

107
00:05:56.350 --> 00:05:59.720
It is actually something
that we have to think about.

108
00:05:59.720 --> 00:06:04.970
If you have relatively few number of
ports on your switch, this can consume

109
00:06:04.970 --> 00:06:09.790
if you think about it, three links on
this side, three links on this side and

110
00:06:09.790 --> 00:06:15.080
each one is ten so 12,
like I said out of 24 ports here, okay?

111
00:06:15.080 --> 00:06:17.700
Six ports are actually just being used so

112
00:06:17.700 --> 00:06:20.670
that vlans can communicate
with each other.

113
00:06:20.670 --> 00:06:23.421
That's a lot of ways to bandwidth-
>> Doesn't seem very efficient.

114
00:06:23.421 --> 00:06:24.430
>> Just to do that.

115
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:26.203

00:14:42.230 --> 00:14:46.810

00:15:02.200 --> 00:15:06.473
So when you choose one over the other,

254
00:15:06.473 --> 00:15:12.481
Okay, ISL or interswitch linking, this is
a Cisco proprietary way of doing VLANs,

255
00:15:12.481 --> 00:15:16.473
okay, in terms of going
across the trunk here, right.

256
00:15:16.473 --> 00:15:17.858
So when going across the trunk,

257
00:15:17.858 --> 00:15:21.020
how does it identify different
VLAN information going across.

258
00:15:21.020 --> 00:15:24.330
So that the other side knows what
VLAN the information belongs to.

259
00:15:24.330 --> 00:15:27.770
The way that interswitch linking does it,
or ISL,

260
00:15:27.770 --> 00:15:31.830
is that they actually cover or
they change the header.

261
00:15:31.830 --> 00:15:33.500
So they add in a new header to it, and

262
00:15:33.500 --> 00:15:36.340
you'll actually see a header and
a trailer.

263
00:15:36.340 --> 00:15:41.930
And inside that header, just a small
piece of that information includes what

264
00:15:41.930 --> 00:15:47.525
we call VLAN ID as well as BPDU, which
is bridge protocol data unit, as well.

265
00:15:47.525 --> 00:15:50.943
Okay, so this particular
aspect of what we're doing is,

266
00:15:50.943 --> 00:15:53.665
notice that when they
call it encapsulation,

267
00:15:53.665 --> 00:15:58.260
that is because it encapsulates
the entire original Ethernet frame.

268
00:15:58.260 --> 00:16:01.477
Inside its own VLAN information, okay?

269
00:16:01.477 --> 00:16:04.750
VLAN ID is what it encapsulates in.

270
00:16:04.750 --> 00:16:09.670
So it was used, but really only Cisco
proprietary, so only on Cisco equipment.

271
00:16:09.670 --> 00:16:11.940
The one that is more popular today and

272
00:16:11.940 --> 00:16:15.580
probably more used as well

273
00:16:15.580 --> 00:16:18.560
And let's see, I don't know if I can

00:16:20.100 --> 00:16:21.610
Only this one, there we go, okay.

00:16:24.070 --> 00:16:25.990

00:16:25.990 --> 00:16:29.290
Let me move back to,

277
00:16:29.290 --> 00:16:35.930
So on this particular one,
this is different, okay?

278
00:16:35.930 --> 00:16:38.060
When you compare them both and

279
00:16:38.060 --> 00:16:43.500
switch you actually end up seeing, in
the original way that this is done, right?

280
00:16:43.500 --> 00:16:47.390
And original ethernet frame will
include of course destination, MAC,

281
00:16:47.390 --> 00:16:49.250
source address, link and type.

282
00:16:49.250 --> 00:16:52.640
The data itself as well as
it's own frame check sequence.

283
00:16:52.640 --> 00:16:57.030
Preamble, start a frame, whatever you
wanna call it it includes all that, okay?

284
00:16:57.030 --> 00:17:02.470
Instead of doing what ISL does,
which is add in a new header around that.

285
00:17:02.470 --> 00:17:08.470
It inserts a vlan tag in between
the source MAC address and

286
00:17:08.470 --> 00:17:10.790
the link type field, alright?

287
00:17:10.790 --> 00:17:17.780
That's gonna add in four extra bytes here
inside of the original ethernet frame.

288
00:17:17.780 --> 00:17:22.960
Now, when it does that and the ads in that
additional four bytes of information.

289
00:17:22.960 --> 00:17:27.030
It has to recalculate
the frame check sequence

290
00:17:27.030 --> 00:17:30.580
because it's changed by
adding four extra bytes.

291
00:17:30.580 --> 00:17:33.520
You change the calculation here, okay?

292
00:17:33.520 --> 00:17:38.290
So inside that four bytes includes
the priority number as well as the VLANID.

293
00:17:38.290 --> 00:17:41.640
Ethortype not so much important for
us at this point.

294
00:17:41.640 --> 00:17:44.220
But overall though that's what it does.

295
00:17:44.220 --> 00:17:47.780
And that's why you get this recalculated
frame check sequence on the end.

296
00:17:47.780 --> 00:17:50.450
Because it inserts it inside.

297
00:17:50.450 --> 00:17:54.060
You don't get that inside of
the ethernet frame up here at ISL.

298
00:17:54.060 --> 00:17:57.520
Because it's not changing
the frame itself.

299
00:17:57.520 --> 00:18:01.350
It's just putting another
header around the entire frame.

300
00:18:01.350 --> 00:18:05.370
So that frame check sequence inside of
this ethernet frame will remain the same.

301
00:18:05.370 --> 00:18:06.980
It won't change.

302
00:18:06.980 --> 00:18:12.460
But VLAN tagging though, notice it puts
it right inside of the frame itself.

303
00:18:12.460 --> 00:18:16.730
Thereby changing the way
that the frame comes across.

304
00:18:16.730 --> 00:18:21.050
In this sense,
when you start using 802.1q tagging.

305
00:18:21.050 --> 00:18:25.092
An analogy that I've used inside of
CCENT is, well, it should help you out.

306
00:18:25.092 --> 00:18:27.456
At least it helped me out to understand,

307
00:18:27.456 --> 00:18:31.221
is that ISO encapsulation is like
taking that frame and saying.

308
00:18:31.221 --> 00:18:36.110
Look, I need to identify
VLAN20 with red paint.

309
00:18:36.110 --> 00:18:36.720
So what do you do?

310
00:18:36.720 --> 00:18:40.770
You actually just take red paint and
you pour it over the entire frame.

311
00:18:40.770 --> 00:18:43.920
And it covers,
encapsulating that entire frame.

312
00:18:43.920 --> 00:18:45.950
But if you were to wash that off,

313
00:18:45.950 --> 00:18:49.810
if you were to change that, you'd still
have the original frame right there, okay?

314
00:18:49.810 --> 00:18:53.930
It would still be where
you could wash it all off.

315
00:18:53.930 --> 00:18:55.650
And that means that you could cover it or

316
00:18:55.650 --> 00:19:00.960
recover it with another paint job if you
wanted to, and change the VLAN type okay?

317
00:19:00.960 --> 00:19:04.550
So if you think about that,
it can be a little bit easier for

318
00:19:04.550 --> 00:19:06.240
somebody to hack in that sense.

319
00:19:06.240 --> 00:19:11.070
Somebody to attack with the 802.1q
tagging, it's not that it can't be done,

320
00:19:11.070 --> 00:19:13.020
but it's a lot more difficult.

321
00:19:13.020 --> 00:19:18.640
Because now what we're doing, instead of
pouring red paint over the entire frame.

322
00:19:18.640 --> 00:19:22.150
We're injecting it into
the middle of the frame.

323
00:19:22.150 --> 00:19:27.970
And even the ethernet frame itself says,
I've gotta recalculate this value.

324
00:19:27.970 --> 00:19:32.770
For you to pull that out and
insert in whatever you want.

325
00:19:32.770 --> 00:19:35.740
It changes the frame
check sequence as well.

326
00:19:35.740 --> 00:19:39.000
Which means the other side might
actually look at and go look.

327
00:19:39.000 --> 00:19:43.490
You have to calculate this as well as
change this to make sure it matched it

328
00:19:43.490 --> 00:19:44.900
on the other side.

329
00:19:44.900 --> 00:19:49.360
If you only change the tagging part
inside the four bytes here nut

330
00:19:49.360 --> 00:19:52.550
you forget to change this,
well then we've got you.

331
00:19:52.550 --> 00:19:55.740
You can't actually easily
manipulate that instead.

332
00:19:55.740 --> 00:20:00.320
So 802.1q Tagging today is probably
the default in what we see.

333
00:20:00.320 --> 00:20:02.790
In that idea of auto or

334
00:20:02.790 --> 00:20:07.680
negotiate, it just says whatever the other
side wants is perfectly fine with me.

335
00:20:07.680 --> 00:20:10.510
That is also what I want as well, okay.

336
00:20:10.510 --> 00:20:12.730
So that's what we're also seeing.

337
00:20:12.730 --> 00:20:15.030
So along with everything
else that we're doing here,

00:20:15.030 --> 00:20:18.950
if I come back here that

00:28:39.410 --> 00:28:43.250
I can actually change this up on NYCORE1.

467
00:28:43.250 --> 00:28:44.300
Or can I?

468
00:28:44.300 --> 00:28:45.750
Well, let's see.

469
00:28:45.750 --> 00:28:49.651
So NYCORE1, this is our VTP server.

470
00:28:53.169 --> 00:28:56.180
So can I add a VLAN in here?

471
00:28:56.180 --> 00:28:59.138
So I should be able to add in vlan 30.

472
00:29:01.551 --> 00:29:03.571
Now look at that,
it actually says something else.

473
00:29:03.571 --> 00:29:06.620
It's like look,
hey are you sure you can do this?

474
00:29:06.620 --> 00:29:08.785
This needs to be a primary server.

475
00:29:08.785 --> 00:29:13.870
VTP version three also requires
an additional step here

476
00:29:13.870 --> 00:29:16.100
to be able to do this as well.

477
00:29:16.100 --> 00:29:20.230
So it says look, we also use this idea
of what's called a primary server,

478
00:29:20.230 --> 00:29:21.470
saying you can add many servers,

479
00:29:21.470 --> 00:29:24.900
but the only way that you can configure
this is on a primary server as well.

480
00:29:24.900 --> 00:29:27.100
So then they've added in an extra layer.

481
00:29:27.100 --> 00:29:31.183
And the way that we set that
one up is just vtp primary.

482
00:29:34.246 --> 00:29:37.930
And now notice it gives me
a configuration, I can't type it in there.

483
00:29:42.575 --> 00:29:46.230
So it, of course, has locked it up here
for just a moment, at least I hope.

484
00:29:46.230 --> 00:29:47.150
There we go.

485
00:29:47.150 --> 00:29:51.530
So it's locked it up here, I was like
why is it locking it up, that's strange.

486
00:29:51.530 --> 00:29:54.050
So it is doing that, and
I just confirmed it, and

487
00:29:54.050 --> 00:29:56.990
you can also see now where
I'm getting that change.

488
00:29:56.990 --> 00:30:01.580
Primary server change for
the VTP is what we want.

489
00:30:01.580 --> 00:30:05.686
Now let's get back in, vlan 30.

490
00:30:07.873 --> 00:30:08.920
And we'll give it a name.

491
00:30:08.920 --> 00:30:15.343
We'll call it test2, just as a name here.

492
00:30:15.343 --> 00:30:17.144
Show vlan brief.

493
00:30:20.000 --> 00:30:23.751
Do show vlan brief.

494
00:30:23.751 --> 00:30:25.478
Grief, that's not good.

495
00:30:25.478 --> 00:30:30.923
[LAUGH] Now where did my,

496
00:30:30.923 --> 00:30:34.210
see this is where all of a sudden
it's like did work or not?

497
00:30:34.210 --> 00:30:35.900
And this one though did not.

498
00:30:35.900 --> 00:30:38.850
That's why, wait,
I'm on the wrong one, that's why.

499
00:30:38.850 --> 00:30:40.250
I was like what's up.

500
00:30:40.250 --> 00:30:41.700
I was on access.

501
00:30:41.700 --> 00:30:43.000
There it is.

502
00:30:43.000 --> 00:30:44.650
Why is this not, no, that's right.

503
00:30:44.650 --> 00:30:46.280
I was supposed to be on the other one,
wasn't I?

504
00:30:46.280 --> 00:30:49.220
NYCORE1, because I can't
change it on the other one.

505
00:30:49.220 --> 00:30:53.150
But this is where I found
inconsistencies with our lab here.

506
00:30:54.450 --> 00:30:56.170
And now I have to do that again.

507
00:30:58.260 --> 00:31:04.110
So vlan 30, name test2, try it again here.

508
00:31:06.450 --> 00:31:09.733
Exit, exit, show vlan brief.

509
00:31:12.562 --> 00:31:13.200
There we go.

510
00:31:14.670 --> 00:31:20.511
So now that's change, now I should
be able to go back to NYACCESS1 and

511
00:31:20.511 --> 00:31:24.975
see if it actually did,
once again, if I can zoom in.

512
00:31:32.968 --> 00:31:39.350
Here, And now notice VLAN 30 was
also created here as well, okay?

513
00:31:39.350 --> 00:31:42.470
So all this actually is allowing
us to just configure and

514
00:31:42.470 --> 00:31:46.950
to be able to verify VLAN 30 is
actually doing what we want to, okay?

515
00:31:46.950 --> 00:31:49.260
Now, Zack,
at this point there is still a bit for

516
00:31:49.260 --> 00:31:50.310
us to go.
>> Yep.

517
00:31:50.310 --> 00:31:51.980
>> But I have run out of time for

518
00:31:51.980 --> 00:31:54.080
this episode, so
that means we'll have to continue on.

519
00:31:54.080 --> 00:31:58.630
Well, just in another part to finish up
everything that we need to on trunking,

520
00:31:58.630 --> 00:32:01.391
but it won't be for this time though.
>> Well that's because you're so

521
00:32:01.391 --> 00:32:03.012
thorough and
you did a wonderful job Ronnie.

522
00:32:03.012 --> 00:32:05.750
Configure Trunking part 2,
there will be a part 3.

523
00:32:05.750 --> 00:32:07.730
Make sure you see everything.

524
00:32:07.730 --> 00:32:10.460
And before we move on, Ronnie,
anything else you'd like to say?

525
00:32:10.460 --> 00:32:12.070
>> Well this is one of the, again,

526
00:32:12.070 --> 00:32:15.130
confusing things that you
have to deal with, right?

527
00:32:15.130 --> 00:32:19.960
We're throwing a lot more information at
you now, and it means yes, you have to be

528
00:32:19.960 --> 00:32:25.300
willing to take the time to slow down
now before you get ready for that exam.

529
00:32:25.300 --> 00:32:29.880
So review again the stuff that you
already know, but at the same time learn

530
00:32:29.880 --> 00:32:33.030
about these other concepts that
you may not be as familiar with.

531
00:32:33.030 --> 00:32:35.980
This is actually important because
if there's anything in dealing

532
00:32:35.980 --> 00:32:40.400
with troubleshooting on the CCNA
routing and switching, it's not missing

533
00:32:40.400 --> 00:32:44.620
the details like what we're showing you
and making sure that you understand this.

534
00:32:44.620 --> 00:32:46.690
So take a look at VTP a little bit more.

535
00:32:46.690 --> 00:32:50.126
But we'll be showing you a lot more
in terms of trunking in just, well,

536
00:32:50.126 --> 00:32:55.093
our next episode is what we'll be doing.
>> That's right, CCNA routing and

537
00:32:55.093 --> 00:32:57.752
switching exam 200-105.

538
00:32:57.752 --> 00:32:59.380
Make sure you watch every single episode.

539
00:32:59.380 --> 00:33:01.510
You're gonna be so glad you did.

540
00:33:01.510 --> 00:33:03.240
And you'll be in the course library too.

541
00:33:03.240 --> 00:33:06.360
There's thousands of other videos there
designed to help you to go further.

542
00:33:06.360 --> 00:33:07.670
Check those out as well.

543
00:33:07.670 --> 00:33:09.861
And tell everybody you
know about ITPRO.TV.

544
00:33:09.861 --> 00:33:11.440
ITPRO.TV is binge worthy.

545
00:33:11.440 --> 00:33:12.180
That's right.

546
00:33:12.180 --> 00:33:14.310
Thanks for watching I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

547
00:33:14.310 --> 00:33:16.156
>> We will see you soon.

548
