Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with the lab by assigning interfaces to vlans after vtp configuration.  Verify the working of vtp and vlans. Lastly, they describe VTP pruning and it's use.
episodes.title: Configure Trunking Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:01.107
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.107 --> 00:00:02.802
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.802 --> 00:00:08.052
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.052 --> 00:00:11.744
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.744 --> 00:00:14.165
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.165 --> 00:00:16.510
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.510 --> 00:00:19.910
I'm your host, Zach Memos as we
continue on with CCNA routing and

8
00:00:19.910 --> 00:00:22.600
switching exam 200-105.

9
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:25.374
This is configure trunking part 3.

10
00:00:25.374 --> 00:00:27.500
That's right and guess who's here?

11
00:00:27.500 --> 00:00:28.072
Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:28.072 --> 00:00:29.476
>> [LAUGH]
>> He's gonna tell us all about it,

13
00:00:29.476 --> 00:00:30.460
aren't you, Ronnie?

14
00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:31.340
>> Yes, I am, Zach.

15
00:00:31.340 --> 00:00:35.750
Thank you for again being with me as we
continue on in this little journey through

16
00:00:35.750 --> 00:00:37.750
configuring trunking.

17
00:00:37.750 --> 00:00:42.740
We are, of course, in our third part,
we're taking a look at a lab that's taken

18
00:00:42.740 --> 00:00:46.560
us a little bit of time and
we're about to jump right back into this.

19
00:00:46.560 --> 00:00:48.770
And let's remember the goal and
the idea of trunking.

20
00:00:48.770 --> 00:00:52.358
So if for one reason or
other you decided to jump into part three,

21
00:00:52.358 --> 00:00:54.956
I again don't understand
why you would do so.

22
00:00:54.956 --> 00:01:00.250
But if you have for one reason or another,
okay, that's perfectly fine with us too.

23
00:01:00.250 --> 00:01:04.430
But if your going hey, I'm feeling a
little bit lost, make sure you go back and

24
00:01:04.430 --> 00:01:07.840
take a look at parts one and
two and then join back in with us.

25
00:01:07.840 --> 00:01:11.780
But if you don't, if you got to knock and
pick up for me, that's perfectly fine.

26
00:01:11.780 --> 00:01:14.022
Let me review what we've actually done so
far, okay?

27
00:01:14.022 --> 00:01:15.600
>> Thank you.
>> We've actually gone ahead and

28
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:18.700
we've explained the idea of what
happened without trying, okay?

29
00:01:18.700 --> 00:01:22.860
If we have multiple switches and we
need to spread VLANs out across multiple

30
00:01:22.860 --> 00:01:27.060
switches without trunking, we essentially
need a link, a physical link between

31
00:01:27.060 --> 00:01:31.270
each of those VLANs that we've
created on those switches.

32
00:01:31.270 --> 00:01:33.870
So instead, we can use trunking.

33
00:01:33.870 --> 00:01:38.890
And trunking allows us to take one link if
we want to, adding minimum one link here.

34
00:01:38.890 --> 00:01:43.750
And then we can allow for VLAN information
regardless of what VLANs are out there,

35
00:01:43.750 --> 00:01:45.378
to go across a single link.

36
00:01:45.378 --> 00:01:49.899
And that helps us to conserve our port
density on our switches allowing us to

37
00:01:49.899 --> 00:01:54.860
take advantage of adding more ports
into a single VLAN as we need to do so.

38
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:58.720
So we've been configuring that
idea along with that, right?

39
00:01:58.720 --> 00:02:02.380
We showed you how you
hard set the trunking but

40
00:02:02.380 --> 00:02:07.720
remember that by default also that CISCO
switches right out of the box will work.

41
00:02:07.720 --> 00:02:12.090
And when we do that, that means if we plug
in a switchport to another switchport on

42
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:16.600
another switch, if I hard set one side,
normally the other sides

43
00:02:16.600 --> 00:02:20.690
gonna also configure itself to
whatever the hard set side is.

44
00:02:20.690 --> 00:02:24.630
And that's because we're set to some
type of dynamic trunking protocol, or

45
00:02:24.630 --> 00:02:28.400
DTP, and usually that's
an automatic configuration for us.

46
00:02:28.400 --> 00:02:29.690
We don't have to set it up.

47
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:32.370
We just need to set up one side and
the other side will go ahead and agree and

48
00:02:32.370 --> 00:02:34.060
negotiate and set it up.

49
00:02:34.060 --> 00:02:37.020
And then that way,
you don't have to do any trunking at all.

50
00:02:37.020 --> 00:02:40.620
Once we got the trunking setup, we also
talked about the management of VLANs.

51
00:02:40.620 --> 00:02:42.890
After creating them on one switch,

52
00:02:42.890 --> 00:02:46.210
we have two different ways we
can also manage that as well.

53
00:02:46.210 --> 00:02:50.760
>> One, of course, is simply to say, hey,
look, as I create a trunk on, excuse me.

54
00:02:50.760 --> 00:02:53.540
As I create VLANs on one switch, okay?

55
00:02:53.540 --> 00:02:57.180
Then I have to go over to the second
switch and create those same VLANs again.

56
00:02:57.180 --> 00:02:59.590
And then the same thing goes on and
on and on.

57
00:02:59.590 --> 00:03:03.460
But if I make that configuration,
I'd have to make them on both switches.

58
00:03:03.460 --> 00:03:08.640
But if we use something that we call VTP,
VLAN Trunking Protocol.

59
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:11.771
If we have a trunk, well,
hence the term VLAN trunking protocol.

60
00:03:11.771 --> 00:03:16.262
If we have a trunk in between those,
well now we can start

61
00:03:16.262 --> 00:03:21.055
exchanging the VLAN information
on one of those switches.

62
00:03:21.055 --> 00:03:25.657
And make sure that we get a consistent
VLAN structure throughout the entirety of

63
00:03:25.657 --> 00:03:27.780
what we call the VLAN domain.

64
00:03:27.780 --> 00:03:31.150
All those that are actually
participating inside of VTP.

65
00:03:31.150 --> 00:03:34.037
And that means if I configure
VLAN 20 on one switch,

66
00:03:34.037 --> 00:03:38.207
if they're actually all in agreement
inside of VTP, it actually go ahead and

67
00:03:38.207 --> 00:03:41.626
configure the other switches
without me having to touch them.

68
00:03:41.626 --> 00:03:44.420
And there are three different
modes to this as well.

69
00:03:44.420 --> 00:03:46.990
There's actually a VTP server mode.

70
00:03:46.990 --> 00:03:48.850
There's a VTP client mode.

71
00:03:48.850 --> 00:03:50.800
And there's a VTP transparent,

72
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:53.590
we went through all that as well
as talk about revision numbers.

73
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:56.340
So if all that's now starting
to sound like, my gosh,

74
00:03:56.340 --> 00:03:58.580
that's starting to sound
a little bit unfamiliar.

75
00:03:58.580 --> 00:04:01.430
My advice cuz we're not gonna review
it again, we're gonna go back,

76
00:04:01.430 --> 00:04:06.440
you're gonna watch parts one and two, and
we'll show you how to do that as well.

77
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:10.899
But we're picking up essentially at the
end of that configuration where we've been

78
00:04:10.899 --> 00:04:12.923
I don't wanna say messing around..

79
00:04:12.923 --> 00:04:18.572
Cuz that doesn't sound like of configuring
VLANs, and after setting up VTP.

80
00:04:18.572 --> 00:04:23.400
We showed you what would happen if you
tried to configure a VLAN inside of

81
00:04:23.400 --> 00:04:24.373
a VTP client.

82
00:04:24.373 --> 00:04:25.614
It kinda rejects and says no,

83
00:04:25.614 --> 00:04:29.410
you can't configure it here because it's
only supposed to be done on the server.

84
00:04:29.410 --> 00:04:31.560
And we showed you where you
could do it on the server and

85
00:04:31.560 --> 00:04:33.560
that actually propagated through.

86
00:04:33.560 --> 00:04:37.295
So now we're at this point where we need
to verify, not only is that working,

87
00:04:37.295 --> 00:04:38.320
which we did.

88
00:04:38.320 --> 00:04:41.860
We showed you where the VLANs were
actually again propagating properly

89
00:04:41.860 --> 00:04:43.710
throughout our VTP domain.

90
00:04:43.710 --> 00:04:48.160
But now we want to set some interfaces
in those VLANs and use, well, traffic.

91
00:04:48.160 --> 00:04:51.410
Now we're sending pings between them to
say, all right, this is actually set up

92
00:04:51.410 --> 00:04:54.970
the way that we want to without
a lot of additional configuration.

93
00:04:54.970 --> 00:04:59.420
So we're gonna pick up right here on
NYCORE1, so if you've been following along

94
00:04:59.420 --> 00:05:05.380
in the lab setting here from part two,
let me kinda zoom out here for a moment.

95
00:05:05.380 --> 00:05:09.290
It's a little bit different in
my zooming here but I'll try and

96
00:05:09.290 --> 00:05:11.130
make sure that we can see everything.

97
00:05:11.130 --> 00:05:17.416
We are still in the configure verified and
troubleshoot interswitch connectivity.

98
00:05:17.416 --> 00:05:20.700
So even though it is three parts,
it's actually one big lab inside

99
00:05:20.700 --> 00:05:23.940
of our practicelabs.com,
which you as a member have access to.

100
00:05:23.940 --> 00:05:26.196
So make sure you take advantage of this
if you don't have your own equipment.

101
00:05:26.196 --> 00:05:26.888
>> Yeah, you should.

102
00:05:26.888 --> 00:05:30.454
>> How to set this up, yes you should
because it's actually a great utility.

103
00:05:30.454 --> 00:05:33.990
Cuz you're not actually just getting
access to a simulator or an emulator.

104
00:05:33.990 --> 00:05:36.710
This is real Sysco equipment
that you get to work on, so

105
00:05:36.710 --> 00:05:40.490
it's really a good platform for
you to be getting to do this.

106
00:05:40.490 --> 00:05:43.872
So over on NYCORE1, let me select NYCORE1.

107
00:05:43.872 --> 00:05:47.902
And that will bring me here and
then I'll zoom in, in just a moment so

108
00:05:47.902 --> 00:05:51.240
that we can see just a little,
or at least I think I will.

109
00:05:51.240 --> 00:05:56.780
Let me zoom in, that way we can see it
just a little bit better here, okay?

110
00:05:56.780 --> 00:06:02.207
And now that I'm zoomed in,
I am now ready to assign fast

111
00:06:02.207 --> 00:06:07.751
Ethernet 10/1 and 10, excuse me, 1/0/1 and

112
00:06:07.751 --> 00:06:14.120
1/0/2 into VLAN 10, and
into VLAN 20, respectively.

113
00:06:14.120 --> 00:06:16.070
I need to make sure that I
actually said that right.

114
00:06:16.070 --> 00:06:18.670
So that's what we are going to do here.

115
00:06:18.670 --> 00:06:22.730
So I just need to go in my
global configuration mode, and

116
00:06:22.730 --> 00:06:27.020
once I'm in this I need to
get access into that VLAN, or

117
00:06:27.020 --> 00:06:32.590
into that Interface fa1/0/1.

118
00:06:32.590 --> 00:06:38.500
And now I need to make sure that this
is gonna be a switchport mode access.

119
00:06:38.500 --> 00:06:43.520
So this is me hard setting it to
the access port mode, which for you and

120
00:06:43.520 --> 00:06:48.620
me turns off any possibility
of dynamic trunking off.

121
00:06:48.620 --> 00:06:51.780
We have now hard set this to say,
don't become a trunk.

122
00:06:51.780 --> 00:06:54.040
The other command that I
always like adding in,

123
00:06:54.040 --> 00:07:01.177
cuz it's just a way that I've done this
forever and ever, which is nonegotiate.

124
00:07:01.177 --> 00:07:03.597
If I can spell it, nonegotiate.

125
00:07:03.597 --> 00:07:05.240
I got to spell it right here.

126
00:07:05.240 --> 00:07:09.900
This says any possible trunking at all,
don't even try and participate in it.

127
00:07:09.900 --> 00:07:12.840
So don't just say I'm not doing
trunking but don't even try and

128
00:07:12.840 --> 00:07:15.630
participate in anything
that comes across here.

129
00:07:15.630 --> 00:07:19.946
And once I get to that,
then I can assign this to

130
00:07:19.946 --> 00:07:24.398
switchport access vlan and
this will be a 10.

131
00:07:24.398 --> 00:07:27.060
Let me make sure I actually
got that one right.

132
00:07:27.060 --> 00:07:29.670
So once I did that, now that
something else that we can do here.

133
00:07:29.670 --> 00:07:31.520
And I don't mention it too often but

134
00:07:31.520 --> 00:07:34.380
it can become important especially
if you're doing a lot of these.

135
00:07:34.380 --> 00:07:38.660
You can also add in a description
if you choose to, okay.

136
00:07:38.660 --> 00:07:41.411
Now let me go ahead and
type this okay to help you out, okay.

137
00:07:41.411 --> 00:07:43.693
Now you might be saying,
what the heck is the description about?

138
00:07:43.693 --> 00:07:45.599

00:16:07.210 --> 00:16:12.620
And once we get VLAN 30 and
40 here, we now want to actually

260
00:16:12.620 --> 00:16:17.150
add in what's gonna be allowed across
that trunk, which is also VLAN 30 and 40.

261
00:16:17.150 --> 00:16:19.240
So now we've already
configured it one time,

262
00:16:19.240 --> 00:16:23.606
how about adding additional VLANs is
what we're talking about to do this.

263
00:16:23.606 --> 00:16:25.830
All right, so
the way that we have to do it,

264
00:16:25.830 --> 00:16:30.650
now that we're still in VTP mode from
an earlier episode, is that we have to go

265
00:16:30.650 --> 00:16:36.770
back to NYCORE1 because that is
our VTP mode server over here.

266
00:16:36.770 --> 00:16:41.240
So an NYCORE1, let's go ahead and
configure a couple of different VLANs.

267
00:16:41.240 --> 00:16:43.435
Let me zoom in for us.

268
00:16:43.435 --> 00:16:53.400
Once again, Configure terminal,
and then vlan 30.

269
00:16:53.400 --> 00:16:55.950
And this one is gonna
have a name of Marketing.

270
00:17:02.257 --> 00:17:03.984
And then vlan 40.

271
00:17:05.803 --> 00:17:08.730
And this one is going to
have a name of Research.

272
00:17:15.125 --> 00:17:19.828
Verify that they are created, And

273
00:17:19.828 --> 00:17:22.980
there we go we've added in 30 and
40 which is fine.

274
00:17:22.980 --> 00:17:28.275
We've also created the Native VLAN 99
which is shut down too, so that's fine.

275
00:17:28.275 --> 00:17:32.460
We're not actually doing anything else
with that native VLAN for right now.

276
00:17:32.460 --> 00:17:35.089
So we can work with that too, okay?

277
00:17:35.089 --> 00:17:40.057
So once we've got that configured,
now we need to configure for the allowance

278
00:17:40.057 --> 00:17:44.960
of those additional VLANs that we've
just created across the trunk as well.

279
00:17:44.960 --> 00:17:49.817
Now let's do a show int trunk here.

280
00:17:49.817 --> 00:17:54.045
Once again, let's verify that, yep,
the information is still the same,

281
00:17:54.045 --> 00:17:57.330
only VLANs 10 and 20 are actually allowed.

282
00:17:57.330 --> 00:18:02.230
So now if I get back into that interface,
1/0/22, oops, interface I forget

283
00:18:02.230 --> 00:18:08.281
the fast Ethernet,

284
00:18:08.281 --> 00:18:15.384
fa, fastethernet 1/0/22.

285
00:18:15.384 --> 00:18:23.750
Now I can do a switchport,
trunk allowed, and then vlan.

286
00:18:26.490 --> 00:18:31.150
And now we actually need to take a look at
these commands just briefly here, okay?

287
00:18:31.150 --> 00:18:34.020
Notice that we can of course
enter in the VLAN IDs which is

288
00:18:34.020 --> 00:18:35.210
probably the one that we want.

289
00:18:35.210 --> 00:18:39.863
But if we do this it's gonna replace
the current VLANs that we have.

290
00:18:39.863 --> 00:18:42.150
That's not what we wanna do,
we want them to add, okay?

291
00:18:42.150 --> 00:18:44.620
So if I go and do this it's just
gonna take out 10 and 20 and

292
00:18:44.620 --> 00:18:46.100
replace it with this.

293
00:18:46.100 --> 00:18:48.670
So the word that we want is add,

294
00:18:48.670 --> 00:18:51.940
notice you can actually just put
in all which of course means all.

295
00:18:51.940 --> 00:18:56.400
You can also add in all of them except for
the following VLANs.

296
00:18:56.400 --> 00:18:59.790
Two, and the you can say none, and
then of course you can remove.

297
00:18:59.790 --> 00:19:03.560
Unless you used the word allowed here,
and add.

298
00:19:07.517 --> 00:19:14.110
So now I can do vlan add 30,
40 remember no spaces here.

299
00:19:18.760 --> 00:19:25.583
Do show int trunk.

300
00:19:27.700 --> 00:19:33.730
And now you can see where added in,
VLANs 30 and

301
00:19:33.730 --> 00:19:37.940
40, where it actually just would
have just replaced VLANs 10 and

302
00:19:37.940 --> 00:19:40.300
20 if we didn't do this.
>> Mm-hm.

303
00:19:40.300 --> 00:19:41.740
>> What if we wanted to remove one

304
00:19:41.740 --> 00:19:42.640
of these VLANs?

305
00:19:42.640 --> 00:19:45.120
Well, it's the same configuration here.

306
00:19:45.120 --> 00:19:48.280
But this time we'll actually use
the key word remove instead.

307
00:19:51.976 --> 00:19:55.903
So now what I do is I
come back over here and

308
00:19:55.903 --> 00:19:59.960
I type in remove, and then we can do 20.

309
00:20:02.196 --> 00:20:07.820
Do show, interface trunk.

310
00:20:12.134 --> 00:20:15.077
And now you see where it actually did
take out that one VLAN without disturbing

311
00:20:15.077 --> 00:20:16.305
the other VLANs as well, okay?

312
00:20:16.305 --> 00:20:21.901
So this really does set up just about
everything that we actually want

313
00:20:21.901 --> 00:20:27.880
to be able to do to ensure we can add and
remove VLANs as well, okay?

314
00:20:27.880 --> 00:20:31.970
So its a big part of what we have
to be able understand and do.

315
00:20:31.970 --> 00:20:35.450
This is part of that idea
of being given commands and

316
00:20:35.450 --> 00:20:39.510
can you actually know which
syntax is gonna be proper?

317
00:20:39.510 --> 00:20:43.266
Some of the other things you have to
pay attention to of course is remember,

318
00:20:43.266 --> 00:20:49.950
syntax is exactly 100% right or
is 100% wrong.

319
00:20:49.950 --> 00:20:58.687
So if you do a coma, 30 coma space
40 that is incorrect 100%, okay?

320
00:20:58.687 --> 00:21:02.439
So those are some of the things that you
want to pay attention to in the setup and

321
00:21:02.439 --> 00:21:04.060
the configuration.

322
00:21:04.060 --> 00:21:07.390
So this lab is actually showing
us quite a bit of information and

323
00:21:07.390 --> 00:21:10.390
working with the idea of
the native VLAN and changing it.

324
00:21:10.390 --> 00:21:14.500
Some of it is actually just instruction
that you have to know how to do.

325
00:21:14.500 --> 00:21:18.130
You and I are not really gonna be
working deeply with the idea and

326
00:21:18.130 --> 00:21:21.310
the concept of native VLANs
until we get into the management

327
00:21:21.310 --> 00:21:24.390
portion of some of the things
that we want to set up.

328
00:21:24.390 --> 00:21:27.440
But overall those it should
help us to finish out and

329
00:21:27.440 --> 00:21:30.680
round out some of the information
that we need to understand

330
00:21:30.680 --> 00:21:33.882
when we start configuring trunking.
>> Configure trunking,

331
00:21:33.882 --> 00:21:37.490
episode number four, make sure you
see one, two, and three and four.

332
00:21:37.490 --> 00:21:39.060
It'll be good for you.

333
00:21:39.060 --> 00:21:40.300
And Ronnie anything
else you'd like to say?

334
00:21:40.300 --> 00:21:40.829
>> Well,

335
00:21:40.829 --> 00:21:45.855
just remember this is a big concept and
we've kind of deep dived into

336
00:21:45.855 --> 00:21:52.280
it pretty well in terms of trunking, but
it means you also have to again, practice.

337
00:21:52.280 --> 00:21:56.828
So continue to practice on a daily basis
commands that you already know, but

338
00:21:56.828 --> 00:21:59.750
especially these commands
that you do not know.

339
00:21:59.750 --> 00:22:02.421
And do not proceed forward
until you have mastered or

340
00:22:02.421 --> 00:22:06.488
at least gotten a good hold on this, where
if you're asked a question about it or

341
00:22:06.488 --> 00:22:10.460
you think about it, you wanna research

342

So all that's actually important,

I should say, [LAUGH] when you're

So that will only bring you more

the exam quicker and more accurately,
as well, so, more practice and

347

more knowledge at this point.

if a lot of you are planning

349

switching exam 200-105.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce STP, spanning-tree-protocol.  They begin with describing what each port does when it powers on and the port states it goes through.  The guys emphasize the issues with redundancy between switches and the results that happen:  broadcast storms, mac address table instabiity nad duplication of frames.  Lastly, they discuss the purpose of STP protocol and mention the end result of what it does.
episodes.title: Understand and Configure STP
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:06.535
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.535 --> 00:00:07.264
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.264 --> 00:00:12.060
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:12.060 --> 00:00:14.680
>> Hello again, thank you for
choosing ITPro TV,

5
00:00:14.680 --> 00:00:17.290
helping you learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:17.290 --> 00:00:20.552
I'm Zach Memos, your host for
CCNA Routing and Switching Exam 200-105.

7
00:00:20.552 --> 00:00:25.919
In this episode we're gonna be
understanding and configuring STP,

8
00:00:25.919 --> 00:00:31.760
that's not the motor oil by the way,
and Ronnie Wong is here to help us out.

9
00:00:31.760 --> 00:00:33.010
Ronnie, good to see you.

10
00:00:33.010 --> 00:00:34.600
>> Well, Zach, thank you again for

11
00:00:34.600 --> 00:00:39.220
having me back as we continue on in
our CCNA routing and switching show.

12
00:00:39.220 --> 00:00:42.000
You're right, we are up to this point
where we're talking about understanding

13
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:45.640
and configuring STP, and
what does STP stand for?

14
00:00:45.640 --> 00:00:49.990
Well, exactly like what Zach said, it's
not about some type of motor oil additive.

15
00:00:49.990 --> 00:00:52.560
So that's not gonna help you
in CCNA routing and switching.

16
00:00:52.560 --> 00:00:56.240
But it is about a protocol that we
call Spanning Tree Protocol, okay?

17
00:00:56.240 --> 00:00:58.170
Spanning Tree Protocol.

18
00:00:58.170 --> 00:01:04.240
Spanning Tree Protocol, as we begin, it
actually does help us with one thing and

19
00:01:04.240 --> 00:01:07.600
really one thing only, but
it's actually very good at what it does.

20
00:01:07.600 --> 00:01:11.900
And it helps us to actually kind of get
rid of what we call switching loops

21
00:01:11.900 --> 00:01:15.150
that can happen inside of networks, okay?

22
00:01:15.150 --> 00:01:18.570
And you might be wondering, so what's
the big deal about a switching loop?

23
00:01:18.570 --> 00:01:23.920
Well, a switching loop can cause unusual
damage in a couple of different ways.

24
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:28.580
Logically, it can actually hurt
to where the switch doesn't

25
00:01:28.580 --> 00:01:32.720
function normally the way you think it can
and then of course actually physically

26
00:01:32.720 --> 00:01:36.590
you can overwhelm a port to the point
where that port's not gonna function.

27
00:01:36.590 --> 00:01:37.860
So you now have hardware and

28
00:01:37.860 --> 00:01:41.020
equipment that doesn't function
the way it's supposed to anyways.

29
00:01:41.020 --> 00:01:44.750
So there's a couple reasons why we
wanna talk about Spanning Tree and

30
00:01:44.750 --> 00:01:48.171
the great thing though, and
tell you this in all seriousness.

31
00:01:48.171 --> 00:01:53.037
We don't really have to configure much
in terms of Spanning Tree on the Cisco

32
00:01:53.037 --> 00:01:54.329
switch itself, but

33
00:01:54.329 --> 00:01:59.116
it is one of the more difficult
concepts that we have to learn about.

34
00:01:59.116 --> 00:02:03.340
So we're gonna be spending a lot more time
in talking about it, and describing it and

35
00:02:03.340 --> 00:02:06.280
I'm gonna of course show you
how it actually comes about and

36
00:02:06.280 --> 00:02:08.782
it functions the way that it does as well.

37
00:02:08.782 --> 00:02:10.850
>> And, Ronnie,
this is something that could appear or

38
00:02:10.850 --> 00:02:12.402
will appear on the exam, right?

39
00:02:12.402 --> 00:02:15.440
>> It is,
it will actually appear on the exam and

40
00:02:15.440 --> 00:02:19.100
it will be one of the more frustrating
things that will get you on the exam if

41
00:02:19.100 --> 00:02:24.030
you don't have a good grasp of it
before you go to the exam as well.

42
00:02:24.030 --> 00:02:27.430
And that is because it's
a lot of moving parts, okay?

43
00:02:27.430 --> 00:02:31.966
There's a lot of pieces and a lot of
concepts that you have to be willing to

44
00:02:31.966 --> 00:02:36.580
deal with and understand as things
start to happen to do that, okay?

45
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:40.070
So that's what we wanna pick up on
today is how we understand it, and

46
00:02:40.070 --> 00:02:41.200
that's what we're taking a look at.

47
00:02:41.200 --> 00:02:45.200
So I've got a lot of diagrams
to help us out so that we can

48
00:02:45.200 --> 00:02:50.190
actually understand this concept a little
bit better as we get started here, okay?

49
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:53.930
So, Zach, before we get started in terms
of Spanning Tree and the idea of switching

50
00:02:53.930 --> 00:02:56.635
leaves which we'll have a talk about
in detail here just in a moment.

51
00:02:56.635 --> 00:02:59.490
We wanna start off with something
a little bit more basic and

52
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:04.460
simple to get started here and
that is the idea we called port states.

53
00:03:04.460 --> 00:03:08.120
Let's take a look at my diagram and
this will help us out a little bit.

54
00:03:08.120 --> 00:03:13.710
I know it's not the fanciest drawing
that I ever put up here in the slide on,

55
00:03:13.710 --> 00:03:16.550
my screen, I should say,
that I've ever made but

56
00:03:16.550 --> 00:03:20.020
I think it helps us to
understand something here, okay?

57
00:03:20.020 --> 00:03:24.050
When we start to plug
a switch in with power, okay?

58
00:03:24.050 --> 00:03:28.630
The switch ports themselves,
they don't just automatically blink and

59
00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:31.710
turn on and then you're ready to go, okay?

60
00:03:31.710 --> 00:03:35.439
When you apply power to them
after it goes through its post,

61
00:03:35.439 --> 00:03:38.840
its power-on self-test, after it
checks everything that it needs to,

62
00:03:38.840 --> 00:03:42.880
after it actually begins to kind
of load up what it needs to,

63
00:03:42.880 --> 00:03:47.430
all of the ports during that point
in time that's going on, okay?

64
00:03:47.430 --> 00:03:51.920
It has to go through what we
call a different port states.

65
00:03:51.920 --> 00:03:55.050
So that's why when you watch a switch,
if you ever power one on and

66
00:03:55.050 --> 00:03:58.430
you watch it power on,
it takes a little bit of time.

67
00:03:58.430 --> 00:04:02.110
Every single one of those ports is
actually going to light up maybe for

68
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:06.750
a brief second, and then it may actually
go off or it may actually blink, or

69
00:04:06.750 --> 00:04:08.730
it does whatever it does here.

70
00:04:08.730 --> 00:04:11.910
But what it's doing is
it's transitioning to its

71
00:04:11.910 --> 00:04:16.990
final state when the switch comes to
idle and what it needs to do, okay?

72
00:04:16.990 --> 00:04:20.860
So we wanna talk about this idea of
port states because it matters in

73
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:25.590
the way that Spanning Tree works as well,
and what will happen in Spanning Tree.

74
00:04:25.590 --> 00:04:29.120
So if you don't have a good understanding
of what happened with an individual

75
00:04:29.120 --> 00:04:32.320
port on a switch,
when it actually comes up,

76
00:04:32.320 --> 00:04:36.790
then it's hard to understand how it also
works during Spanning Tree too, okay?

77
00:04:36.790 --> 00:04:41.700
So, when we start talking about the idea
of port states, imagine that you have,

78
00:04:41.700 --> 00:04:44.330
let's not just go with
even a five port switch.

79
00:04:44.330 --> 00:04:46.730
Imagine you have a 48-port switch.

80
00:04:46.730 --> 00:04:49.400
Every single one of
these ports goes through

81
00:04:50.950 --> 00:04:53.060
some type of state here like this, okay?

82
00:04:53.060 --> 00:04:55.100
So let's walk through this process.

83
00:04:55.100 --> 00:04:58.330
I didn't label everything
out in super detail here,

84
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:00.790
cuz we we're gonna talk
about it as we go along, but

85
00:05:00.790 --> 00:05:04.740
we'll just use FA0/2 as an example
on this particular switch.

86
00:05:04.740 --> 00:05:08.880
So when you power it on and
it begins to do whatever it begins to do,

87
00:05:08.880 --> 00:05:11.430
there's a couple of
things that can happen.

88
00:05:11.430 --> 00:05:17.360
If the configuration says this
port is actually shut down, okay?

89
00:05:17.360 --> 00:05:20.260
Administratively shut down or
just shut down.

90
00:05:20.260 --> 00:05:24.550
It will ultimately end up in what
we call the disabled state, okay?

91
00:05:24.550 --> 00:05:26.960
And that means look,
it's just not functioning right now.

92
00:05:26.960 --> 00:05:30.600
So either there's nothing on
the other side of it, okay?

93
00:05:30.600 --> 00:05:34.210
Or you've actually
administratively turned it off.

94
00:05:34.210 --> 00:05:39.370
So that is very possible that something
like that could happen on that port.

95
00:05:39.370 --> 00:05:43.990
But when the switch first boots up and
power is applied,

96
00:05:43.990 --> 00:05:48.720
before it just starts allowing you to
send information as it's powering on,

97
00:05:48.720 --> 00:05:53.466
it actually powers it up in what
we call blocking state instead.

98
00:05:53.466 --> 00:05:56.839
Now the reason why it actually
does blocking state, and

99
00:05:56.839 --> 00:06:01.647
the reason why we're talking about this
today, is because if you just allow for

100
00:06:01.647 --> 00:06:05.810
that port to begin to immediately
forward traffic when it powers on,

101
00:06:05.810 --> 00:06:08.791
you could end up in what
we call a switching loop.

102
00:06:08.791 --> 00:06:10.922
So what it does is it powers up, but

103
00:06:10.922 --> 00:06:16.570
it actually keeps everything in blocking
mode to prevent the idea of loops here.

104
00:06:16.570 --> 00:06:21.950
Now, during that time, if the switches
are connected together again

105
00:06:21.950 --> 00:06:26.280
with trunks, Spanning Tree Protocol
is already running in the background.

106
00:06:26.280 --> 00:06:29.060
You and I don't have to turn it on,
we don't have to do anything,

107
00:06:29.060 --> 00:06:31.100
it's already running in the background.

108
00:06:31.100 --> 00:06:32.550
And what happens then,

109
00:06:32.550 --> 00:06:37.240
as it's in blocking mode, it will begin
to send out pieces of information.

110
00:06:37.240 --> 00:06:42.410
Which is still gonna be allowed to go
through while it's in blocking mode, okay?

111
00:06:42.410 --> 00:06:46.530
But no other data and
traffic's gonna be allowed to do that.

112
00:06:46.530 --> 00:06:50.240
So even though it starts up it's not
allowing traffic to go across but it will

113
00:06:50.240 --> 00:06:54.138
allow for one switch to communicate with
another switch during that time, okay?

114
00:06:54.138 --> 00:06:59.930
So, once it's in blocking here, it's not
gonna actually immediately do anything,

115
00:06:59.930 --> 00:07:02.340
it's just gonna stay there for
just a moment.

116
00:07:02.340 --> 00:07:07.297
And when it does that what will happen
then is that the switch will determine,

117
00:07:07.297 --> 00:07:10.732
because Spanning Tree is
working in the background,

118
00:07:10.732 --> 00:07:15.539
it will determine whether this particular
port has a chance to become one of

119
00:07:15.539 --> 00:07:19.156
the ports that's involved
actively in Spanning Tree.

120
00:07:19.156 --> 00:07:21.958
So every single port is
actually configured to say hey,

121
00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.240
I'm possibly gonna be
involved in Spanning Tree.

122
00:07:25.240 --> 00:07:26.880
It's a possibility here.

123
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:31.760
So the way that it does that is it
actually puts it into listening mode.

124
00:07:31.760 --> 00:07:35.960
Listening mode says look, as information
is coming across these ports here,

125
00:07:35.960 --> 00:07:38.080
okay, well then I'm gonna
be listening whether or

126
00:07:38.080 --> 00:07:40.660
not I get to participate in this or not.

127
00:07:40.660 --> 00:07:43.633
And that's true, is it also has
what's called a port role and

128
00:07:43.633 --> 00:07:47.752
the port role is actually, again, another
definition in Spanning Tree which we'll

129
00:07:47.752 --> 00:07:49.489
get to look at a little bit later on.

130
00:07:49.489 --> 00:07:51.752
So it will determine whether or

131
00:07:51.752 --> 00:07:56.894
not FA0/2 can become what it calls
a designated port or a root port.

132
00:07:56.894 --> 00:07:59.191
I know that doesn't make
much sense at this point.

133
00:07:59.191 --> 00:08:02.648
But it says, essentially,
are we gonna be participating in it?

134
00:08:02.648 --> 00:08:07.550
And it hears information, it has
a chance to become a participant in it.

135
00:08:07.550 --> 00:08:11.895
But if it's not connected to anything,
it's listening, it's listening,

136
00:08:11.895 --> 00:08:14.860
but nobody's saying, yes,
you're gonna become a participant.

137
00:08:14.860 --> 00:08:19.530
So that point, it could be,
okay, that it actually listens.

138
00:08:19.530 --> 00:08:21.980
And when it doesn't
actually hear anything else

139
00:08:21.980 --> 00:08:26.940
it could end up reverting back into
blocking or essentially disabled, okay.

140
00:08:26.940 --> 00:08:30.280
But let's say that it
starts to hear information.

141
00:08:30.280 --> 00:08:32.430
Hey, I'm starting to hear information, so

142
00:08:32.430 --> 00:08:35.260
I need to learn about the information
on that other switch.

143
00:08:35.260 --> 00:08:37.300
Well then after a period of
what they call fore delay,

144
00:08:37.300 --> 00:08:42.130
about 15 seconds, it will learn for
about 15 seconds as well.

145
00:08:42.130 --> 00:08:44.120
Trying to get information from
the other switch like, hey,

146
00:08:44.120 --> 00:08:49.360
look, I'm here in this management or
this traffic from your switch,

147
00:08:49.360 --> 00:08:52.590
from you,
about what I should be participating in.

148
00:08:52.590 --> 00:08:54.840
So let me learn about
the information from you.

149
00:08:54.840 --> 00:08:58.070
And it now it's active and
doing everything that it can.

150
00:08:58.070 --> 00:09:01.270
Well, then it will load it
into forwarding state, okay.

151
00:09:01.270 --> 00:09:06.950
But there is a possibility though that
during that time a loop could be detected,

152
00:09:06.950 --> 00:09:10.700
and that happens it may end
up in blocking as well.

153
00:09:10.700 --> 00:09:14.580
So it can actually end up reverting
back around because it has to do this

154
00:09:14.580 --> 00:09:17.850
automatically without you and
I actually needing to consider.

155
00:09:17.850 --> 00:09:21.880
So that's why we have to understand this,
and we'll take a look at these states

156
00:09:21.880 --> 00:09:25.560
when we show everything on the switch
itself because it is important.

157
00:09:26.610 --> 00:09:30.660
The ones that are transitory here, right,
essentially listening and learning.

158
00:09:30.660 --> 00:09:34.860
They happen so quickly at times,
depending on the type of entry,

159
00:09:34.860 --> 00:09:36.270
there's more than one.

160
00:09:36.270 --> 00:09:38.270
Depending on the protocol
that we're using,

161
00:09:38.270 --> 00:09:41.460
that you may not even see it happen,
okay, very very quickly, okay.

162
00:09:41.460 --> 00:09:44.445
It may just kind of go,
all of a sudden it's just done.

163
00:09:44.445 --> 00:09:47.210
So usually we see the idea of it
turning on, it might be even blocking,

164
00:09:47.210 --> 00:09:49.490
and then it turns into forwarding, okay.

165
00:09:49.490 --> 00:09:53.050
But or it actually goes into blocking
again and then, at some point.

166
00:09:53.050 --> 00:09:57.370
But finding the idea of listening and
learning today on a switch actively,

167
00:09:57.370 --> 00:10:01.900
it's probably not going to happen
very often but in the first realm, or

168
00:10:01.900 --> 00:10:07.700
the first primary edition of Spanning Tree
Protocol, it was actually able to do this.

169
00:10:07.700 --> 00:10:11.340
So because it took about 15 seconds for
each time for it to go through.

170
00:10:11.340 --> 00:10:16.584
So this process could take anywhere
between 30, 60, 45, maybe up to a couple

171
00:10:16.584 --> 00:10:21.420
of minutes to get through everything
before everything kinda settled down here.

172
00:10:21.420 --> 00:10:22.940
So take a look at this timing,

173
00:10:22.940 --> 00:10:25.840
cuz I don't have everything exactly
right in terms of the timing here.

174
00:10:25.840 --> 00:10:27.790
But you can look at that
as you learn through, okay,

175
00:10:27.790 --> 00:10:29.030
as you go through this, right.

176
00:10:29.030 --> 00:10:30.630
So why is this important?

177
00:10:30.630 --> 00:10:31.960
Why does this matter?

178
00:10:31.960 --> 00:10:35.510
It's all about the idea here
of what I was talking about

179
00:10:35.510 --> 00:10:40.210
which is that you can actually end up
having what we call a switching loop.

180
00:10:41.310 --> 00:10:42.190
All right, so

181
00:10:42.190 --> 00:10:48.110
let me show you how a switching loop ends
up working here between two switches.

182
00:10:48.110 --> 00:10:51.370
Now normally when you talked
about between two switches,

183
00:10:51.370 --> 00:10:55.050
if I only have a single link,
not two like I show you right here.

184
00:10:55.050 --> 00:10:58.380
Okay, if only I have a single link
I'm not gonna have a switching link

185
00:10:58.380 --> 00:11:02.520
because there's only one path or
something to get there and to get back.

186
00:11:02.520 --> 00:11:07.320
But now I might set up two links here for
the sake of redundancy.

187
00:11:07.320 --> 00:11:11.161
Let's say that on the port on the switch
over here on the left-hand side,

188
00:11:11.161 --> 00:11:12.940
fa0/1 somehow fails.

189
00:11:12.940 --> 00:11:15.610
Well I don't mean for

190
00:11:15.610 --> 00:11:20.190
all traffic to stop when it fails,
so I may set up another connection,

191
00:11:20.190 --> 00:11:25.980
which is on fa0/2, and if I do something
like that that provides me redundancy.

192
00:11:25.980 --> 00:11:33.200
So in redundant switch configurations,
switching loops are very, very possible

193
00:11:33.200 --> 00:11:38.810
and likely to happen if we do not put
something in place to take care of it.

194
00:11:38.810 --> 00:11:41.975
When a switching loop ends up happening,
okay,

195
00:11:41.975 --> 00:11:46.465
it usually brings about one of
three different results here, okay.

196
00:11:46.465 --> 00:11:51.470
And the first one is probably more likely,
it's what we call a broadcast storm.

197
00:11:51.470 --> 00:11:56.178
A broadcast storm is when,
let's say 200.10

198
00:11:56.178 --> 00:12:00.888
here sends a broadcast out
over the switch, right.

199
00:12:00.888 --> 00:12:04.960
Well remember that a switch only does
three things in its functionality.

200
00:12:04.960 --> 00:12:10.340
It either forwards traffic to its
destination port, it floods the switch,

201
00:12:10.340 --> 00:12:13.310
okay, or it filters it out, okay.

202
00:12:13.310 --> 00:12:19.136
So in this sense the idea of
the broadcast storm is simple.

203
00:12:19.136 --> 00:12:24.743
If 192.168.200.10 doesn't find in its
Mac address table like we see here,

204
00:12:24.743 --> 00:12:28.744
the destination that it's supposed
to go to, it will go ahead and

205
00:12:28.744 --> 00:12:33.960
flood it out every other port except for
the one it came in on, and that's FA0/3.

206
00:12:33.960 --> 00:12:37.930
It will send out all the other
ports that's directly connected so

207
00:12:37.930 --> 00:12:45.650
that I need to know the Mac address
of this particular, Address, okay.

208
00:12:45.650 --> 00:12:49.270
Or it will send it to its broadcast
address and we'll do the same thing.

209
00:12:49.270 --> 00:12:54.870
Well when it sends it out that
means that the map address table

210
00:12:54.870 --> 00:12:59.680
will actually end up here on this switch,
learning about the source

211
00:12:59.680 --> 00:13:04.640
address that's connected to it,
you can see here on FA0/3.

212
00:13:04.640 --> 00:13:07.355
0/3 it learned about
the Mac address over here.

213
00:13:07.355 --> 00:13:12.969
Well now when it sends it out across
this way, okay, well on FA0/1 and

214
00:13:12.969 --> 00:13:19.340
0/2 because it will flood it out every
other port except the one that came in on.

215
00:13:19.340 --> 00:13:26.236
Over on switch B, okay,
on switch B, that means FA0/1,

216
00:13:26.236 --> 00:13:31.240
it will learn about
a source Mac address from

217
00:13:31.240 --> 00:13:37.345
the other switch right there,
and then on FA0/2.

218
00:13:40.627 --> 00:13:44.820
Here too, okay, so
it will also learn that.

219
00:13:44.820 --> 00:13:48.516
But it will also learn of course about
the one that's over here that actually is

220
00:13:48.516 --> 00:13:50.261
the source from FA0/3 over here.

221
00:13:50.261 --> 00:13:53.410
So it will actually learn about that.

222
00:13:54.750 --> 00:14:00.760
Now because it's a broadcast, right,
and nobody else is responding,

223
00:14:01.840 --> 00:14:07.630
well switch over here on the right-hand
side will also begin the broadcast, okay.

224
00:14:07.630 --> 00:14:11.300
Now in this broadcast it's
a little bit more unusual.

225
00:14:11.300 --> 00:14:13.620
Remember, a broadcast, or
whatever in the switch,

226
00:14:13.620 --> 00:14:17.120
it can send out every other port
except for the one it came in on.

227
00:14:17.120 --> 00:14:23.778
So the broadcast that came in on FA0/1,
it will go out to FA0/3.

228
00:14:23.778 --> 00:14:27.790
But it will also go out to FA0/2, and

229
00:14:27.790 --> 00:14:33.760
when it does that it will actually say,
look, here it is.

230
00:14:33.760 --> 00:14:37.693
What we are going to do is we are going
to also forward it back out FA0/2.

231
00:14:37.693 --> 00:14:42.622
And when it does that it will come
back over to the left-hand side, and

232
00:14:42.622 --> 00:14:47.552
from that the switch over here on
the left-hand side will say, look,

233
00:14:47.552 --> 00:14:51.080
the new source Mac address
that I'm also seeing,

234
00:14:53.165 --> 00:14:58.360
Is coming across from FA0/2.

00:14:58.360 --> 00:15:00.260
Well now look at what's
just happened here,

00:15:00.260 --> 00:15:03.510
if I can actually find my
pen to help us out here.

00:15:07.670 --> 00:15:09.487
Remember where we started off the traffic.

It starting here, we flooded it out,

00:15:15.670 --> 00:15:18.840
Switch over here said, hey,

00:15:18.840 --> 00:15:21.759

00:15:21.759 --> 00:15:25.900

So that's what will end up

00:15:31.100 --> 00:15:33.480
So when you do something,
let me see if I can select that one.

Of course I can't, okay.

00:15:38.180 --> 00:15:41.280
right, it continues to form a loop around,
and

00:15:41.280 --> 00:15:44.310
that's where we'll end up

249
00:15:44.310 --> 00:15:48.623
Now at the same time, the other port will

00:15:48.623 --> 00:15:54.435
So the one that came in on FA0/2,
well that will also get forwarded out,

251
00:15:54.435 --> 00:15:59.343
FA0/3 and also FA0/1, and
send it back out on this side.

252
00:15:59.343 --> 00:16:07.480
And it also will end up reporting Hey,
there's a source Mac address right here.

253
00:16:07.480 --> 00:16:10.210
And then,
you'll actually have some issues, okay?

00:16:10.210 --> 00:16:14.630
Notice the second option here is
what we call Mac table instability.

255
00:16:14.630 --> 00:16:15.760
Mac stable instability.

256
00:16:15.760 --> 00:16:18.000
I only did four ports here as an example.

257
00:16:18.000 --> 00:16:20.600
But you fill in that
entire Mac address table

258
00:16:20.600 --> 00:16:24.650
by just sending the data around
because of the way that it broadcasts.

259
00:16:24.650 --> 00:16:28.280
Well, whatever original data was
in those ports, eventually it will

00:16:28.280 --> 00:16:31.790
push the rest of that out and
then you'll have some instabilities.

261
00:16:31.790 --> 00:16:35.690
Also because we're actually sending the
same packet out both of these interfaces

262
00:16:35.690 --> 00:16:40.090
here on either switch, cuz it's going
to forward it out from the switch over

263
00:16:40.090 --> 00:16:42.130
here on the left-hand side again.

264
00:16:42.130 --> 00:16:45.050
Well, you'll actually end up with
duplicate frames going across this too,

265
00:16:45.050 --> 00:16:46.680
which is a waste of bandwidth.

266
00:16:46.680 --> 00:16:53.350
So, it is a tremendously bad situation
when you end up with a switching loop.

Now along with that, let's take a look

Let's say that what we want to do

00:17:53.640 --> 00:18:00.567

00:18:00.567 --> 00:18:06.490

>> So even if you tried to have

So switching loops are really,

00:21:43.666 --> 00:21:44.560
>> [LAUGH] I think so.

>> And this is why, in Cisco land,

the idea of a spanning tree

00:21:52.010 --> 00:21:55.980
So you and I don't have to go I forgot

00:21:58.710 --> 00:22:00.920

wait a minute, those are single links.

00:22:00.920 --> 00:22:02.970
But it is redundant, right?

00:22:02.970 --> 00:22:06.710
The very fact that even if we actually

00:22:06.710 --> 00:22:07.860
from the left-hand side,

00:22:07.860 --> 00:22:11.390
we'll call it switch one, we still have

00:22:11.390 --> 00:22:16.820
So any time you see any type of redundancy
in the links, it is going to end up having

347
00:22:16.820 --> 00:22:22.620
a problem like this, unless something
intervenes in the switching loop here.

348
00:22:22.620 --> 00:22:26.060
And that's what spanning
tree protocol does for us.

349
00:22:26.060 --> 00:22:30.160
What spanning tree protocol does,
it sounds simple.

00:22:52.840 --> 00:22:57.270

00:23:02.810 --> 00:23:04.920
Okay, that's what we need here.

So right now, if we were to send

00:23:26.820 --> 00:23:31.530
The problem with that is that it

365
00:23:31.530 --> 00:23:34.780
What we want to do is we want

00:23:36.070 --> 00:23:37.890

00:23:37.890 --> 00:23:43.531
And the way it does that is that now

00:23:43.531 --> 00:23:48.803
tree here, spanning tree protocol

to eliminate or to essentially

The very fact is there is

00:24:14.009 --> 00:24:14.726

00:24:15.480 --> 00:24:19.495

the idea if we were to do that, okay?

00:24:19.495 --> 00:24:25.390
Is to be able to take that one,
And to be able to say that there's

00:24:25.390 --> 00:24:30.489
only one path here, because that other
port is gonna be in blocking state, okay?

379
00:24:30.489 --> 00:24:33.783
So that that way you're not
going to form that loop.

00:24:33.783 --> 00:24:37.287
So, regardless of how many

as long as there's a redundancy there,
in other words, probably two or

00:24:47.144 --> 00:24:52.310

00:24:52.310 --> 00:24:56.450
So that you will always
take that same path,

385
00:24:56.450 --> 00:25:01.920
single path, through the entirety

386
00:25:01.920 --> 00:25:05.418
So that is the overall goal

387
00:25:05.418 --> 00:25:07.811
So that that sounds simple, okay?

Is like yeah that makes sense.

>> The very fact is switching

this because the default nature of

Makes sense, okay?

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie explain the STP process.  They describe how the election of root bridge works.  The guys also explain the use of Hello BPDUs and the BID in the election process.  Then they describe what is included in the Hello BPDU.

Well, the way that spanning tree protocol

Well, it's because there is a technical

Yes, you realize that if you

what we can do is make sure that the

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with the STP process.  The process moves now to the nonroot bridge to determine the root port, according to the guys.  This root port is one of the different spanning-tree roles, the team describes, along with designated ports and non designated ports.  They also discuss the different port states and show the result of the spanning tree protocol.
episodes.title: Understand and Configure STP Part 3

00:24:54.373 --> 00:24:59.221
you can actually have different
route bridges for each VLAN.

00:24:59.221 --> 00:25:04.326
Okay so that way, all of the data,
let's say if the blue one

is VLAN 20 is and
the orange one here is VLAN 30, okay?

00:25:09.347 --> 00:25:12.453
So instead of every single
packet of VLAN 20 and

430
00:25:12.453 --> 00:25:17.670
30 going through one switch, you can
divide it up, separate it out here.

431
00:25:17.670 --> 00:25:19.620
Essentially split the traffic up,

432
00:25:19.620 --> 00:25:22.870
where now all the VLAN 20 traffic
goes to the blue one, and

433
00:25:22.870 --> 00:25:27.890
then all the VLAN 30 traffic, and it'll
have to go through the other one, okay?

00:25:27.890 --> 00:25:31.305
The other thing that now becomes
a little bit unusual here,

435
00:25:31.305 --> 00:25:35.060
okay, is that you'll also end
up seeing something else too.

00:25:35.060 --> 00:25:39.970
So it might be where you end
up having where the idea of

00:25:41.550 --> 00:25:44.060
another terminology here, okay?

00:25:44.060 --> 00:25:50.360
So instead of blocking, that actually
used a term discarding or D, okay?

439
00:25:50.360 --> 00:25:53.770
So they don't actually block anything,
they actually just discard it.

00:25:53.770 --> 00:25:55.340
Now is that really any different?

00:25:55.340 --> 00:25:58.640
No, but the reason why this
is actually kind of key for

00:26:02.622 --> 00:26:07.200

00:26:07.200 --> 00:26:09.140
And then I can actually implement, well,

00:26:09.140 --> 00:26:14.730

446
00:26:14.730 --> 00:26:19.820
So I can literally separate it
out like that where this one

00:26:19.820 --> 00:26:24.260

00:26:24.260 --> 00:26:28.770
And this one can forward
traffic to VLAN 30, okay?

00:26:28.770 --> 00:26:32.550
So on both links here, okay,
it literally can discard for

00:26:32.550 --> 00:26:36.430
one VLAN and allow for

00:26:36.430 --> 00:26:38.540
And I can do the same thing back and
forth and

where you actually still have to decide

we want to get across that this

00:26:56.803 --> 00:27:00.223

00:27:53.670 --> 00:27:57.740
That's because, it actually can

00:28:01.920 --> 00:28:05.920

00:28:16.586 --> 00:28:19.360

00:28:22.485 --> 00:28:24.520

00:28:24.520 --> 00:28:27.200

00:28:27.200 --> 00:28:31.605

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie beging to show the result of spanning-tree protocol using the labs.  They demonstrate how identify the root bridge and the different show commands used to see more spanning-tree information.  They also show the use of PVST to set different root bridges for different vlans too.

So spanning-tree,

227
00:13:26.025 --> 00:13:31.372
spanning-tree mode and

228
00:13:31.372 --> 00:13:37.743
we'll type in rapid-pvst.

229
00:13:37.743 --> 00:13:40.661
Now let's see if there's anything
else I need to add in there, nope,

230
00:13:40.661 --> 00:13:42.597
it doesn't look like it,
there it is, okay?

231
00:13:42.597 --> 00:13:45.135
So now when we do something like this.

232
00:13:45.135 --> 00:13:49.013
You go, all right, so everything is
actually working and we should now

233
00:13:49.013 --> 00:13:53.095
be in rapid spanning-tree mode,
well, it takes time once again, okay?

234
00:13:53.095 --> 00:13:55.964
Now we've just kinda changed this mode and

235
00:13:55.964 --> 00:13:59.079
it's now actually kinda
having to take time.

236
00:13:59.079 --> 00:14:03.328
Once you change it,
it can take up to, again, a minute.

237
00:14:03.328 --> 00:14:07.854
Before everything actually does
converge the way that we need to to get

238
00:14:07.854 --> 00:14:09.626
everything settled down.

239
00:14:09.626 --> 00:14:13.932
So don't believe that it's actually
just going to be a snap of a finger and

240
00:14:13.932 --> 00:14:16.299
everything is going to end up changing.

241
00:14:16.299 --> 00:14:20.158
And let me show you what just
happened there, when we changed it,

242
00:14:20.158 --> 00:14:21.783
noticed it went from down.

243
00:14:21.783 --> 00:14:26.023
And it actually stayed down for
what looks like,

244
00:14:26.023 --> 00:14:29.616
almost 20, almost 30 seconds, right?

245
00:14:29.616 --> 00:14:33.448
So as I take a look at that
timestamp here, Zach, okay?

246
00:14:33.448 --> 00:14:34.031
>> Mm-hm.

247
00:14:34.031 --> 00:14:38.688
>> Notice it went down at 02:32:31

248
00:14:38.688 --> 00:14:42.692
>> And then the upstate change, okay?

249
00:14:42.692 --> 00:14:47.594
It actually came back up almost
exactly 30 seconds later before it

250
00:14:47.594 --> 00:14:49.315
actually came back up.

251
00:14:49.315 --> 00:14:53.455
So it didn't take a full minute but
it took 30 seconds before it

252
00:14:53.455 --> 00:14:56.608
could actually go ahead and
do what we need it to.

253
00:14:56.608 --> 00:14:59.354
So right at the beginning, it does that.

254
00:14:59.354 --> 00:15:03.605
Now, does that actually affect
another switch though as we start

255
00:15:03.605 --> 00:15:05.469
to see something like that?

256
00:15:05.469 --> 00:15:08.237
Well, let's go and
check out any effect here first.

257
00:15:08.237 --> 00:15:15.607
So let's verify that we are actually
running this mode instead,

258
00:15:15.607 --> 00:15:20.163
and we do a show spanning-tree vlan1.

259
00:15:20.163 --> 00:15:26.791
I'll just take this one for right now,
and now notice it has changed here, okay?

260
00:15:26.791 --> 00:15:31.531
Rapid spanning tree protocol has
actually been changed right here, so

261
00:15:31.531 --> 00:15:34.227
we are actually able to see that change.

262
00:15:34.227 --> 00:15:39.196
And now that means that these things can
actually come up faster if we don't have

263
00:15:39.196 --> 00:15:40.988
BPDUs coming through them.

264
00:15:40.988 --> 00:15:46.760
But also notice the change here too,
okay, underneath the Type,

265
00:15:46.760 --> 00:15:52.444
notice one says Peer and
the other one here just says P2P, okay?

266
00:15:52.444 --> 00:15:58.068
So these are still operating on legacy And
what does that it actually means for

267
00:15:58.068 --> 00:16:01.910
us if that one is still
operating on legacy?

268
00:16:01.910 --> 00:16:06.652
Well that one actually means that
these ports are connected to other

269
00:16:06.652 --> 00:16:11.738
switches in which are probably not
running rapid spanning tree, okay?

270
00:16:11.738 --> 00:16:16.232
So when you see that peer(STP) you now
have where probably the other switch is

271
00:16:16.232 --> 00:16:18.206
running per VLAN spanning tree and

272
00:16:18.206 --> 00:16:21.990
this one is running the rapid
spanning tree protocol.

273
00:16:21.990 --> 00:16:24.510
The nice thing is you can leave it, okay?

274
00:16:24.510 --> 00:16:26.951
They're backward compatible,
they will work just fine.

275
00:16:26.951 --> 00:16:30.950
But remember what this is saying,
that even if this is set to rapid,

276
00:16:30.950 --> 00:16:35.022
it's still gonna operate just like
per VLAN spanning tree unless you

277
00:16:35.022 --> 00:16:37.429
change it as what it's actually doing.

278
00:16:37.429 --> 00:16:40.585
But if I go to NYCORE2 now,

279
00:16:46.119 --> 00:16:50.523
And now I do a show spanning-tree vlan1.

280
00:16:53.784 --> 00:16:57.850
We can now see where that's exactly
what it's saying here is that it's

281
00:16:57.850 --> 00:17:01.880
still running the IEEE and
now look at this here, okay?

282
00:17:01.880 --> 00:17:05.210
So there is actually something
else going on right here.

283
00:17:05.210 --> 00:17:10.545
And it's saying, hey,
this type is actually an *TYPE_Inc, okay?

284
00:17:10.545 --> 00:17:15.130
So this is something else that's actually
a little bit different where it's

285
00:17:15.130 --> 00:17:19.658
actually finding like look here's
the state that I'm actually in, okay?

286
00:17:19.658 --> 00:17:22.990
BKN, whatever that actually
state means there,

287
00:17:22.990 --> 00:17:27.589
some type of blocking at some point
I believe is what that one means but

288
00:17:27.589 --> 00:17:33.190
with an asterisk here meaning that's
a candidate for blocking now too okay?

289
00:17:33.190 --> 00:17:36.646
So it's actually probably having
a mismatch between what it's trying

290
00:17:36.646 --> 00:17:40.736
to report from here, all the way to rapid
spanning tree because sometimes the actual

291
00:17:40.736 --> 00:17:44.782
terminology changes, and we're probably
seeing that information as well okay?

292
00:17:44.782 --> 00:17:49.022
So that's really kinda the end of what
we're actually trying to take a look

293
00:17:49.022 --> 00:17:49.574
at here.

294
00:17:49.574 --> 00:17:55.128
But just remember that even though they
are not exactly 100% matching protocols,

295
00:17:55.128 --> 00:17:56.585
they are compatible.

296
00:17:56.585 --> 00:18:01.082
So whether you wanna run per VLAN rapid
spanning tree, rapid VLAN spanning tree or

297
00:18:01.082 --> 00:18:04.089
even STP, which you can't
do on this switch at least.

298
00:18:04.089 --> 00:18:06.160
It's not gonna allow
you to do that anymore.

299
00:18:06.160 --> 00:18:09.460
At least those two, you can actually
make them work together, and

300
00:18:09.460 --> 00:18:11.640
you don't have to reconfigure anything but

301
00:18:11.640 --> 00:18:14.750
it's probably gonna be better if you do
reconfigure them all to actually match,

302
00:18:14.750 --> 00:18:19.110
cuz it will probably help out, once again,
all the devices on your network to do so.

303
00:18:19.110 --> 00:18:22.210
But we're not really getting into
a lot of the technicalities,

304
00:18:22.210 --> 00:18:25.500
at least in our lab here
on rapid spanning tree.

305
00:18:25.500 --> 00:18:29.300
But yes, do take a look at that,
and what it can do for you.

306
00:18:29.300 --> 00:18:32.722
But we've kind of described the gist of
what you'll actually need as you get ready

307
00:18:32.722 --> 00:18:35.520
for the exam.
>> A wonderful foundation from Ronnie,

308
00:18:35.520 --> 00:18:38.546
Understand and Configure STP,
the mini-series.

309
00:18:38.546 --> 00:18:39.560
>> Yes.

310
00:18:39.560 --> 00:18:40.860
>> Parts one through five,

311
00:18:40.860 --> 00:18:44.730
make sure you watch them and
digest them and get going on them.

312
00:18:44.730 --> 00:18:47.280
And by the way, Ronnie, anything else
you'd like to say before we move on?

313
00:18:47.280 --> 00:18:47.872
>> Yeah well,

314
00:18:47.872 --> 00:18:51.732
just remember to take some time here,
and don't rush through this process.

315
00:18:51.732 --> 00:18:55.010
Research what you don't understand and
know.

316
00:18:55.010 --> 00:18:57.770
Make sure you ask
questions if you need to.

317
00:18:57.770 --> 00:19:01.340
And take advantage of what
we have access to in our

318
00:19:01.340 --> 00:19:03.410
forums to ask those questions as well.

319
00:19:03.410 --> 00:19:07.330
But on this one, it is kind of the newest
topic that we've come across but

320
00:19:07.330 --> 00:19:11.252
we haven't had to actually just go you
remember a lot of these topics from

321
00:19:11.252 --> 00:19:13.940
the CISCO CSAT cuz this one is brand new.
>> Mm-hm.

322
00:19:13.940 --> 00:19:15.320
>> Just slow down and

323
00:19:15.320 --> 00:19:19.000
make sure you digest this
information before you move on.

324
00:19:19.000 --> 00:19:23.190
Don't move onto a more difficult topic
when you don't have another one already

325
00:19:23.190 --> 00:19:26.030
at least understood
before you move on here.

326
00:19:26.030 --> 00:19:29.107
Cuz that will kind of build up and
then anxiety will build up and

327
00:19:29.107 --> 00:19:33.350
you won't be ready for the exam.
>> Great advice from Ronnie once again.

328
00:19:33.350 --> 00:19:36.370
CCNA Routing and Switching Exam 200-105,

329
00:19:36.370 --> 00:19:42.300
please watch all of the episodes, watch
them carefully, and watch them again.

330
00:19:42.300 --> 00:19:45.632
And while you're at it you'll be in the
course library where there's thousands of

331
00:19:45.632 --> 00:19:47.544
other videos there,
designed to do one thing.

332
00:19:47.544 --> 00:19:49.340
To help you go further.

333
00:19:49.340 --> 00:19:51.782
Check those out too.
Tell every you know about ITProTV.

334
00:19:51.782 --> 00:19:53.940
ITProTV is binge worthy.

335
00:19:53.940 --> 00:19:56.414
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

336
00:19:56.414 --> 00:19:57.386
>> And we will see you again soon.

337
00:19:57.386 --> 00:20:04.580
[MUSIC]

338
00:20:04.580 --> 00:20:07.316
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe some of the layer 2 attacks that may need to be mitigated.  They show the application of 802.1x and DHCP snooping.  Lastly, they configure the nondefault native LAN.
episodes.title: Configure PortFast and BPDU guard
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:05.362
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:05.362 --> 00:00:11.597
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.597 --> 00:00:14.124
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

4
00:00:14.124 --> 00:00:16.550
helping you learn everywhere you go.

5
00:00:16.550 --> 00:00:21.063
I'm your host, Zach Memos, for
this episode of CCNA Routing and

6
00:00:21.063 --> 00:00:23.622
Switching, Exam 200-105.

7
00:00:23.622 --> 00:00:29.020
This episode is Configure PortFast and
BPDU Guard.

8
00:00:29.020 --> 00:00:30.607
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now see I did that slowly to make sure

9
00:00:30.607 --> 00:00:31.378
I didn't make a mistake.

10
00:00:31.378 --> 00:00:31.946
>> Right.

11
00:00:31.946 --> 00:00:34.359
>> The person bringing us all
the information we need is Ronnie Wong,

12
00:00:34.359 --> 00:00:35.660
Ronnie, good to see you sir.

13
00:00:35.660 --> 00:00:36.480
>> Hello again, Zach.

14
00:00:36.480 --> 00:00:40.240
Thank you for joining me today as we
continue on in our CCNA Routing and

15
00:00:40.240 --> 00:00:41.400
Switching show.

16
00:00:41.400 --> 00:00:44.170
Today we are jumping into
exactly like what Zach said,

17
00:00:44.170 --> 00:00:49.010
is talking about the idea of using
PortFast and then BPDU Guard.

18
00:00:49.010 --> 00:00:52.360
Now, when we start talking about that,
you might go finally Ronnie,

19
00:00:52.360 --> 00:00:55.070
after five episodes of
spanning tree protocol.

20
00:00:55.070 --> 00:00:56.130
We are done with that and

21
00:00:56.130 --> 00:00:59.395
we should never have to actually
darken the doorsteps of that again.

22
00:00:59.395 --> 00:01:01.434
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I'd be lying to you, and

23
00:01:01.434 --> 00:01:06.749
the reason why is that, we talk about
these technologies right here, the idea of

24
00:01:06.749 --> 00:01:12.630
PortFast and BPDU guard, essentially it's
tuning the idea of spanning tree protocol.

25
00:01:12.630 --> 00:01:13.290
>> Fine tuning.

26
00:01:13.290 --> 00:01:15.033
>> Yeah, it's really fine tuning and

27
00:01:15.033 --> 00:01:18.241
actually helping it along to do
the things we that we want it to do.

28
00:01:18.241 --> 00:01:22.147
And try and make it a little bit more
efficient in some of the things we want it

29
00:01:22.147 --> 00:01:23.720
to do as well, okay.

30
00:01:23.720 --> 00:01:27.560
So, if we remember, we're not gonna go
through all the spanning tree again, but

31
00:01:27.560 --> 00:01:32.100
let's talk about one of the primary kind
of downfalls of spanning tree protocol.

32
00:01:32.100 --> 00:01:35.960
It does great in everything that it needs
to do such as blocking the ports it needs.

33
00:01:35.960 --> 00:01:39.864
Ensuring that we only have a single
path through our switch network,

34
00:01:39.864 --> 00:01:43.984
so that we don't end up with routing
loops which can cause real dangers.

35
00:01:43.984 --> 00:01:47.717
But the downfall, again downfall
is probably too harsh of a word,

36
00:01:47.717 --> 00:01:51.396
the drawback of it or the idea of
the issues that have to deal with.

37
00:01:51.396 --> 00:01:52.212
>> Issues, there you go.

38
00:01:52.212 --> 00:01:57.110
>> Yeah, it really comes down to the idea
of well, more than anything, speed, okay?

39
00:01:57.110 --> 00:02:00.610
It takes some time for
us to end up converging.

40
00:02:00.610 --> 00:02:04.890
In other words, it takes a little bit of
time before spanning tree kicks in and

41
00:02:04.890 --> 00:02:06.960
works the way that it needs to.

42
00:02:06.960 --> 00:02:11.220
So during that time, right,
we've talked about what ends up happening.

43
00:02:11.220 --> 00:02:16.000
All the ports on the switch end up going
through some of the different port states.

44
00:02:16.000 --> 00:02:19.064
We've talked about blocking,
listening, learning and then,

45
00:02:19.064 --> 00:02:21.749
of course, forwarding or
blocking again if it needs to.

46
00:02:21.749 --> 00:02:27.580
And then, even the idea of disabled is
technically a port state as well, okay?

47
00:02:27.580 --> 00:02:31.251
But that can go anywhere
between 30 to 50 seconds, okay,

48
00:02:31.251 --> 00:02:33.664
depending on how it's actually set up.

49
00:02:33.664 --> 00:02:36.313
We showed you that there's
other technologies that

50
00:02:36.313 --> 00:02:39.080
are out there such as using
the per VLAN spanning tree,

51
00:02:39.080 --> 00:02:42.490
and the rapid VLAN spanning
tree that bring that time down.

52
00:02:42.490 --> 00:02:45.960
But some of the other things that we want
to do to actually tune this a little bit

53
00:02:45.960 --> 00:02:47.160
better of course,

54
00:02:47.160 --> 00:02:52.080
is that we wanna make sure that it
only works when we need it to, okay?

55
00:02:52.080 --> 00:02:56.110
And the idea right, at least currently
when we talk about the way that we've been

56
00:02:56.110 --> 00:03:00.300
discussing spanning tree is that,
hey when you turn it on, it's enabled.

57
00:03:00.300 --> 00:03:04.240
It's just going to work, and it can
take whatever period of time it needs to

58
00:03:04.240 --> 00:03:06.550
to do everything that it needs to.

59
00:03:06.550 --> 00:03:09.426
Well remember I also mentioned
during that series as well,

60
00:03:09.426 --> 00:03:11.046
that if I have a 48 port switch.

61
00:03:11.046 --> 00:03:15.758
Well every single port on that switch
essentially has to take the time to go

62
00:03:15.758 --> 00:03:20.394
through those different port states
before it arrives at what it needs to

63
00:03:20.394 --> 00:03:24.840
in its final state and not
a transitional state that it's in, okay?

64
00:03:24.840 --> 00:03:29.879
So in that sense of things,
there are things that we can do, and

65
00:03:29.879 --> 00:03:34.820
using PortFast and BPDU Guard will
help us out to do that, okay?

66
00:03:34.820 --> 00:03:39.180
So remember that when we started off
with the idea of spanning tree, okay.

67
00:03:39.180 --> 00:03:42.789
What starts to happen is that because
this is actually on as a protocol

68
00:03:42.789 --> 00:03:45.776
in the background,
when we plug two switches together,

69
00:03:45.776 --> 00:03:49.346
they will begin sending out particular
message type to each other.

70
00:03:49.346 --> 00:03:54.592
That we call a BPDU, okay,
a bridge protocol data unit.

71
00:03:54.592 --> 00:03:55.629
If you're saying,

72
00:03:55.629 --> 00:04:00.152
well why are we talking about bridges when
we're actually still using switches today?

73
00:04:00.152 --> 00:04:03.159
That's because that's when
this technology was developed,

74
00:04:03.159 --> 00:04:07.270
that's when the protocol was essentially
created, if you want to call it that.

75
00:04:07.270 --> 00:04:11.120
And then at that point, right,
we still use that terminology.

76
00:04:11.120 --> 00:04:13.630
And so in the background,
that's the terminology we're still using,

77
00:04:13.630 --> 00:04:18.170
it's called a BPDU, and that BPDU
helps out with the election process.

78
00:04:18.170 --> 00:04:21.570
And actually continues to
affirm that election process

79
00:04:21.570 --> 00:04:23.950
just about every two seconds,
if I remember correctly,

80
00:04:23.950 --> 00:04:26.880
as we started to look at some of
the different timers that we have.

81
00:04:26.880 --> 00:04:30.500
So it's a lot of these messages
that come out that's constant.

82
00:04:30.500 --> 00:04:34.990
Well, the only devices that
tend to send BPDUs though,

83
00:04:34.990 --> 00:04:39.280
okay, are devices that are in
the midst of that election process.

84
00:04:39.280 --> 00:04:40.690
But once the election is done and

85
00:04:40.690 --> 00:04:46.080
somebody has decided to be the root bridge
at that point, well then only that root

86
00:04:46.080 --> 00:04:51.740
bridge begins to advertise out
the idea of BPDU use, okay?

87
00:04:51.740 --> 00:04:56.360
So that is the only one, so regardless of
whether we have 3 switches, or 2 switches,

88
00:04:56.360 --> 00:05:01.810
or 5 switches or 15 switches,
only 1 will actually issue out BPDUs.

89
00:05:01.810 --> 00:05:04.810
And then the other switches
will just propagate that along

90
00:05:04.810 --> 00:05:07.260
to other switches as it begins to see it.

91
00:05:07.260 --> 00:05:11.450
So that's all it does, but
nobody else originates those BPDUs, okay?

92
00:05:11.450 --> 00:05:16.710
So if you think about it, when should
we actually hear another BPDU, okay?

93
00:05:16.710 --> 00:05:20.860
Well, we really shouldn't,
unless that switch goes down.

94
00:05:20.860 --> 00:05:23.800
Now unless the root
bridge itself goes down,

95
00:05:23.800 --> 00:05:27.050
then an election process will happen
again with the remaining switches and

96
00:05:27.050 --> 00:05:30.380
then you'll have BPDUs from
other switches too, okay?

97
00:05:30.380 --> 00:05:35.700
So that means that if a network is stable,
we should only have one,

98
00:05:35.700 --> 00:05:39.940
that one switch, the root bridge
itself sending out the BPDUs.

99
00:05:39.940 --> 00:05:41.630
So in other words,

100
00:05:41.630 --> 00:05:44.980
what we also want to do is realize that
we're gonna have other types of devices

101
00:05:44.980 --> 00:05:49.410
connecting to our switches that
probably will never send out BPDUs.

102
00:05:49.410 --> 00:05:54.320
So for example, a desktop computer
isn't gonna send out a BPDU okay,

103
00:05:54.320 --> 00:05:58.790
a server that we attach to it
is not gonna send out a BPDU.

104
00:05:58.790 --> 00:06:02.010
And that's the majority of
the ports that we work with

105
00:06:02.010 --> 00:06:03.590
when we actually work with switches.

106
00:06:03.590 --> 00:06:07.260
Setting up the spanning tree protocol,
we don't even to set that up.

107
00:06:07.260 --> 00:06:10.098
We just have to verify that it's
working and we can manipulate and

108
00:06:10.098 --> 00:06:11.552
change it the way that we want to.

109
00:06:11.552 --> 00:06:14.887

the problem has to be fixed first, okay?

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with another way to configure Etherchannel.  They describe PAgP and LACP and demonstrate it's configuration, paying attention to the terms. Using the show etherchannel summary command, they describe how to verify it has changed to PAgP and that it is operational unless both switches are set to auto or passive
