490
00:27:55.722 --> 00:27:58.561
Do not take LACPs syntax, right, and

491
00:27:58.561 --> 00:28:04.347
then think that you can put that together
with the desirable and auto, okay?

492
00:28:04.347 --> 00:28:08.248
So if you're configuring LACP, you're
not gonna configure desirable in auto.

493
00:28:08.248 --> 00:28:12.150
If you're configuring PAgP, you're not
gonna use active and passive, okay?

494
00:28:12.150 --> 00:28:14.778
It sounds simple enough until it's for

495
00:28:14.778 --> 00:28:19.940
a timed exam, and now your brain is
running through like, which one?

496
00:28:19.940 --> 00:28:22.491
Was PAgP active, or was that desirable?

497
00:28:22.491 --> 00:28:26.140
Or was one side supposed to be active and
the other side auto?

498
00:28:26.140 --> 00:28:30.490
Now, you've gotta remember that all these
are set up specifically for this, and

499
00:28:30.490 --> 00:28:33.210
you've gotta keep it clear and
free of technology.

500
00:28:33.210 --> 00:28:35.150
PAgP, Cisco proprietary.

501
00:28:35.150 --> 00:28:39.520
LACP, is gonna be vendor neutral,
should be able to be worked between

502
00:28:39.520 --> 00:28:41.740
all the other devices that
support LACP as well,

503
00:28:41.740 --> 00:28:45.660
and that's probably more common of
what you'll see in today's networks.

504
00:28:45.660 --> 00:28:49.540
All right, Zach, we've got one
more technology to actually cover.

505
00:28:49.540 --> 00:28:50.800
This one is a little bit stranger.

506
00:28:50.800 --> 00:28:54.130
It's not gonna take us a long time,
but it is something that we call

507
00:28:54.130 --> 00:28:59.150
Layer 3 EtherChannel that we have
to actually consider as well.

508
00:28:59.150 --> 00:29:04.790
I'm gonna show you how to take this and
make it a routed port as well.

509
00:29:04.790 --> 00:29:06.970
So that's gonna actually be
interesting as we do that.

510
00:29:06.970 --> 00:29:09.570
But Zach, I am out of time again.

511
00:29:09.570 --> 00:29:12.320
So it looks like we'll have to
carry on to another part here.

512
00:29:12.320 --> 00:29:13.820
>> Well done, Ronnie, well done.

513
00:29:13.820 --> 00:29:15.739
So configure ether channel part two.

514
00:29:15.739 --> 00:29:16.690
We will have a part three.

515
00:29:16.690 --> 00:29:19.490
Make sure you see all three parts,
important.

516
00:29:19.490 --> 00:29:20.130
Very important.

517
00:29:20.130 --> 00:29:22.420
And Ronnie, you look like you
wanna say something else.

518
00:29:22.420 --> 00:29:27.749
>> Well, once again,
terminology 100% important at this point.

519
00:29:27.749 --> 00:29:29.300
We only showed you one example, right?

520
00:29:29.300 --> 00:29:32.875
And usually it's not that difficult
to know as you're actually doing it.

521
00:29:32.875 --> 00:29:35.950
The hard part is remembering it all for
the exam.

522
00:29:35.950 --> 00:29:39.080
The only way for
you to do this is be in it daily.

523
00:29:39.080 --> 00:29:42.240
Make sure you go through these
technologies that you're less familiar

524
00:29:42.240 --> 00:29:44.750
with more on a daily basis.

525
00:29:44.750 --> 00:29:49.220
The ones you're more familiar, again, let
that kinda go, I need to review that, but

526
00:29:49.220 --> 00:29:52.270
that's not important as
the ones I'm unfamiliar with.

527
00:29:52.270 --> 00:29:56.307
So make sure you make the time to go
through these and it gets into your head

528
00:29:56.307 --> 00:30:00.211
because this is where it's going to
actually really matter, is do you

529
00:30:00.211 --> 00:30:04.937
know the technology itself, and that is
what Cisco is actually testing on, right?

530
00:30:04.937 --> 00:30:08.912
Not testing on whether you can name the 16
different facts, but actually testing

531
00:30:08.912 --> 00:30:13.116
whether or not you actually understand the
technology that's actually before you, so

532
00:30:13.116 --> 00:30:15.100
make sure you pay attention there.

533
00:30:15.100 --> 00:30:18.596
>> Well said, Ronnie, and make sure
you take the time to go through every

534
00:30:18.596 --> 00:30:22.230
single episode of CCNA, routing,
switching, exam 200-105.

535
00:30:22.230 --> 00:30:25.910
You'll be very glad you did!

536
00:30:25.910 --> 00:30:27.540
And you'll be in the course library, too.

537
00:30:27.540 --> 00:30:31.287
And there's thousands of other videos
there designed to help you go further, so

538
00:30:31.287 --> 00:30:32.289
look at those, too.

539
00:30:32.289 --> 00:30:34.958
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

540
00:30:34.958 --> 00:30:35.980
ITProTV is binge worthy.

541
00:30:35.980 --> 00:30:36.920
Thanks for watching.

542
00:30:36.920 --> 00:30:37.790
I'm Zach Memos.

543
00:30:37.790 --> 00:30:38.630
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

544
00:30:38.630 --> 00:30:44.456
>> And we will see you soon.

545
00:30:44.456 --> 00:30:46.679
[MUSIC]

546
00:30:46.679 --> 00:30:49.540
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure a layer 3 etherchannel.  The demonstrate how to remove previous EtherChannel configuration.  They point out how is different from the layer 2 etherchannel
episodes.title: Configure Etherchannel Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.576
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.576 --> 00:00:04.869
Coming at you live from San Francisco.

3
00:00:04.869 --> 00:00:07.239
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.239 --> 00:00:08.226
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:08.226 --> 00:00:10.683
>> Hello, and thank you for

6
00:00:10.683 --> 00:00:16.420
choosing ITPRO.TV helping
you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.420 --> 00:00:17.770
I'm your host Zack Memos.

8
00:00:17.770 --> 00:00:23.340
This episode of CCNA Routing and
Switching Exam 200-105,

9
00:00:23.340 --> 00:00:29.200
Configure Etherchannel Part 3,
is the title of this episode.

10
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:31.290
And once again,
Ronnie Wong is with us to help us out.

11
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:32.790
Ronnie, thanks for joining us.

12
00:00:32.790 --> 00:00:37.100
>> Thank you for again, being with me as
we continue through our CCNA routing and

13
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:38.310
switching show.

14
00:00:38.310 --> 00:00:43.040
We are now taking a look at a third
part here of course of etherchannel, and

15
00:00:43.040 --> 00:00:46.580
we're focusing on some new technology
that you may have actually heard about or

16
00:00:46.580 --> 00:00:50.760
you may not have,
which is Layer 3 Etherchannel.

17
00:00:50.760 --> 00:00:52.640
So this is a little bit strange, right?

18
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:53.900
The very fact that you and

19
00:00:53.900 --> 00:00:58.500
I might aggregate links that we've
talked about between switches, right?

20
00:00:58.500 --> 00:01:02.630
To be able to actually
use that extra bandwidth.

21
00:01:02.630 --> 00:01:04.120
Seems to be natural and normal.

22
00:01:04.120 --> 00:01:05.720
It seems to be great.

23
00:01:05.720 --> 00:01:09.330
The idea that we might need extra
bandwidth between those switches.

24
00:01:09.330 --> 00:01:10.370
Sounds like a good idea,

25
00:01:10.370 --> 00:01:13.900
but why would I actually need
something that layered three to do so?

26
00:01:13.900 --> 00:01:17.760
That's kind of the question that you and
I have to actually ponder and

27
00:01:17.760 --> 00:01:19.240
think about for a moment.

28
00:01:19.240 --> 00:01:22.740
Most of the time I can't think of
a really good reason to do so.

29
00:01:22.740 --> 00:01:25.330
But for those people that may
end up working of course,

30
00:01:25.330 --> 00:01:28.460
in edge networks,
I shouldn't say edge networks,

31
00:01:28.460 --> 00:01:32.970
actually, service provider networks,
this is something you may choose to do.

32
00:01:32.970 --> 00:01:36.990
So there may be where you do
have different VLANs of course,

33
00:01:36.990 --> 00:01:39.860
in different locations and
different places.

34
00:01:39.860 --> 00:01:42.730
And I mean geographically different.

35
00:01:42.730 --> 00:01:45.530
Well, sometimes what you
have the ability to do,

36
00:01:45.530 --> 00:01:49.250
is on one switch let's say
we set up VLAN 10, but then

37
00:01:49.250 --> 00:01:54.150
on another switch somewhere down the line,
you don't have VLAN 30 or anything else.

38
00:01:55.260 --> 00:01:59.690
And you also don't,
maybe you don't actually end up having

39
00:01:59.690 --> 00:02:03.650
where in that configuration,
where VTP is turned on,

40
00:02:03.650 --> 00:02:07.820
you don't get direct access into that VLAN
30, that maybe two or three switches away.

41
00:02:07.820 --> 00:02:12.640
But you still need to be able
to send data down that way, and

42
00:02:12.640 --> 00:02:16.200
have aggregated information between them.

43
00:02:16.200 --> 00:02:21.000
So it could be that you're already running
that port channel that is configured,

44
00:02:21.000 --> 00:02:23.540
that lead you from where
your switch is down to

45
00:02:23.540 --> 00:02:27.260
a somewhere exterior wherever you
are that leads to another switch.

46
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:30.580
And it's actually all the way aggregated
all the way down that far, but

47
00:02:30.580 --> 00:02:34.980
you don't actually want to send it on that
layer to either channel along the way.

48
00:02:34.980 --> 00:02:36.190
You want to be able to route it.

49
00:02:36.190 --> 00:02:39.182
Because it's actually in a different VLAN,
it's actually somewhere else.

50
00:02:39.182 --> 00:02:40.530
You wanna be able to do that,

51
00:02:40.530 --> 00:02:45.090
well that's why you choose to use
Layer 3 etherchannel instead.

52
00:02:45.090 --> 00:02:49.490
So, it doesn't make much sense to the
majority of us because we probably will

53
00:02:49.490 --> 00:02:51.970
end up working in an office environment,

54
00:02:51.970 --> 00:02:54.840
in a single network environment,
in that sense.

55
00:02:54.840 --> 00:02:58.010
But in terms of actually being able
to do this between, let's say,

56
00:02:58.010 --> 00:03:03.070
a campus with multiple buildings and
doing this, it may be the way to go,

57
00:03:03.070 --> 00:03:05.490
where you might actually choose
to do something like this.

58
00:03:05.490 --> 00:03:08.140
Layer 3 etherchannel is
going to be doing this.

59
00:03:08.140 --> 00:03:13.440
Now to do this, we wanna create our own
port channel is what we want to do.

60
00:03:13.440 --> 00:03:18.240
And we also wanna get rid of the current
etherchannel that we have on our switches.

61
00:03:18.240 --> 00:03:22.570
But that is what we gonna do first, and
then we reestablish this with layer three,

62
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:26.540
making routed ports on the actual
channel itself for us.

63
00:03:27.900 --> 00:03:30.540
So lets go ahead and
remove the configuration.

64
00:03:30.540 --> 00:03:33.610
Now, I was gonna do this
between our break here.

65
00:03:33.610 --> 00:03:37.670
But I showed you one part of actually
just removing the configuration.

66
00:03:37.670 --> 00:03:39.850
But I didn't show you
removing the port channel.

67
00:03:39.850 --> 00:03:41.510
So I said let me go ahead and
show that as well.

68
00:03:41.510 --> 00:03:45.180
So let's go ahead and jump right in,
and we'll get that one configured.

69
00:03:45.180 --> 00:03:48.560
So once I'm in my global
configuration mode here.

70
00:03:48.560 --> 00:03:52.060
I want to get access into the range.

71
00:03:52.060 --> 00:03:55.765
Interface range for where I created this.

72
00:03:55.765 --> 00:04:02.931
Interface range fa1/0/23- 24.

73
00:04:02.931 --> 00:04:10.070
Then I'm gonna just do a no channel-group
and I can just generically do a 1.

74
00:04:10.070 --> 00:04:13.200
That removes the actual channel group
itself, I don't have to be very specific

75
00:04:13.200 --> 00:04:17.690
about what I did the last time, but yes
you see where I actually removed it there.

76
00:04:17.690 --> 00:04:19.935
But then the next one here is no.

77
00:04:19.935 --> 00:04:25.202
So I've exited out,
I'm in the global configuration mode.

78
00:04:25.202 --> 00:04:29.424
And now, I also do a no interface.

79
00:04:32.588 --> 00:04:35.850
Port-channel 1.

80
00:04:39.354 --> 00:04:41.040
And that will also get
rid of that interface.

81
00:04:41.040 --> 00:04:42.860
Now you probably will say,
how can you do that?

82
00:04:42.860 --> 00:04:45.080
Well, remember that this
is a virtual interface.

83
00:04:45.080 --> 00:04:47.230
So it's not a physical
port that I'm getting of.

84
00:04:47.230 --> 00:04:50.280
I'm just getting rid of a virtual
interface one that's been configured

85
00:04:50.280 --> 00:04:51.350
in software.

86
00:04:51.350 --> 00:04:54.916
We want to do the same
thing over on NYCORE2.

87
00:04:54.916 --> 00:04:59.776
So we'll do it one more time here, so
we can actually have the base mached

88
00:04:59.776 --> 00:05:04.167
up that we need to before we
configure this for layer 3 ethernet.

89
00:05:04.167 --> 00:05:06.253
Yeah, etherchannel.

90
00:05:06.253 --> 00:05:08.150
So the same thing over here.

91
00:05:13.528 --> 00:05:15.510
So, if I do this quickly.

92
00:05:17.060 --> 00:05:23.028
Then we want to say no channel-group 1.

93
00:05:23.028 --> 00:05:28.861
And then exit and then no int port 1.

94
00:05:33.955 --> 00:05:35.970
And that should do it as well.

95
00:05:35.970 --> 00:05:39.940
So now we're back to where there's no
port channel configuration on this, and

96
00:05:39.940 --> 00:05:48.000
we are now ready to configure the NYCORE1
with a routed interface or ether channel.

97
00:05:48.000 --> 00:05:52.530
So let's go back to NYCORE1 here and
you'll see the difference.

98
00:05:52.530 --> 00:05:56.450
It's not really a lot of difference,
but remember that on most switches.

99
00:05:56.450 --> 00:06:00.670
You and I cannot put an IP
address on an interface.

100
00:06:00.670 --> 00:06:04.412
So it's not just actually allowed
because is a layer two device, but

101
00:06:04.412 --> 00:06:08.038
we can configure it to do so, and
make it a routed port If we need to.

102
00:06:08.038 --> 00:06:11.959
So on NYCORE1, let's go back into
our global configuration mode, and

103
00:06:11.959 --> 00:06:14.221
we're gonna choose the same range here.

104
00:06:14.221 --> 00:06:22.920
Interface range fa1/0/23- 24.

105
00:06:22.920 --> 00:06:27.390
And the way that we are able to
configure an IP address on this,

106
00:06:27.390 --> 00:06:30.760
is that we type in the word no switchport.

107
00:06:32.580 --> 00:06:37.630
Now, when you, I have to spell switchport
correctly, no switchport, how's that?

108
00:06:37.630 --> 00:06:41.330
There we go, it helps, and
like I said syntax, if it's bad it's bad.

109
00:06:41.330 --> 00:06:42.335
It just doesn't accept it.

110
00:06:42.335 --> 00:06:43.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're fine.

111
00:06:43.680 --> 00:06:48.190
Now once we actually tell it no
switchboard, NYCORE1 is actually a 3750,

112
00:06:48.190 --> 00:06:51.880
which if you're not familiar with
numbers that doesn't mean anything.

113
00:06:51.880 --> 00:06:54.300
But it's essentially a layer three switch.

114
00:06:54.300 --> 00:06:59.090
Which means it will allow you to actually
put routing information on its interfaces,

115
00:06:59.090 --> 00:07:00.390
so that we can do this.

116
00:07:00.390 --> 00:07:03.920
This will not work with a layer
two switch directly, but

117
00:07:03.920 --> 00:07:06.890
you need a layer three
switch that can do this.

118
00:07:06.890 --> 00:07:11.618
So now that I actually have no
switch port configured here,

119
00:07:11.618 --> 00:07:16.265
now I want to go ahead and
turn on the actual ether channel.

120
00:07:16.265 --> 00:07:20.804
So this time, we're not using PagP we're
not going to actually end up using LagP.

121
00:07:20.804 --> 00:07:23.930
We're just gonna set it as on statically.

122
00:07:23.930 --> 00:07:29.310
So the great thing is, you and I have
already done this, channel-group here.

123
00:07:29.310 --> 00:07:31.439
And for us this is going to be,

124
00:07:31.439 --> 00:07:35.881
once we get the channel -group
we need a number and mode is on.

125
00:07:35.881 --> 00:07:40.670
And that means we are hard setting
the actual port interface to on here.

126
00:07:42.987 --> 00:07:45.107
And we are fine.

127
00:07:45.107 --> 00:07:50.729
Now once that's on,
now I can enter into that interface,

128
00:07:50.729 --> 00:07:53.499
interface port channel 1.

129
00:07:53.499 --> 00:07:57.573
And look at it it actually did change, it
says hey all right that's fine you can now

130
00:07:57.573 --> 00:08:00.510
configure this and
work with it as an interface.

131
00:08:00.510 --> 00:08:02.620
So can I apply an IP address?

132
00:08:04.270 --> 00:08:08.910
I can do IP address if I
can spell it correctly, and

133
00:08:08.910 --> 00:08:14.999
I want 192.168.18.1 with
a 24-bit subnet mask.

134
00:08:16.143 --> 00:08:18.820
And we'll go ahead and leave it like that.

135
00:08:18.820 --> 00:08:21.720
So there is something that you don't
see every day, most of us don't end up

136
00:08:21.720 --> 00:08:25.840
assigning IP addresses on switch
interfaces, but here you go.

137
00:08:25.840 --> 00:08:32.390
So we've now actually bundled
together fast ethernet 1/0/23 and 24,

138
00:08:32.390 --> 00:08:38.010
and not only that we do that, we change
it from a switch port to a routed port,

139
00:08:38.010 --> 00:08:40.630
we add an IP address to that port now.

140
00:08:41.750 --> 00:08:44.670
So, if I can actually do that but

141
00:08:44.670 --> 00:08:48.540
remember that we actually created
that port channel first now.

142
00:08:48.540 --> 00:08:53.400
So this way, as we continue to go through
this, we'll actually end up seeing that it

143
00:08:53.400 --> 00:08:58.320
will end up working like just routing
between two switches on the other side.

144
00:08:58.320 --> 00:09:00.530
We want to reconfigure NYCORE2,

145
00:09:00.530 --> 00:09:04.780
in the same way that we configured
NYCORE1 to work this way.

146
00:09:06.610 --> 00:09:14.057
I'm gonna go NYCORE2, and
is here I'm gonna get back in and

147
00:09:14.057 --> 00:09:20.057
do our interface range fa1/0/23- 24.

148
00:09:22.283 --> 00:09:27.110
And no switch port that allows
me to sign an IP address to it.

149
00:09:27.110 --> 00:09:28.820
Then I wanna create a channel group.

150
00:09:31.329 --> 00:09:35.360
1 mode on.

151
00:09:35.360 --> 00:09:41.579
So we're hard setting eitherchannel,
is what we're gonna do.

152
00:09:41.579 --> 00:09:47.242
And now I want to add an IP
address to this interface,

153
00:09:47.242 --> 00:09:50.604
Interface port-channel 1.

154
00:09:50.604 --> 00:09:52.860
And now an IP address.

155
00:09:52.860 --> 00:09:56.356
And this is gonna be

156
00:09:56.356 --> 00:10:02.039
192.168.18.2 of

157
00:10:02.039 --> 00:10:06.414
a 24 bit subnet mask.

158
00:10:06.414 --> 00:10:11.129
If everything else is good and we are up
and ready to go, now I can actually start

159
00:10:11.129 --> 00:10:15.643
doing some routing if I chose to,
now that this two switches are together.

160
00:10:15.643 --> 00:10:21.580
I should be able to
ping 192.168.18.1 here.

161
00:10:21.580 --> 00:10:24.250
And we'll just give it a moment and
see if it actually works, and there we go.

162
00:10:25.290 --> 00:10:29.590
So that ping now means that even
between NYCORE1 and NYCORE2.

163
00:10:29.590 --> 00:10:32.300
If I do have those different
VLANs that are not

164
00:10:32.300 --> 00:10:36.100
directly connected through each other,
to be able to get across this.

165
00:10:36.100 --> 00:10:40.120
I can now route between those
two switches if I need to.

166
00:10:40.120 --> 00:10:44.730
So, you and I are not gonna really
do this inside of our own networks.

167
00:10:44.730 --> 00:10:48.566
More than likely, if anything, it's
probably gonna be ISPs that do something

168
00:10:48.566 --> 00:10:50.641
like this and not us,
that end up doing it.

169
00:10:50.641 --> 00:10:54.779
So, let's take a look at what
the etherchannel shows us.

170
00:10:54.779 --> 00:11:00.485
So I do a show etherchannel summary

171
00:11:03.198 --> 00:11:06.730
now we'll see something
just a bit different here.

172
00:11:06.730 --> 00:11:11.770
So before, when you and
I looked at the port channel, right here,

173
00:11:11.770 --> 00:11:13.760
notice it says RU.

174
00:11:14.925 --> 00:11:17.400
So before when we created the PagP,
and LACP, and

175
00:11:17.400 --> 00:11:22.330
the static etherchannel, it actually
had the letter S in place of the R.

176
00:11:22.330 --> 00:11:26.200
Which was a Layer 2 type of port.

177
00:11:26.200 --> 00:11:27.646
Now you're seeing the R.

178
00:11:27.646 --> 00:11:31.790
It says Layer 3, which means router port,
and the capital letter U,

179
00:11:31.790 --> 00:11:33.550
which means it's in use.

180
00:11:33.550 --> 00:11:38.680
You see the common component of the P
here, says it is now bundled together.

181
00:11:38.680 --> 00:11:44.650
So we actually have a much more
bandwidth in between the route here,

182
00:11:44.650 --> 00:11:47.540
to the other side of
what we also configured

183
00:11:47.540 --> 00:11:50.820
to be able to start doing
some routing if we chose to.

184
00:11:50.820 --> 00:11:55.250
So this one we're just showing
you the initial configuration.

185
00:11:55.250 --> 00:11:59.070
As you see this more, you will
probably watch the CCNP routing and

186
00:11:59.070 --> 00:12:02.910
switching show,
that you'll actually be seeing as well.

187
00:12:02.910 --> 00:12:06.490
And so as you go on, but
we wanted to at least show you this.

188
00:12:06.490 --> 00:12:09.100
It is technically one
of the exam objectives,

189
00:12:09.100 --> 00:12:13.910
where you have to be able to differentiate
between the layer two and layer three, for

190
00:12:13.910 --> 00:12:17.890
us in terms of differentiation it's
right here, it's this letter R.

191
00:12:17.890 --> 00:12:23.070
But the other one for you is gonna be
the addition of adding IP addresses

192
00:12:23.070 --> 00:12:25.640
on the port channel interface itself,

193
00:12:25.640 --> 00:12:30.160
which we are not able to do if this
is layer two interface for us.

194
00:12:30.160 --> 00:12:33.710
So, that's the only differentiation
that you and I will really need.

195
00:12:33.710 --> 00:12:36.560
But they did set up a nice little
lab demonstration for us and

196
00:12:36.560 --> 00:12:39.910
practice labs, and
is worth us walking through it.

197
00:12:39.910 --> 00:12:42.940
So that you could see it, but you'll
actually see that we'll configure it and

198
00:12:42.940 --> 00:12:44.490
we'll use it a little
bit more effectively,

199
00:12:44.490 --> 00:12:48.310
once we get into the CCMP routing and
switching shows as well.

200
00:12:48.310 --> 00:12:52.630
>> Fantastic episode,
in Figure Etherchannel Part 3.

201
00:12:52.630 --> 00:12:54.620
Now make sure you see all three parts.

202
00:12:54.620 --> 00:12:56.310
Parts one, two and three.

203
00:12:56.310 --> 00:12:58.540
And Ronnie,
what else would you like to say?

204
00:12:58.540 --> 00:13:01.260
>> Well we wanna take a moment here.

205
00:13:01.260 --> 00:13:05.840
Even though this technology is not
the most difficult to configure,

206
00:13:05.840 --> 00:13:07.080
to remind you,

207
00:13:07.080 --> 00:13:12.700
you gotta slow down because of all the new
information that we've just showed you.

208
00:13:12.700 --> 00:13:17.060
It's not so much it's a ton of conceptual
knowledge that you have to pick up, but

209
00:13:17.060 --> 00:13:19.800
it is a ton of terminology.

210
00:13:19.800 --> 00:13:24.486
You have to be able to distinguish
the different terminologies between LagP,

211
00:13:24.486 --> 00:13:28.660
PagP, the statically set etherchannel.

212
00:13:28.660 --> 00:13:33.090
Know the difference between layer two and
layer three etherchannel as well.

213
00:13:33.090 --> 00:13:35.160
Know the verification commands,

214
00:13:35.160 --> 00:13:41.250
as well as how do you actually set it up,
to configure them for what they need.

215
00:13:41.250 --> 00:13:44.980
All of these commands are actually things
that you'll have to be able to do and

216
00:13:44.980 --> 00:13:50.800
spot, as you start to get ready for the
CCNA Routing and Switching Exam as well.

217
00:13:50.800 --> 00:13:52.420
It's all important technology.

218
00:13:52.420 --> 00:13:54.730
Don't get me wrong, it really is.

219
00:13:54.730 --> 00:13:57.560
But this is one of those where
we don't see it as often as we

220
00:13:57.560 --> 00:13:58.310
think that we should.

221
00:13:58.310 --> 00:14:01.390
And you'll actually be seeing a lot more.

222
00:14:01.390 --> 00:14:01.920
Like I said, for

223
00:14:01.920 --> 00:14:06.150
those of you going on towards like
the CCNP switch show in itself.

224
00:14:06.150 --> 00:14:10.140
But that entire series for
the CCNP shows that you'll see.

225
00:14:10.140 --> 00:14:13.450
So Zach,
that really does end the technology for

226
00:14:13.450 --> 00:14:16.360
what we wanted to make
sure that we covered here.

227
00:14:16.360 --> 00:14:20.750
For the idea of etherchannels,
so that should be good.

228
00:14:20.750 --> 00:14:23.210
>> Well said and well done Ronnie,
thank you for all of your hard work.

229
00:14:23.210 --> 00:14:27.945
And make sure you all watch every single
episode of CCNA Routing and Switching Exam

230
00:14:27.945 --> 00:14:34.190
200-105 episodes, you'll be so glad
that you did, and it's gonna help you.

231
00:14:34.190 --> 00:14:36.040
And by the way you'll be
in the course library,

232
00:14:36.040 --> 00:14:37.850
there's thousands of other videos there.

Designed to do one thing,
take you further.

234
00:14:39.770 --> 00:14:41.520
Take a look at those, as well.

235
00:14:41.520 --> 00:14:43.322
And tell everybody you

236

You know ITPro.TV is bingeworthy.

237
00:14:45.360 --> 00:14:46.090
Thanks for watching.

238

I'm Zack Memos.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe switch aggregation technologies: Switch Stacking and Chassis Aggregation.  They describe it's usages and application as well as the benefits to implementing them.
episodes.title: Describe Switch Aggregation Benefits
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.031 --> 00:00:01.992
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:01.992 --> 00:00:04.520
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.520 --> 00:00:07.841
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.841 --> 00:00:11.060
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.060 --> 00:00:14.052
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.052 --> 00:00:16.580
helping you learn everywhere you go.

7
00:00:16.580 --> 00:00:21.366
I'm your host Zach Memos,
with this episode of CCNA, Routing and

8
00:00:21.366 --> 00:00:24.024
Switching, Exam 200-105.

9
00:00:24.024 --> 00:00:27.743
This episode describes switch
aggregation benefits, and

10
00:00:27.743 --> 00:00:31.620
the only person I know who can
describe that, is Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:31.620 --> 00:00:32.682
And there he is, right there.

12
00:00:32.682 --> 00:00:33.808
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Hey, Ronnie, how are you?

13
00:00:33.808 --> 00:00:37.150
>> Hey, Zack, thank you again for
joining me on our journey here.

14
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:41.520
Right, we are continuing on in our
CCNA Routing and Switching show.

15
00:00:41.520 --> 00:00:45.388
And we are now at this topic where
we're gonna be taking a look and

16
00:00:45.388 --> 00:00:48.408
just describing the idea
of switch aggregation.

17
00:00:48.408 --> 00:00:51.089
And some of the different
ways that we can do that, and

18
00:00:51.089 --> 00:00:53.541
especially focusing in
on the benefits to this.

19
00:00:53.541 --> 00:00:56.347
Because we need know it not only for
the exam, but

20
00:00:56.347 --> 00:01:00.864
this is real world scenarios that you're
actually going to see a lot of times as

21
00:01:00.864 --> 00:01:04.320
you start to actually go through and
do that, okay?

22
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:08.045
So let's make sure that we
understand what is happening and

23
00:01:08.045 --> 00:01:10.586
the way that things actually go, okay?

24
00:01:10.586 --> 00:01:14.389
So what you normally end up with as
you start to add in switches is that,

25
00:01:14.389 --> 00:01:17.498
you don't just add them in
haphazardly to your network.

26
00:01:17.498 --> 00:01:22.408
You have a design to the way that you
want switches to kind of end up in

27
00:01:22.408 --> 00:01:23.920
your network.

28
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:25.900
So let's take a look at my screen for
a moment, and

29
00:01:25.900 --> 00:01:28.890
this will help us out as we get started.

30
00:01:28.890 --> 00:01:30.330
So normally what you want to do, and

31
00:01:30.330 --> 00:01:34.900
we've talked about this idea from a design
concept or an architecture concept here.

32
00:01:34.900 --> 00:01:38.640
That what you may find in large businesses
is that you may have what we call core

33
00:01:38.640 --> 00:01:39.580
switches.

34
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:43.360
And then from that point, distribution
layer switches, and then after that,

35
00:01:43.360 --> 00:01:46.450
of course,
access layered switches as well.

36
00:01:46.450 --> 00:01:53.650
We can also see what we call the idea
here of a collapsed core type of design,

37
00:01:53.650 --> 00:01:59.400
in which the distribution and core layers
are kind of condensed into one layer.

38
00:01:59.400 --> 00:02:01.360
And then you have access
layer switches too.

39
00:02:01.360 --> 00:02:05.509
Now, if this is a brand new concept for
you, I want you to go back and

40
00:02:05.509 --> 00:02:09.737
watch the actual Cisco CCENT episodes
where we did talk about this in

41
00:02:09.737 --> 00:02:12.797
the networking fundamentals
a little bit more.

42
00:02:12.797 --> 00:02:15.202
We're not going to jump
right back into it and

43
00:02:15.202 --> 00:02:17.490
then make a whole description once again.

44
00:02:17.490 --> 00:02:20.427
But what I wanted us to see
was exactly this concept and

45
00:02:20.427 --> 00:02:25.720
this structure that we're talking about in
terms of the networking infrastructure.

46
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:31.620
So notice that I have two switches here,
labeled as core/distribution layer and

47
00:02:31.620 --> 00:02:34.897
then I have four different
access layer switches.

48
00:02:34.897 --> 00:02:36.640
And then access layer switches,

49
00:02:36.640 --> 00:02:41.790
these are normally gonna be switches in
which we plug end point devices into.

50
00:02:41.790 --> 00:02:47.880
But that I mean things like servers,
and of course workstations, printers,

51
00:02:47.880 --> 00:02:52.500
these types of devices are what we
normally plug into access layer switches.

52
00:02:52.500 --> 00:02:56.440
Now because our network is actually
going to be able to change and

53
00:02:56.440 --> 00:03:00.240
grow, what we also have
are distribution layer switches.

54
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:03.867
And the idea of actually making
this type of structure, right,

55
00:03:03.867 --> 00:03:05.760
goes to the idea of scalability.

56
00:03:05.760 --> 00:03:09.550
When we talk about the scaling up for
a network, right,

57
00:03:09.550 --> 00:03:13.583
the idea of scaling up allows us
to be able to put more data and

58
00:03:13.583 --> 00:03:18.120
traffic onto our network, and
our infrastructure can handle it.

59
00:03:18.120 --> 00:03:22.002
We can also talk about it in terms of
scaling out, in other words adding in more

60
00:03:22.002 --> 00:03:25.648
and more devices because our network
is growing in terms of the numbers of

61
00:03:25.648 --> 00:03:30.020
devices that we're adding in which means
we might need more infrastructure.

62
00:03:30.020 --> 00:03:33.462
We need an easy way to be able
to scale out as well, okay.

63
00:03:33.462 --> 00:03:37.175
Expanding our same services
to multiple devices or

64
00:03:37.175 --> 00:03:39.949
more devices than we currently have.

65
00:03:39.949 --> 00:03:44.270
So both of those concepts
are what this helps okay.

66
00:03:44.270 --> 00:03:48.728
So we don't really have to actually change
the entire network infrastructure just

67
00:03:48.728 --> 00:03:50.584
because we add in a single switch.

68
00:03:50.584 --> 00:03:54.146
Or just because we add in three or
four more switches into this,

69
00:03:54.146 --> 00:03:58.370
the idea of actually separating
that out really does help us, okay?

70
00:03:58.370 --> 00:04:03.170
So in that sense in this description here,
it does work, but

71
00:04:03.170 --> 00:04:06.270
it does also add in challenges too, okay?

72
00:04:06.270 --> 00:04:10.260
The more challenges that you have,
it has to do with a couple of things.

73
00:04:10.260 --> 00:04:13.830
The first challenge is the number
of pieces of equipment, okay.

74
00:04:13.830 --> 00:04:17.240
We've already seen that where
we may have to configure, well,

75
00:04:17.240 --> 00:04:18.290
things like trunk ports.

76
00:04:18.290 --> 00:04:22.630
So if we look between these access layers
and these distribution layer switches,

77
00:04:22.630 --> 00:04:25.910
these are essentially trunk lines
that we'd have to configure.

78
00:04:25.910 --> 00:04:29.963
But we wouldn't only configure on one
side such as the access layer, but

79
00:04:29.963 --> 00:04:33.429
we'd also configure on
the distribution layer side as well.

80
00:04:33.429 --> 00:04:38.520
And for you and me, even on this small
scale that you're seeing in my diagram.

81
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:42.096
It means that we have to
touch six individual switches

82
00:04:42.096 --> 00:04:45.910
to get the configurations
the way they want to even though

83
00:04:45.910 --> 00:04:50.453
they're gonna be relatively
identical kinds of configurations.

84
00:04:50.453 --> 00:04:52.552
And I say relatively, right,

85
00:04:52.552 --> 00:04:56.850
you have to change a few things
depending on the switch itself.

86
00:04:56.850 --> 00:05:01.134
But overall though, and the ports that
you have access to, but overall though,

87
00:05:01.134 --> 00:05:04.233
the same, pretty much the same
types of configurations.

88
00:05:04.233 --> 00:05:10.006
So if it's a matter of let's say six or
seven commands per interface as we do so.

89
00:05:10.006 --> 00:05:15.046
We can eliminate some of that duplication
by doing that interface range

90
00:05:15.046 --> 00:05:20.860
command that allows us to kind of shrink
that down a little bit more, right?

91
00:05:20.860 --> 00:05:24.160
We can even go a little bit faster
than that where we go ahead and

92
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:28.600
get all that typed out in something
like notepad inside of Windows.

93
00:05:28.600 --> 00:05:32.096
And make sure all of those commands
are typed out syntactically perfectly.

94
00:05:32.096 --> 00:05:34.411
Then I can highlight and
copy all those and

95
00:05:34.411 --> 00:05:38.660
then just go around pasting them to
each of the individual six switches too.

96
00:05:38.660 --> 00:05:43.505
And that will speed up the processes much
quicker than even me typing it out here as

97
00:05:43.505 --> 00:05:48.006
we've been doing during the whole
episodes that we've been doing so far.

98
00:05:48.006 --> 00:05:50.262
So we can speed some of that process up,
but

99
00:05:50.262 --> 00:05:53.031
the management of this
doesn't make it any easier.

100
00:05:53.031 --> 00:05:57.528
If we start to have to troubleshoot it, we
still have to actually be able to isolate

101
00:05:57.528 --> 00:06:01.000
and identify what devices
that we're talking about.

102
00:06:01.000 --> 00:06:01.930
And not only that, though,

103
00:06:01.930 --> 00:06:03.980
we'll still have some other
issues that we have to deal with.

104
00:06:03.980 --> 00:06:08.690
Such as limitations of bandwidth that
we may have to deal with as well, okay?

105
00:06:08.690 --> 00:06:12.350
So there's a lot of different
things that can happen here

106
00:06:12.350 --> 00:06:16.340
that we have to really take
the idea here of management.

107
00:06:16.340 --> 00:06:19.140
And we have to really be on top
of the game especially if our

108
00:06:19.140 --> 00:06:20.430
network is changing.

109
00:06:20.430 --> 00:06:24.260
If we're growing it means that we have to
make sure that everything that we do is

110
00:06:24.260 --> 00:06:26.480
actually gonna be equal and the same.

111
00:06:26.480 --> 00:06:29.968
But the great thing is,
what Zach described here right,

112
00:06:29.968 --> 00:06:32.594
the idea of aggregation is the key, okay.

113
00:06:32.594 --> 00:06:36.671
And switch aggregation brings
us two different technologies,

114
00:06:36.671 --> 00:06:40.982
I shouldn't say technology,
two different methods I should say.

115
00:06:40.982 --> 00:06:43.956
And the reason why it actually
is two different methods and

116
00:06:43.956 --> 00:06:47.776
we're gonna talk about this a little
more in the moment, is gonna be well,

117
00:06:47.776 --> 00:06:50.350
it depends on what layer
you are doing this.

118
00:06:50.350 --> 00:06:53.230
Are you doing this at the core and
distribution layer?

119
00:06:53.230 --> 00:06:56.930
Or are you gonna end up doing
this at the access layer itself?

120
00:06:56.930 --> 00:06:58.760
So that's what we want to talk about.

121
00:06:58.760 --> 00:07:02.981
And so in those two, okay,
the two technologies I'm mentioning,

122
00:07:02.981 --> 00:07:05.869
one is what we call Cisco Switch Stacking,
and

123
00:07:05.869 --> 00:07:09.369
then the other one is what
we call chassis aggregation.

124
00:07:09.369 --> 00:07:12.902
I know chassis aggregation,
typing that out, I don't know why,

125
00:07:12.902 --> 00:07:15.629
it took me a long time as I
was typing these notes up.

126
00:07:15.629 --> 00:07:19.358
Like man, that's a long, but
both words I had too many S's in one,

127
00:07:19.358 --> 00:07:21.790
too many G's in the other one,
you name it.

128
00:07:21.790 --> 00:07:24.990
It was just kind of getting me
all flustered a little bit.

129
00:07:24.990 --> 00:07:27.810
But I did, I was actually able to say it,
which is kind of neat.

130
00:07:27.810 --> 00:07:31.865
And so but we wanna tackle these and make
sure that we understand what they are, and

131
00:07:31.865 --> 00:07:34.490
then we want to talk about
those benefits as well, okay?

132
00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:37.110
So let's start off with the,
we'll take it one at a time,

133
00:07:37.110 --> 00:07:40.120
that way I'm not racing back and
forth as my mind always does here.

134
00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:42.339
So let's start off with Switch Stacking.

135
00:07:42.339 --> 00:07:44.690
>> Yeah, what are the benefits
of Switch Stacking, Ronnie?

136
00:07:44.690 --> 00:07:48.390
>> Well when it comes down to
the benefits of Switch Stacking, okay?

137
00:07:48.390 --> 00:07:51.357
Let's kind of take this diagram here and

138
00:07:51.357 --> 00:07:55.295
break it apart a little bit
more to help us out, okay?

139
00:07:55.295 --> 00:08:00.107
So what we can do essentially
when we start to do this Instead

140
00:08:00.107 --> 00:08:05.019
of having to manage four
individual access layer switches,

141
00:08:05.019 --> 00:08:11.940
we normally take switch stacking and
we implement those at the access layer.

142
00:08:11.940 --> 00:08:16.610
Now when we do so, it reduces
the management in this way, okay?

143
00:08:16.610 --> 00:08:19.120
And then the other one
on chastity aggregation.

144
00:08:19.120 --> 00:08:21.610
Here's what will end up happening,
normally,

145
00:08:21.610 --> 00:08:23.900
when we use these two technologies, okay?

146
00:08:23.900 --> 00:08:28.780
Let me see if I can do this without
causing a lot of fuss here, okay?

147
00:08:28.780 --> 00:08:33.210
So what we do is we take all
those access layer switches, and

148
00:08:33.210 --> 00:08:34.670
we can stack them together.

149
00:08:34.670 --> 00:08:36.530
Now, in the diagram that I have,

150
00:08:36.530 --> 00:08:41.440

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe some of the layer 2 attacks that may need to be mitigated.  They show the application of 802.1x and DHCP snooping.  Lastly, they configure the nondefault native LAN.

What normally ends up happening is simple.

00:17:12.500 --> 00:17:16.000

00:17:16.000 --> 00:17:18.080

00:17:18.080 --> 00:17:22.110

309
00:17:22.110 --> 00:17:28.440
And when they do that, well that DHCP
server now becomes active on your network.

310
00:17:28.440 --> 00:17:29.970
When it becomes active on your network,

311
00:17:29.970 --> 00:17:33.760
the problem that you don't understand
if you haven't gone through this yet,

312
00:17:33.760 --> 00:17:38.750
right, is that a machine doesn't care
where it gets its IP address from.

313
00:17:38.750 --> 00:17:39.920
It really doesn't.

314
00:17:39.920 --> 00:17:41.930
So if the machine is actually waiting for

315
00:17:41.930 --> 00:17:44.800
an IP address it would just get
the one that's closer to it,

316
00:17:44.800 --> 00:17:48.810
in other words the one that responds
faster is the one that will happen.

317
00:17:48.810 --> 00:17:53.450
So what you can end up with on a
legitimate network on a network of course

318
00:17:53.450 --> 00:17:56.610
if going to be your own
authorized DHCP server the one

319
00:17:56.610 --> 00:17:59.290
you set up to do everything
that you wanted to.

320
00:17:59.290 --> 00:18:03.150
And there is a possibility
that you will also end up with

321
00:18:03.150 --> 00:18:07.860
an unauthorized wireless router
being set up on the network as well.

322
00:18:07.860 --> 00:18:11.970
And on most wireless routers you
already have the HTP running as

323
00:18:11.970 --> 00:18:13.850
soon as you plug the power in.

324
00:18:13.850 --> 00:18:15.880
And as soon as that
wireless signal goes out,

325
00:18:15.880 --> 00:18:18.580
it's going to start handing
out IP addresses, okay?

326
00:18:18.580 --> 00:18:21.700
So anything that is connected to this, so

327
00:18:21.700 --> 00:18:25.310
let's say that this is what happens

328
00:18:25.310 --> 00:18:26.690
You have an office in,

329
00:18:26.690 --> 00:18:32.000
let's say way away from the rest of the
building here for one reason or another.

00:18:32.000 --> 00:18:36.050
You've asked the IT guy to say, hey,
I need wireless access, you know, for

331
00:18:36.050 --> 00:18:38.510
these devices and it's slow coming.

332
00:18:38.510 --> 00:18:40.800
What can you do that
actually bypasses that?

333
00:18:40.800 --> 00:18:45.650
You go out and you buy a cheapo wireless
router, and you plug that into your wall

334
00:18:45.650 --> 00:18:50.360

00:18:50.360 --> 00:18:55.480

your iPad, whatever it might be,

00:18:55.480 --> 00:19:00.000

you also have your workstation plugged in.

00:19:00.000 --> 00:19:02.480
And everything begins to work well.

338
00:19:02.480 --> 00:19:06.947
But at the same time, you might find

339
00:19:06.947 --> 00:19:11.808

the network, essentially taking over.

340
00:19:11.808 --> 00:19:13.772
That's bad, okay?

341
00:19:13.772 --> 00:19:18.141
The reason it's bad is because some
attacker out there can do this and

342
00:19:18.141 --> 00:19:22.736
use it to essentially overwhelm and
reassign all of the addresses on your

343
00:19:22.736 --> 00:19:28.350
network to where it no longer functions
the way that you expect it to function.

344
00:19:28.350 --> 00:19:31.590
And when that happens,
that's' really a bad day, okay?

345
00:19:31.590 --> 00:19:36.130
So it can be used of course to take
over as a rogue server to take over.

346
00:19:36.130 --> 00:19:39.230
It can be used in the man in
the middle attack a lot of times and

347
00:19:39.230 --> 00:19:40.480
even a denial of service.

348
00:19:40.480 --> 00:19:41.992
The idea of it taking over and

349
00:19:41.992 --> 00:19:45.963
handing out IP addresses that are not
valid is a denial of service, right?

350
00:19:45.963 --> 00:19:49.633
The idea of a man in the middle attack
is hey, somebody's actual able to go and

351
00:19:49.633 --> 00:19:53.980
put something like this on the network and
still gain access to the whole network.

352
00:19:53.980 --> 00:19:56.980
Well, now, traffic that comes back, right?

353
00:19:56.980 --> 00:20:00.900
So essentially there's a little

00:20:00.900 --> 00:20:02.490
there's a switch over here.

00:20:02.490 --> 00:20:06.490
It's possible that there's a BPDU
that goes out across this link.

356
00:20:06.490 --> 00:20:10.300
It's possible that a loop can also end
up forming between these links, too.

357
00:20:10.300 --> 00:20:13.130
So you got to realize,
especially if you duplicate that link, but

358
00:20:13.130 --> 00:20:16.050
overall though,
it shouldn't happen too much, but

359
00:20:16.050 --> 00:20:20.000
you do see where this could
cause issues if you do that.

360
00:20:20.000 --> 00:20:24.664
So the way that we can prevent that on

00:20:31.201 --> 00:20:33.231

I've implemented it because

00:21:11.530 --> 00:21:16.204

00:21:16.204 --> 00:21:19.707

00:21:19.707 --> 00:21:23.407
But its just turning on dhcp snooping and

00:21:23.407 --> 00:21:26.130

00:21:26.130 --> 00:21:28.952

00:21:28.952 --> 00:21:33.187

00:21:33.187 --> 00:21:35.728

00:21:35.728 --> 00:21:38.760

00:21:38.760 --> 00:21:42.750
And then all the other interfaces

00:21:42.750 --> 00:21:47.990
So if it actually now begins to receive

00:21:47.990 --> 00:21:51.060

00:21:51.060 --> 00:21:53.640
Or we can limit it instead.

00:21:58.190 --> 00:22:02.520

00:22:02.520 --> 00:22:07.080
So that way it actually slows it down

390
00:22:07.080 --> 00:22:08.730

00:29:43.110 --> 00:29:46.500
But we did wanna show you some of
the ones that you have available.

508
00:29:46.500 --> 00:29:51.140
And on the other ones, you can again jump
over into your CCNA security to see that.

509
00:29:51.140 --> 00:29:55.300
But, there not required for this exam,
knowledge of them is, okay, so

510
00:29:55.300 --> 00:29:57.060
make sure you understand that.

511
00:29:57.060 --> 00:30:01.140
These concepts, fairly easy, but at the
same time if you don't know about them.

512
00:30:01.140 --> 00:30:04.310
Again, points that could be easily
rectified by you just knowing

513
00:30:04.310 --> 00:30:08.250
just a little bit about each of these
mitigation techniques that we showed you.

514
00:30:08.250 --> 00:30:09.440
>> Thanks, Ronnie, great job.

515
00:30:09.440 --> 00:30:12.860
And you know, as a member,
you have access to those videos,

516
00:30:12.860 --> 00:30:14.680
so make sure you take a look at them.

517
00:30:14.680 --> 00:30:18.270
And take a look at all the episodes
in the CCNA routing and

518
00:30:18.270 --> 00:30:22.980
switching exam 200-105 series,
you'll be glad you did.

519
00:30:22.980 --> 00:30:26.095
Course libraries available to you
with thousands of other videos,

520
00:30:26.095 --> 00:30:28.650
that are all designed to take you further.

521
00:30:28.650 --> 00:30:29.820
Check those out too.

522
00:30:29.820 --> 00:30:33.570
And I'll tell you what I know about
ITPro.TV, ITPro.TV is binge worthy.

523
00:30:33.570 --> 00:30:35.120
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

524
00:30:35.120 --> 00:30:35.810
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

525
00:30:35.810 --> 00:30:37.870
>> We'll see you again soon.

526
00:30:37.870 --> 00:30:43.850
[MUSIC]

527
00:30:43.850 --> 00:30:46.718
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review the concepts of intervlan routing, specifically, "Router on a Stick. They talk about each component to be configured as well verifying the correct configuration necessary for it to work.
episodes.title: Configure InterVLAN Routing

5

6

this episode of CCNA Routing and
Switching Exam 200-105.

7

This episode configure inter VLAN routing.

8
00:00:27.220 --> 00:00:30.820
Sounds like fun and the person I know who
can help us with that is Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:32.030
Ronnie good to see you sir.

10

>> Good to see you too Zach as we continue
on in our CCNA routing and switching show.

11
00:00:37.190 --> 00:00:40.500
We are now heading in well to
our other domain objective.

12
00:00:40.500 --> 00:00:43.730
As we come to it which is
gonna be routing technologies.

13
00:00:43.730 --> 00:00:45.560
So we're switching gears a little bit.

14
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:50.048
And we're gonna begin with a topic that
we did cover inside of the Cisco CCENT.

15
00:00:50.048 --> 00:00:54.672
So it's a good reminder of some of the
different things we have covered already.

16
00:00:54.672 --> 00:00:57.961
A good little review to get us

17
00:00:57.961 --> 00:01:00.815
So that is what we are gonna be
covering today is, off course.

18
00:01:00.815 --> 00:01:02.235
And routing is what we are gonna do.

19
00:01:02.235 --> 00:01:05.305
>> And they're very lucky because as
a member they can go back to those

20

C Cent videos which is terrific.

21

sure that you do pay attention.

22

But we are off course

23
00:01:11.525 --> 00:01:15.515
Just in case it's been a while since

24

videos as well.

25

So we know life gets in the way and it's
actually easy to take one exam and go.

26
00:01:20.515 --> 00:01:23.690
All right I've conquered that and
then also say I'm gonna slow down.

27
00:01:23.690 --> 00:01:25.540
And make sure I get
through all this material.

28
00:01:25.540 --> 00:01:27.420
And all of a sudden before you
know it weeks have gone by.

29
00:01:27.420 --> 00:01:29.480
And sometimes even months have gone by.

30
00:01:29.480 --> 00:01:31.960
And now you're having to
review those concepts again.

31
00:01:31.960 --> 00:01:33.590
Well we understand but

32
00:01:33.590 --> 00:01:36.680
let's make sure that we do get
our review started off right.

33
00:01:36.680 --> 00:01:39.630
And we're gonna begin
with inter VLAN routing.

34
00:01:39.630 --> 00:01:40.430
>> Yes.
>> So let's take a look at

35
00:01:40.430 --> 00:01:43.840
my diagram here and this will help
us to get started a little bit.

36
00:01:43.840 --> 00:01:46.830
I've hidden some material, I wish I could
tell you to make it match seamless.

37
00:01:46.830 --> 00:01:49.310
But this is as close as
I can get here okay?

38
00:01:49.310 --> 00:01:51.740
So with this time,
as we continue to move through and

39
00:01:51.740 --> 00:01:53.720
we start talking about the information.

40
00:01:53.720 --> 00:01:57.900
We're also going to be emphasizing some
of the steps or some of the logic.

41
00:01:57.900 --> 00:02:00.950
That we have to go through as
we troubleshoot them too, okay.

42
00:02:00.950 --> 00:02:03.130
So when it comes down to
intervlan routing, right?

43
00:02:03.130 --> 00:02:07.970
Remember that we can have multiple
vlan's set up on a switch.

44
00:02:07.970 --> 00:02:12.230
But let's say that E Lan 16,
17 and 18 setup in this way.

45
00:02:12.230 --> 00:02:16.165
Well these two cannot directly
communicate to each other.

46
00:02:16.165 --> 00:02:22.420
Then if they are actually plugged in
you know, in port 16, 17 and 18, okay.

47
00:02:22.420 --> 00:02:26.440
And they want to communicate
directly to each other.

48
00:02:26.440 --> 00:02:30.000
They can't just do so, because they
are plugged into the same device.

49
00:02:31.570 --> 00:02:34.900
There are seperate broadcast domains.

50
00:02:34.900 --> 00:02:39.380
And so when we start doing this, what
has to happen is on v land sixteen and

51
00:02:39.380 --> 00:02:40.900
sixteen dot ten.

52
00:02:40.900 --> 00:02:45.380
It has to actually go through a layer
three device, and get routed.

53
00:02:45.380 --> 00:02:47.600
And come back in and then go out to 17.

54
00:02:47.600 --> 00:02:51.180
In the same thing would also have
to happened between 17 and 18,

55
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:53.020
18 and 16, etc.

56
00:02:53.020 --> 00:02:55.510
As we continue to go forward.

57
00:02:55.510 --> 00:02:58.720
Now the reason why that
concept is important

58
00:02:58.720 --> 00:03:01.300
is because there's a couple
of different configurations.

59
00:03:01.300 --> 00:03:04.990
That we have to remember
as we set this up, okay.

60
00:03:04.990 --> 00:03:09.030
One, the way that we have set of right
now this is call a router on a stick

61
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:09.960
configuration.

62
00:03:09.960 --> 00:03:11.380
>> Right.
>> Okay, the router on stick

63
00:03:11.380 --> 00:03:11.890
configuration.

64
00:03:11.890 --> 00:03:14.670
If you take a look at it it
looks like a router on a stick

65
00:03:14.670 --> 00:03:17.150
right up here at the top so
it makes sense.

66
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:20.360
But what we have is a trunk
link in between the router.

67
00:03:20.360 --> 00:03:24.630
And of course one of the interfaces
on the switch that we have.

68
00:03:24.630 --> 00:03:27.230
And when that trunk link is set up and
we configure the router.

69
00:03:27.230 --> 00:03:29.520
And the switch to do
what we want them to do.

70
00:03:29.520 --> 00:03:36.110
It will allow us to send data into the
router itself and have it come back out.

71
00:03:36.110 --> 00:03:37.710
Now there is an issue, and

72
00:03:37.710 --> 00:03:40.520
the reason why I actually want
to point out this issue is.

73
00:03:40.520 --> 00:03:45.060
Because of the way that routers normally
are configured from the factory by

74
00:03:45.060 --> 00:03:49.060
default is that it doesn't
allow us to do this.

75
00:03:49.060 --> 00:03:54.340
In other words, if I get information
coming in to one port, okay?

76
00:03:54.340 --> 00:04:00.000
And it's supposed to go out the same port,
it will not allow me to do so.

77
00:04:00.000 --> 00:04:04.530
And that is due to a technology or
a particular methodology that is called.

78
00:04:04.530 --> 00:04:07.480
Why can't I remember what it's called,
split horizon.

79
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:08.850
See, my memory is starting to go.

80
00:04:08.850 --> 00:04:10.920
>> There you go.
>> Okay, split horizon says look,

81
00:04:10.920 --> 00:04:13.340
if I can get information about this.

82
00:04:13.340 --> 00:04:16.860
And it's actually meant to go out that
same port, I am not going to do it.

83
00:04:16.860 --> 00:04:20.060
I'm not gonna forward it out the same port
because I learned the information from

84
00:04:20.060 --> 00:04:20.940
that port.

85
00:04:20.940 --> 00:04:24.310
So I can't be sending
it back out that port.

86
00:04:24.310 --> 00:04:28.640
>> So how does the router on the stick
configuration end up working?

87
00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:33.870
>> The way it actually begins to work is
it means, when we configure the router.

88
00:04:33.870 --> 00:04:38.700
You and I have to configure what we call
sub interfaces on the router instead.

89
00:04:38.700 --> 00:04:42.980
We essentially take that one port
that we're connecting to right here.

90
00:04:42.980 --> 00:04:48.620
And we divide it up into multiple ports,
is what we do logically.

91
00:04:48.620 --> 00:04:52.910
And so, when you see this configuration,
you actually see where it's like Gigabit,

92
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:53.800
Ethernet.

93
00:04:53.800 --> 00:04:57.310
0 slash 0 dot something.

94
00:04:57.310 --> 00:05:02.850
So it might be 0 dot 0 dot 16 17 18 and
you can divide that up.

95
00:05:02.850 --> 00:05:08.040
In theory we can actually divide
it up between 0 and 65,035.

96
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:09.345
I don't think you'd ever wanna do that.

97
00:05:09.345 --> 00:05:11.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> But overall though, you can,

98
00:05:11.140 --> 00:05:13.300
because that's what it's
based on as a port number.

99
00:05:13.300 --> 00:05:15.340
Which is 16 bit port number.

100
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:18.780
So just kinda realize,
it is possible for you to do that.

101
00:05:18.780 --> 00:05:21.890
But for us, we'd have to make
sure that we get that set up.

102
00:05:21.890 --> 00:05:25.720
We'd also have to do an encapsulation
on each one of those subinterfaces.

103
00:05:25.720 --> 00:05:28.590
With the proper vlan ID number and

104
00:05:28.590 --> 00:05:32.290
then we have to make sure that
the physical interface itself is on.

105
00:05:32.290 --> 00:05:34.220
Okay, so that we can do that.

106
00:05:34.220 --> 00:05:36.730
Then, on the switch side,
we're gonna actually implement.

107
00:05:36.730 --> 00:05:38.480
I believe, the switch first if, yep.

108
00:05:38.480 --> 00:05:41.300
And we're gonna configure
a trunkling on the switch first.

109
00:05:41.300 --> 00:05:44.860
Well, on this side, we just have to
set this one up as being a trunk

110
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:47.740
matching the same encapsulation type.

111
00:05:47.740 --> 00:05:50.110
Most of them today,
I'm going to use dot one Q.

112
00:05:50.110 --> 00:05:55.440
So you're going to match this side as well
and make sure that one is set to one Q.

113
00:05:55.440 --> 00:05:59.580
On some of the switches that you
encounter if you do this, perfectly fine.

114
00:05:59.580 --> 00:06:02.350
You might find out it doesn't actually
give you any option of whether

115
00:06:02.350 --> 00:06:03.230
it's I or dot Q.

116
00:06:03.230 --> 00:06:06.600
That's the model of the switch itself too.

117
00:06:07.780 --> 00:06:11.790
And then of course you have to have
proper VLAN set up on this switch for

118
00:06:11.790 --> 00:06:13.270
each one of the machines.

119
00:06:13.270 --> 00:06:16.750
That we have to be able to route
traffic in between them, okay?

120
00:06:16.750 --> 00:06:17.360
>> Okay.
>> So

121
00:06:17.360 --> 00:06:20.100
that's what we want to emphasize there,
okay?

122
00:06:20.100 --> 00:06:23.000
Now there is another component
to this that they really want us

123
00:06:23.000 --> 00:06:24.900
to emphasize as well, okay?

124
00:06:24.900 --> 00:06:27.890
Once we get everything set
up the way that we want to.

125
00:06:27.890 --> 00:06:29.370
When we begin to troubleshoot,

126
00:06:29.370 --> 00:06:32.810
you wanna take a logical
approach to this as well, okay?

127
00:06:32.810 --> 00:06:38.420
So, first of all, you wanna begin with
verification process of things, right?

128
00:06:38.420 --> 00:06:39.650
So always,

129
00:06:39.650 --> 00:06:43.700
always make sure that you verify a couple
of different things as you go through.

130
00:06:43.700 --> 00:06:47.610
And take a look at each component here
during your troubleshooting process.

131
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:48.910
So, for example, right here,

132
00:06:48.910 --> 00:06:53.470
notice it says I put down here
verify the configuration.

133
00:06:53.470 --> 00:06:58.810
Do you have sub interfaces on that port
that we're using for that connection?

134
00:06:58.810 --> 00:07:02.340
If you don't it's not gonna work because
it will allow you to send traffic in.

135
00:07:02.340 --> 00:07:05.420
But it won't allow you to forward
traffic back out of it, okay.

136
00:07:05.420 --> 00:07:06.240
So it's not gonna do that.

137
00:07:07.480 --> 00:07:12.330
Secondly verify your encapsulation
type on the router interface as well.

138
00:07:12.330 --> 00:07:16.370
Verify that you have the proper
VLAN ID with the actual proper IP

139
00:07:16.370 --> 00:07:17.290
address on there too.

140
00:07:17.290 --> 00:07:18.830
And then of course,

141
00:07:18.830 --> 00:07:24.040
did you forget to turn the port on
when you actually finish configuring.

142
00:07:24.040 --> 00:07:25.200
I know I've done it before,

143
00:07:25.200 --> 00:07:27.940
so usually what I do is I
turn it on at the beginning.

144
00:07:27.940 --> 00:07:28.680
Don't have to worry about it.

145
00:07:28.680 --> 00:07:30.730
But it is neat to actually
see all the stuff come up.

146
00:07:30.730 --> 00:07:32.535
So we are going to turn
it on at the end here.

147
00:07:32.535 --> 00:07:37.350
Okay so you can actually verify all that,
then move down to the switch.

148
00:07:37.350 --> 00:07:39.120
Notice we are following logical order.

149
00:07:39.120 --> 00:07:43.480
We are starting at the top and
we are moving down here to do this.

150
00:07:43.480 --> 00:07:46.000
Now notice this when configuring
the truck interface.

151
00:07:46.000 --> 00:07:50.870
We are just verifing we have the proper
trucking configuration on it, okay?

152
00:07:50.870 --> 00:07:52.060
That's all we want to do.

153
00:07:52.060 --> 00:07:55.580
Make sure that it's actually running
the proper configuration type.

154
00:07:55.580 --> 00:07:59.933
And then at the very end here make
sure that everything is working.

155
00:07:59.933 --> 00:08:02.341
Verify on your end point devices.

156
00:08:02.341 --> 00:08:05.491
That you have the proper
default gateway for

157
00:08:05.491 --> 00:08:10.015
each one of these different VLANs
on those machines at the end.

158
00:08:10.015 --> 00:08:10.871
Any one of those,

159
00:08:10.871 --> 00:08:14.478
anything here that we've talked about
in the troubleshooting part of it.

160
00:08:14.478 --> 00:08:17.322
When we start taking a look at,
if any of those are wrong,

161
00:08:17.322 --> 00:08:19.472
it's not gonna work
the way you want it to.

162
00:08:19.472 --> 00:08:21.828
>> Right.
>> So always start in one order.

163
00:08:21.828 --> 00:08:24.440
Whether you start down here and
move up, it's fine, or

164
00:08:24.440 --> 00:08:28.805
whether you start at the top and move I
always logically move down, and I always

165
00:08:28.805 --> 00:08:33.325
see diagrams like this in my head, is
what when we start to trouble shoot here.

166
00:08:33.325 --> 00:08:37.913
Alright, so while we're on the stick
configuration that's kind of the big one

167
00:08:37.913 --> 00:08:42.295
that we do, now, the problem is when
you & I would see something like this,

168
00:08:42.295 --> 00:08:44.255
is going to be in a lab setting.

169
00:08:44.255 --> 00:08:48.321
Today, router on a stick configuration,
you'll see it on Cisco exams.

170
00:08:48.321 --> 00:08:51.938
But you won't see it in a real
live environment anymore.

171
00:08:51.938 --> 00:08:54.063
And that's because it
really is a slow down.

172
00:08:54.063 --> 00:08:56.439
In this trunk link that
we have right here,

173
00:08:56.439 --> 00:09:01.474
that becomes a bottleneck when we start
separating out, let's say, 10 or 15 VLANs.

174
00:09:01.474 --> 00:09:04.716
That's sharing all
the bandwidth on that one link.

175
00:09:04.716 --> 00:09:08.584
It will work, but it will be
much slower than you think here.

176
00:09:08.584 --> 00:09:13.788
So usually we don't see this in any place
besides the idea of a lab setting for

177
00:09:13.788 --> 00:09:15.348
the majority of time.

178
00:09:15.348 --> 00:09:19.566
To eliminate that idea
then what might end up

179
00:09:19.566 --> 00:09:24.697
happening is that we just
kinda take the router away.

180
00:09:24.697 --> 00:09:26.110
Now why would I do that?

181
00:09:26.110 --> 00:09:29.636
Because if we're running
a layer three switch,

182
00:09:29.636 --> 00:09:35.240
we can configure the routing side directly
on the layer three switch itself.

183
00:09:35.240 --> 00:09:40.650
And we do that by using what we call SVIs,
switched virtual interfaces.

184
00:09:40.650 --> 00:09:45.482
And when we do that, we have to enable
the routing component on the switch first.

185
00:09:45.482 --> 00:09:51.645
And then you and I will configure virtual
interfaces and act in the same way.

186
00:09:51.645 --> 00:09:52.431
In other words,

187
00:09:52.431 --> 00:09:56.267
they'll substitute the way that we
actually use these sub interfaces instead.

188
00:09:56.267 --> 00:09:58.886
And we'll configure that
in the same process.

189
00:09:58.886 --> 00:10:01.962
Once all that's done,
it's the same troubleshooting,

190
00:10:01.962 --> 00:10:04.356
except that you just
switch all this around.

191
00:10:04.356 --> 00:10:09.154
You don't have to worry about the routing
side, but now you just verify that you

192
00:10:09.154 --> 00:10:13.608
actually do have the proper configuration
of those virtual interfaces.

193
00:10:13.608 --> 00:10:17.621
Usually we used to see it actually being
interface, VLAN, and you can name,

194
00:10:17.621 --> 00:10:19.491
you can number however you want to.

195
00:10:19.491 --> 00:10:22.262
But I normally number along
with the VLAN that I want.

196
00:10:22.262 --> 00:10:26.078
The IP address and then you're off and
ready to go to the races.

197
00:10:26.078 --> 00:10:29.213
Because once you actually
have the routing turned on,

198
00:10:29.213 --> 00:10:32.289
you'll see a routing table also for
this device too.

199
00:10:32.289 --> 00:10:34.064
If it was turned off, it won't be there.

200
00:10:34.064 --> 00:10:35.460
And lastly, of course,

201
00:10:35.460 --> 00:10:39.253
verify that you have default gateways
on the devices that you need.

202
00:10:39.253 --> 00:10:44.711
So that is kind of a very fast and
short review of what we did.

203
00:10:44.711 --> 00:10:49.995
Cuz we went over this in pretty good
detail inside of the Cisco CCENT Show.

204

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie begin with an over of dynamic routing protcols and how they work on the router.  They emphasize terminology used with them.  The guys describe the two major categories of IP routing protocols.
episodes.title: Compare and Contrast IGPs

We have now started to get
into another domain objective,

where we are talking about
routing technologies.

15

And so in a previous episode, as we've

16

bit of review of what we learned about

17
00:00:53.440 --> 00:00:57.080
Where we did inter-VLAN routing, we showed

18

And that was just a good reminder

and the idea of how

20

And we need to work through Layer 3
devices, whether it's a router or

At this time, we also need to learn

the CCNA Routing and
Switching exam itself, the ICND2.

24
00:01:17.849 --> 00:01:22.220
And we need to talk about this
idea of being able to compare and

25
00:01:22.220 --> 00:01:24.785

26
00:01:24.785 --> 00:01:31.470
Now, IGP stands for Inter-Gateway Protocol
or Interior Gateway Protocol.

27
00:01:31.470 --> 00:01:33.500
I don't know why I keep
saying inter-gateway.

28
00:01:33.500 --> 00:01:34.100
>> Interstate.

29
00:01:34.100 --> 00:01:37.040
>> Yeah,
it's actually Interior Gateway Protocol.

30
00:01:37.040 --> 00:01:38.340
I'm gonna say things wrong,

31
00:01:38.340 --> 00:01:42.120
it's just my nature of not remembering
a lot of terms here, okay?

32
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:45.430
Now, when we start talking about that
term everybody always wonders what

33
00:01:45.430 --> 00:01:48.160
what is Interior Gateway Protocol about?

34
00:01:48.160 --> 00:01:50.200
Well we can define it and
everyone’s been using the term,

35
00:01:50.200 --> 00:01:52.200
but why is the term Gateway?

36
00:01:52.200 --> 00:01:55.630
Well you can just substitute
the term Gateway for router, so

37
00:01:55.630 --> 00:01:58.930
you can actually talk about
the idea of inter-routing, okay?

38
00:01:58.930 --> 00:02:03.090
Or Interior Routing Protocols,
is what you can talk about as well.

39
00:02:03.090 --> 00:02:07.440
And that's because a long time ago
before the term routers became popular,

40
00:02:07.440 --> 00:02:09.460
well routers were called gateways.

41
00:02:09.460 --> 00:02:13.300
And so the terminology is still
continuing through to this day, and

42
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:16.880
we just use it not only historically,
because that's the way it's been true.

43
00:02:16.880 --> 00:02:19.040
We've just never changed the terminology.

44
00:02:19.040 --> 00:02:21.410
So just as we mentioned in Layer 2,

45
00:02:21.410 --> 00:02:24.400
where before there were
switches there were bridges.

46
00:02:24.400 --> 00:02:28.920
Well, before the term router became
popular it was called a gateway instead.

47
00:02:28.920 --> 00:02:32.990
And that's because it did lead
from one network into another one.

48
00:02:32.990 --> 00:02:35.130
And so that's what we're talking about.

49
00:02:35.130 --> 00:02:38.730
So we're gonna jump into this, and
we're gonna make sure that we understand

50
00:02:38.730 --> 00:02:41.940
the idea here of the different
Inter Gateway Protocols.

51
00:02:41.940 --> 00:02:45.550
But before we do,
we need to do just a basic

52
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:50.158
review of the dynamic routing
protocols is what we need do.

53
00:02:50.158 --> 00:02:54.470
In other words, just a quick overview here
of the idea of routers and routing and

54
00:02:54.470 --> 00:02:55.650
what is all about.

55
00:02:55.650 --> 00:02:58.300
And that's what we're gonna take
to look at as we get started.

56
00:02:58.300 --> 00:03:01.620
And then we'll jump into the idea
of the IGPs themselves, and

57
00:03:01.620 --> 00:03:05.530
we'll spend the majority of
time describing those too.

58
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:09.220
In a future episode we'll also
