59
00:03:09.220 --> 00:03:13.450
we'll talk about that in just a moment and
what that actually means.

60
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:19.100
But we're mostly, actually just about
95% of what we will be covering here

61
00:03:19.100 --> 00:03:24.060
in our CCNA routing switching, will be
all about the Interior Gateway Protocols.

62
00:03:24.060 --> 00:03:29.680
Very little about the External or
Exterior Gateway Protocols instead.

63
00:03:29.680 --> 00:03:34.460
So, let's start here and
let's talk about this idea of routers and

64
00:03:34.460 --> 00:03:36.680
what they end up doing for us.

65
00:03:36.680 --> 00:03:40.660
Remember that the whole purpose
of the router a lot of times,

66
00:03:40.660 --> 00:03:43.402
it is to separate out broadcast domains.

67
00:03:43.402 --> 00:03:46.876
So normally, when we have multiple
interfaces on the router,

68
00:03:46.876 --> 00:03:49.770
each router represents it's own network.

69
00:03:49.770 --> 00:03:55.145
So if I had two interfaces on this router,
well one router might be for

70
00:03:55.145 --> 00:03:58.866
example 192168 16.0 with a /24.

71
00:03:58.866 --> 00:04:04.397
And then the interface might represent
1721616.0 as well, with a /24, too.

72
00:04:04.397 --> 00:04:07.497
So we can actually do that and
then actually,

73
00:04:07.497 --> 00:04:09.960
there are two different networks.

74
00:04:09.960 --> 00:04:11.320
So going through a router,

75
00:04:11.320 --> 00:04:14.640
when you have moved traffic from
one interface to another interface.

76
00:04:14.640 --> 00:04:19.600
You're moving off a network to send it to
another network, is what you're doing.

77
00:04:19.600 --> 00:04:22.170
Now, the way that this
ends up working though.

78
00:04:22.170 --> 00:04:28.020
Is that a router continues to
learn about the idea of route.

79
00:04:28.020 --> 00:04:31.340
How does it actually route from
one interface to another, and

80
00:04:31.340 --> 00:04:33.600
how does a router do so?

81
00:04:33.600 --> 00:04:38.270
There's three basic ways in which
a router learns about routes.

82
00:04:38.270 --> 00:04:42.070
And when we start to take a look
at the first way is fairly simple.

83
00:04:42.070 --> 00:04:46.090
Let me get rid of those commas
here as I type them in here.

84
00:04:46.090 --> 00:04:50.702
I was talking about this idea of
connected at the very beginning.

85
00:04:50.702 --> 00:04:57.500
So when we talk about a connected
interface here, what do we say?

86
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:03.070
What a router will do, is it will
automatically know about networks

87
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:08.820
that are directly connected off of this
router, on one interface or another.

88
00:05:08.820 --> 00:05:13.890
So it doesn't have to learn about it,
because it is directly connected there,

89
00:05:13.890 --> 00:05:17.300
that we will be able to actually
know what the routes are.

90
00:05:17.300 --> 00:05:21.240
So if it knows what it is,
it can then take that route and

91
00:05:21.240 --> 00:05:25.790
end up learning how to actually say this
network, if it goes to this other one

92
00:05:25.790 --> 00:05:29.010
that's connected, I can route that
from one interface to another.

93
00:05:29.010 --> 00:05:30.860
And I don't have to worry about it.

94
00:05:30.860 --> 00:05:34.492
So that is kind of the primary
way that it begins to do so.

95
00:05:34.492 --> 00:05:39.470
But there's also gonna be possibilities
here, that we'll learn about networks or

96
00:05:39.470 --> 00:05:41.680
we'll actually need the router
to learn about networks,

97
00:05:41.680 --> 00:05:44.478
that we are not directly connected to.

98
00:05:44.478 --> 00:05:47.630
Let's take some example that
there's another router here

99
00:05:47.630 --> 00:05:52.240
that's off to the left, off the screen
that we have that we're connected to.

100
00:05:52.240 --> 00:05:55.970
But I need to be able to send traffic
to the router on the left hand side of

101
00:05:55.970 --> 00:05:58.860
the screen off of that router.

102
00:05:58.860 --> 00:06:03.130
Well, I don't actually have a method to do
so, because I'm not directly connected or

103
00:06:03.130 --> 00:06:04.410
this router isn't.

104
00:06:04.410 --> 00:06:07.918
But the very fact is,
if I know what that network number is,

105
00:06:07.918 --> 00:06:12.510
I can manually go into this router,
and I can configure and

106
00:06:12.510 --> 00:06:17.400
statically enter a route in there for
that network.

107
00:06:18.410 --> 00:06:22.890
When I do so, I can administratively
put the effort behind it and

108
00:06:22.890 --> 00:06:26.340
say, here's what you're going to
enter in into the routing table.

109
00:06:26.340 --> 00:06:30.990
If traffic comes in to this router
destined for that network, it has

110
00:06:30.990 --> 00:06:35.130
a static entry in there, I have actually
been the one that programmed it in,

111
00:06:35.130 --> 00:06:37.160
and it knows how to get there as well.

112
00:06:38.630 --> 00:06:42.910
Now in both of those it
relies on the idea here,

113
00:06:42.910 --> 00:06:46.530
that things are really not
gonna change too often.

114
00:06:46.530 --> 00:06:51.470
But if they do change,
when we start to take a look at this idea.

115
00:06:51.470 --> 00:06:53.362
We're not talking about
dynamic routing protocols yet,

116
00:06:53.362 --> 00:06:55.338
we're just talking about
the basic function of the router.

117
00:06:55.338 --> 00:06:59.519
If they do change, whether it's connected
or whether it's dynamic, it means I also

118
00:06:59.519 --> 00:07:02.784
have to make an administrative
effort to keep up with that change.

119
00:07:02.784 --> 00:07:04.537
And that means I have to go in and

120
00:07:04.537 --> 00:07:07.304
manually actually change
some configuration,

121
00:07:07.304 --> 00:07:11.960
to make sure that the router understands
that a change has taken place.

122
00:07:11.960 --> 00:07:14.300
Now, if I don't want to do
anything like that, and

123
00:07:14.300 --> 00:07:17.430
I want the router to
essentially handle it for me.

124
00:07:17.430 --> 00:07:20.080
Because a router's pretty much
a computer on its own, and

125
00:07:20.080 --> 00:07:22.680
it has the ability to do stuff like that.

126
00:07:22.680 --> 00:07:29.330
I instead can configure the router itself,
to use a dynamic routing protocol.

127
00:07:29.330 --> 00:07:33.900
And in dynamic routing protocol,
it can dynamically learn routes

128
00:07:33.900 --> 00:07:39.240
by communicating with
other routers to do so.

129
00:07:39.240 --> 00:07:41.520
So, this is actually
a very important concept,

130
00:07:41.520 --> 00:07:45.160
when we talk about the overview
of dynamic routing protocols.

131
00:07:45.160 --> 00:07:48.540
Normally, if we know that we are in
a network that's going to grow in

132
00:07:48.540 --> 00:07:49.980
the future.

133
00:07:49.980 --> 00:07:54.130
We want the plan for that and we may not
choose to use static routes anymore.

134
00:07:54.130 --> 00:07:59.129
What we may choose to do instead,
is go ahead and implement a dynamic route,

135
00:07:59.129 --> 00:08:02.423
a dynamic routing protocol
on the router itself.

136
00:08:02.423 --> 00:08:07.275
And when we do so, it means it can learn
from other routers that are running that

137
00:08:07.275 --> 00:08:09.810
same routing protocol itself.

138
00:08:09.810 --> 00:08:12.940
And if it does so,
it can learn about the routes that way.

139
00:08:12.940 --> 00:08:16.703
And that means that if data is sent
through this router, it knows how to get

140
00:08:16.703 --> 00:08:20.223
to those networks without you and
me having to actually ever change or

141
00:08:20.223 --> 00:08:22.976
configure anything on
the router itself too, okay?

142
00:08:22.976 --> 00:08:27.320
So that's some of the other
things that it can do.

143
00:08:27.320 --> 00:08:32.922
Now, when we start to learn about the idea
of these routes, we can go ahead.

144
00:08:32.922 --> 00:08:37.948
And normally, dynamic routing protocol
is what it also does for us, is it also

145
00:08:37.948 --> 00:08:43.371
decides what gets entered into the routing
table by doing what it calls, of course.

146
00:08:43.371 --> 00:08:47.029
It tries to find the best
path to that destination

147
00:08:47.029 --> 00:08:52.160
network based off of a term that
we used called a metric, okay?

148
00:08:52.160 --> 00:08:57.330
So depending on the dynamic routing
protocol, the metric will be different.

149
00:08:57.330 --> 00:09:00.970
So that's why it actually requires us,
if we're going to be sharing route

150
00:09:00.970 --> 00:09:04.600
with other routers, that they're
running the same routing protocols.

151
00:09:04.600 --> 00:09:08.340
So whatever that term means, which we'll
discuss in a little bit here, okay?

152
00:09:08.340 --> 00:09:11.970
But at this point, just understand that
it's usually based on the metric, and

153
00:09:11.970 --> 00:09:14.310
whatever the best metric is,
is what gets to there.

154
00:09:14.310 --> 00:09:17.230
Now, you might be wondering, why the heck
do I care about what the metric is?

155
00:09:18.280 --> 00:09:23.362
The reason that you care about that
is because, in a network that becomes

156
00:09:23.362 --> 00:09:28.443
more complex as your network continues
to grow, it is very possible that

157
00:09:28.443 --> 00:09:33.559
this single router can learn about
more than one route to a destination.

158
00:09:33.559 --> 00:09:34.861
Well, at that point,

159
00:09:34.861 --> 00:09:39.670
it wants to only place what it calls
the best route into the routing table.

160
00:09:39.670 --> 00:09:43.220
So it doesn't do a term that you learned
about inside of your CCNP routing and

161
00:09:43.220 --> 00:09:47.070
switching, that we call
suboptimal routing, okay?

162
00:09:47.070 --> 00:09:50.909
So that's the goal and the idea, is that
we can actually prevent it from learning

163
00:09:50.909 --> 00:09:54.704
about suboptimal routes, as long as
everything is actually set up correctly.

164
00:09:54.704 --> 00:09:58.466
But they do creep in at times and we have
to take care of them, but at this point,

165
00:09:58.466 --> 00:10:01.230
we're not really learning about that yet,
okay?

166
00:10:01.230 --> 00:10:05.291
So the metric is really about that, is
what gets entered into the routing table,

167
00:10:05.291 --> 00:10:08.771
so that this router can consistently
use that best path as possible.

168
00:10:08.771 --> 00:10:11.350
We'll talk about how
that's decided as well.

169
00:10:11.350 --> 00:10:14.652
Now, Zach, I ended up using a couple
of terms here though, okay?

170
00:10:14.652 --> 00:10:17.409
>> Mm-hm, mm-hm.
>> I used the term routing protocol, but

171
00:10:17.409 --> 00:10:21.853
you'll also hear the term routed
protocol when you talk about

172
00:10:21.853 --> 00:10:25.060
the idea here of networking, okay?

173
00:10:25.060 --> 00:10:29.803
And if there's anything that gets
confusing for the person that's really

174
00:10:29.803 --> 00:10:34.844
beginning their journey into the Cisco
CCNA, and CCENT, and CCNA here, it's

175
00:10:34.844 --> 00:10:39.832
actually distinguishing the difference
between the term routing protocol.

176
00:10:39.832 --> 00:10:42.855
Which, apparently,
I can't spell, protocol.

00:10:42.855 --> 00:10:43.597
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay,

178
00:10:43.597 --> 00:10:48.180
and, of course,
the term routed protocol as well.

179
00:10:48.180 --> 00:10:52.802
So this is a great place for
us to just slow down for a moment and

180
00:10:52.802 --> 00:10:59.255

00:10:59.255 --> 00:11:01.373
So, of course,

the way that I wanted to

00:11:03.400 --> 00:11:07.236
So let's start off with the idea of
the routed protocol instead, and that way,

184
00:11:07.236 --> 00:11:09.194
we'll do this a little bit more, okay?

185
00:11:09.194 --> 00:11:14.082
Now, when we talk about a routed
protocol at times, technically,

186
00:11:14.082 --> 00:11:16.010
what does this do, okay?

187
00:11:16.010 --> 00:11:20.601
This really describes the idea of
the encapsulation process itself,

188
00:11:20.601 --> 00:11:22.479
all the way down to Layer 3.

189
00:11:22.479 --> 00:11:26.398
Now, when we start to take a look at that,
in terms of the routed protocol,

190
00:11:26.398 --> 00:11:31.180
I should've highlighted that one instead,
the routed protocol, what does that mean?

191
00:11:31.180 --> 00:11:35.340
Well, for you and me,
it is about the addressing, okay?

192
00:11:35.340 --> 00:11:38.080
It is the idea of the IP addressing.

193
00:11:38.080 --> 00:11:42.620
So, for example, we just used the most
generic term routed protocol, and

194
00:11:42.620 --> 00:11:47.880
if we go back to our CCENT show and
we take a look at that,

00:11:47.880 --> 00:11:50.610
right at the beginning when we talked

00:11:50.610 --> 00:11:57.265
We take some good time and we describe
the OSI model and the TCP/IP model here.

197
00:11:57.265 --> 00:12:01.924
And when we start doing that and we get
down to the Layer 3, the network layer or

198
00:12:01.924 --> 00:12:04.770
the Internet layer in the TCP/IP model.

199
00:12:04.770 --> 00:12:08.320
We are now talking about
this idea of the networking,

200
00:12:08.320 --> 00:12:09.860
which it actually has to do with routing.

201
00:12:09.860 --> 00:12:12.836
So at that point,
when you are sending data off,

202
00:12:12.836 --> 00:12:17.786
you're actually adding in multiple layers

203
00:12:17.786 --> 00:12:24.190
And when it gets down to that layer,

204
00:12:24.190 --> 00:12:27.820
So our routed protocol is IP,
but for you and me,

00:12:27.820 --> 00:12:31.070
a strict example is just an IP address,

206
00:12:31.070 --> 00:12:35.160
So if you and I are actually using IP,
that is our routed protocol here.

00:12:40.260 --> 00:12:44.055
Let me see if I can type that

00:12:44.055 --> 00:12:47.474
So IP address is an example of that, okay?

00:12:47.474 --> 00:12:50.964
So when we see 192.168.16.12,

00:12:50.964 --> 00:12:55.710

00:12:55.710 --> 00:13:01.039
Now, the reason why that’s important,
that if think about this idea, the routing

212
00:13:01.039 --> 00:13:06.290
table on a router itself is made of,
well, those types of entries, right?

213
00:13:06.290 --> 00:13:08.370
It is looking for the routed protocol.

00:13:08.370 --> 00:13:13.810
The information that's inside

00:13:13.810 --> 00:13:15.690

216
00:13:15.690 --> 00:13:17.570
So that's what it's looking for

217
00:13:17.570 --> 00:13:20.600
to be able to send it from one
network to another one, okay?

218
00:13:20.600 --> 00:13:24.560
So we can talk about IP addresses, or
IP version 6 addresses, whatever it is.

219
00:13:24.560 --> 00:13:27.645
That is an example of a routed protocol.

220
00:13:27.645 --> 00:13:32.993
But when we compare that to a routing
protocol, a routing protocol

221
00:13:32.993 --> 00:13:39.920
is more of the idea here of how it learns
about the routed protocol itself, okay?

222
00:13:39.920 --> 00:13:43.005
So for you and me,
a routed protocol example,

00:13:43.005 --> 00:13:47.293
the biggest one that most people
end up using is one called OSPF.

224
00:13:47.293 --> 00:13:52.274
We have EIGRP, and of course, RIP,

225
00:13:52.274 --> 00:13:56.418
And if we wanted to go
the exterior gateway protocol,

226
00:13:56.418 --> 00:14:01.403
we could even do BGP as well, so
those are examples themselves.

227
00:14:01.403 --> 00:14:05.830
Now, notice that in the routing protocols,
we're not talking about IP addresses.

228
00:14:05.830 --> 00:14:10.290
We're not talking about IPX/SPX,
Apple Talk, anything like that.

229
00:14:10.290 --> 00:14:15.360
What we're really talking about
here is gonna be how that router

230
00:14:15.360 --> 00:14:20.100
can actually be able to choose the best
possible route to the destination.

231
00:14:20.100 --> 00:14:22.718
The routing protocol makes that decision.

232
00:14:22.718 --> 00:14:25.590
Whereas, the routed protocol
essentially tells us, or

233
00:14:25.590 --> 00:14:30.860
identifies, the route or the network
that we're trying to get to, okay?

234
00:14:30.860 --> 00:14:34.713
So that's how the router ends up
functioning, at least at the basic here,

235
00:14:34.713 --> 00:14:36.400
in terms of terminology.

236
00:14:36.400 --> 00:14:41.010
You need to make sure that you get

237
00:14:41.010 --> 00:14:44.818
But this a distinction that people will

238
00:14:44.818 --> 00:14:45.970
understand.

00:14:45.970 --> 00:14:48.124
>> Well,
how do routing protocols function, Ronnie?

00:14:48.124 --> 00:14:50.897
>> Well, when it begins here,
when we start taking away,

00:14:50.897 --> 00:14:53.990
cuz that's the more complex of
these two terms here, right?

242
00:14:53.990 --> 00:14:55.467
Routed protocol versus routing protocol.

243
00:14:55.467 --> 00:15:00.870
Well, the routing protocol is decided for
us today, and that's just gonna be TCP/IP.

00:15:00.870 --> 00:15:02.202

There's not really a ton of other networks

00:15:06.622 --> 00:15:09.210
protocol on the Internet, at least, okay?

And there is not anything, normally

Are there still holdouts for IPX/SPX?

Yes, there's still a few

IP is the only one that

00:15:34.624 --> 00:15:36.925

00:15:50.325 --> 00:15:54.975
Let me go ahead and

well, something that ends up happening.

00:15:57.230 --> 00:15:59.300

Okay, that's what I wanna do,

00:16:03.528 --> 00:16:06.480
let's start talking about

00:16:06.480 --> 00:16:11.028
And how they really do begin to function,

266
00:16:11.028 --> 00:16:15.364
So on your screen I've made this simple
diagram here of an example of some

267
00:16:15.364 --> 00:16:18.550
of the different routing protocols, okay?

268
00:16:18.550 --> 00:16:22.160
Each cloud represents in itself its

269
00:16:22.160 --> 00:16:25.650
own administrative domain
in terms of routing, okay?

00:16:25.650 --> 00:16:28.950
We technically call that an AS or

00:16:28.950 --> 00:16:31.754

00:16:31.754 --> 00:16:33.740
But when we start to do this, right,

273
00:16:33.740 --> 00:16:37.277
we have those two different
branches here of routing protocols.

274
00:16:37.277 --> 00:16:41.320
There's what we call IGPs,

00:16:41.320 --> 00:16:45.758

00:16:45.758 --> 00:16:48.077
Regardless of which one it is, okay,

00:16:48.077 --> 00:16:53.004
they normally kind of all break down into

00:16:53.004 --> 00:16:56.770
down here toward the bottom

00:16:56.770 --> 00:17:00.160
So the first thing that
a routing protocol does, okay?

00:17:00.160 --> 00:17:01.650
Normally, okay, and

00:17:01.650 --> 00:17:05.970
we can put an exception to EGP
here in a little bit here, okay?

00:17:05.970 --> 00:17:08.877
But all routing protocols,

00:17:08.877 --> 00:17:12.710
they do what we call route
selection here based on the metric.

284
00:17:12.710 --> 00:17:17.594
Now the route selection, right, it's not
just pick any route that's out there.

285
00:17:17.594 --> 00:17:23.642
It's about picking the best possible route
to the destination that it needs to go to,

286
00:17:23.642 --> 00:17:24.700

00:17:24.700 --> 00:17:27.850
And in IGPs especially and primarily,

00:17:27.850 --> 00:17:30.360
since that's the one we're

00:17:30.360 --> 00:17:34.980
It really has to do with what we

290
00:17:34.980 --> 00:17:38.370
So when it actually wants to

291
00:17:38.370 --> 00:17:40.870
it will base it on the metric itself.

292
00:17:40.870 --> 00:17:43.330
Now once we actually understand that,

00:17:43.330 --> 00:17:47.500
every routing protocol, every dynamic

294
00:17:47.500 --> 00:17:49.660
the routing function,

00:17:49.660 --> 00:17:51.540
It wants to pick the best possible route.

296
00:17:52.570 --> 00:17:57.398
Secondly what a routing protocol also

00:18:01.020 --> 00:18:06.265
So if the other routers are using the same

00:18:06.265 --> 00:18:11.372

00:18:11.372 --> 00:18:15.870

00:18:15.870 --> 00:18:19.620
So that's what it does, once again,
regardless of everything else,

302
00:18:19.620 --> 00:18:22.980
set all the details that
are different behind it.

303
00:18:22.980 --> 00:18:26.100
Generically, all of
these routing protocols,

304
00:18:26.100 --> 00:18:27.970
they will learn from each other.

305
00:18:27.970 --> 00:18:31.200
The nice thing about it,
it means I do not have to go in and

306
00:18:31.200 --> 00:18:36.630
administratively configure every single
route to every possible destination.

307
00:18:36.630 --> 00:18:40.350
Because now the routers actually
that are in them can do so.

308
00:18:40.350 --> 00:18:42.700
Okay, they can actually
learn from each other.

309
00:18:42.700 --> 00:18:47.491
The other things that routing protocols
also do is that they set up their own

310
00:18:47.491 --> 00:18:50.774
ability here to not only
learn from other routers.

311
00:18:50.774 --> 00:18:54.028
But to also make sure that
they are propagating and

312
00:18:54.028 --> 00:18:58.985
helping other routers by advertising
their own routes to other routers that

313
00:18:58.985 --> 00:19:03.600
are running the same dynamic
routing protocol as well.

314
00:19:03.600 --> 00:19:08.004
So they try and ensure that, hey if you're
running the same routing protocol as I am,

315
00:19:08.004 --> 00:19:10.342
that you're not left out on your own,
okay?

316
00:19:10.342 --> 00:19:13.031
But that you're actually getting
the same information that I'm getting.

317
00:19:13.031 --> 00:19:17.680
So that you too can actually have the best
possible update that's out there.

318
00:19:17.680 --> 00:19:21.400
And you too can make the best
possible selection that you have.

319
00:19:21.400 --> 00:19:22.490
So that's what else it does.

320
00:19:22.490 --> 00:19:26.950
So not only does it learn from others,
it also advertises to others as well.

321
00:19:26.950 --> 00:19:32.050
And then finally here, routers, as far as
their function in the routing protocols,

322
00:19:32.050 --> 00:19:35.410
they will dynamically
respond to network changes.

323
00:19:35.410 --> 00:19:40.343
That means if we lose a particular path,
well, the routers themselves

324
00:19:40.343 --> 00:19:44.713
can realize the path has changed
to that destination network.

325
00:19:44.713 --> 00:19:49.315
And try and actually discover what
is the best metric that now exists,

326
00:19:49.315 --> 00:19:52.960
now that the first one is no longer there,
okay?

327
00:19:52.960 --> 00:19:57.392
So that's essentially how a routing
protocol does end up functioning in

328
00:19:57.392 --> 00:19:58.925
the most generic sense.

329
00:19:58.925 --> 00:20:02.740
But are there detailed
differences between each one?

330
00:20:02.740 --> 00:20:05.520
Yes, and are we gonna be
talking about some of them?

331
00:20:05.520 --> 00:20:08.088
Yes, we are, we're going to be
talking about two in particular

332
00:20:08.088 --> 00:20:11.970
in our CCNA Routing and Switching show.

333
00:20:11.970 --> 00:20:16.050
Because in the CCENT show we did
talk about the first one that

334
00:20:16.050 --> 00:20:20.320
really helped us to understand the basic
concept of routing, which was RIP.

335
00:20:20.320 --> 00:20:24.110
And in this one, we'll spend a lot more
time talking about the two that are left

336
00:20:24.110 --> 00:20:28.450
that are a little bit more sophisticated,
which we call EIGRP and OSPF.

337
00:20:29.670 --> 00:20:33.710
So that's also something else that
we'll have to be able to do as well.

338
00:20:33.710 --> 00:20:35.968
Here's the basic function, okay?

339
00:20:35.968 --> 00:20:39.899
All right, so when we start to do this,
right, and we start to take a look then,

00:20:39.899 --> 00:20:43.480
let's talk about what's actually
happening here too, okay?

341
00:20:43.480 --> 00:20:44.700
So I went ahead and

342
00:20:44.700 --> 00:20:48.490
in this diagram as we set up the idea
of the differences between them.

343
00:20:48.490 --> 00:20:53.339
Okay, when we talk about interior gateway
protocols versus exterior gateway

344
00:20:53.339 --> 00:20:57.752
protocols, both of them have dynamic
routing protocols behind them.

345
00:20:57.752 --> 00:21:02.862
But what makes the difference between
them is this, interior gateway protocols,

346
00:21:02.862 --> 00:21:06.595
they work within a single
autonomous system itself, okay?

347
00:21:06.595 --> 00:21:09.591
So that means we can run
the same routing protocol, and

348
00:21:09.591 --> 00:21:13.307
normally that's what ends up
happening is that you normally choose

349
00:21:13.307 --> 00:21:16.320
one routing protocol for
your own autonomous system.

350
00:21:16.320 --> 00:21:20.739
So for example over here on
the left-hand side I choose for

351
00:21:20.739 --> 00:21:25.262
AS 65438 here, okay,
EIGRP as my routing protocol.

352
00:21:25.262 --> 00:21:28.437
So anywhere inside when I'm
running routers inside,

353
00:21:28.437 --> 00:21:31.346
that is the routing protocol
we're going to run.

354
00:21:31.346 --> 00:21:35.380
And they're gonna do all there functions
that we just talked about down here, okay.

355
00:21:35.380 --> 00:21:39.288
But over here on this it's
running OSPF version 3.

356
00:21:39.288 --> 00:21:43.321
So this is saying hey, I'm running IPv6 so
I can actually do that, and

357
00:21:43.321 --> 00:21:45.440
it will also do the same thing.

358
00:21:45.440 --> 00:21:50.110
This one down here running OSPF and
this one over here running EIGRP again.

359
00:21:50.110 --> 00:21:52.165
Within our own autonomous system,

360
00:21:52.165 --> 00:21:56.149
that is the key in understanding
what that term means as well, okay?

361
00:21:56.149 --> 00:22:01.339
An autonomous system, even though I
alluded to it inside of our CCENT episode,

362
00:22:01.339 --> 00:22:05.444
essentially the autonomous system
is what I am responsible for

363
00:22:05.444 --> 00:22:08.086
taking care of in my own routing domain.

364
00:22:08.086 --> 00:22:12.059
So if I've paid for the equipment,
okay, if I am responsible for

365
00:22:12.059 --> 00:22:15.660
insuring that routes are getting
where they need to be.

366
00:22:15.660 --> 00:22:18.500
And that they can actually communicate and
do everything.

367
00:22:18.500 --> 00:22:21.060
That is my own autonomous system.

368
00:22:21.060 --> 00:22:25.920
Now when we also talk about it as well,
because you and

369
00:22:25.920 --> 00:22:28.680
I also run not only our
own autonomous system.

370
00:22:28.680 --> 00:22:30.285
But we expect to connect to, well,

00:22:30.285 --> 00:22:32.699
other networks that are out
there in the world today.

372
00:22:32.699 --> 00:22:37.612
We also need another type of routing
protocol that may help us to be able to

373
00:22:37.612 --> 00:22:40.608
communicate between autonomous systems.

374
00:22:40.608 --> 00:22:43.307
And that is going to be
what we call an EGP,

375
00:22:43.307 --> 00:22:46.450
which is an Exterior Gateway Protocol.

376
00:22:46.450 --> 00:22:51.052
And even though there were a couple
during the last 30 or 40 years, okay.

377
00:22:51.052 --> 00:22:55.700
Today there's only one which is BGP,
border gateway protocol, okay.

378
00:22:55.700 --> 00:23:01.257
So when we actually route between
autonomous systems, we're gonna use BGP.

379
00:23:01.257 --> 00:23:05.810
But this is where BGP works is
in between autonomous systems.

380
00:23:05.810 --> 00:23:10.570
Now unlike the idea of the interior
gateway protocols, you're gonna actually

381
00:23:10.570 --> 00:23:15.060
find something else out here about
the exterior gateway protocols.

382
00:23:15.060 --> 00:23:18.960
They do not always function together,
okay?

383
00:23:18.960 --> 00:23:21.320
They actually do function
just about independently,

00:23:21.320 --> 00:23:24.360
and let me just give you
a brief explanation of why.

385
00:23:24.360 --> 00:23:28.661
You and I might be able to control what
goes on in our own autonomous system.

386
00:23:28.661 --> 00:23:35.476
But I do not get that luxury of
actually saying a lot of times,

387
00:23:35.476 --> 00:23:40.423
okay, what direction I

00:23:40.423 --> 00:23:45.380
AS65438 going to AS64998.

389
00:23:45.380 --> 00:23:47.480
So that's not my responsibility.

390
00:23:47.480 --> 00:23:52.191
But inside of our ISPs that are actually
routing the information for

391
00:23:52.191 --> 00:23:56.370
us, a lot of times,
they can decide how that gets there.

392
00:23:56.370 --> 00:23:59.040
And they'll use BGP to

393
00:23:59.040 --> 00:24:03.623
Now I can actually make it where

00:24:03.623 --> 00:24:07.893
On Edge minor, say whether I'll
allow traffic command on this one or

00:24:07.893 --> 00:24:12.280
I'll allow traffic to come in on
this one and by Tuesday, okay?

396
00:24:12.280 --> 00:24:15.146
But it doesn't necessarily
mean that it always works out,

397
00:24:15.146 --> 00:24:18.780
because I can't tell this ISP,
you're gonna send it here, okay?

398
00:24:18.780 --> 00:24:22.393
I can just tell the ISP that once
it gets to my place here, okay?

399
00:24:22.393 --> 00:24:25.017
I want it to actually route
through something else.

400
00:24:25.017 --> 00:24:28.396
So we can do stuff like that, but
we're really not getting in that.

401
00:24:28.396 --> 00:24:31.798
For those of you that want

make sure you jump ahead and you go and

We'll definitely be diving deeper

00:24:49.546 --> 00:24:53.220
So just kind of realize that those

407

But the key here is understanding at least

408
00:24:57.140 --> 00:25:03.150
So now hopefully, you understand
the difference between IGP and

00:25:03.150 --> 00:25:05.520
EGP, an Exterior Gateway Protocol.

And we've also talked about

00:25:09.270 --> 00:25:13.270

This is just for the sake of you

I don't know which one you'll get,

I've tend to use thi,s

Overall, you may see either one

That's the idea and the goal is

00:29:02.770 --> 00:29:05.060
So the idea of split horizon is simple.

00:29:05.060 --> 00:29:09.360
To stop this idea of actually

00:29:09.360 --> 00:29:11.910

00:29:11.910 --> 00:29:16.320
But where we saw where it went from two

00:29:16.320 --> 00:29:17.794

00:29:17.794 --> 00:29:23.608
Split horizon essentially says,

491
00:29:36.360 --> 00:29:38.562
Because that'd be silly,
you already know the information,

492
00:29:38.562 --> 00:29:39.770
why am I telling you again?

493
00:29:40.980 --> 00:29:45.618
So split horizon is a primary mechanism
that we tend to see, and again,

494
00:29:45.618 --> 00:29:48.730
it's actually enabled by default.

495
00:29:48.730 --> 00:29:52.210
The other one is also what
is called poison reverse.

496
00:29:52.210 --> 00:29:56.590
So instead of it doing the count to
infinity where it gets to 16 and

497
00:29:56.590 --> 00:30:01.760
then drops it, what it instead
can do is once a route drops for

498
00:30:01.760 --> 00:30:05.160
router three,
it doesn't just stop advertising it.

499
00:30:05.160 --> 00:30:09.524
It instead says, look, let me go and
advertise out that for

500
00:30:09.524 --> 00:30:15.393
the 30 network here, okay, it's gonna
be advertised with a metric of 16.

501
00:30:15.393 --> 00:30:18.114
And what's advertised with a metric of 16,

502
00:30:18.114 --> 00:30:22.159
the next time it actually updates
this table, it will get the 16 and

503
00:30:22.159 --> 00:30:26.590
go, I can't put anything above a 16
in here, and it will drop the route.

504
00:30:26.590 --> 00:30:29.975
And then the same thing will happen
as it continue to propagate this way.

505
00:30:29.975 --> 00:30:34.100
So that way the route actually
ends up clearing out too.

506
00:30:34.100 --> 00:30:38.363
But it can also lead to what we
call to a triggered update as well.

507
00:30:38.363 --> 00:30:43.140
The very fact that that one route drops
out, that may actually indicate a trigger

508
00:30:43.140 --> 00:30:47.635
that allows it to do this and really
updating in that way, a partial update,

509
00:30:47.635 --> 00:30:50.870
in terms of a few different things, okay?

510
00:30:50.870 --> 00:30:54.120
But the other one is, lastly,
is what we call a hold down timer.

511
00:30:55.360 --> 00:30:58.480
So instead of doing
either the one of these,

512
00:30:58.480 --> 00:31:01.790
right, instead of actually doing the split
horizon and then poison reverse,

513
00:31:01.790 --> 00:31:06.180
those two are also there,
hold down timers are also a part of this.

514
00:31:06.180 --> 00:31:11.190
So if this one ends up dropping,
what router can can do is say,

515
00:31:11.190 --> 00:31:14.990
look, I'm not hearing anything from them,
but it says,

516
00:31:14.990 --> 00:31:21.700
I'm just gonna stop receiving an update
about this route until my timer is done.

517
00:31:21.700 --> 00:31:26.069
So it will say, let me lock down
the route to the 30.0 network,

518
00:31:26.069 --> 00:31:29.279
I'm just gonna lock it down for
a period of time.

519
00:31:29.279 --> 00:31:31.889
As I lock it down for a period of time,

520
00:31:31.889 --> 00:31:37.798
I'm also not gonna advertise this out
until I hear something is different, okay?

521
00:31:37.798 --> 00:31:39.560
Can it receive updates from other places?

522
00:31:39.560 --> 00:31:43.870
Yes, okay, but it's not gonna
change it until the timer is up.

523
00:31:43.870 --> 00:31:47.770
By that point, it could be that
the issue has resolved itself, and

524
00:31:47.770 --> 00:31:51.280
then it hears about a new route from
that source, then it's ready to go.

525
00:31:51.280 --> 00:31:53.445
And that's the key on the hold down timer.

526
00:31:53.445 --> 00:31:58.671
It doesn't actually allow for
an update to continue to cascade out.

527
00:31:58.671 --> 00:32:05.950
Until it hears from the original one that
actually said, I'm not updating anymore.

528
00:32:05.950 --> 00:32:08.199
So if router 2 starts a hold down timer,

529
00:32:08.199 --> 00:32:11.610
it is only because he
didn't hear from router 3.

530
00:32:11.610 --> 00:32:15.680
And until router 3 says, I'm now back up,

531
00:32:15.680 --> 00:32:19.830
it says I won't propagate out a bad route,
I'm just not gonna do it.

532
00:32:19.830 --> 00:32:22.940
But if router 3 comes back up,
it says router 3's back up, so

533
00:32:22.940 --> 00:32:26.350
now I'll go ahead and
start forwarding the information along.

534
00:32:26.350 --> 00:32:31.030
So all of these are actually valid ways
of dealing with the idea of loops.

535
00:32:31.030 --> 00:32:35.170
So there are problems with
the idea of actually doing

536
00:32:35.170 --> 00:32:38.120
distance vector protocols
when you start seeing them.

537
00:32:38.120 --> 00:32:42.746
Now, in terms of some of the examples of
distance vector protocols, the great thing

538
00:32:42.746 --> 00:32:47.520
is you can go back to CCENT show, you can
see where we referred to these as well.

539
00:32:47.520 --> 00:32:51.004
But just remember that for us,
it's primarily gonna be RIP,

540
00:32:51.004 --> 00:32:54.692
specifically RIP version 2 is
the one that you're looking for.

541
00:32:54.692 --> 00:32:58.620
Because RIP version 2 is what we
called a classless routing protocol.

542
00:32:58.620 --> 00:33:01.876
It will support the use of
subnets is what it will do,

543
00:33:01.876 --> 00:33:05.576
most of us don't do routing
here classically anymore, and

544
00:33:05.576 --> 00:33:09.729
it will also support of course
auto summarization as well, okay.

545
00:33:09.729 --> 00:33:13.559
The other thing of course is to
remember there's also a possibility

546
00:33:13.559 --> 00:33:17.871
that's out there for what we will be
doing, especially in this day and age.

547
00:33:17.871 --> 00:33:21.579
That Rip also has IP version four and
IP version 6.

548
00:33:21.579 --> 00:33:26.159
And that is also still the same
distance vector protocol, but

549
00:33:26.159 --> 00:33:27.931
just for IP version 6.

550
00:33:27.931 --> 00:33:32.156
EIGRP is the one that's the most
controversy of these that's

551
00:33:32.156 --> 00:33:35.007
considered a distance vector protocol.

552
00:33:35.007 --> 00:33:38.926
The reason why is part of it functions
as a distance vector protocol, but

553
00:33:38.926 --> 00:33:40.349
the other part doesn't.

554
00:33:40.349 --> 00:33:44.737
So you'll hear the term balanced hybrid,
you'll hear the term hybrid,

555
00:33:44.737 --> 00:33:49.573
you'll hear the term advanced distance
vector, or enhanced distance vector.

556
00:33:49.573 --> 00:33:52.950
There's so many terms with this,
but the base of what it does,

557
00:33:52.950 --> 00:33:54.910
it is a distance vector protocol.

558
00:33:54.910 --> 00:33:58.740
It's just modified or enhanced, or
considered advanced at that point.

559
00:33:58.740 --> 00:34:01.743
So you'll either see Cisco
at some time saying,

560
00:34:01.743 --> 00:34:06.881
it's a completely different beast onto its
own and it separates out the category.

561
00:34:06.881 --> 00:34:09.318
And then at times you'll actually read and

562
00:34:09.318 --> 00:34:14.134
you'll say at it's heart it's a distance
vector protocol, and it puts it back in.

563
00:34:14.134 --> 00:34:17.733
I cannot tell you when you'll
actually see that on the exam,

564
00:34:17.733 --> 00:34:21.134
but kind of know something this,
right, just as a hint.

565
00:34:21.134 --> 00:34:24.927
If they ask you which of the following
is an advanced distance vector protocol,

566
00:34:24.927 --> 00:34:26.581
there's only one which is EIGRP.

567
00:34:26.581 --> 00:34:32.701
And they list, which of the following
are distance vector protocols, right?

568
00:34:32.701 --> 00:34:36.963
And they give you that choice that EIGRP
is in there, I would also choose that.

569
00:34:36.963 --> 00:34:40.030
If they don't separate that
one out as well, okay?

570
00:34:40.030 --> 00:34:42.752
So just realize that there's
no easy way around this.

571
00:34:42.752 --> 00:34:46.692
I wish I could tell you, yeah, this is
easy, this absolutely totally different.

572
00:34:46.692 --> 00:34:49.504
But I've just seen it written over
the years so many different ways,

573
00:34:49.504 --> 00:34:52.430
there's no way to account for
the way that Cisco's gonna get you this.

574
00:34:52.430 --> 00:34:57.240
But as far as what I can tell you, is
that it is an interior gateway protocol.

575
00:34:57.240 --> 00:35:01.350
It is at its heart,
a distance vector protocol as well, so

576
00:35:01.350 --> 00:35:04.920
make sure that you also
treat it that way too, okay.

577
00:35:04.920 --> 00:35:06.550
So Zach, for us,

578
00:35:06.550 --> 00:35:11.860
that will help us in understanding the
nature of the idea of just the distance

579
00:35:11.860 --> 00:35:16.390
vector protocols in itself when we start
comparing and contrasting them as well.

580
00:35:16.390 --> 00:35:19.825
The big difference between the RIP and
the EIGRP, and

581
00:35:19.825 --> 00:35:23.803
we'll summarize this also as we
get to the next episode here.

582
00:35:23.803 --> 00:35:27.829
Is that one's metric is hop count,
and the other one's metric though,

583
00:35:27.829 --> 00:35:29.946
is actually based on something else.

584
00:35:29.946 --> 00:35:34.065
And I do have a table somewhere if
I can find it, yeah at some point,

585
00:35:34.065 --> 00:35:35.284
there we go, okay.

586
00:35:35.284 --> 00:35:38.839
So let's just take a look at
this one table as we begin, and

587
00:35:38.839 --> 00:35:42.195
we'll focus in on just
information like this, okay.

588
00:35:42.195 --> 00:35:43.760
So here's a couple of different things,
right.

589
00:35:43.760 --> 00:35:47.200
When you start to take a look in
distance vector protocols, okay.

590
00:35:47.200 --> 00:35:51.740
So now I've actually shown you where
you'll see it even in stuff like this.

591
00:35:51.740 --> 00:35:55.405
Advanced distance vector,
it is in its heart distance vector, but

592
00:35:55.405 --> 00:35:57.601
the algorithms are different, right?

593
00:35:57.601 --> 00:36:00.331
One is technically
a Bellman-Ford algorithm, okay,

594
00:36:00.331 --> 00:36:02.137
it's hop count is what it is, okay?

595
00:36:02.137 --> 00:36:05.555
And the other one is what they
call Diffusing Update Algorithm,

596
00:36:05.555 --> 00:36:08.290
usually the l is written
in the lowercase l, okay?

597
00:36:08.290 --> 00:36:11.220
That's kinda how they normally do that.

598
00:36:11.220 --> 00:36:14.730
Also, the metric itself like we said
is hop count, advanced distance vector,

599
00:36:14.730 --> 00:36:17.520
a little bit more sophisticated here.

600
00:36:17.520 --> 00:36:22.618
Where it actually is complex, it adds
in what we call bandwidth and delay.

601
00:36:22.618 --> 00:36:26.068
And you might be wondering,
well how the heck complex is that?

602
00:36:26.068 --> 00:36:28.307
Well, delay is counted
in tens of microseconds.

603
00:36:28.307 --> 00:36:29.263
I don't even know what that means, okay?

604
00:36:29.263 --> 00:36:32.356
>> [LAUGH]
>> But you tell me, yeah.

605
00:36:32.356 --> 00:36:35.928
Why is it counted in tens of, I don't know
why it's counted in tens of microseconds.

606
00:36:35.928 --> 00:36:38.299
But that's the way it's counted,
not milliseconds, but

607
00:36:38.299 --> 00:36:39.590
tens of microseconds instead.

608
00:36:39.590 --> 00:36:40.157
>> Sounds good.

609
00:36:40.157 --> 00:36:44.571
>> And of course,
examples of these protocols RIP, RIPv1,

610
00:36:44.571 --> 00:36:46.522
RIPv2, and then EIGRP.

611
00:36:46.522 --> 00:36:52.140
But if you only see one category and
then they show you EIGRP in here.

612
00:36:52.140 --> 00:36:54.083
And they talk about the idea
of distance vector and

613
00:36:54.083 --> 00:36:55.801
they're showing you only two categories.

614
00:36:55.801 --> 00:36:59.861
I would make sure that EIGRP is also
listed under there too, okay, so

615
00:36:59.861 --> 00:37:01.694
just realize it is different.

616
00:37:01.694 --> 00:37:05.614
The diagram below is just showing you
the differences here that if you were to

617
00:37:05.614 --> 00:37:08.860
make a choice between them and
their metric itself.

618
00:37:08.860 --> 00:37:10.690
Remember that in distance
vector protocols,

619
00:37:10.690 --> 00:37:13.580
it would just look at hop count,
wherever the destination.

620
00:37:13.580 --> 00:37:17.510
So from router 2 going through
a network to router 1, okay?

621
00:37:17.510 --> 00:37:20.990
Over that 256K link,
well distance vector or

622
00:37:20.990 --> 00:37:25.050
RIP would say that's a clear path to go,
router 2 to router 1.

623
00:37:25.050 --> 00:37:29.992
Even though it's much slower then actually
taking the route between router 2,

624
00:37:29.992 --> 00:37:34.365
router 3, and then to router 1,
which actually is much faster path.

625
00:37:34.365 --> 00:37:37.049
Distance vector though would consider,

626
00:37:37.049 --> 00:37:40.661
what is the faster path in
terms of bandwidth and delay?

627
00:37:40.661 --> 00:37:44.090
And would make a better calculation,
is what we would end up seeing.

628
00:37:44.090 --> 00:37:46.430
So that's why we tend to choose, and

629
00:37:46.430 --> 00:37:50.824
that's why we'll focus in on both EIGRP,
and OSPF, as we go along.

630
00:37:50.824 --> 00:37:52.413
But Zach that is gonna be the end of for

00:37:52.413 --> 00:37:54.683
what we're talking about
here in distance vector.

But we still need to spend just a little
bit of time, a brief bit of time, in

00:37:58.499 --> 00:38:02.770
talking about the other type of interior
gateway protocol which is link-state.

But we'll do that in a final episode

00:38:06.330 --> 00:38:07.507
>> Very well done Mike.

Compare and Contrast IGPs Part Two,
make sure you see part one and

Not only here but

In CCENT I probably go abut the same

But it's again another

00:38:34.282 --> 00:38:38.445
but review is foundational here because

RIP's probably been the one that's

at that point but they realized something,

00:28:56.526 --> 00:28:57.960
That may be complex.

506
00:28:57.960 --> 00:29:02.820
But when you get into EIGRP and you're
now adding in the idea of bandwidth and

507
00:29:02.820 --> 00:29:03.840
delay.
>> Mm-hm.

508
00:29:03.840 --> 00:29:05.170
>> In tens of microseconds,

509
00:29:05.170 --> 00:29:08.036
once again,
>> That's much more complex.

510
00:29:08.036 --> 00:29:10.783
And then when you do OSPF,
it's based on bandwidth but

511
00:29:10.783 --> 00:29:13.292
you have to actually take
the actual bandwidth and

512
00:29:13.292 --> 00:29:16.892
divide it by the reference bandwidth
to come up with that for each link.

513
00:29:16.892 --> 00:29:20.360
Well now you actually start seeing
where you can start to rate

514
00:29:20.360 --> 00:29:23.580
how this comes along.
>> So that's what they've done is that

515
00:29:23.580 --> 00:29:26.900
they've gone ahead and
done something like that as well, right?

516
00:29:26.900 --> 00:29:31.980
So it is about trying to also understand
that this is a part of what we see.

517
00:29:31.980 --> 00:29:36.810
And the routing table, which we did
point out in our Cisco c set, right?

518
00:29:36.810 --> 00:29:41.000
We did see this inside of the square
brackets in the routing table itself

519
00:29:41.000 --> 00:29:42.560
as actually being able to turn that.

520
00:29:42.560 --> 00:29:45.270
One number was, of course, for
the administrative distance.

521
00:29:45.270 --> 00:29:46.298
And the other one was for

522
00:29:46.298 --> 00:29:48.833
the metric itself that we'll
actually end up seeing too.

523
00:29:48.833 --> 00:29:52.269
We'll be looking at those in a much
closer and much more in depth.

524
00:29:52.269 --> 00:29:55.064
Or we'll be looking at both
of those much closer and

525
00:29:55.064 --> 00:29:59.050
more in depth as we get into each
one of those protocols as well.

526
00:29:59.050 --> 00:30:01.070
But at this point,
when we start seeing it,

527
00:30:01.070 --> 00:30:05.480
administrative distance essentially is the
tie breaker when it comes down to that.

528
00:30:05.480 --> 00:30:06.770
Do I need to memorize these?

529
00:30:06.770 --> 00:30:08.191
Yes, okay?

530
00:30:08.191 --> 00:30:13.132
You don't have to worry about the ones
where I put the parentheses beside

531
00:30:13.132 --> 00:30:14.610
them so much.

532
00:30:14.610 --> 00:30:18.467
But you do need to make sure that you at
least take a look at the ones that you

533
00:30:18.467 --> 00:30:19.867
know about at this point.

534
00:30:19.867 --> 00:30:25.039
OSPF, RIP, EIGRP, make sure you know those
numbers as well as the connected and

535
00:30:25.039 --> 00:30:26.970
the static ones as well.

536
00:30:26.970 --> 00:30:27.470
That will help you.

537
00:30:28.500 --> 00:30:29.760
Now, excuse me,

538
00:30:29.760 --> 00:30:32.670
the last one that I wanna talk about
is actually the one that says unusable.

539
00:30:32.670 --> 00:30:36.940
If I spelled that correctly, which I
might not, nope, I sure as heck didn't.

540
00:30:36.940 --> 00:30:39.930
See, I was like, look, as far as,
I started looking at it, I was like,

541
00:30:39.930 --> 00:30:41.620
that is not right either.

542
00:30:41.620 --> 00:30:46.650
So my ability to spell
unusable was insane.

543
00:30:46.650 --> 00:30:50.030
I don't know how many u's I put in there,
but it was more than I needed, okay.

544
00:30:50.030 --> 00:30:55.290
Unusable, when you see
a administrative distance of 255,

545
00:30:55.290 --> 00:30:59.270
it means it's not gonna ever
get into the routing table.

546
00:30:59.270 --> 00:31:00.960
Okay?
So that's what's gonna end up happening.

547
00:31:00.960 --> 00:31:03.014
It's never gonna get into
the routing table at that

548
00:31:03.014 --> 00:31:03.757
point.
>> Mm-hm.

549
00:31:03.757 --> 00:31:05.269
>> The strange thing is, right,

550
00:31:05.269 --> 00:31:07.140
you should never actually need that.

551
00:31:07.140 --> 00:31:10.040
But if you happen to run across this,

552
00:31:10.040 --> 00:31:12.395
it's probably not gonna ever
be in the routing table.

553
00:31:12.395 --> 00:31:14.860
But normally the reason
why you want to do this

554
00:31:14.860 --> 00:31:19.170
is because a route keeps
appearing in your routing table.

555
00:31:19.170 --> 00:31:20.260
For reason or another.

556
00:31:20.260 --> 00:31:22.000
RIP, OSPF, you can't explain.

557
00:31:22.000 --> 00:31:24.920
You looked at every possible way and
you're trying figure out why.

558
00:31:24.920 --> 00:31:28.190
But the route keeps appearing there,
and you don't want it to be there.

559
00:31:28.190 --> 00:31:31.200
Well, we can change the administrative
distance and go look.

560
00:31:31.200 --> 00:31:33.760
I do not wanna use that route.

561
00:31:33.760 --> 00:31:37.350
And that way you can set that
up to 255 and it will never

562
00:31:37.350 --> 00:31:39.378
ever get in to your routing table.
>> Ooh, I see.

563
00:31:39.378 --> 00:31:40.325
>> But for us though, okay,

564
00:31:40.325 --> 00:31:42.410
we probably won't have
to worry about that.

565
00:31:42.410 --> 00:31:46.010
But if you do happen to see that and
go I never wanted to use that.

566
00:31:46.010 --> 00:31:47.900
And you go ahead and
you just put it here and

567
00:31:47.900 --> 00:31:53.260
you reset the administrative distance
which we did do in our CCENT show.

568
00:31:54.510 --> 00:31:58.360
Check and verify that you at least have
another path that you want it to use.

569
00:31:58.360 --> 00:32:00.860
If it now disappears and
you can't get into that network, well,

570
00:32:00.860 --> 00:32:04.210
that may be a reason why it's actually
appearing, cuz you actually need it.

571
00:32:04.210 --> 00:32:08.710
But overall though, normally that last one
is only because I need to configure it.

572
00:32:08.710 --> 00:32:12.380
So I don't want that route to ever
appear inside my routing table.

573
00:32:12.380 --> 00:32:12.980
Okay?

574
00:32:12.980 --> 00:32:18.436
So Zach, that will at least help us out
as we begin to be able to contrast and

575
00:32:18.436 --> 00:32:22.405
compare these different
IGP's that we have, okay?

576
00:32:22.405 --> 00:32:24.402
Like I said, it's kind of weird, right?

577
00:32:24.402 --> 00:32:26.650
Have to keep a balance of,
am I telling too much?

578
00:32:26.650 --> 00:32:28.440
Or I'm not telling enough here.

579
00:32:28.440 --> 00:32:28.990
But at this point,

580
00:32:28.990 --> 00:32:33.740
that should give us a good overview
of these contrast and comparisons.

581
00:32:33.740 --> 00:32:36.150
That we need to talk about.
>> And you did it very well, Ronnie.

582
00:32:36.150 --> 00:32:37.230
Thank you very much.

583
00:32:37.230 --> 00:32:40.250
Compare and contrast IGPs, Part Three.

584
00:32:40.250 --> 00:32:42.540
Make sure you see Part One and
Part Two, as well.

585
00:32:42.540 --> 00:32:44.330
And Ronnie,
you have that look in your eye again.

586
00:32:44.330 --> 00:32:47.696
You want to say something else, don't you?
>> Well, just remember, right, this again,

587
00:32:47.696 --> 00:32:49.616
review material, but at the same time,

588
00:32:49.616 --> 00:32:52.215
very important that you get
this terminology down That

589
00:32:52.215 --> 00:32:56.140
you feel comfortable with the concepts
that we've been talking about.

590
00:32:56.140 --> 00:32:59.030
Once we start diving in to
the routing protocols itself,

591
00:32:59.030 --> 00:33:03.410
you'll see we actually do depend
on this base knowledge heavily.

592
00:33:03.410 --> 00:33:05.000
So don't let it out of your sight.

593
00:33:05.000 --> 00:33:06.112
Don't just forget about it.

594
00:33:06.112 --> 00:33:08.390
It's gonna be very heavily
tested on the exam.

595
00:33:08.390 --> 00:33:10.659
So make sure you understand it.
>> Thank you again, Ronnie.

596
00:33:10.659 --> 00:33:17.550
And make sure you dive into the CCNA
routing and switching exam 200-105 series.

597
00:33:17.550 --> 00:33:19.290
Every single episode is gold.

598
00:33:19.290 --> 00:33:20.730
Make sure you take a look at them all.

599
00:33:20.730 --> 00:33:22.107
And you'll be in the course library.

600

There's thousands of other videos here,
and they're here for

601
00:33:25.114 --> 00:33:28.370
one reason to help you go further,

And tell everybody you know about
ITPRO.TV, ITPRO.TV is binge worthy.

Thanks for watching I'm Zach Memos.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the basic OSPF operations.  The guys talke a look at the purpose of the neighbor adjacency and how they become neighbors step by step.
episodes.title: Configure Single Area OSPFv2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:02.563
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.563 --> 00:00:09.212
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

3
00:00:09.212 --> 00:00:13.158
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

4
00:00:13.158 --> 00:00:16.670
helping you learn everywhere you go.

5
00:00:16.670 --> 00:00:19.382
I'm your host Zach Memos for
another episode of CCNA routing and

6
00:00:19.382 --> 00:00:20.846
switching exam 200-105.

7
00:00:20.846 --> 00:00:27.740
This episode we're gonna configure
single area OSPF version two.

8
00:00:27.740 --> 00:00:29.130
What's that all about?

9
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:30.800
Well we're gonna ask this guy over here.

10
00:00:30.800 --> 00:00:32.510
Ronnie Wong, good to see you.

11
00:00:32.510 --> 00:00:33.408
Thanks for joining us.

12
00:00:33.408 --> 00:00:37.260
>> Thank you Zach for joining me as we
continue on in our CCNA routing and

13
00:00:37.260 --> 00:00:38.160
switching show.

14
00:00:38.160 --> 00:00:43.660
We are now into,
well the idea of deep-diving into OSPF.

15
00:00:43.660 --> 00:00:46.980
Now remember that we've already
talked about the different dynamic

16
00:00:46.980 --> 00:00:49.720
routing protocols, and
especially in the CCNA.

17
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:55.050
We're staying away, really,
from the exterior gateway protocols,

18
00:00:55.050 --> 00:00:58.980
and we're really going back in to
the interior gateway protocols.

19
00:00:58.980 --> 00:01:03.030
And we're gonna begin with OSPF and
we need to have a little bit of

20
00:01:03.030 --> 00:01:07.533
background information on the working
of how OSPF ends up working out.

21
00:01:07.533 --> 00:01:11.166
And then of course as we move through
we'll start talking more about some of

22
00:01:11.166 --> 00:01:15.146
the details and do probably two or three
episodes on this because of the complexity

23
00:01:15.146 --> 00:01:17.190
that we're actually diving into.

24
00:01:17.190 --> 00:01:19.140
So just hang on a little bit.

25
00:01:19.140 --> 00:01:22.990
We do have to know about some information
as we continue to move forward here.

26
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:25.180
So when we first start off here,

27
00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:30.080
let's talk about the idea of just
the word OSPF before we get through this.

28
00:01:30.080 --> 00:01:33.740
OSPF is an interior gateway
routing protocol and

29
00:01:33.740 --> 00:01:38.810
not only that when we divided that out
it's also a link state protocol as well.

30
00:01:38.810 --> 00:01:43.650
So it is a subset of an interior
gateway protocol and it is by far

31
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:49.160
the most popular interior gateway protocol
that's being used in most networks today.

32
00:01:49.160 --> 00:01:53.110
The reason behind that, one is that
it's actually open standard, and

33
00:01:53.110 --> 00:01:57.750
that means we can run more than just
one vendor's equipment, such as Cisco.

34
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:01.090
If you actually start mixing and
matching equipment.

35
00:02:01.090 --> 00:02:05.290
OSPF actually does help us to do
that because it's open standard.

36
00:02:05.290 --> 00:02:08.500
It's not just proprietary to Cisco itself.

37
00:02:08.500 --> 00:02:13.130
The other thing behind it is that
if you have a well developed IP

38
00:02:13.130 --> 00:02:16.830
scheme that you're working
with OSPF works magnificently.

39
00:02:16.830 --> 00:02:20.580
It actually is a great way of
actually doing a lot of routing and

40
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:23.860
is completely scalable in
terms of some of the different

41
00:02:23.860 --> 00:02:27.570
things that we want a networking
protocol to be able to do.

42
00:02:27.570 --> 00:02:29.080
Before we get to that point,

43
00:02:29.080 --> 00:02:34.080
right, we wanna talk about the idea
of how OSPF begins to work.

44
00:02:34.080 --> 00:02:37.950
So let me just describe a little bit of
the basic functions before we continue to

45
00:02:37.950 --> 00:02:39.220
get into this, okay?

46
00:02:39.220 --> 00:02:40.090
So let's go ahead and

47
00:02:40.090 --> 00:02:44.220
take a look at my diagram, and hopefully
this will help us out when we begin, okay?

48
00:02:44.220 --> 00:02:48.850
So as we start off here, let's just
kinda make sure that we understand this

49
00:02:48.850 --> 00:02:51.170
process just right at the beginning.

50
00:02:51.170 --> 00:02:56.380
So, if I’m running OSPF, one of
the first things that OSPF has to do,

51
00:02:56.380 --> 00:02:59.870
is that it has to form what it
calls a neighbor relationship.

52
00:02:59.870 --> 00:03:02.270
Or an adjacency, technically,

53
00:03:02.270 --> 00:03:07.850
with another router within its
own administrative area, okay?

54
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:12.310
So, the way that it does that is by
sending out what they call, hello’s.

55
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:14.070
So here,
you actually see on the left-hand side,

56
00:03:14.070 --> 00:03:16.010
I have all these routers
here running OSPF.

57
00:03:16.010 --> 00:03:21.050
But if OSPF is sending out
hellos out of its interfaces,

58
00:03:21.050 --> 00:03:24.440
just like what I show you right here,
hello, will you be my neighbor?

59
00:03:24.440 --> 00:03:27.080
Again, I kind of stole that from Mr.
Rogers here.

60
00:03:27.080 --> 00:03:28.760
>> Won't you be my neighbor?

61
00:03:28.760 --> 00:03:32.784
>> If you actually do have some of that,
if the other end though is running RIP,

62
00:03:32.784 --> 00:03:34.800
t's probably not gonna respond,

63
00:03:34.800 --> 00:03:38.990
that's because you're essentially speaking
two different routing protocol languages.

64
00:03:38.990 --> 00:03:40.060
One guy is saying something and

65
00:03:40.060 --> 00:03:43.090
the other guy is just ignoring it cuz I
don't know what you're actually saying.

66
00:03:43.090 --> 00:03:43.960
So that's not gonna work.

67
00:03:43.960 --> 00:03:49.670
And the same thing would happen if
the other side is also running EIGRP,

68
00:03:49.670 --> 00:03:51.750
you are not going to actually go ahead and

69
00:03:51.750 --> 00:03:57.750
be able to start running OSPF if
the other side is also EIGRP, as well.

70
00:03:57.750 --> 00:04:02.310
Okay, so, it is trying to find
a neighbor is what it's trying to do.

71
00:04:02.310 --> 00:04:05.460
Now, does it automatically
become a neighbor

72
00:04:05.460 --> 00:04:09.530
if the other side between
these two routers is OSPF?

73
00:04:09.530 --> 00:04:14.775
Well, it can be but
it doesn't necessarily have to be.

74
00:04:14.775 --> 00:04:17.780
So here I have the response, well maybe.

75
00:04:17.780 --> 00:04:19.230
But that's only if we agree.

76
00:04:19.230 --> 00:04:22.000
So, in other words,
the neighbor ship does work almost like

77
00:04:22.000 --> 00:04:24.769
what a real neighbor would do,
Zack, in this way.

78
00:04:25.840 --> 00:04:29.050
New neighbor moves into your neighborhood.

79
00:04:29.050 --> 00:04:31.530
Less say he moves into the house
right next to you, Zach.

80
00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:34.030
And go over and you talk to him.

81
00:04:34.030 --> 00:04:38.820
And you might go all right, here's some
of the things that we share in common.

82
00:04:38.820 --> 00:04:41.300
And if there's enough of them,
you might actually go hey,

83
00:04:41.300 --> 00:04:43.140
he's gonna be a good neighbor.

84
00:04:43.140 --> 00:04:45.020
>> But let's say on the other side,

85
00:04:45.020 --> 00:04:47.630
hopefully I'm not really picking
on somebody that [INAUDIBLE].

86
00:04:47.630 --> 00:04:50.520
Let's say on the other side
though you run into the guy and

87
00:04:50.520 --> 00:04:51.820
you speak the same language.

88
00:04:51.820 --> 00:04:53.450
He's just moved in but

89
00:04:53.450 --> 00:04:58.010
you find out you don't have a lot of
things in common and you might go,

90
00:04:58.010 --> 00:05:01.220
okay he lives in the neighborhood but
I won't know if he's a neighbor.

91
00:05:01.220 --> 00:05:03.830
I wouldn't exchange a lot
of information with him.

92
00:05:03.830 --> 00:05:07.420
He's there and we'll be civil but
we're probably not gonna talk that often.

93
00:05:07.420 --> 00:05:09.420
We're probably not gonna talk at all,
okay?

94
00:05:09.420 --> 00:05:13.760
So it happens in that same way,
OSPF finds the same thing.

95
00:05:13.760 --> 00:05:16.930
Before OSPF will share any information,

96
00:05:16.930 --> 00:05:20.600
especially about routes that it
knows about to somebody else.

97
00:05:20.600 --> 00:05:23.950
It has to form this neighbor
relationship itself.

98
00:05:23.950 --> 00:05:26.900
So routers themselves
have to become neighbors

99
00:05:26.900 --> 00:05:30.000
before OSPF will actually end
up working very well for us.

100
00:05:30.000 --> 00:05:32.940
>> So Ronnie, what is the purpose of
the OSPF neighbor relationships and

101
00:05:32.940 --> 00:05:34.360
what's the actual reason
why we're doing this?

102
00:05:34.360 --> 00:05:38.000
>> Right, and that's actually a good
question because it doesn't make sense.

103
00:05:38.000 --> 00:05:41.440
Why do they have to become
a neighbor if we're gonna do this.

104
00:05:41.440 --> 00:05:45.010
Well, one other reasons that we actually
wanna make sure that we talk about,

105
00:05:45.010 --> 00:05:50.510
is that the way that OSPF actually
has to be able to do things, right.

106
00:05:50.510 --> 00:05:54.380
Is that, it has to be able
because of the link state

107
00:05:54.380 --> 00:05:57.600
protocols itself the way that
link state protocols are defined.

108
00:05:57.600 --> 00:06:00.340
They have to individually identify

109
00:06:00.340 --> 00:06:04.110
where each of the pieces of
the information is coming from.

110
00:06:04.110 --> 00:06:07.290
So the first thing that they have to do
to become a neighbor is that they have to

111
00:06:07.290 --> 00:06:10.710
identify themselves in this process and

112
00:06:10.710 --> 00:06:14.950
this is done by checking some certain
settings as we send out the hello.

113
00:06:14.950 --> 00:06:19.390
And being they'll say, I'm different
from you, but I'm actually gonna try and

114
00:06:19.390 --> 00:06:21.870
be your neighbor at the same time, okay?

115
00:06:21.870 --> 00:06:23.600
The other information behind this,

116
00:06:23.600 --> 00:06:26.340
as a good neighbor,
is the information that we end up sharing.

117
00:06:26.340 --> 00:06:28.950
Technically we call them keepalives,
right?

118
00:06:28.950 --> 00:06:33.860
And that is, if I don't hear from this
potential neighbor after a while,

119
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:36.270
I might just drop that
neighbor relationship.

120
00:06:36.270 --> 00:06:39.650
So it is the idea of keeping that
relationship up and running and

121
00:06:39.650 --> 00:06:41.210
doing what we need to.

122
00:06:41.210 --> 00:06:44.130
So what happens if
the relationship goes down as

123
00:06:44.130 --> 00:06:46.660
far as the neighbor relationship here,
okay?

124
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:50.850
If it actually does go down once
the neighbor relationship is there, okay,

00:07:31.940 --> 00:07:35.050

The reason why this is important, because

Now, the reason behind that,

00:18:27.980 --> 00:18:32.510
Well will then happen at that particular

345
00:20:42.210 --> 00:20:44.660
it is just gonna send
the header information.

346
00:20:44.660 --> 00:20:48.880
And those are technically inside of
what we call the idea of the DBD here,

347
00:20:48.880 --> 00:20:51.800
which is a database descriptor packet.

348
00:20:51.800 --> 00:20:55.820
Once they begin to exchange that
information, well they again

349
00:20:55.820 --> 00:21:00.056
can compare and see what they're actually
have ready to go and that is fine.

350
00:21:00.056 --> 00:21:02.510
And the other part of this process here

351
00:21:02.510 --> 00:21:05.860
is in the EXSTART is that they
are starting to just exchange that.

352
00:21:05.860 --> 00:21:07.990
It's like the beginning
of the exchange for

353
00:21:07.990 --> 00:21:09.930
the final topology that
we're going to see.

354
00:21:11.170 --> 00:21:17.140
During this point I also put in this
terminology here, Master and Slave.

355
00:21:17.140 --> 00:21:21.510
Now what is this about,
in the x start here?

356
00:21:21.510 --> 00:21:26.275
One side is actually going to be
decided on who is really going to start

357
00:21:26.275 --> 00:21:30.974
sending updates, okay, and
who is really gonna receive updates.

358
00:21:30.974 --> 00:21:34.404
So it doesn't mean that both
sides can't get updates back, but

359
00:21:34.404 --> 00:21:38.277
what ends up happening here is that
usually the master is the only one that

360
00:21:38.277 --> 00:21:41.540
sends out updates where as
the slave only receives updates.

361
00:21:41.540 --> 00:21:45.650
Now, what if the slave actually ends
up getting an update back to itself?

362
00:21:45.650 --> 00:21:49.450
Well what it does is, it waits until the
time when the master ends up requesting it

363
00:21:49.450 --> 00:21:51.270
and then that's what ends up happening.

364
00:21:51.270 --> 00:21:54.800
So that's the idea here, is that one side
will have a higher or a, yeah a higher

365
00:21:54.800 --> 00:21:59.090
priority than the other one and that one
will become between those two routers.

366
00:21:59.090 --> 00:22:01.750
One side will always be a master and
one side will always be the slave.

367
00:22:01.750 --> 00:22:04.690
And it's actually down to what
we call a priority number,

368
00:22:04.690 --> 00:22:07.720
which we'll have to get into
a little bit later on okay?

369
00:22:07.720 --> 00:22:11.795
So once all of that begins to happen
right, if everything is in agreement, and

370
00:22:11.795 --> 00:22:15.501
everything is set okay, we now have
of course that designated router if

371
00:22:15.501 --> 00:22:17.692
we actually have everything ready to go.

372
00:22:17.692 --> 00:22:19.625
Then a backup designated router,

373
00:22:19.625 --> 00:22:23.750
then they'll begin to exchange
the actual link state database.

374
00:22:23.750 --> 00:22:28.320
And that is the topology of everything
that the routers can actually learn from

375
00:22:28.320 --> 00:22:32.890
the other routers on the information
that they have, and that will now give

376
00:22:32.890 --> 00:22:37.360
everybody that road analyst that have been
mentioning in the earlier episodes here.

377
00:22:37.360 --> 00:22:40.680
That every router will now
have a consistent topology

378
00:22:40.680 --> 00:22:45.390
of everything that all the other routers
know, so that every single router inside

379
00:22:45.390 --> 00:22:49.520
of OSPF that's operating now
has that consistent database.

380
00:22:49.520 --> 00:22:54.410
That consistent database is important
because of the very fact that

381
00:22:54.410 --> 00:22:59.360
now every router will have the ability as
it needs to build its routing table, that

382
00:22:59.360 --> 00:23:03.550
it's not having to go and learn about new
things all the time, it is saying nope.

383
00:23:03.550 --> 00:23:08.500
I know that my particular topology that
I have has the same as Zack's, okay.

384
00:23:08.500 --> 00:23:12.210
And that way we know that we're
always gonna have that exact same

385
00:23:12.210 --> 00:23:16.550
match throughout the entire routing
domain no matter what it is,

386
00:23:16.550 --> 00:23:20.300
we'll actually be able to based
off the same information, okay.

387
00:23:20.300 --> 00:23:24.390
So when we exchange that database,
we're not completely done yet.

388
00:23:25.630 --> 00:23:30.570
At this particular point it goes into
what we call the loading state, okay?

389
00:23:30.570 --> 00:23:34.900
In that loading state,
once you get to this point here, okay?

390
00:23:34.900 --> 00:23:39.813
You're still exchanging what we call
the database descriptor packets, but

391
00:23:39.813 --> 00:23:41.938
now it's the full LSAs instead.

392
00:23:41.938 --> 00:23:44.801
So you get every bit of
information that's advertised,

393
00:23:44.801 --> 00:23:48.269
not just the headers at this point,
everything that it advertises.

394
00:23:48.269 --> 00:23:52.764
And this is important because
this is when, now everybody else,

395
00:23:52.764 --> 00:23:56.932
when they start doing things,
okay, Well, the master, or

396
00:23:56.932 --> 00:24:00.820
the actual designated router
at our point here, okay?

397
00:24:00.820 --> 00:24:04.230
It will begin to give out
link state advertisements

398
00:24:04.230 --> 00:24:06.330
to everybody else it's
actually a neighbor with.

399
00:24:06.330 --> 00:24:09.621
And then everybody else will
actually end up receiving it, okay,

400
00:24:09.621 --> 00:24:12.104
from that particular
designated router as well.

401
00:24:12.104 --> 00:24:16.640
Okay, so that's kind of the process here.

402
00:24:16.640 --> 00:24:20.700
Lastly, at the very end,
normal operation, okay?

403
00:24:20.700 --> 00:24:24.350
Both routers, at that point,
will now become full neighbors.

404
00:24:24.350 --> 00:24:26.370
So Zach, it took me about, let's say, 10,

405
00:24:26.370 --> 00:24:28.980
15 minutes to describe
that entire process.

406
00:24:28.980 --> 00:24:30.260
>> Yes, it did.
[LAUGH]

407
00:24:30.260 --> 00:24:32.630
>> But the thing is, it takes about,

408
00:24:32.630 --> 00:24:37.600
maybe, half a second, maybe not even
that long, for that to actually do that,

409
00:24:37.600 --> 00:24:41.100
so depending on the topology and
all of that other stuff, right?

410
00:24:41.100 --> 00:24:43.620
So once these things are in
full adjacency, okay,

411
00:24:43.620 --> 00:24:47.130
it will operate normally and very quietly.

412
00:24:47.130 --> 00:24:51.630
The exchange of the information,
though, at the very beginning, okay,

413
00:24:51.630 --> 00:24:54.910
every time it has to do that periodic
update, about every 30 minutes,

414
00:24:54.910 --> 00:24:59.250
to get the right topology down,
that's a lot of information.

415
00:24:59.250 --> 00:25:01.960
It is processor-intensive at that point.

416
00:25:01.960 --> 00:25:06.444
But even though it's processor-intensive,
it's happening only every 30 minutes,

417
00:25:06.444 --> 00:25:09.099
whereas if we take the idea
of distance vector or RIP,

418
00:25:09.099 --> 00:25:11.670
it happens every 30 seconds, instead.

419
00:25:11.670 --> 00:25:14.280
So now we're slowing down that, so

420
00:25:14.280 --> 00:25:19.674
even though the processor intensity,
I'm not gonna be able to say that,

421
00:25:19.674 --> 00:25:24.298
intensity is higher for a time,
it happens less often as well.

422
00:25:24.298 --> 00:25:28.723
Okay, the full operation is how
we know that OSPF is working

423
00:25:28.723 --> 00:25:31.050
exactly like it means.

424
00:25:31.050 --> 00:25:34.610
Now, Zach, even though we're not gonna
get into it too much, even in our lab and

425
00:25:34.610 --> 00:25:36.040
our settings that we're doing.

426
00:25:36.040 --> 00:25:41.950
But you can see where anywhere along that
process, when something is not right, any

427
00:25:41.950 --> 00:25:46.485
step along the way can indicate a failure,
cuz there's so many pieces in that.

428
00:25:46.485 --> 00:25:47.030
>> Mm-hm.

429
00:25:47.030 --> 00:25:50.300
>> So if something ends up getting
stuck in a particular state,

430
00:25:50.300 --> 00:25:52.660
it means something didn't occur, okay?

431
00:25:52.660 --> 00:25:56.220
If something stays in the state,
it could be meaning that something

432
00:25:56.220 --> 00:26:00.190
didn't match up the way that it needed to,
or information's not getting through.

433
00:26:00.190 --> 00:26:03.664
So there's a lot of different things
that end up really taking that

434
00:26:03.664 --> 00:26:07.199
particular process all the way down
to the point where it's a little

435
00:26:07.199 --> 00:26:09.510
bit more impossible for
things to get done.

436
00:26:09.510 --> 00:26:14.370
Okay, so that is kind of a key
when we start to see this.

437
00:26:14.370 --> 00:26:16.950
But that neighbor relationship is, by far,

438
00:26:16.950 --> 00:26:21.750
one of the most important aspects of what
we've been talking about this entire

439
00:26:21.750 --> 00:26:25.260
episode so far, because without it,
it doesn't matter.

440
00:26:25.260 --> 00:26:27.908
You can actually bring up
every single router in OSPF.

441
00:26:27.908 --> 00:26:31.594
If they don't work, and you don't know
what the process is or what's some of

442
00:26:31.594 --> 00:26:34.670
the information you're gonna see in it,
it's not gonna really help.

443
00:26:34.670 --> 00:26:38.075
So now we've shown you the the neighbor
states and how they become neighbors.

444
00:26:38.075 --> 00:26:40.225
We still need to talk about
a little bit more, but Zach,

445
00:26:40.225 --> 00:26:41.135
I'm looking over at the clock.

446
00:26:41.135 --> 00:26:43.515
Even though there's just
a few minutes more here,

447
00:26:43.515 --> 00:26:47.520
we just need to at least wrap our
heads around those different states.

448
00:26:47.520 --> 00:26:50.501
>> Mm-hm.
>> Do I have to memorize the states?

449
00:26:50.501 --> 00:26:54.910
I would, okay, you may not get it
where it's the entire process.

450
00:26:54.910 --> 00:26:58.890
But you will get the idea here,
where they ask, hey,

451
00:26:58.890 --> 00:27:07.080
at which state does the beginning of the
link state database, XJR, is ready to go?

452
00:27:07.080 --> 00:27:11.410
Or which state indicates that they're
ready to exchange information?

453
00:27:11.410 --> 00:27:14.813
Well, all this gets kind of jumbled,
and I go, it's gotta be x star,

454
00:27:14.813 --> 00:27:15.752
that makes sense.

455
00:27:15.752 --> 00:27:19.028
Well, it's actually the stage before,
the two-way, okay?

456
00:27:19.028 --> 00:27:23.220
So one, seeing that some routers will
end up staying in firm states, and

457
00:27:23.220 --> 00:27:27.210
some routers will not, that at this
point here, make sure you have a good

458
00:27:27.210 --> 00:27:30.820
understanding of those seven particular
neighbor states that we have.

459
00:27:30.820 --> 00:27:34.820
And so that should take you through
everything that we've talked about here,

460
00:27:34.820 --> 00:27:38.410
from the hello process all the way
to the fact that we have now formed

461
00:27:38.410 --> 00:27:39.925
the neighborships that we need to.

462
00:27:39.925 --> 00:27:44.440
Okay, so once we do that, okay,
then we can start configuring it,

463
00:27:44.440 --> 00:27:47.120
and we'll see
the configurations fairly easy.

464
00:27:47.120 --> 00:27:51.070
And the great thing is, even though I took
you through all that, right, you and I,

465
00:27:51.070 --> 00:27:53.910
once we turn on the routing
process itself,

466
00:27:53.910 --> 00:27:57.150
we don't have to make every single
one of those things come true.

467
00:27:57.150 --> 00:28:01.720
We just have to actually verify that it's
actually working the way that we need to.

468
00:28:01.720 --> 00:28:05.278
So if you get to the full state,
okay, you know it's done.

469
00:28:05.278 --> 00:28:09.260
But if, for some reason or another,
it's not working and it's not doing that,

00:28:09.260 --> 00:28:12.950
make sure you understand these processes,
and understand where they stopped here.

471
00:28:12.950 --> 00:28:14.732
And we've described the whole thing.

472
00:28:14.732 --> 00:28:18.420
So Zach, when we get back, we're gonna
have to do a part two here, of course.

473
00:28:18.420 --> 00:28:23.370
When we get back at
the end of this episode,

474
00:28:23.370 --> 00:28:27.260
and we move on to the next, we'll be doing
a lab to show you how this also works out.

475
00:28:27.260 --> 00:28:29.515
We still got a little bit more
that we've gotta talk about,

00:28:29.515 --> 00:28:32.930
cuz there's some stuff that you'll just

00:28:32.930 --> 00:28:34.940
We'll talk more about this idea,
the designated router,

00:28:34.940 --> 00:28:39.070
and the backup designated router as well,

00:28:39.070 --> 00:28:41.014
overwhelm you, but
we did show you a lot here.

480
00:28:41.014 --> 00:28:44.690
>> Well done, Ronnie,
Configure Single Area OSPF version 2.

Part two coming your way.

This has been part one, and before we move

00:28:49.670 --> 00:28:50.880
I know you wanna say something else.

You can, it's just gonna take

So once again, my admonition to you and

my suggestion to you, right, is that

even though we covered it all within

00:29:11.150 --> 00:29:14.370
okay, don't try and

490
00:29:14.370 --> 00:29:18.697
Okay, take the first two steps in that
neighbor state, and learn about it, and

00:29:18.697 --> 00:29:19.610
understand it.

492
00:29:19.610 --> 00:29:21.523
Okay, I tried to break it up a little bit,

493
00:29:21.523 --> 00:29:25.420
where I showed you the first three
are pretty much combined together, okay?

494
00:29:25.420 --> 00:29:28.910
And then the last three are really
pretty much combined together.

495
00:29:28.910 --> 00:29:32.330
And finally, the end here is by itself,
which, again,

496
00:29:32.330 --> 00:29:35.040
means everything is actually
the way that it needs to be.

00:29:35.040 --> 00:29:36.790
So if you can break it down like that and

00:29:36.790 --> 00:29:40.340
learn about that,
that will help you out in your studies.

00:29:40.340 --> 00:29:46.300
So yes, it is a full seven-step process
unto itself, but at the same time,

00:29:46.300 --> 00:29:50.310
break it down so that you can digest

501
00:29:50.310 --> 00:29:54.902
Do not speed through this and

00:29:54.902 --> 00:29:58.340
You wanna make sure that you have
a good understanding of this process.

00:29:58.340 --> 00:30:00.160
Because without that understanding,

00:30:00.160 --> 00:30:02.780
troubleshooting becomes
much more difficult, and

00:30:02.780 --> 00:30:05.820
you have to actually be able to know that,
especially for this exam.

>> Well said, Ronnie,
and you'll be doing well

Check those out, too, and

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with the basic operations focusing in on what is in a neighbor hello and the agreement that must occur for the neighbor adjacency.  They describe the DR, BDR and DROTHER and the DR election.  They discuss briefly the idea of ospf "cost" and area.

1

Welcome to ITProTV,
