>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

5
00:00:13.967 --> 00:00:15.815
helping you learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:15.815 --> 00:00:20.519
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with CCNA Routing and

7
00:00:20.519 --> 00:00:23.109
Switching Exam 200-105.

8
00:00:23.109 --> 00:00:29.166
And this is part two of configure
singular area ospf version two, part two.

9
00:00:29.166 --> 00:00:31.461
We did have a part one,
hopefully you saw that too.

10
00:00:31.461 --> 00:00:33.907
And the person bringing us all
the information we need is the one and

11
00:00:33.907 --> 00:00:34.613
only Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:34.613 --> 00:00:35.898
Ronnie, great to have you.

13
00:00:35.898 --> 00:00:39.819
>> Zach, thanks for having me back as
we continue on our CCNA Routing and

14
00:00:39.819 --> 00:00:40.842
Switching Show.

15
00:00:40.842 --> 00:00:43.540
In this part two, we're going to be, well,

16
00:00:43.540 --> 00:00:47.800
trying to fill out the rest of our
information that we need that we talked

17
00:00:47.800 --> 00:00:50.995
about at the very beginning
of the course in part one.

18
00:00:50.995 --> 00:00:55.485
Where we did a little bit of a deep dive
into this idea of what it means to form up

19
00:00:55.485 --> 00:00:57.107
a neighbor relationship.

20
00:00:57.107 --> 00:01:00.280
And it sounds pretty complicated
because if you think about it,

21
00:01:00.280 --> 00:01:03.525
it's not like two humans just
putting them in a room and talking.

22
00:01:03.525 --> 00:01:06.685
All this stuff has to be
configured at some point.

23
00:01:06.685 --> 00:01:09.632
They have to be able to agree, they have
to be able to do a lot of things, and

24
00:01:09.632 --> 00:01:10.643
there's a lot going on.

25
00:01:10.643 --> 00:01:14.627
But I realized in between our little break
here that we had between part one and

26
00:01:14.627 --> 00:01:16.478
part two I was looking at the title.

27
00:01:16.478 --> 00:01:21.213
And I realized that I never actually
explained what OSPF v2 was about.

28
00:01:21.213 --> 00:01:25.574
So just in case if you are still if for
one reason you had gotten this far.

29
00:01:25.574 --> 00:01:26.987
And you started going hey,

30
00:01:26.987 --> 00:01:30.131
he never does actually mention
why it's called version 2.

31
00:01:30.131 --> 00:01:34.203
Because the reason why it actually is
called version 2 is that it is actually

32
00:01:34.203 --> 00:01:36.250
designed for IP version 4 networks.

33
00:01:36.250 --> 00:01:40.376
And I why they chose not
to just do version 1, but

34
00:01:40.376 --> 00:01:45.309
they just look we will start
off with version 2 and IPv6,

35
00:01:45.309 --> 00:01:49.656
OFPI for
IPv6 is actually called OFPI version 3.

36
00:01:49.656 --> 00:01:54.923
So I don't know why, it's just
the way that they chose to do that.

37
00:01:54.923 --> 00:01:57.206
So I guess I better
explain that right now.

38
00:01:57.206 --> 00:02:00.003
It is important we understand that, and

39
00:02:00.003 --> 00:02:05.035
OSPF is kind of one of those protocols
which is very unique in this sense.

40
00:02:05.035 --> 00:02:07.600
The idea here is if we start
to think about and look at,

41
00:02:07.600 --> 00:02:11.248
even though it was actually developed
during the days when there were a lot of

42
00:02:11.248 --> 00:02:13.417
different networking protocols out there.

43
00:02:13.417 --> 00:02:17.140
Well, SPF was specifically designed
to work with IEP networks.

44
00:02:17.140 --> 00:02:20.506
So it doesn't work with any other network
types that are out there in terms of

45
00:02:20.506 --> 00:02:21.568
the routed protocols.

46

00:28:27.000 --> 00:28:29.795
And then the same thing would
also have to happen over here.

488
00:28:29.795 --> 00:28:34.325
Is they would essentially exchange entire
routing tables so that you'd have every

489
00:28:34.325 --> 00:28:38.850
single one, and every single router
along the path would do that.

490
00:28:38.850 --> 00:28:43.190
But notice, Zach, though,
there's actually only one path in and

491
00:28:43.190 --> 00:28:46.740
one path out of each of these two routers,
okay?

492
00:28:46.740 --> 00:28:51.860
So it doesn't make sense to have
to send additional four networks

493
00:28:51.860 --> 00:28:54.150
all the way over to this router over here.

494
00:28:54.150 --> 00:28:56.000
It doesn't make any sense at all.

495
00:28:56.000 --> 00:28:59.140
But that's essentially what
will end up happening, okay?

496
00:28:59.140 --> 00:29:02.970
So that's what we're gonna end up seeing,
is that this is what happens.

497
00:29:02.970 --> 00:29:06.610
In a single-area OSPF, what we're trying
to do, what we're trying to create,

498
00:29:06.610 --> 00:29:07.733
a consistent topology.

499
00:29:07.733 --> 00:29:11.801
And then we'll also end up seeing that
the routing table will also end up being

500
00:29:11.801 --> 00:29:12.560
consistent.

501
00:29:12.560 --> 00:29:14.390
And everybody will actually
have their own way.

502
00:29:14.390 --> 00:29:19.212
But because there's only one path through,
okay, to be able to do this, well,

503
00:29:19.212 --> 00:29:23.105
we'll end up seeing that there's actually
gotta be a better way to make this work,

504
00:29:23.105 --> 00:29:26.420
a more efficient way to
make this work instead.

505
00:29:26.420 --> 00:29:29.030
And that's when we get
into multi-area OSPF.

506
00:29:29.030 --> 00:29:29.920
But at this point,

507
00:29:29.920 --> 00:29:34.080
this is essentially what we're gonna
end up seeing when we get ready, okay?

508
00:29:34.080 --> 00:29:37.337
So Zach, that's actually a good place for
us to stop here, and

509
00:29:37.337 --> 00:29:41.091
then to actually now jump into our
single area of configuration on OSPF.

510
00:29:41.091 --> 00:29:43.242
>> You did an excellent job as usual,
Ronnie.

511
00:29:43.242 --> 00:29:47.415
Configure Single-Area OSPF, Version Two,
Part Three, will be coming your way,

512
00:29:47.415 --> 00:29:49.900
of course, and
make sure you see all three parts.

513
00:29:49.900 --> 00:29:52.524
And before we move on,
Ronnie, anything else?

514
00:29:52.524 --> 00:29:54.660
>> Well, just remember, right?

515
00:29:54.660 --> 00:29:56.640
Take a little bit of time, go back, and

516
00:29:56.640 --> 00:30:01.310
make sure you are swallowing small
bits and pieces as you need to.

517
00:30:01.310 --> 00:30:04.340
Do not try and
swallow the whole thing at one time.

518
00:30:04.340 --> 00:30:06.222
Is it a lot of information, yes, okay?

519
00:30:06.222 --> 00:30:08.310
And do we still have a lot to go,
yes, okay?

520
00:30:09.310 --> 00:30:13.127
So only chew up what you can chew
at any one particular time, and

521
00:30:13.127 --> 00:30:15.680
don't get overwhelmed by it.

522
00:30:15.680 --> 00:30:18.570
Learn it, then move on to the next chunk.

523
00:30:18.570 --> 00:30:20.880
Learn it, move on to the next chunk.

524
00:30:20.880 --> 00:30:24.220
Do not get overwhelmed just
because it's a lot of information.

525
00:30:24.220 --> 00:30:25.510
There is a lot more to come.

526
00:30:25.510 --> 00:30:29.490
So take small bites at
each time as you learn.

527
00:30:29.490 --> 00:30:31.500
>> Great advice, and
here's some more advice for you.

528
00:30:31.500 --> 00:30:34.641
Make sure you watch every single
episode of CCNA Routing and Switching,

529
00:30:34.641 --> 00:30:36.000
Exam Exam 200-105.

530
00:30:36.000 --> 00:30:37.496
You're gonna be so glad you did.

531
00:30:37.496 --> 00:30:38.244
And guess what?

532
00:30:38.244 --> 00:30:39.794
You'll be in the course library.

533
00:30:39.794 --> 00:30:42.306
There's thousands of other
videos that are there, and

534
00:30:42.306 --> 00:30:45.139
they're all just trying to do one thing,
help you go further.

535
00:30:45.139 --> 00:30:46.154
So check them all out.

536
00:30:46.154 --> 00:30:48.131
>> And
tell everybody you know about IT Pro TV,

537
00:30:48.131 --> 00:30:49.788
you know IT Pro TV is binge-worthy.

538
00:30:49.788 --> 00:30:50.804
Thanks for watching.

539
00:30:50.804 --> 00:30:51.606
I'm Zach Nemus.

540
00:30:51.606 --> 00:30:52.622
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

541
00:30:52.622 --> 00:30:54.477
>> We'll see you again very soon.

542
00:30:54.477 --> 00:30:55.440
>> very soon.

543

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie begin with describing the results of a single area ospf routing domain.  They also demonstrate how to configure it between 3 routers.  Using they lab, the guys configure multiple routers to show neighborships, and syslog messages as well the operation the protocol.
episodes.title: Configure Single Area OSPFv2 Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

2

I'm your host, Don Pezet-

3
00:00:08.186 --> 00:00:11.702
[MUSIC]
>> You're watching ITPro TV,

00:00:11.702 --> 00:00:13.094
>> Hello and thank you for

This is part three of
Configure Single Area OSPF Version Two.

9

See how I said that so

And the person bringing us all the

Ronnie Wong.

Ronnie, great to have you back.

>> Well, Zach, thank you, again, for

00:00:37.580 --> 00:00:41.060
joining me as we continue on in
our course, our CCNA routing and

15
00:00:41.060 --> 00:00:42.130
switching journey.

16
00:00:42.130 --> 00:00:44.750
We are now taking a look at configuring

17
00:00:44.750 --> 00:00:50.230
OSPF Version Two here in our
single area environment.

18
00:00:50.230 --> 00:00:53.950
Now, this is going to be where you're
gonna find out something, that of all

19
00:00:53.950 --> 00:00:58.300
the stuff that we've talked about, all
the complexity behind it, you and I really

20

don't have to actually worry about a lot

It really is a light

22

There are the little pieces
that will be complex for us.

23

And that's because it involves us
doing things like wildcard mask.

24
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:17.509
But besides that, the show commands
are really not that difficult for

25
00:01:17.509 --> 00:01:18.798
us to remember and learn.

26
00:01:18.798 --> 00:01:22.273
But we do need to pay attention and
we do need to challenge ourselves

27
00:01:22.273 --> 00:01:26.570
to make sure we go back in and do the lab
as we start to show you as well, okay?

28
00:01:26.570 --> 00:01:30.245
So let me pick back up here just
briefly for a moment where we

29
00:01:30.245 --> 00:01:34.830
remind ourselves of this idea of
configuring a single area OSPF, okay?

30
00:01:34.830 --> 00:01:36.662
So let's take a look at my screen and

31
00:01:36.662 --> 00:01:39.830
that way we'll kind of get reminded again,
okay?

32
00:01:39.830 --> 00:01:41.669
So at the end of the last episode,

33
00:01:41.669 --> 00:01:44.444
I was talking about the idea
of a single area OSPF.

34
00:01:44.444 --> 00:01:48.610
And this is where all the routers
are running in this idea of a single area.

35
00:01:48.610 --> 00:01:53.309
Now a single area is the OSPF way of
describing what the routers will end up

36
00:01:53.309 --> 00:01:54.473
learning about.

37
00:01:54.473 --> 00:01:56.970
In other words,
the limits of what the router will learn.

38
00:01:58.110 --> 00:02:01.809
Well, every single router is
learning in a single area.

39
00:02:01.809 --> 00:02:05.668
That means they will exchange all the
routing information between every single

40
00:02:05.668 --> 00:02:09.467
router, so that every router will have,
well, the routes that they need to,

41
00:02:09.467 --> 00:02:12.640
okay, to be able to get
to where they need to go.

42
00:02:12.640 --> 00:02:17.590
So at the very beginning we were talking
about this idea as a reminder here, okay?

43
00:02:17.590 --> 00:02:22.714
That if we were to do this, and
I needed actually to be able to do that.

44
00:02:22.714 --> 00:02:24.668
I should've actually labeled these things,
but

45
00:02:24.668 --> 00:02:26.730
knowing me of course I didn't label them.

46
00:02:26.730 --> 00:02:31.304
So let me just do it this way and make
sure that we can get this done a little

47
00:02:31.304 --> 00:02:35.598
bit easier here and that will help me out,
at least I think it will.

48
00:02:35.598 --> 00:02:36.302
I could be wrong.

49
00:02:36.302 --> 00:02:40.940
And that way we'll be able
to talk about this, okay?

50
00:02:40.940 --> 00:02:44.500
So I'm just labeling A, B, C, D,
and E, and that will, I hope,

51
00:02:44.500 --> 00:02:48.940
will actually help me out cuz I was trying
to think about how I should've done this

52
00:02:48.940 --> 00:02:51.990
a little bit earlier, and then I still
didn't do what I wanted to do, right?

53
00:02:51.990 --> 00:02:55.540
So let's just labels those routers
right there to help us out, okay?

54
00:02:55.540 --> 00:02:59.080
So if we take a look at routers A,
B, C, D, and

55
00:02:59.080 --> 00:03:04.100
E, that means within OSPF, every router
will actually learn about everything else.

56
00:03:04.100 --> 00:03:09.742
And that also means that if on router E,
it needs to get to 172.16.32.12, okay?

57
00:03:09.742 --> 00:03:18.300
That means that router E has to have
a route on its routing table to get there.

58
00:03:18.300 --> 00:03:21.850
Well in OSPF,
that essentially will go ahead and

59
00:03:21.850 --> 00:03:26.690
at least begin to exchange all the
possibilities of the information to get

60
00:03:26.690 --> 00:03:29.910
to all these other routes
that are over here too, okay?

61
00:03:29.910 --> 00:03:33.850
And then also if router A wanted to
get all the way over to router E,

62
00:03:33.850 --> 00:03:35.930
well it would also do the same thing.

63
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:39.960
So notice the routing tables essentially
getting very big and large, okay?

64
00:03:40.980 --> 00:03:44.690
Now if you take a look at this
from router E's standpoint, okay?

65
00:03:44.690 --> 00:03:49.764
Now, Zach as we take a look here,
okay, it doesn't matter if router E

66
00:03:49.764 --> 00:03:55.184
wants to go to 172.16.16.16 or
172.16.32.45 or

67
00:03:55.184 --> 00:04:00.182
172.16.48.50, 172.16.64.75, okay?

68
00:04:00.182 --> 00:04:01.440
It doesn't matter-
>> Doesn't matter.

69
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:07.257
>> Because of the very fact
that when it leaves router E,

70
00:04:07.257 --> 00:04:14.000
it is only going to go out
in this one interface, okay?

71
00:04:14.000 --> 00:04:17.027
And it is only going to go up to, well,
this one interface here on router D.

72
00:04:17.027 --> 00:04:21.248
It's only gonna only one interface,
it's gonna go across,

73
00:04:21.248 --> 00:04:23.208
it's gonna come back down.

74
00:04:23.208 --> 00:04:28.549
And then it's only right here on A, does
it really matter that it can get there,

75
00:04:28.549 --> 00:04:31.763
to the individual networks
that it needs to go.

76
00:04:31.763 --> 00:04:38.590
But yet, this guy actually has to
have all these route for this.

77
00:04:38.590 --> 00:04:43.510
So what can actually be done when we start
to take a look at something like this,

78
00:04:43.510 --> 00:04:47.150
is to actually say, hey,
is that what has to be done?

79
00:04:47.150 --> 00:04:48.790
Is that what happens?

80
00:04:48.790 --> 00:04:53.516
No, because what we actually really want
to do is try to eliminate as many of these

81
00:04:53.516 --> 00:04:55.531
routes as possible to say, look,

82
00:04:55.531 --> 00:04:58.670
there's only one path to
all four of these networks.

83
00:04:58.670 --> 00:05:04.020
So we'll summarize that information and
we'll send only one route, okay?

84
00:05:04.020 --> 00:05:06.520
From up here, all the way down to route E,

85
00:05:06.520 --> 00:05:09.780
that gets everybody over to router
A before it actually has to route.

86
00:05:10.840 --> 00:05:12.160
And so that's the goal.

87
00:05:12.160 --> 00:05:13.250
But at the very beginning,

88
00:05:13.250 --> 00:05:17.040
when we start, we're only gonna deal
with the idea of a single network

89
00:05:17.040 --> 00:05:20.370
because that's the first place we
should begin, just to see how it works.

90
00:05:20.370 --> 00:05:22.919
And then we'll divide
it off into individual

91
00:05:22.919 --> 00:05:26.685
areas which now we'll actually end
up putting in area one and two.

92
00:05:26.685 --> 00:05:30.150
And then that way we'll see those
routing tables get much smaller.

93
00:05:30.150 --> 00:05:32.690
But at this point this
is what we're gonna do.

94
00:05:32.690 --> 00:05:36.960
For us, the default area is gonna be area
0 which is also considered the backbone

95
00:05:36.960 --> 00:05:41.570
area where all of the actual data
will have to go through, okay?

96
00:05:41.570 --> 00:05:44.110
So for us that's where
we're gonna be configuring.

97
00:05:44.110 --> 00:05:50.420
Now our true lab topology which I've
actually kind of redrawn out here,

98
00:05:50.420 --> 00:05:53.730
really looks something similar to this.

99
00:05:53.730 --> 00:05:56.820
We're not really paying attention
to the switch here in the middle,

100
00:05:56.820 --> 00:05:57.950
because it doesn't matter.

101
00:05:57.950 --> 00:06:00.070
We're not really actually
having to configure,

102
00:06:00.070 --> 00:06:02.030
it's not doing anything
that's going to do this.

103
00:06:02.030 --> 00:06:06.103
But in terms of symbolically and
virtually, okay, this is what we have.

104
00:06:06.103 --> 00:06:11.684
We have NYEDGE1, NYEDGE2, and NYWAN1 and
they have different interfaces,

105
00:06:11.684 --> 00:06:16.645
as well as networks that are connected
off at each one of these routers.

106
00:06:16.645 --> 00:06:21.490
NYWAN1 has a couple of different
networks it's also connected off of too.

107
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:25.450
So that way we can actually see routes
come in and get removed as we do so,

108
00:06:25.450 --> 00:06:27.080
all right?

109
00:06:27.080 --> 00:06:29.240
So this is the topology
that we're gonna use for

110
00:06:29.240 --> 00:06:31.960
the single area OSPF configuration.

111
00:06:33.340 --> 00:06:39.700
Well, we'll be referring back to that
hopefully if I can get to our lab here.

112
00:06:39.700 --> 00:06:43.400
Now we're gonna be using,
of course, our practice labs,

113
00:06:43.400 --> 00:06:45.924
our lab partners over there, in the UK.

114
00:06:45.924 --> 00:06:49.740
We are especially grateful cuz they
have a great lab set up for us.

115
00:06:49.740 --> 00:06:54.355
The lab that we're gonna be using, as you
are a subscriber and you have access, make

116
00:06:54.355 --> 00:06:58.451
sure you choose the one Interconnecting
Cisco Network Devices, ICND2.

117
00:06:58.451 --> 00:07:01.220
Make sure you chose the one
that says version three.

118
00:07:01.220 --> 00:07:05.692
And then Configure, Verify, Troubleshoot
Single Area OSPF version two for

119
00:07:05.692 --> 00:07:09.220
IP version four,
is what we're going to do, okay?

120
00:07:09.220 --> 00:07:13.540
So this is the lab that we're going to use
and we're gonna help us to walk through

121
00:07:13.540 --> 00:07:15.838
our configuration and
what we need to do here, okay?

122
00:07:17.030 --> 00:07:23.210
So we're gonna be using NYEDGE1,
NYEDGE2 and NYWAN1 down here to help

123
00:07:23.210 --> 00:07:28.310
us out in our configuration and between
them and what we need to do,all right.

124
00:07:28.310 --> 00:07:33.190
So let's start out with just
a basic OSFP configuration for

125
00:07:33.190 --> 00:07:38.040
NYEDGE1, and then we'll
duplicate that as we need to for

126
00:07:38.040 --> 00:07:42.080
each of the routers and the networks
that they're represented by, okay?

127
00:07:42.080 --> 00:07:48.003
So in the configuration for NYEDGE1,
I want to configure what we call,

128
00:07:48.003 --> 00:07:53.068
of course, the OSPF router itself and
then also a process ID.

129
00:07:53.068 --> 00:07:55.579
Now that's a new term I
haven't used before, Zach.

130
00:07:55.579 --> 00:07:56.400
>> Yeah.

131
00:07:56.400 --> 00:08:00.987
>> So this idea of a process ID Now
the key here in understanding the process

132
00:08:00.987 --> 00:08:04.780
ID is that it's only
significant to that router.

133
00:08:04.780 --> 00:08:07.630
In other words,
we can reuse this on another router.

134
00:08:07.630 --> 00:08:09.430
It doesn't have to be different.

135
00:08:09.430 --> 00:08:12.520
Now just because it doesn't have to
be different doesn't mean that you

136
00:08:12.520 --> 00:08:15.840
have to make them the same or
you have to make them different.

137
00:08:15.840 --> 00:08:17.310
But I normally do.

138
00:08:17.310 --> 00:08:20.201
But in our lab setting,
they make them all the same numbers here.

139
00:08:20.201 --> 00:08:23.682
And the reason why is that,
especially in a lab setting, for

140
00:08:23.682 --> 00:08:27.571
me to make sure that I'm on the right
router as I'm configuring it,

141
00:08:27.571 --> 00:08:31.689
setting up the process ID just makes
it logically easier for me to do so.

142
00:08:31.689 --> 00:08:36.681
Here, we're gonna configure NYXEDGE1
with the process ID of 1 is what we're

143
00:08:36.681 --> 00:08:38.820
going to do here to get started.

144
00:08:38.820 --> 00:08:42.634
So let's go ahead and do so, and
that way we'll show you how simple

145
00:08:42.634 --> 00:08:46.451
the configuration is for
the complexity that we're going to see.

146
00:08:46.451 --> 00:08:51.360
Let's go into our global configuration
mode, so there I'm in privileged exec, and

147
00:08:51.360 --> 00:08:56.129
if I do a configure terminal, it's simple,
just in the same way that we had set up,

148
00:08:56.129 --> 00:08:58.970
like, rip, We actually start
off with the word router.

149
00:08:58.970 --> 00:09:02.250
And then let's do a question mark so
that you see that there are multiple

150
00:09:02.250 --> 00:09:05.630
different routing protocols that you and
I can have access to.

151
00:09:05.630 --> 00:09:09.495
And you do see where it's actually
ospf and then ospfv3 here.

152
00:09:09.495 --> 00:09:10.624
>> Mm-hm.

153
00:09:10.624 --> 00:09:14.130
>> We're gonna just use ospf
is what we're going to use.

154
00:09:14.130 --> 00:09:17.950
But there are different ones that are out
there, so we're gonna do router, and

155
00:09:17.950 --> 00:09:21.884
we're gonna select ospf, and I am not done
yet, I need to do one more command, and

156
00:09:21.884 --> 00:09:22.590
there it is.

157
00:09:22.590 --> 00:09:26.620
Notice that you have a process ID, and
remember that this ID number doesn't

158
00:09:26.620 --> 00:09:31.560
really matter to any other router in OSP,
it is only about this router.

159
00:09:31.560 --> 00:09:32.900
So, if they're all identical,

160
00:09:32.900 --> 00:09:35.830

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with the lab configuration by adding in one more router into the ospf routing domain.  The team then verifies it's operation and output on the routers by examining not only the neighbor adjacency but running protocol and the routing table.  Lastly, they show how to manipulate ospf to not advertise out an interface using passive-interface commands and chance a router-id after it's operational.

00:22:04.755 --> 00:22:09.090
to verify how this is working or whether
it's actually not working as well, okay.

349
00:22:09.090 --> 00:22:15.410
The passive interface is deciding
on what you need to be doing, okay.

350
00:22:15.410 --> 00:22:18.830
Choose the interface, especially on those
interfaces that are only facing LAN

351
00:22:18.830 --> 00:22:21.920
networks, where there's not another router
attached that you can connect with.

352
00:22:21.920 --> 00:22:25.780
So that way you're not wasting resource
and sending out hellos to a network that

353
00:22:25.780 --> 00:22:29.500
doesn't care,
that it needs to actually do OSPF.

354
00:22:29.500 --> 00:22:32.900
So that's usually the key and
concept for us, okay.

355
00:22:32.900 --> 00:22:35.180
So Zach, a lot of information for us.

356
00:22:35.180 --> 00:22:39.425
A great reminder of some of the stuff
that we can do in a single area OSPF.

357
00:22:39.425 --> 00:22:43.075
But for us now it's actually learning
about the idea of multi-area SPF that

358
00:22:43.075 --> 00:22:46.755
we'll need to do, and we'll take a look
at that as we continue to move forward.

359
00:22:46.755 --> 00:22:47.575
>> Great job, Ronnie.

360
00:22:47.575 --> 00:22:50.445
Configure single area OSPF version two,
part four.

361
00:22:50.445 --> 00:22:52.926
Make sure you see all the parts,
that'd be one through four.

362
00:22:52.926 --> 00:22:56.311
[LAUGH] Before we move on, Ronnie,
anything else you'd like to say?

363
00:22:56.311 --> 00:22:58.085
>> Well remember that this is not the end,
right.

364
00:22:58.085 --> 00:23:01.703
So once again, when I began this series
and said there's a lot of information,

365
00:23:01.703 --> 00:23:04.468
there's a lot more coming,
we still have a configuration.

366
00:23:04.468 --> 00:23:12.418
A multi-area OSPF getting single area
understanding that is actually key.

367
00:23:12.418 --> 00:23:14.530
And then as we go into multi-area,
you'll see the benefits.

368
00:23:14.530 --> 00:23:19.049
And we'll also have to talk about
manual route summarization,

369
00:23:19.049 --> 00:23:23.161
which is never fun,
I don't know how else to describe it.

370
00:23:23.161 --> 00:23:26.972
But we will make sure that we understand
that process because it is a big

371
00:23:26.972 --> 00:23:30.588
part of what we want to be able to
do instead of having the router just

372
00:23:30.588 --> 00:23:34.270
advertise every single route
to every single OSPF router.

373
00:23:34.270 --> 00:23:36.980
We want it to become much more
efficient in the way that we need to.

374
00:23:36.980 --> 00:23:40.220
And that's what multi-area
OSPF will help us to do.

375
00:23:40.220 --> 00:23:40.970
>> Thank you, Ronnie.

376
00:23:40.970 --> 00:23:46.663
And you will understand that process if
you watch every single episode of CCNAs,

377
00:23:46.663 --> 00:23:50.275
routing and switching exam with 200-105.

378
00:23:50.275 --> 00:23:53.156
And by the way, you'll be in the course
library too, and there's thousands of

379
00:23:53.156 --> 00:23:55.910
other videos there designed to help you
go further, so check those out too.

380
00:23:55.910 --> 00:23:59.644
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

381
00:23:59.644 --> 00:24:01.037
ITProTV is binge worthy.

382
00:24:01.037 --> 00:24:01.750
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

383
00:24:01.750 --> 00:24:02.440
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

384
00:24:02.440 --> 00:24:05.070
>> And we will see you again soon.

385
00:24:05.070 --> 00:24:11.005
[MUSIC]

386
00:24:11.005 --> 00:24:14.117
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss some of the other feature of OSPF.  They also describe the multiarea ospf differences from single-area.
episodes.title: Configure Multiarea OSPFv2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.056 --> 00:00:02.968
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.968 --> 00:00:07.163
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.163 --> 00:00:08.362
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.362 --> 00:00:13.068
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

5
00:00:13.068 --> 00:00:16.449
watching ITProTV, empowering
the world with engaging learning.

6
00:00:16.449 --> 00:00:21.162
I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CCNA routing and

7
00:00:21.162 --> 00:00:23.827
switching, Exam 200-105.

8
00:00:23.827 --> 00:00:28.620
This episode is configure
multi-area OSPF version two.

9
00:00:28.620 --> 00:00:29.660
Boy, good stuff ahead.

10
00:00:29.660 --> 00:00:32.140
And the person bringing us that
information is the one and

11
00:00:32.140 --> 00:00:33.090
only Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:33.090 --> 00:00:35.610
Ronnie, good to see you.
>> Well and Zach thank you again for

13
00:00:35.610 --> 00:00:39.510
having me back on the show as we continue
together to take a look at CCNA routing

14
00:00:39.510 --> 00:00:44.849
and As we are walking through of course
OSPF, we've already spent a good deal

15
00:00:44.849 --> 00:00:49.915
of time talking about the basics of OSPF
as well as configuring single area OSPF.

16
00:00:49.915 --> 00:00:54.531
And now we're gonna go ahead and
make sure that we understand also the idea

17
00:00:54.531 --> 00:00:57.770
of configuring for
multi-area OSPF as well.

18
00:00:57.770 --> 00:01:01.090
So there's been a lot of different
things that we've had to cover.

19
00:01:01.090 --> 00:01:06.400
And now by comparison,
if you've been watching the CCENT show,

20
00:01:06.400 --> 00:01:08.760
and you go man you didn't
even go over any of this.

21
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:14.730
That's right, because we did briefly talk
about the OSPF, and just the basics of it.

22
00:01:14.730 --> 00:01:17.131
But now you're kind of getting
a little bit more of a full treatment.

23
00:01:17.131 --> 00:01:18.990
And just when you think
everything is done,

24
00:01:18.990 --> 00:01:22.256
we're not done yet because there's a lot
more for us to actually talk about so

25
00:01:22.256 --> 00:01:24.346
that's where we're gonna begin.
>> So Ronnie,

26
00:01:24.346 --> 00:01:28.419
I know that OSPF can be used for a single
area, but now we're looking at multi-area,

27
00:01:28.419 --> 00:01:30.536
what is the difference between them?
>> Yeah,

28
00:01:30.536 --> 00:01:33.449
that's actually a great place to
start because of where we picked up.

29
00:01:33.449 --> 00:01:35.251
So even though in the previous episode,

30
00:01:35.251 --> 00:01:38.590
if you've been watching it in the previous
series that we've been doing,

31
00:01:38.590 --> 00:01:41.787
you just kind of picked up from one
episode to the next and seemed right.

32
00:01:41.787 --> 00:01:43.665
But let's say that you go hey, look,

33
00:01:43.665 --> 00:01:47.483
I'm just picking up from right here and
you just decide to jump right into it,

34
00:01:47.483 --> 00:01:50.857
that's perfectly fine you can do
that as well, and we don't mind.

35
00:01:50.857 --> 00:01:53.126
But the very fact is we need a reminder,
okay.

36
00:01:53.126 --> 00:01:57.264
So we wanna make sure that we understand
what the difference is when we talk about

37
00:01:57.264 --> 00:02:00.960
the idea of configuring for OSPF for
single area versus multi-area.

38
00:02:00.960 --> 00:02:02.760
Let's take a look at my screen and,
hopefully,

39
00:02:02.760 --> 00:02:05.170
this will help us out just a little bit,
okay?

40
00:02:05.170 --> 00:02:09.421
In a single area OSPF model,
what ends up happening is that all of

41
00:02:09.421 --> 00:02:13.909
the actual OSPF routers,
they will try and go through, of course,

42
00:02:13.909 --> 00:02:18.187
the neighbor state that they need
to between those two routers.

43
00:02:18.187 --> 00:02:22.291
And eventually what they'll end up with of
course is that same link-state topology

44
00:02:22.291 --> 00:02:24.659
that we talked about in
terms of that database and

45
00:02:24.659 --> 00:02:27.345
then they'll discover those
routes from that point.

46
00:02:27.345 --> 00:02:31.318
But the way that that ends up working out
is fairly simple in the end result of

47
00:02:31.318 --> 00:02:32.480
things.

48
00:02:32.480 --> 00:02:37.300
Right here on Router A,
whatever its original routing table was,

49
00:02:37.300 --> 00:02:40.370
which is actually inside the Cloud here,
okay?

50
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:43.460
That original routing table that
as all the direct routes to,

51
00:02:43.460 --> 00:02:48.780
if it actually ever needs to get
information over to alpha router E,

52
00:02:48.780 --> 00:02:54.220
well it has to also learn about every
single route over there in router E.

53
00:02:54.220 --> 00:02:56.272
Now the unusual thing about this, right,

54
00:02:56.272 --> 00:02:59.408
is not that that really hurts us
with anything with the four routes

55
00:02:59.408 --> 00:03:02.904
that I've actually talked about here,
it's just an additional four.

56
00:03:02.904 --> 00:03:08.052
But the idea is fairly simple, notice
that to get from router A to router E,

57
00:03:08.052 --> 00:03:10.765
there's really only one path to do so.

58
00:03:10.765 --> 00:03:14.462
And that means that that's a lot
of information, when the only

59
00:03:14.462 --> 00:03:19.250
thing I'm really needing to do is send
the data out of this one interface.

60
00:03:19.250 --> 00:03:23.490
And these other routers in this
OSPF area will get it there.

61
00:03:23.490 --> 00:03:26.910
And so we don't need to know about
every single route that's there, but

62
00:03:26.910 --> 00:03:28.660
we will get every single route.

63
00:03:28.660 --> 00:03:29.330
And the same thing,

64
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:33.830
if E also wanted to actually send to
any of the networks off of router A.

65
00:03:33.830 --> 00:03:37.850
They would also end up building
the entire table here of routes to

66
00:03:37.850 --> 00:03:42.170
every single route or every single
network that router A knows about, too.

67
00:03:42.170 --> 00:03:46.051
And along the path of B, C, D,
and E, it'd be the same thing.

68
00:03:46.051 --> 00:03:49.138
So that way,
you'd actually have that path.

69
00:03:49.138 --> 00:03:52.945
But every single one of those is
gonna end up really just saying yeah,

70
00:03:52.945 --> 00:03:56.700
everything's going out this
one direction and one place.

71
00:03:56.700 --> 00:04:01.539
So now, we have a nice consistent
topology, but also all of the routers in

72
00:04:01.539 --> 00:04:06.001
between are keeping this routing table and
they're pretty large.

73
00:04:06.001 --> 00:04:08.157
Now when we start dealing with that,

74
00:04:08.157 --> 00:04:11.157
it's not really a big deal
on a small network okay.

75
00:04:11.157 --> 00:04:16.236
So single area OSPF is designed
actually for kind of a small and

76
00:04:16.236 --> 00:04:21.521
static area of routing domain that
we want to be able to control.

77
00:04:21.521 --> 00:04:25.730
So when we start doing that, the problem
happens to be very simple here okay?

78
00:04:25.730 --> 00:04:27.785
That even though this is good,

79
00:04:27.785 --> 00:04:32.064
it now actually begins to kind of
do some other problems in OSPF.

80
00:04:32.064 --> 00:04:33.014
For example,

81
00:04:33.014 --> 00:04:38.630
every router along this path now has
to store a larger link-state database.

82
00:04:38.630 --> 00:04:40.460
So what does that really mean?

83
00:04:40.460 --> 00:04:44.940
Well, that means it doesn't store
it at this point in flash memory,

84
00:04:44.940 --> 00:04:47.240
which is essentially
the same as the hard drive.

85
00:04:47.240 --> 00:04:50.460
It stores it all in
the RAM of that router.

86
00:04:50.460 --> 00:04:54.500
So the more routes that every
single router has to learn the less

87
00:04:54.500 --> 00:04:58.500
RAM that it has access to, the less memory
that it has access to to perform all of

88
00:04:58.500 --> 00:05:02.930
the other functions that the router
would actually need to be able to do.

89
00:05:02.930 --> 00:05:06.500
So the amount of data that we're
sending in that link-state database,

90
00:05:06.500 --> 00:05:09.090
it consumes more resource, okay?

91
00:05:09.090 --> 00:05:14.040
The other thing of course then is that
as we start to remember the process of

92
00:05:14.040 --> 00:05:18.334
this right, Once we become neighbors
then we exchange that idea of that link

93
00:05:18.334 --> 00:05:22.855
state database right, and that way we
have that full link state database.

94
00:05:22.855 --> 00:05:27.016
Then we have to actually be able to
put routes into the routing table.

95
00:05:27.016 --> 00:05:31.179
Well if you think about right,
that's the algorithm okay.

96
00:05:31.179 --> 00:05:35.700
If we run that against a large linked
state database which is on every router

97
00:05:35.700 --> 00:05:37.951
that's consistently the same.

98
00:05:37.951 --> 00:05:39.695
throughout the entire area.

99
00:05:39.695 --> 00:05:44.637
Well now even that, right, when we run
that algorithm, it is more processor

100
00:05:44.637 --> 00:05:49.749
intensive because it has to run it more
often because that database is so large.

101
00:05:49.749 --> 00:05:53.420
So instead of limiting it,
every time we start adding in more routes,

102
00:05:53.420 --> 00:05:55.890
it has to run it more and more often here.

103
00:05:55.890 --> 00:05:58.970
So that's something else that we
also have to think about, okay?

104
00:05:58.970 --> 00:06:04.020
The other thing that can also affect OSPF,
is the very fact that

105
00:06:04.020 --> 00:06:09.290
if a change happens in any one
of these routers here, okay?

106
00:06:09.290 --> 00:06:13.956
Because they're all part of a single
area OSPF, that can actually mean

107
00:06:13.956 --> 00:06:18.776
that it affects the very fact that a route
is gonna change along the path for

108
00:06:18.776 --> 00:06:22.856
any one of them in this configuration
that we have right here.

109
00:06:22.856 --> 00:06:25.902
So if a single link goes down,
every router,

110
00:06:25.902 --> 00:06:29.751
at this point, will also have
to kind of recognize that it

111
00:06:29.751 --> 00:06:33.369
has to recalculate
the possibilities of new routes.

112
00:06:33.369 --> 00:06:37.339
Because all of its other routes
are essentially based on one interface or

113
00:06:37.339 --> 00:06:39.180
one link or another here.

114
00:06:39.180 --> 00:06:44.170
So every single router in this
particular area here would end up having

115
00:06:44.170 --> 00:06:48.610
to run through again it's link-state
database and run through that Dijkstra

116
00:06:48.610 --> 00:06:52.730
algorithm to try and generate a new
possible path if there is one.

117
00:06:52.730 --> 00:06:55.820
The problem that we'd have here is
that there isn't another path and so

118
00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:58.740
that's where that single area
would also have to, okay?

119
00:06:58.740 --> 00:07:04.930
So that's kind of some of the big issues,
but the worst issue in just a single

120
00:07:04.930 --> 00:07:09.590
area that we have to deal with is the very
fact that it's not really scalable.

121
00:07:09.590 --> 00:07:14.990
You and I are really not gonna notice
a big gigantic performance hit too often

122
00:07:14.990 --> 00:07:16.760
until we hit about 50 routers.

123
00:07:16.760 --> 00:07:20.020
So it still actually can handle it
pretty well on most of the modern

124
00:07:20.020 --> 00:07:21.180
routers that we have.

125
00:07:21.180 --> 00:07:24.870
But once we hit 50 routers and
once we start hitting hundreds of subnets,

126
00:07:24.870 --> 00:07:31.330
not the idea of 10 or 20 subnets here,
but hundreds of subnets.

127
00:07:31.330 --> 00:07:35.350
Well at that particular point, each router
will actually end up consuming more

128
00:07:35.350 --> 00:07:39.090
resources almost exponentially
at that point too okay?

129
00:07:39.090 --> 00:07:44.310
So that's where a single area really does
affect us, because it's not scalable.

130
00:07:44.310 --> 00:07:48.480
It doesn't actually do
anything well in that way.

131
00:07:48.480 --> 00:07:51.693
Now, when we compare that,
what then can we do?

132
00:07:51.693 --> 00:07:55.359
Well the great thing is,
you and I don't have to try and

133
00:07:55.359 --> 00:08:00.300
go, what are some of the different
options that we have And, you know,

134
00:08:00.300 --> 00:08:05.803
how do I actually figure this out because
in the realm of the OSPF protocol itself,

135
00:08:05.803 --> 00:08:08.069
here's how you fix that, okay?

136
00:08:08.069 --> 00:08:11.501
Here's how you actually
solve this problem.

137
00:08:11.501 --> 00:08:17.044
And the way that we do so is by instead
of actually just using a single area for

138
00:08:17.044 --> 00:08:22.091
our OSPF start implementing
what we call multi-area OSPF.

139
00:08:22.091 --> 00:08:26.500
And there's a bit of terminology here
that you will have to know also for

140
00:08:26.500 --> 00:08:31.650
the exam and some different abbreviations
that you will also have to know as well.

141
00:08:31.650 --> 00:08:33.130
>> That's very colorful Ronnie.

142
00:08:33.130 --> 00:08:34.389
>> Yeah I tried to make sure that

143
00:08:34.389 --> 00:08:35.680
we could see this.
>> [LAUGH]

144
00:08:35.680 --> 00:08:36.982
>> But this is what we call

145
00:08:36.982 --> 00:08:41.042
a multi-area OSPF and we're going
to talk about the configuration.

146
00:08:41.042 --> 00:08:44.608
The great thing is it's not very
difficult in its configuration,

147
00:08:44.608 --> 00:08:47.460
understanding the concept behind it is,
okay?

148
00:08:47.460 --> 00:08:49.290
So that's why we wanna do this.

149
00:08:49.290 --> 00:08:54.495
So now in this particular situation,
what I've done is actually kind of

150
00:08:54.495 --> 00:08:59.345
tried to shorten the overall punch and
effect of what we needed to, okay?

151
00:08:59.345 --> 00:09:00.635
Well now,

152
00:09:00.635 --> 00:09:04.705
because of the way that I described that
what happens in the single area, right?

153
00:09:04.705 --> 00:09:09.267
We want to limit the effects of the
problems that we've talked about, okay,

154
00:09:09.267 --> 00:09:12.315
multi-area OSPF allows us to do that.

155
00:09:12.315 --> 00:09:16.725
It allows us to say all right, a single
area, it will always have these problems,

156
00:09:16.725 --> 00:09:20.240
it's just the nature and
what happens in OSPF.

157
00:09:20.240 --> 00:09:25.680
So what if we start to actually kind of
isolate them by creating other areas and

158
00:09:25.680 --> 00:09:28.560
then we isolate those issues
down to that one area.

159
00:09:28.560 --> 00:09:31.990
So all of those problems I just
talked about for lets say Area 1,

160
00:09:31.990 --> 00:09:37.150
they're essentially isolated right
here in this particular area.

161
00:09:37.150 --> 00:09:38.370
Now, I have more than one router,

162
00:09:38.370 --> 00:09:39.910
that's perfectly fine.
>> Right.

163
00:09:39.910 --> 00:09:40.480
>> But normally,

164
00:09:40.480 --> 00:09:44.940
we need at least one interface
from one router, and

165
00:09:44.940 --> 00:09:49.390
then all the other routers, if all of
those interfaces are in the same area,

166
00:09:49.390 --> 00:09:52.180
that is actually called
an internal router.

167
00:09:52.180 --> 00:09:57.244
if you have one interface that, or
one router, which has an interface in one

168
00:09:57.244 --> 00:10:02.172
area and you also have that same router
having interface in another area.

169
00:10:02.172 --> 00:10:05.047
So, for example,
right here off of Area 1, okay?

170
00:10:05.047 --> 00:10:10.715
Those have one interface here, and I have
one interface in this Area 0 over here.

171
00:10:10.715 --> 00:10:13.314
That now becomes technically an OSPF,

172
00:10:13.314 --> 00:10:18.209
what it's called an area border router,
an ABR, an area border router.

173
00:10:18.209 --> 00:10:20.828
And that is because it has two interfaces,

174
00:10:20.828 --> 00:10:23.900
each of those interfaces
are in a different area.

175
00:10:24.900 --> 00:10:28.370
Area border routers essentially
are what divides up for

176
00:10:28.370 --> 00:10:30.750
us the idea of the multi-area

177
00:10:30.750 --> 00:10:33.110
OSPF configuration that we need.
>> Okay.

178
00:10:33.110 --> 00:10:34.580
>> Now and the advantage of this

179
00:10:34.580 --> 00:10:37.980
idea of the multi-area OSPF will be

a number that begins with at least one.

288
00:17:14.940 --> 00:17:16.870
Going up from that point.

289
00:17:16.870 --> 00:17:21.358
Well, if now the interface is
actually a gigabit interface, and

290
00:17:21.358 --> 00:17:25.601
my reference bandwidth is a fast Ethernet,
100 megabit,

291
00:17:25.601 --> 00:17:30.270
well that would be taking
the reference bandwidth 100 million.

292
00:17:30.270 --> 00:17:33.305
Then I would divide that by a billion.

293
00:17:33.305 --> 00:17:37.815
So if I do that I end up with
an number that's not gonna be one,

294
00:17:37.815 --> 00:17:40.299
it's gonna be point something.

295
00:17:40.299 --> 00:17:45.143
.001, or whatever it is, or
how every many one's it is, or

296
00:17:45.143 --> 00:17:48.031
is it point 0001, I don't know.

297
00:17:48.031 --> 00:17:51.870
So it's gonna be less than a one.

298
00:17:51.870 --> 00:17:53.569
So that's where it's problematic.

299
00:17:53.569 --> 00:17:57.297
So what you may instead do, if you
realize that this is what's happening and

300
00:17:57.297 --> 00:18:01.223
you're getting weird metrics, it's not
turning out the way that you want to.

301
00:18:01.223 --> 00:18:05.900
Is that you may go and change
the reference bandwidth itself to do so.

302
00:18:05.900 --> 00:18:08.050
You can manually change
the ID of the metric,

303
00:18:08.050 --> 00:18:12.590
by typing in in the routing
configuration here ip ospf cost.

304
00:18:13.990 --> 00:18:16.670
And you can change that
to be able to do that.

305
00:18:16.670 --> 00:18:20.200
But if you leave it at the default,
then what it's gonna do,

306
00:18:20.200 --> 00:18:22.510
it's gonna use that reference
bandwidth that we talked about here.

307
00:18:23.690 --> 00:18:24.560
So we instead,

308
00:18:24.560 --> 00:18:27.040
we are going to change this.
>> Wonderful.

309
00:18:27.040 --> 00:18:28.510
>> Is what we're gonna do.

310
00:18:28.510 --> 00:18:31.820
So over on all of our devices.

311
00:18:31.820 --> 00:18:33.180
If you change the reference bandwidth,

312
00:18:33.180 --> 00:18:38.250
you need to make sure to change on every
device that's participating in OSPF, okay?

313
00:18:38.250 --> 00:18:40.020
Not just one, but every device.

314
00:18:40.020 --> 00:18:43.320
So for us, it's gonna be on every
single device except for NYACCESS1,

315
00:18:43.320 --> 00:18:44.760
is what we're gonna change at all.

316
00:18:44.760 --> 00:18:49.670
So let's begin NYEDGE1, and
we'll begin to change there first.

317
00:18:49.670 --> 00:18:53.977
So let me go into our
global configuration mode.

318
00:18:53.977 --> 00:18:59.197
And once I get into the global
configuration mode here,

319
00:18:59.197 --> 00:19:01.314
I want router ospf1.

320
00:19:01.314 --> 00:19:05.094
And then this one is auto-cost,

321
00:19:05.094 --> 00:19:11.176
which is the automatic
cost reference-bandwidth.

322
00:19:15.164 --> 00:19:18.950
Now, let me do a question mark, so
that we can see some of the information.

323
00:19:19.960 --> 00:19:25.150
So if we do this here, the automatic-cost
the default cost essentially

324
00:19:25.150 --> 00:19:27.010
the reference bandwidth can we set it?

325
00:19:27.010 --> 00:19:30.100
Yes, if we don't it's gonna be
set at a hundred megabits here.

326
00:19:30.100 --> 00:19:35.130
Notice it says the reference bandwidth in
terms of megabits per second is the key.

327
00:19:35.130 --> 00:19:41.060
So if I wanna change this
instead to be a gigabit of this.

328
00:19:41.060 --> 00:19:45.903
Well, then I would actually do auto-cost

329
00:19:45.903 --> 00:19:51.935
reference-bandwidth and

330
00:19:51.935 --> 00:19:55.485
that would be what, actually equal

331
00:19:55.485 --> 00:20:00.415
to 1000 megabits would actual be equal
to the idea of the gigabit here.

332
00:20:02.500 --> 00:20:05.410
Now, notice the way that this shows up,
okay?

333
00:20:05.410 --> 00:20:10.240
OSPF is now sending us a syslog message
that says reference bandwidth has changed.

334
00:20:10.240 --> 00:20:14.490
Please ensure reference bandwidth is
consistent across all the routers.

335
00:20:14.490 --> 00:20:18.020
Now, can you leave it and
it'll probably work out?

336
00:20:18.020 --> 00:20:20.550
Probably, but you don't ever want to

337
00:20:20.550 --> 00:20:23.840
take that chance where it could mess
up something that you're trying to do.

338
00:20:23.840 --> 00:20:28.190
So the goal here of course is to ensure
that you can do the same commands,

339
00:20:28.190 --> 00:20:30.430
across well all the other ones here too.

340
00:20:31.470 --> 00:20:33.640
So for us, let's go ahead and do that.

341
00:20:33.640 --> 00:20:35.580
Now before I change over here,

342
00:20:35.580 --> 00:20:40.770
it wants us to take a look at
the routing table for NYEDGE1.

343
00:20:42.700 --> 00:20:47.260
And see if anything actually changed here.

344
00:20:47.260 --> 00:20:48.520
do show IP route.

345
00:20:49.910 --> 00:20:58.325
And we're specifically gonna
take a look at one route here,

346
00:20:58.325 --> 00:21:03.942
which is gonna be 1721616.0.

347
00:21:03.942 --> 00:21:08.335
So from here, let's see,
what is the routing entry,

348
00:21:08.335 --> 00:21:12.836
I'm trying to see what we are going to,
zoom in on here.

349
00:21:12.836 --> 00:21:19.940
So now it's telling what the candidate
route is to leave from 192.168.16.5.

350
00:21:19.940 --> 00:21:22.640
That's what it's talking about,
the route metric is 12,

351
00:21:22.640 --> 00:21:25.390
wait a minute that's kinda weird okay.

352
00:21:25.390 --> 00:21:30.710
So now notice that for
this new route going here,

353
00:21:30.710 --> 00:21:33.850
the metric has now
changed to a 12 instead.

354
00:21:33.850 --> 00:21:39.460
All right now, let's take a look at
this from NYEDGE2, and let's see here.

355
00:21:39.460 --> 00:21:43.922
Now even though this is not gonna
exactly the same, show ip route.

356
00:21:46.393 --> 00:21:49.384
172.16.16.0.

357
00:21:53.417 --> 00:21:57.430
Notice at this point
the metric is actually a 3.

358
00:21:57.430 --> 00:22:00.990
So you see the difference at this
point here, and that's because

359
00:22:00.990 --> 00:22:06.120
what has happened is that that reference
bandwidth which was normally 100 megabits.

360
00:22:06.120 --> 00:22:10.270
Well on this one, it kind of went
to that point whatever, 000, so

361
00:22:10.270 --> 00:22:14.990
it probably counted it as a 0
essentially is what happened here.

362
00:22:14.990 --> 00:22:17.854
So you actually end up seeing
where this can be effective, and

363
00:22:17.854 --> 00:22:19.297
it's actually not changing.

364
00:22:19.297 --> 00:22:25.294
So let's see if we can actually tell
the difference here as we add this one in,

365
00:22:25.294 --> 00:22:26.600
router ospf 1.

366
00:22:26.600 --> 00:22:36.146
And then,
auto-cost reference-bandwidth 1000.

367
00:22:40.033 --> 00:22:44.980
Do ip route 172.16.16.0.

368
00:22:44.980 --> 00:22:48.580
And now notice that
the metric is changing.

369
00:22:48.580 --> 00:22:51.430
So we know that this is
affecting what we want it to do.

370
00:22:51.430 --> 00:22:54.530
We'll do the same thing for

371
00:22:54.530 --> 00:22:59.913
once again all of the other ones, that
are participating inside of our OSPF here.

372
00:22:59.913 --> 00:23:04.357
router, ospf1,

373
00:23:04.357 --> 00:23:09.080
and then auto-cost

374
00:23:09.080 --> 00:23:15.235
reference-bandwidth.

375
00:23:15.235 --> 00:23:18.500
Reference-bandwidth, wow,

376
00:23:21.270 --> 00:23:25.680
that's harder to spell than I thought.

377
00:23:26.980 --> 00:23:28.400
Do this as 1000 again.

378
00:23:30.230 --> 00:23:31.478
So that's what they want us to do,

379
00:23:31.478 --> 00:23:33.774
is just to make sure that they
are consistent all through here.

380
00:23:41.521 --> 00:23:42.660
Router ospf 1.

381
00:23:42.660 --> 00:23:46.862
And once again, auto-cost and

382
00:23:46.862 --> 00:23:50.928
then reference-bandwidth.

383
00:23:50.928 --> 00:23:55.390
On that.

384
00:23:55.390 --> 00:23:56.538
So, that's the idea.

385
00:23:56.538 --> 00:24:00.078
Now, I'm not gonna worry about
the NYCORE2, but you get the idea and

386
00:24:00.078 --> 00:24:02.190
you did see the changes there.

387
00:24:02.190 --> 00:24:06.493
So if you are taking a look at these
routing tables as you are going through.

388
00:24:06.493 --> 00:24:11.494
And you start realizing that you're using
more in gigabit interfaces instead.

389
00:24:11.494 --> 00:24:15.511
And the reference bandwidth this normally
100 mega bits, you wanna change at the map

00:24:15.511 --> 00:24:18.150
what you believe is gonna be
you're highest bandwidth.

391
00:24:18.150 --> 00:24:21.670
It doesn't really matter in
terms of a lot of thing, okay?

392
00:24:21.670 --> 00:24:25.150
But you wanted to actually be relatively
accurate, that's what you want to do is

393
00:24:25.150 --> 00:24:27.710
you wanna make sure that you
are doing something like that.

394
00:24:27.710 --> 00:24:32.010
And that will now change and show you what
you actually need to be able to do, okay?

395
00:24:32.010 --> 00:24:35.200
So that changes it just about
the across everything here.

396
00:24:35.200 --> 00:24:37.470
I do have one more,
let me go ahead and finish it,

397
00:24:37.470 --> 00:24:40.510
so I don't just leave it that way.

398
00:24:40.510 --> 00:24:45.850
Router ospf 1 and then auto-cost,

399
00:24:45.850 --> 00:24:50.906
I hate just leaving it,
auto-cost, reference-bandwidth.

400
00:24:53.751 --> 00:24:58.077
10,000, and that will now ensure that
everything inside is actually gonna make

00:24:58.077 --> 00:24:59.920
the matrix based off the same thing.

00:24:59.920 --> 00:25:02.100
It's not gonna have to
recalculate over and over,

403
00:25:02.100 --> 00:25:04.920
because you're reporting
different things going on, okay?

404
00:25:04.920 --> 00:25:07.220
So this is kind of the idea.

405
00:25:07.220 --> 00:25:08.810
What happens if you don't, okay?

406
00:25:08.810 --> 00:25:11.236
Well, remember that every
single router right,

407
00:25:11.236 --> 00:25:14.249
it independently generates its
own metric to places, okay?

408
00:25:14.249 --> 00:25:19.044
But if you actually set everybody else
to the 1,000 meaning a gigabit is your

00:25:19.044 --> 00:25:21.244
reference versus you not changing.

00:25:21.244 --> 00:25:25.527
Well, if your metric is lower that's gonna
always get entered into that routing table

00:25:25.527 --> 00:25:27.260
for your device, okay?

00:25:27.260 --> 00:25:30.850
The other thing that of course
ends up happening then is that for

you, you might think that you
have the best possible path, but

00:25:34.750 --> 00:25:37.420
it may not be realistic and
that's the problem, right?

00:25:37.420 --> 00:25:40.940
Is that you can't have their router
sitting out there that has an unrealistic

00:25:40.940 --> 00:25:44.640
metric in terms the way that it's done,
cuz everybody else is basing their

417
00:25:44.640 --> 00:25:46.415
particular reference
off of something else.

418
00:25:46.415 --> 00:25:49.410
So make sure that they're
all consistent here, okay?

So, the great thing is for

We have now configured single area and

We've also talked a lot about

00:26:05.770 --> 00:26:08.930
the basic functioning, yes you have
to know about all of it, okay?

00:26:08.930 --> 00:26:11.560
I wish I could tell you, no,
just know about this and this and this and

00:26:11.560 --> 00:26:16.350
you'll be ready to go, but OSPF is one
of the most important protocols and

00:26:16.350 --> 00:26:18.150
you go hey, are we done with it yet?

00:26:18.150 --> 00:26:19.580
No, we're not, okay?

00:26:19.580 --> 00:26:23.220
We still have to actually talk about
the idea of implementing this or

OSPF version three in terms of

But the great thing about this Zack,

And even then, are we finally done?

No, okay.

There's a rabbit hole that you just can

area types that are out there.

What we have actually just done is

You're not gonna have that down,

so pay attention more here.
>> Well, Ronnie, you've play that a great

foundation and this has been configure

Make sure you see the first two parts,

it's good to see [INAUDIBLE] order by the

else, don't you?

Again, slow down, okay?

If any of these is not making sense, don't

Ask questions if you need to,

Do not move on until you actually feel

It's not gonna really help you to do that

So make sure you take this all in.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce OSPFv3.  They describe the functionality as the the same as OSPFv2. The configuration is different that requires configuration at the ospfv3 router and per interface, according to the team.  They show how to configure it and verify taht it works
episodes.title: Configure Single-Area OSPFv3

So we have already talked about OSPF, but

Well, what's the real big

Well in OSPF Version 2, or V2, that is

Those will absolutely change for us.

And you and I don't have configure a lot

Well today you choose that because

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure multiarea OSPFv3.  The guys show the configuration differences from OSPFv2.  They emphasize show commands and remind us to remember to check our commands are for IPv6 rather than IPv4.

We are now going to be configuring

Well, we went over, we did,

00:01:05.831 --> 00:01:10.813
over just generic OSPF information for

the concepts of OSPF inside of

So make sure you go back and see that

So we're just gonna configure

The real big difference, of course,

That we have from OSPFv2 is not gonna

Do not forget that more than likely,

As you continue to move through your

So let's take a look at the lab that

And then we're gonna select

That is the one that we are going to do.

00:02:57.842 --> 00:02:59.330

57

Normally, if you have a single-area,

60

And so what we're actually seeing here,

00:03:17.241 --> 00:03:20.402
Is the blue cloud that you

63
00:03:20.402 --> 00:03:24.514
This is all gonna be Area 0 and I can see

64
00:03:24.514 --> 00:03:28.818
And then the little green one

00:03:28.818 --> 00:03:33.453

66
00:03:33.453 --> 00:03:37.683
So remember that, when we have some of

68

All of the routers that are only

69
00:03:46.238 --> 00:03:51.782
These are gonna be the ones that are, what

70
00:03:51.782 --> 00:03:57.042
And if you actually do have routers that
have an interface in more than one area,

71

such as NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2,
those are gonna be called ABRs here, okay?

72
00:04:02.083 --> 00:04:06.428
Or Area Border Routers where there's
actually an interface in Area 0,

73
00:04:06.428 --> 00:04:09.362
there's an interface in Area 1 as well,
okay?

74
00:04:09.362 --> 00:04:14.385
Off of NYEDGE1, they've created
a bunch of loopback interfaces with

75

different IP addresses on them,
IPv6 addresses, to simulate a lot of

76
00:04:19.407 --> 00:04:24.370
different networks that are also

77
00:04:24.370 --> 00:04:29.513
Now, if they had another router that

78
00:04:29.513 --> 00:04:33.301

79
00:04:33.301 --> 00:04:37.012
Remember that that's gonna be considered

80
00:04:37.012 --> 00:04:39.813
So those are kind of the differences
that we're gonna see.

81
00:04:39.813 --> 00:04:44.407
For us our autonomous system
boarder router would be right here,

82
00:04:44.407 --> 00:04:45.751
which is NYWAN1.

83
00:04:45.751 --> 00:04:49.138
And then that would actually go outside
to another autonomous system out here

84
00:04:49.138 --> 00:04:49.721
somewhere.

85
00:04:49.721 --> 00:04:53.212

00:31:51.270 --> 00:31:54.740
Do not move on from this
topic until you are ready.

533
00:31:54.740 --> 00:31:59.450
Because as we head into EIGRP, you'll see
some things that are very similar to it.

534
00:31:59.450 --> 00:32:01.091
But they're not exactly the same,

535
00:32:01.091 --> 00:32:04.530
and it's very easy to mistake
the differences between the two.

536
00:32:04.530 --> 00:32:06.850
Even though there are actually
very clear differences,

537
00:32:06.850 --> 00:32:09.720
it does work in a similar
fashion to a point.

538
00:32:09.720 --> 00:32:12.553
So there's a lot more detail and
information for us, and

539
00:32:12.553 --> 00:32:15.739
if you just continue on from this
point without mastering this,

540
00:32:15.739 --> 00:32:17.639
you will be overwhelmed and I mean it.

541
00:32:17.639 --> 00:32:22.430
So take the time, slow down now
before you get ready for the exam.

542
00:32:22.430 --> 00:32:25.920
Make sure you understand this
before you move on to EIGRP.

543
00:32:25.920 --> 00:32:27.481
>> Wonderful advice, thanks again, Ronnie.

544
00:32:27.481 --> 00:32:30.135
And make sure you watch every
single episode of CCNA, running and

545
00:32:30.135 --> 00:32:31.543
switching exam 200-105.

546
00:32:31.543 --> 00:32:34.785
The series is wonderful and
will help you, and

547
00:32:34.785 --> 00:32:37.790
by the way it will be
in the course library.

548
00:32:37.790 --> 00:32:39.590
There's thousands of videos there,

549
00:32:39.590 --> 00:32:42.320
designed to do one thing and
help you go even further.

550
00:32:42.320 --> 00:32:43.340
Take a look at those too.

551
00:32:43.340 --> 00:32:48.760
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
ITProTV is binge-worthy, it really is.

552
00:32:48.760 --> 00:32:50.202
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

553
00:32:50.202 --> 00:32:51.222
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

554
00:32:51.222 --> 00:32:53.291
>> And we'll see you again soon.

555
00:32:53.291 --> 00:32:59.394
[MUSIC]

556
00:32:59.394 --> 00:33:02.075
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce EIGRP.  The team compares many of the concepts and operations to ospf and then discuss their differnces.  They describe how EIGRP works to put routes into the routing table.
episodes.title: Understand EIGRP Concepts and Operations

This episode,
new information is coming your way.

Ronnie, good to see you sir.

14

As we continue through of course, taking

15
00:00:43.100 --> 00:00:46.070
We are now talking about well, EIGRP,

16
00:00:46.070 --> 00:00:49.350
I know it sounds like whole bunch

>> Alphabetsu.
>> Alphabetsu is pretty much the key.

18

We already talk about OSPF,

These are of course are both

20

Dynamic routing protocols that you and

21
00:01:02.830 --> 00:01:07.820
As we start with our exam and

22
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:09.100
So just kind of remember that yes,

23
00:01:09.100 --> 00:01:12.400
do you have to know the information
that we're gonna be covering.

24

And it does help if you take
the time to go through it slowly.

25
00:01:16.420 --> 00:01:18.920
It's not everything that
everybody wants it to be, right?

26

There's no easy way around this.

27

This is technical, it does require you
to spend a little bit of time if not

28
00:01:25.670 --> 00:01:29.620
a lot of time in just making
sure you have fundamentals down.

29

But do not move on from

30

From one of these different protocols
to another one without making sure you

31

32

Because if not it builds up and

34

Adjust for each protocol and

then you add another protocol onto

Yeah, it doesn't help, okay?

37

So my suggestion is,
if you're going all right,

38
00:01:52.460 --> 00:01:54.920
now I'm not sure if I'm

39

But I'm moving onto EIGRP,

40

But remember,

41

And understand everything about

42

And then hit OSPF, okay?

43

Or go back but make sure that you dont

44
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:12.840
If you dont understand it do not move on.

45
00:02:12.840 --> 00:02:14.430
That's the key, okay?

46
00:02:14.430 --> 00:02:16.380
Because it's not gonna help you out here.

47
00:02:16.380 --> 00:02:18.410
So that is what we are beginning with.

48
00:02:18.410 --> 00:02:21.750
Now when we start talking
about the idea of EIGRP here.

49
00:02:21.750 --> 00:02:25.390
We wanna give a little bit of some
historical perspective as well.

50
00:02:25.390 --> 00:02:27.810
And then talk about the idea and
the concept and

51
00:02:27.810 --> 00:02:30.315
the reason behind it too, okay.

52
00:02:30.315 --> 00:02:31.970
That is dynamic routing protocol.

53
00:02:31.970 --> 00:02:35.320
The start of ERGRP of course,
doesn't start by itself.

54
00:02:35.320 --> 00:02:38.610
It starts with an old protocol called IGRP

55
00:02:38.610 --> 00:02:43.810
which was Cisco proprietary's way of doing
business vector protocols, is what it did.

56
00:02:43.810 --> 00:02:48.020
But it's popularity never really
got to where it needed to be.

57
00:02:48.020 --> 00:02:51.630
Rip essencially took over and
with the advancment of Rip version 2.

58
00:02:51.630 --> 00:02:56.752
It really did actually kind of
make it very easy for people.

59
00:02:56.752 --> 00:03:00.317
To choose that instead of IGRP
that was more suscope propriatory.

60
00:03:00.317 --> 00:03:04.188
So when they realize it wasn't
really a sufficient protocol for

61
00:03:04.188 --> 00:03:05.628
the needs of networks.

62
00:03:05.628 --> 00:03:06.878
They started to, of course,

63
00:03:06.878 --> 00:03:10.540
work on their own proprietary protocol
that would begin to work better.

64
00:03:10.540 --> 00:03:15.510
What they came up with was
an incredibly sophisticated protocol.

65
00:03:15.510 --> 00:03:20.340
That no longer falls in the bounds
of a distance vector protocol.

66
00:03:20.340 --> 00:03:24.790
It still begins that way but it no
longer really falls in the bounds of it.

67
00:03:24.790 --> 00:03:28.936
It is based on that original
protocol called IGRP.

68
00:03:28.936 --> 00:03:32.408
So the idea of adding the E onto the
beginning means it is enhanced into your

69
00:03:32.408 --> 00:03:34.560
gateway routing protocol.

70
00:03:34.560 --> 00:03:38.860
And the reason why that's important is
because it no longer follows all the rules

71
00:03:38.860 --> 00:03:41.040
of distance vector protocols.

72
00:03:41.040 --> 00:03:44.450
It does a little bit that sounds
like distance vector protocols.

73
00:03:44.450 --> 00:03:47.620
But after it does that little bit that
it sounds like using the way that

74
00:03:47.620 --> 00:03:49.690
distance vector protocols work.

75
00:03:49.690 --> 00:03:52.890
It does something all
by itself on its own.

76
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:57.324
And it begins to be almost more
like a link state protocol.

77
00:03:57.324 --> 00:04:00.210
And it begins to change and
does another thing, too, okay?

78
00:04:00.210 --> 00:04:02.880
So it really helps us in different ways.

79
00:04:02.880 --> 00:04:07.270
So, major advantages here when we
start talking about this, okay?

80
00:04:07.270 --> 00:04:13.870
Is this idea of actually being able to
do a couple of different things, right?

81
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:18.743
So, one of the things that you
actually here about is EIGRP can

82
00:04:18.743 --> 00:04:22.503
provide you with a 100% loop free network.

83
00:04:22.503 --> 00:04:25.113
Distance vector protocols is something
like rip normally has problems

84
00:04:25.113 --> 00:04:26.140
routing loops.

85
00:04:26.140 --> 00:04:30.020
And of course one of the advancements
that they did in EIGRP.

86
00:04:30.020 --> 00:04:33.310
Is they,
changed the idea of the routing metric

87
00:04:33.310 --> 00:04:37.210
from doing a hop a router at-a-time.

88
00:04:37.210 --> 00:04:42.614
In terms of the metric going to a desk
nation is that they made more advanced.

89
00:04:42.614 --> 00:04:48.058
Or a more complex, a metric instead
that we call a composite metric.

90
00:04:48.058 --> 00:04:51.948
And we'll talk about how that's actually
done and we'll spend a bit of time here.

91
00:04:51.948 --> 00:04:56.300
Because, yes, they do like this particular
one and yes you do need to know it.

92
00:04:56.300 --> 00:05:01.290
So, we'll spend a bit of time and take and
look at the idea of the metric, okay.

93
00:05:01.290 --> 00:05:03.820
The other thing here as you start to do it

94
00:05:03.820 --> 00:05:07.920
is that it is actually really
designed to be less aggressive.

95
00:05:07.920 --> 00:05:11.660
Or less intensive I should say for
a router.

96
00:05:11.660 --> 00:05:15.880
So the CPU utilization on this
is not like what we saw in Rip,

97
00:05:15.880 --> 00:05:19.840
where it's handing out the routing
table every 30 seconds.

98
00:05:19.840 --> 00:05:23.410
And it's actually even
less intensive than OSPF

99
00:05:23.410 --> 00:05:27.540
which essentially does that topology
table exchange every 30 minutes.

100
00:05:27.540 --> 00:05:30.120
Okay, EIGRP, it actually says,

101
00:05:30.120 --> 00:05:33.890
look, we're gonna update the routing
table once, the first time.

102
00:05:33.890 --> 00:05:35.580
In other words, give you a full update.

103
00:05:35.580 --> 00:05:38.830
But from that point on,
we'll just update when changes happen.

104
00:05:38.830 --> 00:05:41.750
So it's no longer really
ever sending you a brand

105
00:05:41.750 --> 00:05:44.410
new copy of the full routing table.

106
00:05:44.410 --> 00:05:46.660
Unless a change has happened or

107
00:05:46.660 --> 00:05:51.980
you've been added in to the EIGRP
routing domain unto itself as well.

108
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:54.870
So it is less intensive in
what it does right there too.

109
00:05:54.870 --> 00:05:57.940
The other thing that it does is that

110
00:05:57.940 --> 00:06:02.000
when something ends up happening
that changes in the network.

111
00:06:02.000 --> 00:06:09.240
It doesn't automatically have to rerun
its algorithm to pick a new route, okay?

112
00:06:09.240 --> 00:06:12.759
Atashi kinda replace the old best route.

113
00:06:12.759 --> 00:06:16.617
What it does is determines not only
the first place route that will get you to

114
00:06:16.617 --> 00:06:17.853
the best destination.

115
00:06:17.853 --> 00:06:20.240
But also determines kinda
the second place guide.

116
00:06:20.240 --> 00:06:22.720
This is, hey, here's the first best route,

117
00:06:22.720 --> 00:06:26.040
here's the second best
route that's not there.

118
00:06:26.040 --> 00:06:28.670
And it'll keep attract of both.

119
00:06:28.670 --> 00:06:32.650
If for one reason the first router
goes down because of interface.

120
00:06:32.650 --> 00:06:34.220
It just goes in and reaches in and

121
00:06:34.220 --> 00:06:37.180
says all right where's the second
place guy and it replaces.

122
00:06:37.180 --> 00:06:38.990
So it's sort of like the beauty
queen contest right?

123
00:06:38.990 --> 00:06:41.520
In case you cannot serve
out the full term,

124
00:06:41.520 --> 00:06:44.705
the runner-up will actually end
up serving the rest of your term.

125
00:06:44.705 --> 00:06:47.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> It does the same thing, okay?

126
00:06:47.010 --> 00:06:50.240
So that's what it does so
that's another benefit.

127
00:06:50.240 --> 00:06:53.220
And then,
one of the final benefits that you and

128
00:06:53.220 --> 00:06:56.320
I are probably not gonna ever
really understand it right now.

129
00:06:56.320 --> 00:07:00.460
But as you start to move towards
more of the routing redistribution

130
00:07:00.460 --> 00:07:02.690
towards your CCNP route.

131
00:07:02.690 --> 00:07:09.260
It does what we call unequal costs of
load balancing as well, in OSPF and rip.

132
00:07:09.260 --> 00:07:12.280
You and I can do what we call
equal cost load bouncing.

133
00:07:12.280 --> 00:07:15.980
The very fact is that there is gonna
be you might have more than one route

134
00:07:15.980 --> 00:07:17.730
where the actual metric is identical.

135
00:07:17.730 --> 00:07:21.502
What is identical it gets
put into the routing table.

136
00:07:21.502 --> 00:07:23.560
And then you can take
either path to get there.

137
00:07:23.560 --> 00:07:26.980
Same thing with OSPF,
you can do that and by default, right?

138
00:07:26.980 --> 00:07:31.729
In OSPF you can actually have up to
I think it starts off with four.

139
00:07:31.729 --> 00:07:34.100
In terms of equal cost load balancing and

140
00:07:34.100 --> 00:07:37.720
you can configure it up to
a max of 16 if you want to.

141
00:07:37.720 --> 00:07:40.340
In EIGRP,
it starts off default load balancing,

142
00:07:40.340 --> 00:07:42.180
which is what we expect it to do.

143
00:07:42.180 --> 00:07:43.660
But if we wanted to,

144
00:07:43.660 --> 00:07:48.300
if we really wanted to,
we could do unequal cost load balancing.

145
00:07:48.300 --> 00:07:51.780
By adding in a variance
number that will also say.

146
00:07:51.780 --> 00:07:56.153
Here's what else we want to include in
as part of this load balancing factor,

147
00:07:56.153 --> 00:07:57.109
if we choose to.

148
00:07:57.109 --> 00:08:01.840
So it is amazing in all
the stuff that it actually does.

149
00:08:01.840 --> 00:08:03.826
Now, what are the drawbacks, okay?

150
00:08:03.826 --> 00:08:08.638
There's not a lot of drawbacks today
except for, well, a couple, okay?

151
00:08:08.638 --> 00:08:12.813
Historically, EIGRP
when it first came out,

152
00:08:12.813 --> 00:08:16.356
it was only Cisco proprietary, okay?

153
00:08:16.356 --> 00:08:21.070
Now the neat thing is, right,
is it a sophisticated routing protocol?

154
00:08:21.070 --> 00:08:25.460
It is, it's even more
sophisticated than what OSPF does.

155
00:08:25.460 --> 00:08:30.270
Now even though it's more sophisticated,
it's not as popular because OSPF is

156
00:08:30.270 --> 00:08:34.290
open standard, and that means it
can run between multiple vendors.

157
00:08:34.290 --> 00:08:38.127
You don't only have to have Cisco running,
you can do whatever equipment you want to.

158
00:08:38.127 --> 00:08:42.726
As long as it's supported by the IEEE
standard, it will actually end up running.

159
00:08:42.726 --> 00:08:46.169
So EIGRP though,
because of how sophisticated it was,

160
00:08:46.169 --> 00:08:51.660
it would run incredibly well, and it was
designed of course for Cisco equipment.

161
00:08:51.660 --> 00:08:53.840
They of course made it Cisco proprietary.

162
00:08:53.840 --> 00:08:57.043
Again, this would make the adoption for
Cisco a lot easier and

163
00:08:57.043 --> 00:08:59.083
their routing protocol more popular.

164
00:08:59.083 --> 00:09:02.942
So as sophisticated as it is and
as much as we can actually do with it,

165
00:09:02.942 --> 00:09:06.980
it really didn't become as popular
as they thought it would be.

166
00:09:06.980 --> 00:09:10.950
But it is, it's by far still probably one
of the more superior routing protocols

167
00:09:10.950 --> 00:09:12.190
that we can run.

168
00:09:12.190 --> 00:09:16.780
And it's really not a lot different,
it does actually save a lot here, okay?

169
00:09:16.780 --> 00:09:19.990
Now in saying that,
what's starting to happen?

170
00:09:19.990 --> 00:09:24.710
Well, back in 2013, Cisco opened this up,
it said, look, we're not gonna make

171
00:09:24.710 --> 00:09:29.870
EIGRP itself only Cisco proprietary.

172
00:09:29.870 --> 00:09:33.720
Now let's kind of pump the breaks here for
a moment, cuz that's not, all right,

173
00:09:33.720 --> 00:09:36.440
let's open the doors and
let's make it happen here.

174
00:09:36.440 --> 00:09:37.920
But when they released this, and

175
00:09:37.920 --> 00:09:42.870
they actually put it out to the IEEE
standard here as making it open standard.

176
00:09:42.870 --> 00:09:48.620
They only allowed for the most basic
functions of EIGRP to be non-proprietary.

177
00:09:48.620 --> 00:09:51.940
So in other words,
they didn't actually open up everything.

178
00:09:51.940 --> 00:09:56.740
It was like, all right, here's partially
what we're allowing to be open standard.

179
00:09:56.740 --> 00:09:59.990
But if you wanna run the more
advanced stuff, the more

180
00:09:59.990 --> 00:10:05.150
sophisticated things that EIGRP can do,
you still have to go all Cisco, okay?

181
00:10:05.150 --> 00:10:07.627
So it was kind of an open door, but

182
00:10:07.627 --> 00:10:13.039
it does actually allow it to be a little
more put out there into the world.

183
00:10:13.039 --> 00:10:18.048
To be adopted a little more easier and
to become a more standardized protocol.

184
00:10:18.048 --> 00:10:19.780
So up into 2013,

185
00:10:19.780 --> 00:10:24.260
that's what essentially ended up happening
when we started to see that, okay?

186
00:10:24.260 --> 00:10:29.700
Now, there's only one other thing that we
wanna talk about, so what is EIGRP, okay?

187
00:10:29.700 --> 00:10:33.250
Well, is it what you normally hear about,
okay?

188
00:10:33.250 --> 00:10:38.880
The terminology has gone back and forth
over the years between the term advanced

189
00:10:38.880 --> 00:10:45.080
distance vector, okay, to the term hybrid,
to the term balanced hybrid.

190
00:10:45.080 --> 00:10:47.930
You name it,
everybody's called it something different.

191
00:10:47.930 --> 00:10:50.550
In Cisco terminology and
Cisco documentation,

192
00:10:50.550 --> 00:10:53.720
it's called different over time and
over the years here.

193
00:10:53.720 --> 00:10:58.290
Okay, so yeah,
whatever term it is is what it is.

194
00:10:58.290 --> 00:11:00.760
So when I first started learning about it,

195
00:11:00.760 --> 00:11:04.938
it was considered what they call
an advanced distance vector protocol.

196
00:11:04.938 --> 00:11:05.870
And that meant, look,

197
00:11:05.870 --> 00:11:10.770
let's recognize the fact that at
the heart of it, it's still IGRP, okay?

198
00:11:10.770 --> 00:11:14.650
It still does the basic
function at the very beginning

199
00:11:14.650 --> 00:11:17.970
of the process as we talk about here,
and you'll see it in a moment.

200

>> Active, okay, that's what you and

>> So it's actually very different, right?

I'm not having to learn about this,

Passive is actually the one that

okay, that's what we're seeing here, okay?

448

If you see Active,

Both the best possible route and

FD stands for

This always used to confuse me when

This idea of the codes, the routing codes,
so why the heck didn't they use E?

And then if you're missing a route in the

I went through a tremendous amount

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie, continue with EIGRP details.  The guys discuss the metric weights and how EIGRP metric works.  They also demonstrate how to determine the metric using the EIGRP formula, providing examples.
episodes.title: Understand EIGRP Concepts and Operations Part 2

3

4

5

helping you learn everywhere you go.

6

I'm your host Zach Memos for
this episode of CCNA routing and

7
00:00:20.406 --> 00:00:22.973

8
00:00:22.973 --> 00:00:28.095
This is understanding IGRP concepts and
operations, part two.

9

There is more coming your way and
the one and

only Ronnie Wong is

11

Ronnie, thanks so much.

12
