>> Well, Zach, thank you again for

13
00:00:34.563 --> 00:00:38.570
having me back on the show as we continue
together with CCMP and routing, CCMA.

14
00:00:38.570 --> 00:00:40.037
I did it again.

15
00:00:40.037 --> 00:00:42.572
CCMA routing and
switching here is what we're

16
00:00:42.572 --> 00:00:45.890
actually continuing on with in
getting ready for that exam.

17
00:00:45.890 --> 00:00:49.270
So we are taking a look at EIGRP.

18
00:00:49.270 --> 00:00:51.779
I'm gonna not actually
say any of these letters.

19
00:00:51.779 --> 00:00:52.427
EIGRP and

20
00:00:52.427 --> 00:00:58.020
we're now at this point where we need to
dive a little bit deeper into this metric.

21
00:00:58.020 --> 00:00:58.599
>> Deeper we go.

22
00:00:58.599 --> 00:01:03.146
>> Because it is one of the things that
makes EIGRP the more sophisticated

23
00:01:03.146 --> 00:01:05.004
protocol that it is, okay?

24
00:01:05.004 --> 00:01:08.328
So we need to make sure that
we are able to do that.

25
00:01:08.328 --> 00:01:12.862
Now before we get started, let's make sure
we review what we've already talked about

26
00:01:12.862 --> 00:01:14.922
in the previous episode just briefly.

27
00:01:14.922 --> 00:01:17.430
And then we'll jump into trying
to determine the metric and

28
00:01:17.430 --> 00:01:20.892
trying to make sure that we understand all
the other things that we have to actually

29
00:01:20.892 --> 00:01:22.160
take a look at here.

30
00:01:22.160 --> 00:01:24.473
So let's go ahead and do that, okay?

31
00:01:24.473 --> 00:01:28.134
So right here on my screen, this is some
of the stuff that we did talk about here.

32
00:01:28.134 --> 00:01:32.394
The very fact that EIGRP maintains,
essentially, three tables.

33
00:01:32.394 --> 00:01:34.802
We even showed you that
inside of our lab settings so

34
00:01:34.802 --> 00:01:36.710
that you understood what had to happen.

35
00:01:36.710 --> 00:01:41.046
We learned for neighbor discovery,
what happened with EIGRP, you have to have

36
00:01:41.046 --> 00:01:44.996
hellos but in those hellos you also
have to have matching information for

37
00:01:44.996 --> 00:01:46.435
us as we start doing this.

38
00:01:46.435 --> 00:01:47.620
I want to make sure I'm
actually telling you right.

39
00:01:47.620 --> 00:01:48.305
Yep, there it is.

40
00:01:48.305 --> 00:01:50.600
AS number and K metrics, okay?

41
00:01:50.600 --> 00:01:54.666
Those things have to actually match if
you're gonna be doing neighbor discovery.

42
00:01:54.666 --> 00:01:57.530
If those don't match,
you're not gonna discover new neighbors.

43
00:01:57.530 --> 00:01:59.380
Pretty much is what we have there, okay?

44
00:01:59.380 --> 00:02:03.768
And that is essential because we're not
gonna exchange any other information if we

45
00:02:03.768 --> 00:02:05.093
don't have a neighbor.

46
00:02:05.093 --> 00:02:09.820
But by comparison, it's not as
complex as what we saw in OSPF.

47
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:13.380
And we kind of lingered on that for
a little bit of time.

48
00:02:13.380 --> 00:02:15.810
You don't have to worry
about neighbor states or

49
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:17.620
a bunch of other matching information.

50
00:02:17.620 --> 00:02:22.650
AS number is primarily the key unless
you're messing around with the K metrics

51
00:02:22.650 --> 00:02:25.570
on purpose,
which most of us are not going to do.

52
00:02:25.570 --> 00:02:27.083
>> No.

53
00:02:27.083 --> 00:02:28.410
>> If you're not gonna do that,

54
00:02:28.410 --> 00:02:31.289
then it's probably just only AS
number when it comes down to it.

55
00:02:31.289 --> 00:02:35.431
Okay, once they do become neighbors then,
then they will actually exchange

56
00:02:35.431 --> 00:02:38.935
the topology information that
the routers actually need to, and

57
00:02:38.935 --> 00:02:42.530
they'll end up building what
they call a topology table.

58
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:47.290
A topology table is just pretty
much an entire database, right,

59
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:52.321
of every possible route that all of
the routers actually know about.

60
00:02:52.321 --> 00:02:57.864
So instead of us having to actually get
this information from one update source,

61
00:02:57.864 --> 00:03:01.450
in OSPF we call that the DR,
the designated router,

62
00:03:01.450 --> 00:03:05.872
EIGRP very quickly and
efficiently does this using multicast.

63
00:03:05.872 --> 00:03:08.540
And here is the new information that
I probably didn't mention that I

64
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:09.095
should have.

65
00:03:09.095 --> 00:03:13.945
Is that it does it over an IP
address of 224.0.0.10 if I'm

66
00:03:13.945 --> 00:03:16.593
actually telling you, yep, 10.

67
00:03:16.593 --> 00:03:19.201
I just wanna make sure cuz
I do get those confused.

68
00:03:19.201 --> 00:03:25.610
The OSPF actually did 224.0.0.5, and
then RIP is 224.0.0.9 if I remember right.

69
00:03:25.610 --> 00:03:27.400
But this is .10.

70
00:03:27.400 --> 00:03:31.850
So the topology information is
sent as a multicast to do so, but

71
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:34.400
using reliable transport protocol or RTP.

72
00:03:34.400 --> 00:03:38.181
At the very beginning it
does a full update, okay?

73
00:03:38.181 --> 00:03:40.980
So it sends everything
over to its neighbor.

74
00:03:40.980 --> 00:03:43.490
But then from that point,
it only updates when needed.

75
00:03:43.490 --> 00:03:45.713
So you only get partial
updates from that point.

76
00:03:45.713 --> 00:03:47.647
So if the neighbor ship drops and
you come back up,

77
00:03:47.647 --> 00:03:50.103
you're considered a full neighbor,
or a new neighbor again.

78
00:03:50.103 --> 00:03:51.656
Then you'll get a full update, okay?

79
00:03:51.656 --> 00:03:56.272
That shouldn't happen too often, but if it
does, that's what will end up happening.

80
00:03:56.272 --> 00:03:59.906
Finally, after everything
is actually exchanged and

81
00:03:59.906 --> 00:04:04.804
you now have this new full topology
table inside of your router for EIGRP,

82
00:04:04.804 --> 00:04:09.939
at that point, you'll run through the dual
algorithm to be able to determine

83
00:04:09.939 --> 00:04:14.840
what is the best possible route to
any particular destination out there.

84
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:18.340
And that is the route that will get
entered into the routing table.

85
00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:22.783
And we talked about this idea that there
is some specific terminology to EIGRP, and

86
00:04:22.783 --> 00:04:27.730
that best route is not just called a best
route, it's called a successor, okay?

87
00:04:27.730 --> 00:04:33.117
And if it is possible, you will also
determine a feasible successor, okay?

88
00:04:33.117 --> 00:04:35.960

00:28:41.541 --> 00:28:42.805
so they're both equal.

545
00:28:42.805 --> 00:28:47.085
So, it doesn't matter which one, you then
take delay and you divide those by 10,

546
00:28:47.085 --> 00:28:48.244
10 and 10 is 20.

547
00:28:48.244 --> 00:28:53.364
Add that and then we multiply that by 256,
and now you start to see where,

548
00:28:53.364 --> 00:28:58.404
this particular number down here, and
off course then router A in the EIGRP

549
00:28:58.404 --> 00:29:03.680
in the routing table, he would off
course end up selecting this one.

550
00:29:03.680 --> 00:29:06.330
Now, you may I should say I could
have seen that just by looking at

551
00:29:06.330 --> 00:29:10.770
the diagram by realising, that yes the one

552
00:29:10.770 --> 00:29:14.580
with the fastest bandwidth there,
is probably the way to go.

553
00:29:14.580 --> 00:29:16.350
>> Right.
>> But could you prove it?

554
00:29:16.350 --> 00:29:20.120
Okay, if they don't give you that
could you actually prove it?

555
00:29:20.120 --> 00:29:21.410
Yes, you can.

556
00:29:21.410 --> 00:29:24.890
So, you need at least that
information to do so.

557
00:29:24.890 --> 00:29:28.370
But if they ask you about this, like which
of these metrics is actually gonna be,

558
00:29:28.370 --> 00:29:32.460
or it is possible right, that they could
say, hey, what is the metric here for

559
00:29:32.460 --> 00:29:34.720
one of these links to be able to do this.

560
00:29:34.720 --> 00:29:38.530
And they might give you the majority of
this, but you have to figure out which one

561
00:29:38.530 --> 00:29:42.580
might get entered in to the routing
table to be able to do that.

562
00:29:42.580 --> 00:29:46.430
So, just realize it is a possibility,
okay.

563
00:29:46.430 --> 00:29:49.020
Now, that we've determined
the idea of the metric,

564
00:29:49.020 --> 00:29:54.430
we know how the routing table get build,
but that's only a part of how EIGRP works.

565
00:29:54.430 --> 00:29:58.840
Because EIGRP really wants us to be
a very static and stable network.

566
00:29:58.840 --> 00:30:02.220
It also now needs to
determine other things

567
00:30:02.220 --> 00:30:04.850
based off of the metric
that we just learned about.

568
00:30:04.850 --> 00:30:09.306
That's actually going to be for another
episode, because as I look at Zach,

569
00:30:09.306 --> 00:30:10.413
we are out of time.

570
00:30:10.413 --> 00:30:12.710
That means that we have to continue
this on in another episode.

571
00:30:12.710 --> 00:30:17.637
>> Understanding IGRP concepts and
operations, part three.

572
00:30:17.637 --> 00:30:19.590
I guess, we'll be coming [LAUGH] your way.

573
00:30:19.590 --> 00:30:20.780
Make sure you see part one and part two.

574
00:30:20.780 --> 00:30:22.365
They are very important as well and,

575
00:30:22.365 --> 00:30:24.160
Ronnie, anything else you'd
like to say before we go in?

576
00:30:24.160 --> 00:30:25.740
>> Well, just remember, right?

577
00:30:25.740 --> 00:30:28.940
We're not showing you this just to make
sure that your mind is blown [LAUGH].

578
00:30:28.940 --> 00:30:29.630
I know.

579
00:30:29.630 --> 00:30:31.970
But I do need to show you
the background minus.

580
00:30:31.970 --> 00:30:35.440
There is no need for you to accept
information just blindly and for

581
00:30:35.440 --> 00:30:36.980
me to say trust me on this.

582
00:30:36.980 --> 00:30:37.600
Okay?

583
00:30:37.600 --> 00:30:41.430
So, we're trying to shwo you eevry part
that we can, so that you do have a good

584
00:30:41.430 --> 00:30:46.240
solid basis of why decisions
are being made the way that they are.

585
00:30:46.240 --> 00:30:47.760
That you have to understand this.

586
00:30:47.760 --> 00:30:51.235
So, this by far the wildest metrics
that you and I have actually seen.

587
00:30:51.235 --> 00:30:52.790
>> Mm-hm.
>> In Rip it was very simple,

588
00:30:52.790 --> 00:30:53.740
Hop Count, okay?

589
00:30:53.740 --> 00:30:56.300
>> Right.
>> In OSPF it was essentially based off of

590
00:30:56.300 --> 00:30:57.340
bandwidth, right?

591
00:30:57.340 --> 00:30:59.930
Reference bandwidth divided
by the actual bandwidth.

592
00:30:59.930 --> 00:31:01.400
>> Right.
>> This time though,

593
00:31:01.400 --> 00:31:04.000
the formula is a little bit
more complicated, okay?

594
00:31:04.000 --> 00:31:05.510
So, we can say that.

595
00:31:05.510 --> 00:31:09.350
And this is why it actually gives you
much better metrics in between and

596
00:31:09.350 --> 00:31:11.620
actual calculations that are based.

597
00:31:11.620 --> 00:31:13.130
And you will see wild numbers like this.

598
00:31:13.130 --> 00:31:16.700
There is no doubt that you can see
numbers that are just this crazy.

599
00:31:16.700 --> 00:31:19.000
A lot of times it may not
be in the 40 millions, or

600
00:31:19.000 --> 00:31:21.800
so, cuz mine is just kind
of a whipped up diagram.

601
00:31:21.800 --> 00:31:23.140
But you may see the hundred thousands.

602
00:31:23.140 --> 00:31:24.130
You may see the millions.

603
00:31:24.130 --> 00:31:25.540
It does happen.

604
00:31:25.540 --> 00:31:26.800
So, don't think it can't.

605
00:31:26.800 --> 00:31:28.800
It really is possibly out there.

606
00:31:28.800 --> 00:31:33.319
>> Great advice, well said, well taught,
and make sure you see every episode of

607
00:31:33.319 --> 00:31:36.893
the CCNA Routing and
Switching Exam 200-105 series.

608
00:31:36.893 --> 00:31:39.235
You're gonna be so glad that you did.

609

It's gonna help you out in the long run
and you'll be in the course library.

610

There's lots os other videos
there that will help you.

611
00:31:45.550 --> 00:31:46.270
Don't further.

612
00:31:46.270 --> 00:31:47.620
Check those out too.

613
00:31:47.620 --> 00:31:51.760
And tell everybody you know about ITPROTV,
you know, ITPROTV is binge worthy.

614
00:31:51.760 --> 00:31:53.100
Thanks for watching I'm Zach Memes.

615
00:31:53.100 --> 00:31:53.780
>> And I'm Ronny Wong.

616

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:05.763
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2

[MUSIC]

3

4
00:00:11.739 --> 00:00:17.240
>> Hello and thank you for watching ITPro
TV, helping you learn everywhere you go.

5
00:00:17.240 --> 00:00:18.250
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

6
00:00:18.250 --> 00:00:23.500
For this episode of CCNA Routing and
Switching, Exam 200-105, and

7
00:00:23.500 --> 00:00:29.480
Understand EIGRP Concepts and Operations
Part 3 is the title of this episode.

8
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:32.208
More EIGRP goodness coming our way and
Ronnie Wong is gonna help us out.

9
00:00:32.208 --> 00:00:33.796
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ronnie Wong, good to see you, sir.

10
00:00:33.796 --> 00:00:35.552
>> Well, Zach, thank you again for

11
00:00:35.552 --> 00:00:39.610
having me back as we continue on our
CCNA routing and switching show.

12
00:00:39.610 --> 00:00:43.753
We are now taking a look at well a few
other details that we have to know

13
00:00:43.753 --> 00:00:47.769
about the operational nature as
well as those concepts in EIGRP.

14
00:00:47.769 --> 00:00:51.273
We already talked about the one that's
probably the most confusing to everybody

15
00:00:51.273 --> 00:00:52.470
as they first get started.

16
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:54.276
>> The formula.
>> And it begins to overwhelm them,

17
00:00:54.276 --> 00:00:55.570
which is the EIGRP formula.

18
00:00:55.570 --> 00:00:59.500
But we broke it down,
we showed you how to calculate them and

19
00:00:59.500 --> 00:01:03.590
how to determine what the best
route can actually end up being.

20
00:01:03.590 --> 00:01:07.739
So that is where we are going to pick up,
and there's a bit more for

21
00:01:07.739 --> 00:01:12.733
us to actually understand in the rest
of the operational process here, okay?

22
00:01:12.733 --> 00:01:16.990
So let's go back and we'll take a look
here at what we ended up with, okay?

23
00:01:16.990 --> 00:01:20.640
So here,
at the very end of our previous episode,

24
00:01:20.640 --> 00:01:24.090
as we did the calculations and
went through the formula, right?

25
00:01:24.090 --> 00:01:26.260
We saw how everything
ended up reducing and

26
00:01:26.260 --> 00:01:29.270
then we of course did a couple
of different examples here.

27
00:01:29.270 --> 00:01:31.930
We actually did one and
I kind of showed you the rest of these.

28
00:01:31.930 --> 00:01:33.500
But of course you can actually go back and

29
00:01:33.500 --> 00:01:37.480
do them on your own as well to make
sure that you understand, okay?

30
00:01:37.480 --> 00:01:43.030
Now, when we calculate everything out, you
start to now see the idea of the metric

31
00:01:43.030 --> 00:01:49.520
in EIGRP and how each individual router
calculates its best possible path

32
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:54.330
to network F, okay, or to the router E,
whatever you want to call it, okay?

33
00:01:54.330 --> 00:01:57.660
It doesn't really end up
mattering at this point, okay?

34
00:01:57.660 --> 00:02:01.300
But what does actually matter
is that once we get that, well,

35
00:02:01.300 --> 00:02:03.270
what ends up happening, okay?

36
00:02:03.270 --> 00:02:06.980
Well, at this particular point,
what we actually do of course then is that

37
00:02:06.980 --> 00:02:11.840
the one with the best metric right here,
okay,

38
00:02:11.840 --> 00:02:16.410
that we give technically
another name in EIGRP.

39
00:02:16.410 --> 00:02:18.770
And that is what's called the successor.

40
00:02:22.261 --> 00:02:29.015
Successor, so the successor route is,
of course, an EIGRP.

41
00:02:29.015 --> 00:02:33.831
The actual route that has the best
possible metric to any one

42
00:02:33.831 --> 00:02:38.950
particular destination that
we have ready to go, okay?

43
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:41.270
Now once we actually determine that,
though,

44
00:02:41.270 --> 00:02:46.400
we are not done, because the very
fact is it doesn't actually

45
00:02:46.400 --> 00:02:51.885
want to do this every time that there is a
possibility of some change in the network.

46
00:02:51.885 --> 00:02:56.705
What it wants to do is to also be
able to calculate what we call

47
00:02:56.705 --> 00:03:00.615
the idea of a feasible successor as well,
okay?

48
00:03:00.615 --> 00:03:04.865
But for us to do so,
we need more than one metric here, okay?

49
00:03:04.865 --> 00:03:08.130
So, for us,
we showed you how to actually determine

50
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:12.990
the entire metric from
the beginning to the end, okay?

51
00:03:12.990 --> 00:03:18.750
So, when we actually route all the way
through, and that's what happens,

52
00:03:18.750 --> 00:03:23.168
you end up with what we call
the feasible distance, okay?

53
00:03:23.168 --> 00:03:26.980
So this is EIGRP terminology here, okay?

54
00:03:26.980 --> 00:03:29.760
The metric from the actual
source to the destination.

55
00:03:31.230 --> 00:03:33.240
From source to the destination.

56
00:03:41.373 --> 00:03:45.956
And that is called the feasible distance,
okay?

57
00:03:45.956 --> 00:03:49.301
So that takes into account all the PaaS
that are actually in between all

58
00:03:49.301 --> 00:03:52.532
the routers that are in between
the interfaces and the bandwidth and

59
00:03:52.532 --> 00:03:53.840
everything else.

60
00:03:53.840 --> 00:03:56.810
What we calculated out right here
is what we called that idea,

61
00:03:56.810 --> 00:03:58.940
the feasible distance.

62
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:02.500
But for us to also determine,

63
00:04:02.500 --> 00:04:07.190
is there a possibility of what
we call that first runner up?

64
00:04:07.190 --> 00:04:10.330
We also need another metric
that comes in as well.

65
00:04:11.410 --> 00:04:15.280
And that is when we change this up,
so now I've reduced it down, and

66
00:04:15.280 --> 00:04:19.050
now we have the feasible distances
instead just listed right here.

67
00:04:19.050 --> 00:04:23.248
We know the entire distance from where we
were here on router A going all the way

68
00:04:23.248 --> 00:04:24.293
through router E.

69
00:04:24.293 --> 00:04:29.546
We now need to also talk about the idea
of the reported distance, okay?

70
00:04:29.546 --> 00:04:31.400
The order terminology, or

71
00:04:31.400 --> 00:04:36.560
what is called the reported distance here,
it used to be called advertised distance.

72
00:04:36.560 --> 00:04:37.792
>> Right.
>> So the problem is there was some

73
00:04:37.792 --> 00:04:38.480
confusion, right?

74
00:04:38.480 --> 00:04:41.020
AD is also for administrative distance.

75
00:04:41.020 --> 00:04:45.040
And then EIGRP they also added an AD for
advertised distance.

76
00:04:45.040 --> 00:04:46.650
>> Dear.
>> So after a while the terminology did

77
00:04:46.650 --> 00:04:50.960
change and most people started to accept
it and calling it reported distance.

78
00:04:50.960 --> 00:04:53.940
Now, what is the reported distance about,
okay?

79
00:04:53.940 --> 00:04:58.990
Well, if I want to determine
the possibility of a feasible successor,

80
00:04:58.990 --> 00:05:00.080
in other words, the runner up.

81
00:05:00.080 --> 00:05:01.510
I'm trying to get everything
out of the way so

82
00:05:01.510 --> 00:05:04.200
that we can see everything without
me having to keep clicking on

83
00:05:04.200 --> 00:05:05.680
the wrong stuff.

84
00:05:05.680 --> 00:05:11.110
Okay, for us to be able to determine that,
now that I had the feasible distance,

85
00:05:11.110 --> 00:05:16.150
I also can determine what other
things along the path do.

86
00:05:16.150 --> 00:05:19.990
I might want to determine the idea of
what we call this reported distance,

87
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:24.380
which is gonna be the other routers
that are along the path too.

88
00:05:24.380 --> 00:05:30.660
So each one of these, so B, C, and D,
all of them going to router E over here.

89
00:05:30.660 --> 00:05:34.540
They can also do that same calculation

90
00:05:34.540 --> 00:05:37.428
to determine their distance to
the destination as well, okay?

91
00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:43.625
So when they do something like that
let's say from B to E here, okay?

92
00:05:43.625 --> 00:05:48.685
So here is the actual distance that
I ended up calculating by itself and

93
00:05:48.685 --> 00:05:53.490
you'll see that when it calculated
this particular distance, so

94
00:05:53.490 --> 00:05:59.710
the original all the way through is
actually going to be 2,682,031, okay?

95
00:05:59.710 --> 00:06:04.588
But if you only take part of
that distance, okay, B to E, and

96
00:06:04.588 --> 00:06:07.938
you do the same mathematical algorithm,

97
00:06:07.938 --> 00:06:12.455
what I actually ended
up with was 2,170,031.

98
00:06:12.455 --> 00:06:16.759
So notice that this reported
distance is gonna be less than what

99
00:06:16.759 --> 00:06:20.310
the feasible distance is going to be,
okay?

100
00:06:20.310 --> 00:06:23.520
And if you think about it,
this should make sense.

101
00:06:23.520 --> 00:06:29.500
In my path from A all the way to
network E, okay, that distance

102
00:06:29.500 --> 00:06:32.908
if I go somewhere in between it doesn't
matter if it's actually 50/50 or not.

103
00:06:32.908 --> 00:06:38.190
If I go somewhere in between that,
whatever the distance actually is here,

104
00:06:38.190 --> 00:06:43.550
okay, that number should be
less than my entire route path,

105
00:06:43.550 --> 00:06:45.290
which is the metric here, okay?

106
00:06:46.348 --> 00:06:49.370
What happens, though, if this number

107
00:06:49.370 --> 00:06:55.070
happens to actually be greater
than the actual feasible distance?

108
00:06:55.070 --> 00:06:57.940
Well more than likely that means
it's heading in the wrong direction.

109
00:06:57.940 --> 00:07:01.790
It's not actually heading towards network
F, it actually is probably heading towards

110
00:07:01.790 --> 00:07:05.100
something else over here on
the left-hand side, okay?

111
00:07:05.100 --> 00:07:10.035
So if the actual reported distance is
greater than my feasible distance,

112
00:07:10.035 --> 00:07:12.360
I'm not heading in the right direction,
okay?

113
00:07:12.360 --> 00:07:13.600
For my route path.

114
00:07:13.600 --> 00:07:17.650
So I shouldn't ever have that,
maybe possibly what?

115
00:07:17.650 --> 00:07:21.860
My next runner up,
if that were to happen, okay?

116
00:07:21.860 --> 00:07:24.780
So then, you would actually make sure
that that's what would happen, okay?

117
00:07:25.810 --> 00:07:28.970
Same thing here from router C to E.

118
00:07:28.970 --> 00:07:33.118
It too would run the same exact route,
and notice again,

119
00:07:33.118 --> 00:07:39.355
here on the left-hand side on
the feasible distance this is 40,537,600.

120
00:07:39.355 --> 00:07:46.445
And then over here on the right hand side,
this is 40,512,200 here, okay?

121
00:07:46.445 --> 00:07:50.073
And it's what we have as this
particular distance too, okay?

122
00:07:50.073 --> 00:07:52.997
So this one right here is almost equal but

123
00:07:52.997 --> 00:07:56.788
it is still less than what
this side would be, okay?

124
00:07:56.788 --> 00:08:00.173
So I know that this is
still a possible path too.

125
00:08:00.173 --> 00:08:02.171
The network that I'm going to, okay?

126
00:08:02.171 --> 00:08:07.230
And then of course lastly here,
D to E is the same thing.

127
00:08:07.230 --> 00:08:10.060
Notice the number's actually
less than what the actual

128
00:08:10.060 --> 00:08:12.740
feasible distance would be as well, okay?

129
00:08:12.740 --> 00:08:15.490
So we have to actually be
able to determine both.

130
00:08:15.490 --> 00:08:18.560
So reported distance normally is

131
00:08:18.560 --> 00:08:23.220
essentially what router
A is told by router D here.

132
00:08:23.220 --> 00:08:27.020
How far away it is from its destination,
okay?

133
00:08:27.020 --> 00:08:32.690
C is telling router A how far
away it is from the destination.

134
00:08:32.690 --> 00:08:37.559
Router B is telling router A how
far it is from the destination.

135
00:08:37.559 --> 00:08:40.510
So this is how it actually
can determine whether or

136
00:08:40.510 --> 00:08:44.237
not these paths are still along
the path to the destination, or

137
00:08:44.237 --> 00:08:48.560
whether they're actually heading
in the opposite direction.

138
00:08:48.560 --> 00:08:53.070
So the reported distance if it's greater,
it knows that it can actually be in

139
00:08:53.070 --> 00:08:56.480
the path towards the destination
there would be any good

140
00:08:56.480 --> 00:09:00.270
It essentially how she ends up assuming
something that is not along that path.

141
00:09:00.270 --> 00:09:01.610
And it drops down.

142
00:09:01.610 --> 00:09:05.080
So that is a part of something else
that we also have to be able to do.

143
00:09:05.080 --> 00:09:08.780
Now, if that happens that's
perfectly fine, okay?

144
00:09:08.780 --> 00:09:12.290
But that doesn't necessarily
mean that it will also become

145
00:09:12.290 --> 00:09:14.740
the feasible successor, okay?

146
00:09:14.740 --> 00:09:18.330
So it doesn't automatically
become the feasible successor.

147
00:09:20.040 --> 00:09:23.520
No, okay, so that is the key.

148
00:09:23.520 --> 00:09:26.080
Now remember that when we talked about
that idea of the feasible successor,

149
00:09:26.080 --> 00:09:29.200
it essentially is the next best route, but

150
00:09:29.200 --> 00:09:32.340
how do we determine what
the next best route would be?

151

then the number 2.

372
00:24:06.010 --> 00:24:11.750
Now if I do that,
the result of that will actually

373
00:24:11.750 --> 00:24:17.351
be where it takes the successors,
successor.

374
00:24:21.167 --> 00:24:24.220
Gosh, I can't believe I misspelled so
many different things in there.

00:24:24.220 --> 00:24:25.270
That what I get.

00:24:25.270 --> 00:24:28.320
And also my mind and
my eyes start looking towards.

00:24:28.320 --> 00:24:33.183
It takes the successor's feasible
distance and multiplies it.

Multiplies it by the variance number,
*variance number.

379
00:24:43.421 --> 00:24:46.271
Variance number.

00:24:51.491 --> 00:24:53.173
And in our situation here.

00:25:03.343 --> 00:25:04.525
Let me clear that out.

382
00:25:08.320 --> 00:25:13.609
So what it would do is take 261120.

383
00:25:15.809 --> 00:25:17.516
260, crap.

384
00:25:17.516 --> 00:25:25.213
2 [LAUGH] 61,12*02.

00:25:25.213 --> 00:25:30.851
So if I do that, that now actually

00:25:30.851 --> 00:25:36.750
that also has a feasible
distance of 522,240 or less.

00:25:36.750 --> 00:25:40.810
So that would now, and
our little diagram here include,

00:25:40.810 --> 00:25:44.660
well both of these, is what that

00:25:44.660 --> 00:25:48.074
So if we were to do something like that,
that's what would end up happening.

390
00:25:48.074 --> 00:25:50.865
So that way I can load balance.

00:25:50.865 --> 00:25:52.915
Let me copy this here.

392
00:25:55.249 --> 00:25:59.860
And as I zoom in, trying to paste it here.

393
00:26:01.720 --> 00:26:05.280
So now that's what will happen, is that

00:26:05.280 --> 00:26:07.930
And I will go hey, let me put both ahead

00:26:07.930 --> 00:26:13.300

00:26:13.300 --> 00:26:13.910
>> Very good.

397
00:26:13.910 --> 00:26:16.396
>> Now, everybody always ask like okay, so

00:26:20.540 --> 00:26:23.215

00:26:26.700 --> 00:26:29.250
So if you actually chose

402

00:26:32.090 --> 00:26:34.550

00:26:34.550 --> 00:26:37.180

00:26:37.180 --> 00:26:41.780

00:26:41.780 --> 00:26:44.270
where you're not going to be

407
00:26:44.270 --> 00:26:48.010

408
00:26:48.010 --> 00:26:50.310
But on that one link you'll
pretty much destroy it.

409
00:26:51.310 --> 00:26:52.624
So you don't want it to do that.

410
00:26:52.624 --> 00:26:54.665
What you want to do instead,

00:26:54.665 --> 00:27:00.277

00:27:00.277 --> 00:27:05.145
well at least understandable why

413
00:27:05.145 --> 00:27:07.760
This is actually perfectly understandable.

414
00:27:07.760 --> 00:27:12.478
It actually goes hey wait a minute,

00:27:12.478 --> 00:27:13.620
Why not, okay?

It's not that much of a difference

00:27:16.460 --> 00:27:20.410
Why not go ahead and load balance

418
00:27:20.410 --> 00:27:23.285
But to actually add that third one

00:27:23.285 --> 00:27:24.230
But can you do it?

Yes, enter in a variance of 99, or

424

So the great thing is, we'll see just

That variance one at the end, is something

But just kinda realize,
that the only routing protocol for

00:27:56.530 --> 00:28:00.940

is gonna be EIGRP as well.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure an EIGRP routing domain for AS 800.  They show how to configure 3 routers to use EIGRP to adverstise routes.  The verify that the routers are learning routes via EIGRP.
episodes.title: Configure EIGRP for IPv4 ccna2018

us because it's a good guide in showing

And we're specifically really focusing

Of course, it's actually all about

NYCore 2,

And so

So we are gonna begin configuring

00:03:47.430 --> 00:03:50.218
Those were the two routers

00:03:50.218 --> 00:03:53.880
And what we see, so

76
00:03:53.880 --> 00:03:56.660
And this will go ahead and

77
00:03:58.060 --> 00:04:04.380
So here on NYEDGE1, let me get into,

78
00:04:04.380 --> 00:04:09.244
Let me get of the caps lock here, let me

00:04:09.244 --> 00:04:12.040
And then we are gonna go into

80
00:04:12.040 --> 00:04:15.960
The great thing is the configuration

00:04:15.960 --> 00:04:20.020
But there's a couple things we need

00:04:20.020 --> 00:04:21.440
right here, okay?

00:04:21.440 --> 00:04:24.340
So what we want to do is router EIGRP.

00:04:25.850 --> 00:04:31.220
And remember that what follows next is

00:04:31.220 --> 00:04:32.410

Area numbers are only

00:04:34.934 --> 00:04:39.247
And we're gonna give it

88
00:04:39.247 --> 00:04:43.290
From that point, now you can see that

00:04:43.290 --> 00:04:46.918
right here, that once we run that,

00:04:46.918 --> 00:04:50.060
just like it did for

91
00:04:50.060 --> 00:04:51.302
When we configure the router,

00:04:51.302 --> 00:04:55.850
config-router is what we'll

93
00:04:55.850 --> 00:04:56.570
>> Okay.

94
00:04:56.570 --> 00:04:59.030
>> So from this point,
we can start configuring.

95
00:04:59.030 --> 00:05:03.640
Now, we actually have two
possibilities here, okay,

96
00:05:03.640 --> 00:05:08.440
network, and then we actually will

97
00:05:09.640 --> 00:05:15.040
Notice it takes it, and we didn't have to

98
00:05:15.040 --> 00:05:17.170
Now, what other part we might add in?

99
00:05:17.170 --> 00:05:18.662
Well, let's add in another network, and

100
00:05:18.662 --> 00:05:20.493
I'll show you what I'm talking about here,

101
00:05:20.493 --> 00:05:24.839
So we're also configuring

00:05:24.839 --> 00:05:29.170
this time, if I do a question mark so

00:05:29.170 --> 00:05:32.930
Now, notice that fairly similar to OSPF,

00:05:32.930 --> 00:05:38.960

105
00:05:38.960 --> 00:05:41.560
Now, the reason why this
is actually important

00:05:41.560 --> 00:05:45.930
is because there's two reasons to

107
00:05:45.930 --> 00:05:51.740
So if I do this without the wild card mask
added in, notice it accepts it perfectly.

108
00:05:51.740 --> 00:05:52.770
It says, okay, that's fine.

109
00:05:52.770 --> 00:05:55.440
>> Right.
>> But then I can add it in with it, and

110
00:05:55.440 --> 00:05:58.330
so there is a reason why
you might choose to do so.

111
00:05:58.330 --> 00:06:00.376
There's a reason why you
might choose not to do so.

112
00:06:00.376 --> 00:06:02.808
But the reason why you choose not to do so

113
00:06:02.808 --> 00:06:07.701
is if you know that it's gonna fall
along those classful boundaries anyways.

114
00:06:07.701 --> 00:06:11.360
The class A, the class B and
the class C, okay?

115
00:06:11.360 --> 00:06:15.430
But if you actually are going to
go ahead and configure this, and

116
00:06:15.430 --> 00:06:20.570
let's say that you have this, which

117
00:06:20.570 --> 00:06:25.690
is 172.14.0 network, well that is
technically inside of class B.

118
00:06:25.690 --> 00:06:30.045
But I'm actually gonna say that
I'm using a 24bit subnet mask, so

119
00:06:30.045 --> 00:06:31.870
it's a class B network address, but

120
00:06:31.870 --> 00:06:35.480
I'm saying I'm actually using
a class C subnet mask at that point.

121
00:06:35.480 --> 00:06:39.670
Well, that is what now I'm doing,
what we call classless routing.

122
00:06:39.670 --> 00:06:43.840
So if your network supports
classless routing, okay?

123
00:06:43.840 --> 00:06:47.051
Then you need to include
in the wild card bits here.

124
00:06:47.051 --> 00:06:50.150
So let me copy this again and paste it.

125
00:06:50.150 --> 00:06:56.410
We're gonna add in a space, and then
we're gonna do a 24 bit wild card mask.

126

we're gonna actually do a variance here.

245
00:14:36.062 --> 00:14:38.440
And let's,
you may have to do this a couple times.

246
00:14:38.440 --> 00:14:40.850
I normally start with the lowest
possible number that I can.

247
00:14:40.850 --> 00:14:42.650
Let's do a variance of 2.

248
00:14:42.650 --> 00:14:43.748
Then do a show IP route.

249
00:14:47.639 --> 00:14:52.610
And then, let's do show 192.168.224.0.

250
00:14:53.763 --> 00:15:01.139
Okay, notice that that didn't
add anything else then, okay?

251
00:15:01.139 --> 00:15:06.252
So if that's actually not true,
let me do a no variance of 2.

252
00:15:06.252 --> 00:15:08.208
And then, let's do a variance of 4.

253
00:15:08.208 --> 00:15:12.239
So I like doing the even numbers cuz that
normally gets everything in there, but

254
00:15:12.239 --> 00:15:14.354
we'll see if this actually works, too.

255
00:15:14.354 --> 00:15:16.630
So at this point,
let me do this one more time.

256
00:15:17.810 --> 00:15:19.219
Not select that, and do it that way.

257
00:15:22.665 --> 00:15:27.520
So you'd have to watch me type
which is a scary thing unto itself.

258
00:15:27.520 --> 00:15:28.800
There we go, okay?

259
00:15:28.800 --> 00:15:30.440
So now notice the difference, right?

260
00:15:30.440 --> 00:15:33.890
So as I zoom in so
that we can see this, okay?

261
00:15:33.890 --> 00:15:38.410
Even with a variance of 2,
I doubled the actual metric, okay?

262
00:15:38.410 --> 00:15:43.383
To see if there was any other route that
I could, or any other path that I could

263
00:15:43.383 --> 00:15:48.309
actually get to that destination network,
192.168.2.24.

264
00:15:48.309 --> 00:15:50.316
Doubling the actual
successor didn't do it.

265
00:15:50.316 --> 00:15:56.102
But when I actually quadrupled it,
notice it actually added in another route.

266
00:15:56.102 --> 00:15:59.757
And if you look at,
it looks just about quadrupling,

267
00:15:59.757 --> 00:16:03.425
times four Of the actual
successor route to get here.

268
00:16:03.425 --> 00:16:05.171
So you can do that.

269
00:16:05.171 --> 00:16:10.283
But remember the goal is to get
the minimal variance number that you need,

270
00:16:10.283 --> 00:16:15.733
not the maximum variance number that you
need, to be able to get there, okay?

271
00:16:15.733 --> 00:16:20.591
All right, now last concept here for
EIGRP for IP version 4,

272
00:16:20.591 --> 00:16:27.510
which is the idea of the auto-summary is
what we wanna talk about as well, okay?

273
00:16:27.510 --> 00:16:31.320
So I just told you that the idea of
auto-summary, what it used to do,

274
00:16:31.320 --> 00:16:38.700
because EIGRP is based off of IGRP,
Cisco proprietary protocol.

275
00:16:38.700 --> 00:16:43.630
Well, those earliest networks always
auto-summarize to the classful

276
00:16:43.630 --> 00:16:45.390
boundary, okay?

277
00:16:45.390 --> 00:16:48.740
So if you actually took
a look at your networks,

278
00:16:48.740 --> 00:16:52.420
it didn't care if you actually had subnets
or not, cuz it didn't look at them.

279
00:16:52.420 --> 00:16:55.890
The only thing it actually looked
at is what the classful side was.

280
00:16:55.890 --> 00:17:00.786
So if for one reason or another,
you chose to do 172.16.16.0,

281
00:17:00.786 --> 00:17:03.129
and you thought that was 24 bits.

282
00:17:03.129 --> 00:17:06.472
EIGRP would just go I'm
looking at the 172.16,

283
00:17:06.472 --> 00:17:09.097
I don't care what the rest of it is, okay?

284
00:17:09.097 --> 00:17:12.918
Well that means every single network that
you might've had that would've actually

285
00:17:12.918 --> 00:17:16.926
began with those two, and then even if the
third octet was different, it didn't care.

286
00:17:16.926 --> 00:17:22.527
And that is because EIGRP was again,
by default, based off of IGRP,

287
00:17:22.527 --> 00:17:27.640
which said I do automatic
route summarization, okay?

288
00:17:27.640 --> 00:17:31.230
When the iOS version 15 came along,
they decided, look,

289
00:17:31.230 --> 00:17:36.115
it's now a time, we're just going to go
ahead and do a no auto-summary, okay?

290
00:17:36.115 --> 00:17:40.150
No auto-summary command
as the default instead.

291
00:17:40.150 --> 00:17:42.680
So if you need to do summarization,

292
00:17:42.680 --> 00:17:46.400
you now have to turn it on
instead of turning it off.

293
00:17:46.400 --> 00:17:51.291
For me when I first started with EIGRP,
it was kinda drilled into my head

294
00:17:51.291 --> 00:17:55.543
that you type in your router
EIGRP autonomous system number.

295
00:17:55.543 --> 00:18:00.005
The next command, just by doing that,
that you should always do,

296
00:18:00.005 --> 00:18:02.326
is just no auto-summary, okay?

297
00:18:02.326 --> 00:18:05.193
I mean, it was just like it
was one command altogether,

298
00:18:05.193 --> 00:18:06.417
even though it was two.

299
00:18:06.417 --> 00:18:09.671
But that what was drilled into me
as I was learning how to do this,

300
00:18:09.671 --> 00:18:11.072
because you never wanted.

301
00:18:11.072 --> 00:18:15.113
Especially in your networks which
there was always gonna be this idea

302
00:18:15.113 --> 00:18:17.930
of using essentially classless routing.

303
00:18:17.930 --> 00:18:22.280
You never wanted to make sure that it's
summarized anywhere, okay, except for

304
00:18:22.280 --> 00:18:23.850
where you wanted it to.

305
00:18:23.850 --> 00:18:27.360
But if auto-summary's turned on,
it summarizes on every single router.

306
00:18:27.360 --> 00:18:31.650
So what we want to do is actually ensure
that they're off and today in version 15,

307
00:18:31.650 --> 00:18:33.500
it's off by default.

308
00:18:33.500 --> 00:18:38.414
Then that means you get to summarize
where you want it summarized instead of

309
00:18:38.414 --> 00:18:43.723
the routing protocol telling you where
it's going to summarize as well, okay?

310
00:18:43.723 --> 00:18:47.270
So you get to choose that and that's
pretty much the goal behind doing that.

311
00:18:47.270 --> 00:18:48.774
The simple thing about it, right,

312
00:18:48.774 --> 00:18:51.746
is that the command we take a look
at it is actually fairly easy, okay?

313
00:18:51.746 --> 00:18:54.450
So the command is simple.

314
00:18:54.450 --> 00:18:57.931
Where you go auto-summary.

315
00:18:59.992 --> 00:19:05.670
And, when we do so, I have to spell it
right, auto-summary, let's do that, okay.

316
00:19:05.670 --> 00:19:06.966
So now that I've done that,

317
00:19:06.966 --> 00:19:09.623
look at all the neighbor
changes that's going on, okay?

318
00:19:09.623 --> 00:19:13.031
So it took all those different things,
remember we had allowed /30 network,

319
00:19:13.031 --> 00:19:14.146
right?
>> Yeah.

320
00:19:14.146 --> 00:19:15.113
>> We have a lot.

321
00:19:15.113 --> 00:19:18.078
Now, that I've actually just
done this auto-summary,

322
00:19:18.078 --> 00:19:20.264
let's see what happens at routing table.

323
00:19:20.264 --> 00:19:21.861
Do show ip route.

324
00:19:25.822 --> 00:19:30.790
And we'll do a piping here and

325
00:19:30.790 --> 00:19:36.564
we'll begin, the word Gateway.

326
00:19:36.564 --> 00:19:41.444
And now you'll start to see that, hey, a
lot of those networks that are down here,

327
00:19:41.444 --> 00:19:42.224
it shows up.

328
00:19:42.224 --> 00:19:46.453
But notice that we're actually
missing a couple of things here, okay?

329
00:19:46.453 --> 00:19:51.254
So, it does show some that are learned

330
00:19:51.254 --> 00:19:56.690
by, You know, EIGRP.

331
00:19:56.690 --> 00:19:58.380
But notice what has happened.

332
00:19:58.380 --> 00:20:01.360
Look at the actual network
that it learned about, okay?

333
00:20:01.360 --> 00:20:03.340
It's not the /30s that
we had put in there.

334
00:20:03.340 --> 00:20:05.354
There's every once in a while
a /30 cuz they're directly

335
00:20:05.354 --> 00:20:06.236
connected.
>> Uh-huh.

336
00:20:06.236 --> 00:20:09.254
>> But EIGRP though, notice this.

337
00:20:09.254 --> 00:20:12.844
It only shows a /16 on this one, okay?

338
00:20:12.844 --> 00:20:15.570
That's all it actually ends up showing,
okay?

339
00:20:15.570 --> 00:20:19.190
So it doesn't take into account that it's
actually bringing across the ones that

340
00:20:19.190 --> 00:20:23.150
are actually the point to point links that
we've been talking about as well, okay?

341
00:20:23.150 --> 00:20:27.290
So that is something else that you'll
end up seeing where it does that, okay?

342
00:20:27.290 --> 00:20:32.070
So if I now turn it back off, no auto,

343
00:20:32.070 --> 00:20:35.510
that's just as simple as it is cuz there's
no other command so it's unambiguous.

344
00:20:35.510 --> 00:20:39.329
Now notice again, neighbor change
is actually going up and down and

345
00:20:39.329 --> 00:20:40.066
there we go.

346
00:20:40.066 --> 00:20:45.453
Do show IP route, yeah,

347
00:20:45.453 --> 00:20:51.359
ip route, begin Gateway.

348
00:20:55.076 --> 00:20:57.113
And now when we take a look at the ones.

349
00:20:59.408 --> 00:21:01.040
Let me go back up here.

350
00:21:02.140 --> 00:21:04.767
And let's see, where did it go.

351
00:21:04.767 --> 00:21:09.925
Let me zoom out just a little bit so
I can see a little bit better here.

352
00:21:12.700 --> 00:21:15.300
I was hoping we could see
some of those other ones.

353
00:21:15.300 --> 00:21:17.831
I guess they were all directly connected,

354
00:21:17.831 --> 00:21:22.905
I thought that we actually had some that
were /30s that had learned through EIGRP.

355
00:21:22.905 --> 00:21:27.300
But I am lying to you, we did not have
any that were that way, so there we go.

356
00:21:27.300 --> 00:21:31.080
But you do see where there are some in
which they noticed that they are variably

357
00:21:31.080 --> 00:21:33.910
subnetted, okay,
which is what we're actually seeing here.

358
00:21:33.910 --> 00:21:37.290
So you will also find information
like that instead, okay?

359
00:21:37.290 --> 00:21:39.930
But that's kind of the key here is
understanding that there are ins and

360
00:21:39.930 --> 00:21:42.178
outs to all of this stuff that goes on,
okay?

361
00:21:42.178 --> 00:21:45.640
All right, Zach, well at least for IPv4,

362
00:21:45.640 --> 00:21:49.291
you now seen a rundown of
the basic function and

363
00:21:49.291 --> 00:21:54.739
configuration as well of EIGRP on
the equipment that we have, okay?

364
00:21:54.739 --> 00:21:58.994
So that now means that yes, we're
pretty much done with EIGRP except for

365
00:21:58.994 --> 00:22:02.718
the fact that we need to also know
about EIGRP for IP version 6.

366
00:22:02.718 --> 00:22:06.344
So we'll also will be configuring
a lab for that one as well and

367
00:22:06.344 --> 00:22:09.646
that way you'll actually get
to see that in action too.

368
00:22:09.646 --> 00:22:12.758
Zach, that's enough for this episode and
that means we'll have to carry on to

369
00:22:12.758 --> 00:22:16.326
another show.
>> Thank you Ronnie, well done as usual.

370
00:22:16.326 --> 00:22:20.570
Configure EIGRP for IPv4 part two,
make sure you see part one.

371
00:22:20.570 --> 00:22:21.596
Important stuff.

372
00:22:21.596 --> 00:22:24.054
And Ronnie, what else would
you like to say before we go?

373
00:22:24.054 --> 00:22:25.551
>> Well again, practice,

374
00:22:25.551 --> 00:22:27.414
practice, practice, okay?

375
00:22:27.414 --> 00:22:31.540
There's no other way for you to do this
than to type it, get it wrong, and

376
00:22:31.540 --> 00:22:34.731
then go back and
examine what's wrong with the output.

377
00:22:34.731 --> 00:22:39.087
So what I'm trying to also tell you is do
not be afraid of making mistakes at this

378
00:22:39.087 --> 00:22:39.949
point, okay?

379
00:22:39.949 --> 00:22:41.353
Of course, do you want it to be perfect?

380
00:22:41.353 --> 00:22:46.281
Yes, okay, but at the same time,
searching and figuring out your

381
00:22:46.281 --> 00:22:51.308
own mistakes is a big part of you
mastering the way that EIGRP works.

382
00:22:51.308 --> 00:22:53.716
So make sure you take
the time to do that as well.

383
00:22:53.716 --> 00:22:54.318
>> Awesome, and

384
00:22:54.318 --> 00:22:57.731
make sure you take the time to watch every
episode of CCNA Routing and Switching,

385
00:22:57.731 --> 00:22:58.748
Exam 200-105.

386
00:22:58.748 --> 00:23:03.849
Ronnie's done a fantastic job of

387
00:23:03.849 --> 00:23:07.226
It will help you when it gets time for
exams.

388
00:23:07.226 --> 00:23:09.450
And you're gonna be in

00:23:09.450 --> 00:23:12.820
There's thousands of other videos there
and they're gonna be there to help you.

390
00:23:12.820 --> 00:23:16.193
They're just right there, so take
a look at them, you'll be glad you did.

391
00:23:16.193 --> 00:23:17.781
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

You know ITProTV is binge-worthy.

Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:02.322
Welcome to ITPROTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet-

2
00:00:02.322 --> 00:00:03.362
>> Coming at you live from

3
00:00:03.362 --> 00:00:04.685
San Francisco California.

4
00:00:04.685 --> 00:00:06.486
[CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:06.486 --> 00:00:08.384
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.384 --> 00:00:09.154
>> You're watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:09.154 --> 00:00:13.195
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITPROTV,

8
00:00:13.195 --> 00:00:16.795
helping you learn everywhere you go.

9
00:00:16.795 --> 00:00:21.055
>> I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on in the CCNA, running and

10
00:00:21.055 --> 00:00:23.140
switching exam 200-105.

11
00:00:23.140 --> 00:00:26.750
In this episode configure EIGRP for IPv6.

12
00:00:26.750 --> 00:00:29.140
What's that all about?

13
00:00:29.140 --> 00:00:30.570
Well Ronnie Wong's gonna tell us.

14
00:00:30.570 --> 00:00:31.660
Aren't you Ronnie?

15
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:32.230
>> Yes we are.
>> Yeah.

16
00:00:32.230 --> 00:00:34.370
>> And we're gonna make sure
that we do cover this idea and

17
00:00:34.370 --> 00:00:37.800
concept of EIGRP for IPv6.

18
00:00:37.800 --> 00:00:42.470
And of course we are continuing
on in our Cisco CCNA routing and

19
00:00:42.470 --> 00:00:45.540
switching show and
Zach is joining me as we do so.

20
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:49.791
So what we're actually going to
be taking a look at today right

21
00:00:49.791 --> 00:00:53.892
is the idea of using IPv6 with
the routing protocol EIGRP.

22
00:00:53.892 --> 00:00:57.589
Now remember that we've already
configured for IP version 4, so

23
00:00:57.589 --> 00:01:02.143
if you've been watching it in the order
in the series that we've been doing we've

24
00:01:02.143 --> 00:01:05.530
just really finished that and
now we're picking up IPv6.

25
00:01:05.530 --> 00:01:06.408
>> Correct.

26
00:01:06.408 --> 00:01:09.534
>> Remember that the great
idea behind EIGRP, right,

27
00:01:09.534 --> 00:01:13.740
is that they really didn't have to
configure everything over again.

28
00:01:13.740 --> 00:01:19.030
The way that EIGRP was developed and
essentially modularized itself,

29
00:01:19.030 --> 00:01:22.580
is that all they had to do was actually
remove that IP version 4 component or

30
00:01:22.580 --> 00:01:25.140
actually add in another component,
which is IPv6.

31
00:01:25.140 --> 00:01:27.000
And it was off and ready to go.

32
00:01:27.000 --> 00:01:31.118
They didn't have to do like OSPF where
they had to rewrite the entire code

33
00:01:31.118 --> 00:01:35.861
structure from the ground up, to make sure
it could run with the newer IP protocol.

34
00:01:35.861 --> 00:01:38.820
So for us,
it really isn't that big of a change.

35
00:01:38.820 --> 00:01:43.682
And that's actually a blessing in
disguise because you don't really have to

36
00:01:43.682 --> 00:01:46.090
change a lot to do the configuration.

37
00:01:46.090 --> 00:01:47.982
But what we're going to do of course,

38
00:01:47.982 --> 00:01:52.303
is just make sure that you understand the
configuration, is relatively the same, and

39
00:01:52.303 --> 00:01:56.820
of course, we're going to do a lab to help
us to show that configuration as well.

40
00:01:56.820 --> 00:01:58.940
So let's just jump on it,
do it and that will help us out.

41
00:01:58.940 --> 00:02:02.390
So let's take a look at my screen,
and we'll get started here, okay?

42
00:02:02.390 --> 00:02:05.520
So remember that with, of course,
your ITPROTV membership,

43
00:02:05.520 --> 00:02:08.680
you have access to practice-labs.com.

44
00:02:08.680 --> 00:02:11.100
And we're going to log in there, too.

45
00:02:11.100 --> 00:02:12.053
And when you do,

46
00:02:12.053 --> 00:02:17.244
you're gonna select Interconnecting Cisco
Networking Devices ICND2 version 3.0.

47
00:02:17.244 --> 00:02:21.072
Make sure you select this one,
and then configure and

48
00:02:21.072 --> 00:02:23.380
verify EIGRP for IP version 6.

49
00:02:23.380 --> 00:02:28.676
The topology that we're essentially
working with is, we have a larger lab that

50
00:02:28.676 --> 00:02:34.460
we're focusing in, and ironically, really
on these two routers right here, okay.

51
00:02:34.460 --> 00:02:37.401
>> Okay.
>> So NYEDGE1 and NYEDGE2 of course, and

52
00:02:37.401 --> 00:02:40.959
then we also have some
different loopback networks,

53
00:02:40.959 --> 00:02:43.980
that are also gonna be
a part of EIGRP 800.

54
00:02:43.980 --> 00:02:46.400
I know that a little bit difficult to see,

55
00:02:46.400 --> 00:02:49.490
but that's gonna be out
autonomous system number.

56
00:02:49.490 --> 00:02:52.060
And you see where it's actually said
that we're gonna advertise these

57
00:02:52.060 --> 00:02:53.340
networks in there.

58
00:02:53.340 --> 00:02:56.506
So what we should actually see,
of course, is this ability for

59
00:02:56.506 --> 00:02:58.498
that to translate all the way through.

60
00:02:58.498 --> 00:03:05.280
And all these networks that begin
with the 2001 A B 40, okay.

61
00:03:05.280 --> 00:03:09.250
All of those going all the way through 44,
that should actually do what we want to.

62
00:03:09.250 --> 00:03:11.160
Now if you're saying
that's a little bit fuzzy,

63
00:03:11.160 --> 00:03:14.340
it's cuz I zoomed in really big,
that's what happened there.

64
00:03:14.340 --> 00:03:17.845
But of course that means you'll also
have access to this as well, so

65
00:03:17.845 --> 00:03:21.053
you'll be able to follow along
in what we're gonna be doing.

66
00:03:21.053 --> 00:03:25.811
So this is our configuration, and
we've already got these IP addresses

67
00:03:25.811 --> 00:03:28.940
already configured on the routers for
IPv6.

68
00:03:28.940 --> 00:03:33.300
So we should be off and
ready to go along with the loop backs too.

69
00:03:33.300 --> 00:03:36.830
And here you'll probably see something
strange you don't see of course a lot of

70
00:03:36.830 --> 00:03:39.533
times, where the loop back
number is actually get very big.

71
00:03:39.533 --> 00:03:44.596
So notice that's a 641, 256, 768,

PPP, because of what its nature was,

00:05:33.190 --> 00:05:36.090

there's gonna be another

And on your end or on my end, I wanna

Now that I've got Router 1 essentially

00:14:48.168 --> 00:14:50.330

That's 1/2.

IP address 192.168.12.2.

00:14:57.489 --> 00:15:02.303
Now I just said that,

00:15:06.980 --> 00:15:08.630
But I do not have

12.1 So then I can go to 12.2,

00:15:24.338 --> 00:15:28.639
ppp authentication chap.

Here do a no shutdown, which I don't

side as well, so

>> Yep.
>> Yep.

00:15:43.090 --> 00:15:46.300
I swear I should remember, but

299
00:15:46.300 --> 00:15:51.170
So username is gonna be what, for

00:15:51.170 --> 00:15:53.353
So I would actually set up the username.

00:15:53.353 --> 00:15:56.959
And then on the password here,

302
00:15:58.411 --> 00:15:59.499
Here.

303
00:16:01.654 --> 00:16:05.620
All right, so now that that is all set up.

304
00:16:05.620 --> 00:16:07.919
Make sure I got everything

305
00:16:10.940 --> 00:16:12.018
Now that that is up.

306
00:16:12.018 --> 00:16:18.658
Debug PPP, authentication.

307
00:16:18.658 --> 00:16:26.223
Nope, debug ppp authentication.

00:16:28.073 --> 00:16:31.853
All right, so when we start to take a look
at something this here, well, let's see,

That's probably one of the first things

00:16:37.840 --> 00:16:41.892
So the other side is actually accepting

313
00:16:41.892 --> 00:16:43.656
Now let me get back in.

314
00:16:46.630 --> 00:16:49.510
Sometimes we actually don't

315
00:16:50.680 --> 00:16:52.878
Let's do a shutdown first.

316
00:16:56.295 --> 00:16:57.530
Let's turn off the interface.

317
00:17:03.120 --> 00:17:06.271
Make sure I get the interface
is now administratively down.

00:17:10.399 --> 00:17:12.108
Now do a new shutdown.

Here, and

320
00:17:22.950 --> 00:17:23.572
>> Wonderful.

321
00:17:23.572 --> 00:17:25.505
>> So when we start to see this,

322
00:17:25.505 --> 00:17:29.890
okay this is how you know authentication
is actually taking place here okay?

323
00:17:29.890 --> 00:17:34.750
So you see where it says PPP,
using the default call direction, okay.

324
00:17:34.750 --> 00:17:37.518
Challenge handshake
authentication protocol.

325
00:17:37.518 --> 00:17:41.850
The O here for

326
00:17:41.850 --> 00:17:45.710
So on this one, on router two,
it's actually from itself.

327
00:17:45.710 --> 00:17:48.580
Saying, I sent this challenge out, okay.

328
00:17:48.580 --> 00:17:50.640
It received from router one.

329
00:17:52.210 --> 00:17:55.060
The actual challenge, okay?

330
00:17:55.060 --> 00:17:58.560
Then, it actually sent out
the authentication request,

331
00:17:58.560 --> 00:18:03.254
it used the proper host name configured
from the host name, we got the response.

332
00:18:04.875 --> 00:18:05.565
Okay?

333
00:18:05.565 --> 00:18:08.105
But ultimately what you wanna
see is right here on the end,

334
00:18:08.105 --> 00:18:11.145
where it says SUCCESS SUCCESS, okay?

335
00:18:11.145 --> 00:18:12.527
So when something like that happens,

336
00:18:12.527 --> 00:18:15.428
now you've actually successfully
configured authentication on both sides.

337
00:18:15.428 --> 00:18:19.817
Two important pieces here for
the idea of PPP, cuz I don't think you

338
00:18:19.817 --> 00:18:25.110
actually ever really see this again,
okay, but it is on the exam, okay?

339
00:18:25.110 --> 00:18:27.820
One is that the encapsulation
doesn't match,

340
00:18:27.820 --> 00:18:30.730
you're never going to actually get even
pings to come across a lot of times.

341
00:18:30.730 --> 00:18:31.762
>> Right.
>> It's just not going to work.

342
00:18:31.762 --> 00:18:34.370
But normally by default.

343
00:18:34.370 --> 00:18:35.950
Well, do you have to set an encapsulation?

344
00:18:35.950 --> 00:18:37.910
No.
Because a default encapsulation,

345
00:18:37.910 --> 00:18:40.720
is normally set on the interface itself.

346
00:18:40.720 --> 00:18:43.786
So let me see if I can show
you that just briefly.

347
00:18:53.679 --> 00:19:00.340
Spell exit.
Show interface s1/2.

348
00:19:03.405 --> 00:19:07.324
So right here,
you can see the authentication.

349
00:19:07.324 --> 00:19:11.579
Okay, if it actually tells you that
the encapsulation type is different than

350
00:19:11.579 --> 00:19:16.496
the other side, you'll probably never get
the authentication to come through, okay.

351
00:19:16.496 --> 00:19:20.750
So make sure that the authentication is
set exactly the way that you want to.

352
00:19:20.750 --> 00:19:24.497
Then secondly, of course, you also need
to make sure that the user name and

353
00:19:24.497 --> 00:19:25.511
password, right?

354
00:19:25.511 --> 00:19:27.910
It is for the other router.

355
00:19:27.910 --> 00:19:29.040
I know it sounds strange, right?

356
00:19:29.040 --> 00:19:33.180
So router 2, the username is gonna be
essentially the host name for router 1.

357
00:19:33.180 --> 00:19:38.590
Okay, and then on router 1,
the username's gonna be router 2,

358
00:19:38.590 --> 00:19:42.235
but using the same exact password,
okay, and

359
00:19:42.235 --> 00:19:47.430
both of those are case sensitive in terms
of the username and the password itself.

360
00:19:47.430 --> 00:19:50.947
Okay, so getting something like that
actually set up, using that debug command

361
00:19:50.947 --> 00:19:54.326
is probably the easiest way to verify
that authentication is going through.

362
00:19:54.326 --> 00:19:57.004
Sometimes you don't see
anything until you send

363
00:19:57.004 --> 00:19:59.610
traffic like what we did with the pings.

364
00:19:59.610 --> 00:20:03.000
And then a lot of times what I
do is I shut one interface down,

365
00:20:03.000 --> 00:20:04.330
I turn it back on.

366
00:20:04.330 --> 00:20:07.504
Using that debug command, everything
at last should should be up and going.

367
00:20:07.504 --> 00:20:09.380
Okay, and then you'll be fine.

368
00:20:09.380 --> 00:20:11.167
All right, so make sure that you do that.

369
00:20:11.167 --> 00:20:14.757
Now, once everything like
that is actually done,

370
00:20:14.757 --> 00:20:20.014
you wanna also make sure that you do

371
00:20:20.014 --> 00:20:24.697

372
00:20:27.183 --> 00:20:29.298
And then you're perfectly fine, okay?

So Zach, we'll have to carry

>> Okay.

379
00:20:43.770 --> 00:20:46.920
Well, configure PPP, and ML PPP.

Which is essentially what I

Let's show you the multi link side

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with ppp configuration but now adding in the element of loadbalancing by using multilink ppp configuration.  They demonstrate how each interface must be configured along with the multilink interface. Lastly, the team configures ppp authentication on the multilink.
episodes.title: Configure PPP and MLPPP Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:02.781
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.781 --> 00:00:06.593
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.593 --> 00:00:08.403
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.403 --> 00:00:11.966
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.966 --> 00:00:14.220
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITPro.TV,

6
00:00:14.220 --> 00:00:16.033
helping you learn everywhere you go.

7
00:00:16.033 --> 00:00:21.434
I'm your host, Zach Memos, for
this episode of CCNA Routing and

8
00:00:21.434 --> 00:00:27.141
Switching Exam 200-105 configure PPP and
MLPPP, part two.

9
00:00:27.141 --> 00:00:29.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> And Ronnie Wong is here to help us out.

10
00:00:29.620 --> 00:00:30.551
Ronnie, good to see you, sir.

11
00:00:30.551 --> 00:00:33.842
>> Well thank you for having me back
on the show here for CCNA Routing and

12
00:00:33.842 --> 00:00:34.492
Switching.

13
00:00:34.492 --> 00:00:37.638
We are picking up, of course, on part two.

14
00:00:37.638 --> 00:00:39.871
And the reason why is that I
didn't take a look at the clock,

15
00:00:39.871 --> 00:00:42.254
I ended that show a little bit early,
which is perfectly fine.

16
00:00:42.254 --> 00:00:43.696
There's a good logical break for us.

17
00:00:43.696 --> 00:00:45.266
>> It was a logical break.
>> So for us now,

18
00:00:45.266 --> 00:00:49.952
we are now moving on of course
to Multilink PPP, right?

19
00:00:49.952 --> 00:00:54.230
So what is the actual overwhelming problem
with setting up the idea of just regular

20
00:00:54.230 --> 00:00:55.599
point to point protocol?

21
00:00:55.599 --> 00:00:56.527
Well, let me show you.

22
00:00:56.527 --> 00:01:00.454
Let's go back to the topology that
I'll be using for this one and

23
00:01:00.454 --> 00:01:03.230
probably a couple labs
as we go through here.

24
00:01:03.230 --> 00:01:05.441
Is that on PPP, if that is my only link,

25
00:01:05.441 --> 00:01:09.414
now do not look at the orange side that
is for a little bit later on here.

26
00:01:09.414 --> 00:01:11.459
>> Right.
>> How about if we just look at that red

27
00:01:11.459 --> 00:01:14.884
link though, what happens if one
of those interfaces goes down?

28
00:01:14.884 --> 00:01:15.603
We're in trouble.

29
00:01:15.603 --> 00:01:16.180
>> Yeah.

30
00:01:16.180 --> 00:01:19.690
>> That means no communication
process is gonna end up happening.

31
00:01:19.690 --> 00:01:24.519
So, we don't want anything like that
to end up ever happening for us.

32
00:01:24.519 --> 00:01:29.979
So, what we can do instead is
that instead of just configuring

33
00:01:29.979 --> 00:01:34.708
regular PPP,
if we can bring up another link, okay?

34
00:01:34.708 --> 00:01:38.812
Between two routers, this time we're
gonna use router 1 and router 3, okay?

35
00:01:38.812 --> 00:01:39.494
>> Right.

36
00:01:39.494 --> 00:01:43.680
>> If I can actually bring two
of these links up like this,

37
00:01:43.680 --> 00:01:48.143
I can configure them to
essentially load balanced for us.

38
00:01:48.143 --> 00:01:53.574
And essentially to provide failover, in
case one link fails, if we need to, okay?

39
00:01:53.574 --> 00:01:56.871
Now, the idea behind this
normally if we do this, right?

40
00:01:56.871 --> 00:02:02.385
I would have to configure IP addresses on
this link, on this side of the routers,

41
00:02:02.385 --> 00:02:07.352
and then different set of IP addresses
on this side of the router as well.

42
00:02:07.352 --> 00:02:11.527
So that means four IP addresses would
actually normally have to be configured or

43
00:02:11.527 --> 00:02:14.659
whatever other types of addresses
you normally have to do.

44
00:02:14.659 --> 00:02:17.757
Multilink PPP says, no, don't do that.

45
00:02:17.757 --> 00:02:23.530
What we'll do though is logically by
the routers themselves at these endpoints

46
00:02:23.530 --> 00:02:28.887
here, they'll actually treat them
both as a single layer three length.

47
00:02:28.887 --> 00:02:32.602
So even though I'm actually configuring,
okay?

48
00:02:32.602 --> 00:02:38.318
The idea of, well both of these is
actually into what we call a group here,

49
00:02:38.318 --> 00:02:39.528
or a link here.

50
00:02:39.528 --> 00:02:40.995
Once we actually do that,

51
00:02:40.995 --> 00:02:44.677
well then we can actually identify
it by just a single IP address.

52
00:02:44.677 --> 00:02:47.790
So it functions in a way
a single link would do, but

53
00:02:47.790 --> 00:02:50.251
it has the benefits of load balancing.

54
00:02:50.251 --> 00:02:54.549
And it also has the benefit here of
actually being able to essentially afford

55
00:02:54.549 --> 00:02:57.515
us a little bit of fail over if we do so
as well, okay?

56
00:02:57.515 --> 00:03:01.987
But it's true balance in nature
though is more about the idea of load

57
00:03:01.987 --> 00:03:04.583
balancing equally along those lanes.

58
00:03:04.583 --> 00:03:07.218
And the reason why that's important, okay?

59
00:03:07.218 --> 00:03:12.122
Is this, let's say that even though
you might at one point actually was

60
00:03:12.122 --> 00:03:16.961
able to support, let's say,
it's a 512 kilobit length, okay?

61
00:03:16.961 --> 00:03:18.787
That'd be pretty high in the day.

62
00:03:18.787 --> 00:03:23.376
But after a while, you actually realized
that the second zero length that I could

63
00:03:23.376 --> 00:03:26.901
actually afford, I could only
do a fraction of that instead.

64
00:03:26.901 --> 00:03:32.286
And I could only do,
let's say, 384 or 256.

65
00:03:32.286 --> 00:03:37.199
Well, if I just do load balancing between
them and just say send all the charges,

66
00:03:37.199 --> 00:03:40.754
balance that out, and
just use these two links to do that.

67
00:03:40.754 --> 00:03:44.522
Well one side,
I would flood the 256 K line, okay?

68
00:03:44.522 --> 00:03:47.490
But the other side, it would only take up,

69
00:03:47.490 --> 00:03:51.292
well half of that idea of,
let's say the 512 line.

70
00:03:51.292 --> 00:03:55.591
So, one link would essentially be down
because I sent too much information.

71
00:03:55.591 --> 00:03:58.414
The other link would actually be up, but

72
00:03:58.414 --> 00:04:01.495
I'd also have actually
taken up part of it.

73
00:04:01.495 --> 00:04:05.755
So in Multilink it says, I can kind
of load balance this out in this way,

74
00:04:05.755 --> 00:04:06.686
if I choose to.

75
00:04:06.686 --> 00:04:11.097
Which is to ensure that if it's
the 256 and I take a look at it,

But do you have to know how
to do this according to them?

Configure PPP and MLPPP and before we

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce the basic concept of using PPPoE.  Then, they show the configuration of both the server side configuration and the client side configuration.  Though the CCNA candidate is only responsible for the client side configuration, the team explains it's difficult to understand what is being configured on the one side without the other.
episodes.title: Configure Client-Side PPPoE
episodes.transcript:

For this episode of CCNA routing and

only Ronnie Wong, Ronnie Wong, Ronnie

Hopefully, I will not echo that

But today we are taking a look at

configuring a client side PPPOE,

00:00:49.902 --> 00:00:54.440
that is a lot of letters there to have
>> I think I forgot a p in the beginning.

15
00:00:54.440 --> 00:00:58.469
>> Yeah, well, it happens because
everybody forgets the p because

16
00:00:58.469 --> 00:01:02.642
the unusual thing, right,
is that when we talk about the idea of PPP

17
00:01:02.642 --> 00:01:06.710
as Point to Point Protocol and
most of us forget about the end.

18

We always just call it point to point,

>> So it's actually

very easy to forget it here, okay?

21
00:01:12.346 --> 00:01:16.750
So when it comes down to this idea,
in routing and switching, this is one

22
00:01:16.750 --> 00:01:20.810
of these configurations like hey,
I really again, have to emphasize this.

23
00:01:20.810 --> 00:01:26.280
Cuz we're talking about WAN technologies,
most of us entering in at the CCNA level.

24
00:01:26.280 --> 00:01:29.990
You may see it but you and I are probably
never gonna really configure it

25
00:01:29.990 --> 00:01:33.890
in a real production type of
network to get everything going.

26
00:01:33.890 --> 00:01:37.570
Now, just when I say that, that might be

So we're gonna show you,

And we're gonna talk about

>> So, Ronnie, what is PPPOE and

30
00:01:44.920 --> 00:01:49.093
>> All right, so let's kinda
remember the idea of PPP as well and

31
00:01:49.093 --> 00:01:50.628
that will help us out.

And then we'll talk about PPPOE, okay?

33
00:01:52.962 --> 00:01:54.591
>> Mm-hm.
>> So if we go to my diagram,

34
00:01:54.591 --> 00:01:56.080
this will kind of set us up.

35
00:01:56.080 --> 00:01:58.310
We're gonna be taking a look at
the left side of this diagram.

36
00:01:58.310 --> 00:02:01.307
Let me zoom in on the left
side of this diagram.

37
00:02:01.307 --> 00:02:03.357
And that will get us set up, okay?

So when we start taking a look

here's the lab setting

Between router 1 and 2,
normal PPP, okay, happens over

And when we do something like that, once

it really doesn't expect to see anything

44
00:02:27.450 --> 00:02:28.010

45
00:02:28.010 --> 00:02:32.080
Now, when you start talking about the idea

46
00:02:32.080 --> 00:02:35.665
of PPP that's usually what gets

00:02:35.665 --> 00:02:39.850
Point-to-Point, source,

48
00:02:39.850 --> 00:02:40.900

>> Okay.

49

But when you start talking about PPPOE,

It is the point to point protocol but

51

So on the left hand side what I've

is that we are still trying to

We're not accessing it in

56

We have just got connected over

And remember that the term ethernet,

Well, that now adds in

Because if we think of,

that's why kind of drew them

Right?
If these were actually on here,

they would actually still

in the same broadcast domain as what

00:03:52.880 --> 00:03:53.590
But they're not there.

But it is very possible that they are out

Now this technology,

we'll talk about it a little

Not too much more but we'll talk about

This is actually the type of things that

76

So when we start doing that, a lot of
times DSL was actually implemented

to allow us to have this access where

But yet we still needed

Because if not, that means they couldn't

00:04:30.580 --> 00:04:35.010
and everybody ended up inside of a single

So a DSL access, a machine, out of the,

terminology is but it actually ended up

00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:48.530
that meant all of our customers would

00:04:48.530 --> 00:04:51.000
I shouldn't say,
connected to that one point.

86
00:04:51.000 --> 00:04:53.270
Well, how do you differentiate

87
00:04:53.270 --> 00:04:57.010
Well, the way that you do that is that
instead, even though everybody's on

88
00:04:57.010 --> 00:05:01.140
a mutli access, you treat them as if
they're on their individual same network,

89
00:05:01.140 --> 00:05:05.010
though they're connected over
the same physical infrastructure and

90
00:05:05.010 --> 00:05:08.110
the way that we do that is using PPPoE.

91
00:05:08.110 --> 00:05:13.550
So now, if there a connection between

00:05:13.550 --> 00:05:17.820
it can also be monitored as a single

00:05:17.820 --> 00:05:21.700
Same thing if Router 6 went to

00:05:21.700 --> 00:05:24.990
Router 5 went to Router 1,
Router 4 went to Router 1.

95
00:05:24.990 --> 00:05:30.680
All that will be same type of connection,
even though they share a multi-service

96
00:05:30.680 --> 00:05:34.390
network, they're treated as if they

97
00:05:34.390 --> 00:05:34.890
>> Right.

98
00:05:34.890 --> 00:05:38.950
>> So in that configuration,

But super important for

So normally, you have a server side

what they actually have to configure,

But notice, I may have more

In regular PPP that would be it for us.

That will allow us to essentially

117

Once we get that all done then

them, it'll look like they only have one

00:06:49.160 --> 00:06:52.700
Which is all to the server of PPPOE.

They become what we call clients.

Now, even though all that sounds great,

I cannot control how many

Now, I can but the way that we would

authentication in between

146

Well that's what PPP also does for us.

It provides for

That if we set it up, we'll actually be

00:08:21.830 --> 00:08:24.393
So that's part of the objective as well,

is to make sure that not only can we

to also set it up with local

And for us, even though normally that's

it is what's called down on the exam, and

Okay.

00:08:50.440 --> 00:08:50.950
Okay.

So that is what we are set up to do, and
that's what we are going to go ahead and

162

So let's begin by

So here, I am on router one, and we'll

So the first thing I need to do is go

And once I'm in the global

So this is not so much of an important for

the exam, but as to help you understand

172

If I am actually configuring this for

in their own client group for PPPoE,

174

And then I give that group a name, and

175
00:09:47.056 --> 00:09:51.212
Okay, that way we actually see what's
happening as it comes up, okay.

176
00:09:51.212 --> 00:09:55.674
So now that we've got this going on you
actually do see a couple of syslog message

177
00:09:55.674 --> 00:09:58.547

178
00:09:58.547 --> 00:10:02.224
So it actually says hey look here,
you've actually configured

00:10:02.224 --> 00:10:06.050
now line protocol an interface and

180
00:10:06.050 --> 00:10:10.535
So I have now actually created essentially
what they call a virtual access connection

181
00:10:10.535 --> 00:10:13.270
In this group that we're talking about,
okay?

182
00:10:13.270 --> 00:10:15.300
So that's actually the first

We're essentially just gonna set
up the idea of that PPPoE type of

406
00:23:32.497 --> 00:23:36.200
protection here, okay, for authentication.

407
00:23:36.200 --> 00:23:39.700
So I'm gonna set up a username and
password database.

408
00:23:39.700 --> 00:23:44.640
So username, If I can spell username.

409
00:23:44.640 --> 00:23:49.000
Now, this actually does have to
be what the end point device is.

410
00:23:49.000 --> 00:23:52.759
Now, on a regular DSL network that could
be your modem, whatever the name that's

411
00:23:52.759 --> 00:23:56.149
been assigned to your modem that will
actually get assigned here as well.

412
00:23:56.149 --> 00:24:00.410
And we're going to just set
a password of cisco123.

413
00:24:00.410 --> 00:24:05.635
Oops, make sure I type it in
the way I want to, cisco123.

414
00:24:05.635 --> 00:24:09.146
Now, I'm gonna assign this to
the virtual interface template.

415
00:24:09.146 --> 00:24:14.365
Interface virtual-template 1.

416
00:24:14.365 --> 00:24:20.299
And then it's just gonna
be ppp authentication chap,

417
00:24:20.299 --> 00:24:25.460
and this is where we have an option here,
okay?

418
00:24:25.460 --> 00:24:29.060
So at the very end, on the server side,
which you're not responsible for,

419
00:24:29.060 --> 00:24:32.720
I'm just showing you what's gonna be here,
it's callin, okay?

420
00:24:32.720 --> 00:24:36.970
Authenticate remotely incoming call only,
okay?

421
00:24:36.970 --> 00:24:41.200
So that is why I am setting this up,
so that's what we would do,

422
00:24:41.200 --> 00:24:44.480
callin, all right?

423
00:24:44.480 --> 00:24:47.530
So once I do that,
now that I've set this up,

424
00:24:47.530 --> 00:24:50.850
that connection that we just did
is probably gonna drop, okay?

425
00:24:50.850 --> 00:24:54.660
Because now I'm asking for authentication,
and the other side isn't set up for it.

426
00:24:54.660 --> 00:24:57.741
So that connection should
end up dropping here.

427
00:24:57.741 --> 00:25:00.470
And we'll see exactly that.

428
00:25:00.470 --> 00:25:05.491
So that went to router two,
now you can see where the connection,

429
00:25:05.491 --> 00:25:08.887
the virtual interface went to down, okay?

430
00:25:08.887 --> 00:25:12.510
And you are now seeing it's actually
doing it again, it's still changed,

431
00:25:12.510 --> 00:25:16.130
it's still actually at the down
state is what we are doing.

432
00:25:16.130 --> 00:25:18.790
So let me go ahead and
just turn on the debug for right now.

433
00:25:18.790 --> 00:25:21.336
Debug ppp authentication.

434
00:25:26.097 --> 00:25:28.080
That way we can see it
as it comes through.

435
00:25:28.080 --> 00:25:30.790
And let's begin

436
00:25:30.790 --> 00:25:34.610
cuz this also part of what
you'll be responsible for, okay?

437
00:25:34.610 --> 00:25:37.900
Notice here's what the error is, okay?

438
00:25:37.900 --> 00:25:41.340
Right here, unable to authenticate for
the peer, okay?

439
00:25:41.340 --> 00:25:43.880
It has actually been sent, and
it's been received, and it says,

00:25:43.880 --> 00:25:45.820
look, it failed, okay?

441
00:25:45.820 --> 00:25:47.470
So we know that something is wrong, okay?

442
00:25:47.470 --> 00:25:49.450
So I wanted us to be able to see that.

443
00:25:49.450 --> 00:25:53.579
So once we're actually in
our global config here,

444
00:25:53.579 --> 00:25:58.104
on the interface dialer,
if I can spell dialer, dial.

445
00:25:58.104 --> 00:26:01.274
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

446
00:26:01.274 --> 00:26:01.910
>> Okay,

447
00:26:01.910 --> 00:26:06.530
then this is a little bit of a different

448
00:26:06.530 --> 00:26:11.390
So unlike the ppp that we actually did a
little bit earlier, I don't have to do ppp

449
00:26:11.390 --> 00:26:15.570
authentication cuz I'm not asking for
the other side to authenticate to me.

450
00:26:15.570 --> 00:26:19.550
I'm just saying with PPP,
I am going to use chap and

00:26:19.550 --> 00:26:23.358
I'm going to send the password, cisco123.

452
00:26:23.358 --> 00:26:28.218
All right, now, this may actually

00:26:28.218 --> 00:26:32.989
next time it actually does this,

00:26:32.989 --> 00:26:36.150
what I like to do,
is I like to hard set it.

So I like to go ahead and shut this
interface down just for a moment.

456
00:26:39.550 --> 00:26:40.990

457
00:26:40.990 --> 00:26:43.990
And you can see right before I did,
something happens, Zack.

458
00:26:43.990 --> 00:26:46.450
So it was actually faster
than I was this time.

459
00:26:46.450 --> 00:26:49.104
>> It was fast.
>> We're actually seeing where it says,

460
00:26:49.104 --> 00:26:52.304
look, even before you shut it down,
RESPONSE, okay?

461
00:26:52.304 --> 00:26:56.310
And then it says, incoming,
it told me it was successful.

462
00:26:56.310 --> 00:27:00.708
So now we are up, and so now I do a no
shutdown, and this will happen again.

463
00:27:04.754 --> 00:27:08.080
Okay, so in the very end there's
two important pieces for us, right?

464
00:27:08.080 --> 00:27:11.410
The configuration, as far as you and
I go on the client side,

465
00:27:11.410 --> 00:27:13.630
the dialer interface, okay?

466

We don't have to configure

467

As long as you can figure

468
00:27:20.020 --> 00:27:24.310
you'll probably actually do perfectly fine

469
00:27:24.310 --> 00:27:28.330
So that's kinda the key here, and make
sure you actually are able to verify it's

470
00:27:28.330 --> 00:27:32.820
up or down, that show PPPoE session or

471
00:27:32.820 --> 00:27:35.940
sessions, whatever I
actually typed in there.

472
00:27:35.940 --> 00:27:37.700
Session, I always do either single or

00:27:37.700 --> 00:27:41.080
plural, but whenever that
something like that happens, well,

474
00:27:41.080 --> 00:27:43.900
that's also something else that
you want to be able to do as well.

475
00:27:44.980 --> 00:27:49.650
So that way you can verify,
if it's down, then you know, okay?

476
00:27:49.650 --> 00:27:51.820
But remember that way
that we protect this,

477
00:27:51.820 --> 00:27:54.050
right, is by setting up authentication.

478
00:27:54.050 --> 00:27:57.490
And the easiest way that you and
I are doing it right now

479
00:27:57.490 --> 00:28:02.840
is based on local authentication, which
is stored right here on router one, okay?

480
00:28:02.840 --> 00:28:06.680
In reality, this would be stored on
a radius server is where this would be

481
00:28:06.680 --> 00:28:10.740
stored, and not directly on
an interface that's facing a network,

482
00:28:10.740 --> 00:28:12.440
that's facing the internet, I should say.

483
00:28:12.440 --> 00:28:15.300
Or a public network that we have, okay?

484
00:28:15.300 --> 00:28:17.560
So that's what we should
end up seeing here.

485
00:28:17.560 --> 00:28:20.280
So Zack, in the very end,
this is what we've done,

486
00:28:20.280 --> 00:28:23.460
is that we've configured
the idea of a client side PPPoE.

487
00:28:23.460 --> 00:28:26.052
We've also talked about the idea

488
00:28:26.052 --> 00:28:29.124
and just showed you a little bit of extra
because it doesn't make sense to set
