00:28:29.124 --> 00:28:31.870
up one side if you don't know what
the other side is actually doing.

490
00:28:31.870 --> 00:28:33.568
So that's why we wanted to show you both.

491
00:28:33.568 --> 00:28:36.189
>> Excellent information,
well-delivered as usual, Ronnie.

492
00:28:36.189 --> 00:28:39.301
Configure the client side PPPoE.

493
00:28:39.301 --> 00:28:42.570
Great episode, and before we move on,
what else would you like to say?

494
00:28:42.570 --> 00:28:45.960
>> Well, the great thing is this is

495
00:28:45.960 --> 00:28:48.550
But for me,
I would have found it difficult

497
00:28:52.760 --> 00:28:54.060
But just start matching it up.

498
00:28:54.060 --> 00:28:56.400
If you follow along with

with the episode notes,
you just kinda know what's on both sides.

500

One side's gonna be the dialer,
that's the side you're responsible for.

501

So take a look, and as long as it

502
00:29:07.390 --> 00:29:11.440
make sure you look at those
configuration notes that you have, okay?

503
00:29:11.440 --> 00:29:12.550
You and I aren't responsible for

setting up anything else according to
the exam, but just when I say that,

00:29:17.130 --> 00:29:19.940
could they throw something at you like

506
00:29:19.940 --> 00:29:24.360
Yes, okay, it is with the idea of

507
00:29:24.360 --> 00:29:25.620
to be able to do this.

508
00:29:25.620 --> 00:29:28.606
We have another episode coming
up where we'll talk about

WiMAX Access Technologies.

We'll talk about the reasons why we
also implement PPPoE, but you'll see,

it's pretty much the same goal and
idea overall.

512
00:29:37.540 --> 00:29:39.700
But we'll talk about the idea

513
00:29:39.700 --> 00:29:42.630
But at least for now, you now

00:29:42.630 --> 00:29:44.660
that's what we wanted to

>> Excellent advice.

Make sure you see everything in the CCNA

There's thousands of other videos there,

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the basic usage of the GRE tunnel. Using that as a base, they configure the GRE tunnel and verify that it works.
episodes.title: Configure GRE Tunnel Connectivity
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:07.106
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK],

2
00:00:07.106 --> 00:00:11.768
[SOUND].
>> You are watching ITPRO.TV

3
00:00:11.768 --> 00:00:14.882
>> Hello, thank you for watching ITPRO.TV,

4
00:00:14.882 --> 00:00:19.850
helping you learn everywhere you go,
I'm your host Zach Memos on this

5
00:00:19.850 --> 00:00:24.584
episode of CCNA, Routing and
switching exam 200 dash 105.

6
00:00:24.584 --> 00:00:28.770
We're going to configure
GRE Total Connectivity in this episode.

7
00:00:28.770 --> 00:00:29.810
Yes we are.

8
00:00:29.810 --> 00:00:33.870
[LAUGH] And the person who shows you
the way is Ronnie Wong right over here.

9
00:00:33.870 --> 00:00:36.760
Ronnie Wong, it's good to have you sir.
>> Well Zack, thank you very much for

10
00:00:36.760 --> 00:00:40.190
joining me on this CCNA Routing and
Switching show as we continue on our

11
00:00:40.190 --> 00:00:43.810
progressive march here, through some
of these Cisco exam objectives.

12
00:00:43.810 --> 00:00:46.820
We are now taking a look at
different WAN technologies.

13
00:00:46.820 --> 00:00:50.690
And we've gotten to this pont where we're
gonna talk about GRE tunnels briefly.

14
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:52.850
We're not gonna go into
a full configuration and

15
00:00:52.850 --> 00:00:56.020
explanation of everything
that has to do with the GRE.

16
00:00:56.020 --> 00:00:59.280
For those of you that want to go on and
learn more about that, make sure you

17
00:00:59.280 --> 00:01:04.070
hit the CCNP route show and that will
help you out as you get started here.

18
00:01:04.070 --> 00:01:05.340
But that's what we're going to do today.

19
00:01:05.340 --> 00:01:07.770
We're gonna take a look at this
idea of how to actually establish

20
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:09.020
the connectivity.
>> So Ronnie,

21
00:01:09.020 --> 00:01:12.610
what is a GRE tunnel, what is that?
>> Actually, that's a great question.

22
00:01:12.610 --> 00:01:17.670
Because a lot of times today,
people overlook the idea of GRE tunnels.

23
00:01:17.670 --> 00:01:22.530
Because we've kind of gone to the other
end of this where we've taking

24
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:27.810
the idea of creating a tunnel just for
the idea of protecting data.

25
00:01:27.810 --> 00:01:31.580
So, today you hear the term VPN,
virtual private network.

26
00:01:31.580 --> 00:01:34.210
GRE's been around for a long time.

27
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:34.930
GRE stands for

28
00:01:34.930 --> 00:01:39.580
Generic Routing Encapsulation,
is what it actually stands for.

29
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:44.650
And this allows us to create kind of
that same thing that we have in the VPN,

30
00:01:44.650 --> 00:01:47.030
but without the idea of encryption.

31
00:01:47.030 --> 00:01:48.210
So that sounds a little bit funny,

32
00:01:48.210 --> 00:01:51.290
like why the heck would I actually
want to create this tunnel?

33
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:54.790
Between two disparate networks
that are out there, but

34
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:56.790
without any encryption at all.

35
00:01:56.790 --> 00:02:01.780
Well you've gotta go back to the days when
they first started seeing the need for

36
00:02:01.780 --> 00:02:02.620
something like this.

37
00:02:02.620 --> 00:02:06.960
And that's because well as Lan started
growing bigger and you started having of

38
00:02:06.960 --> 00:02:13.440
course, different sites between, you know
and with different geographic locations.

39
00:02:13.440 --> 00:02:17.330
What started happening is technology
started appearing for weigh in access.

40
00:02:17.330 --> 00:02:18.230
It was different.

41
00:02:18.230 --> 00:02:19.180
And they were all different.

42
00:02:19.180 --> 00:02:21.620
So, sometimes you would get a serial link.

43
00:02:21.620 --> 00:02:24.150
Sometimes you would get a metro ethernet.

44
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:27.130
Sometimes you would end up getting PPPoE,
not usually not that.

45
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:30.960
But, sometimes you could get other things
right that were actually on there.

46
00:02:30.960 --> 00:02:34.740
And the problem that you have now to
send traffic all the way through that.

47
00:02:34.740 --> 00:02:38.360
A change all the way through
each one of the networks

48
00:02:38.360 --> 00:02:41.520
before it became what it
actually needed to again.

49
00:02:41.520 --> 00:02:45.540
So it's like every time you stop and
they're telling you hey, before you can go

50
00:02:45.540 --> 00:02:48.480
through this area, you've gotta
add this device onto your car.

51
00:02:48.480 --> 00:02:50.020
Okay, well let's add that device.

52
00:02:50.020 --> 00:02:53.230
Then you go to the next area and you're
like, you gotta take that one off, but

53
00:02:53.230 --> 00:02:54.550
you gotta add this instead.

54
00:02:54.550 --> 00:02:57.340
And then going through again it's like,
why do you need all that?

55
00:02:57.340 --> 00:02:59.940
Just take all that stuff off,
but use ours instead.

56
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:04.370
And so you kept having to do that
with the data as it changed forms

57
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:07.640
going all through these
different types of networks.

58
00:03:07.640 --> 00:03:12.100
So what GRE does, in that generic
routing encapsulation tunnel.

59
00:03:12.100 --> 00:03:16.490
And it says look let establish an end
to end connectivity regardless of what

60
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:20.840
type of network it's actually on and
everybody will essentially support it.

61
00:03:20.840 --> 00:03:24.780
And what will happen for those two
networks at the end is that well,

62
00:03:24.780 --> 00:03:28.620
when they send data over it's not
gonna be tough it just gonna be

63
00:03:28.620 --> 00:03:32.140
just like they are in the next room or
that board directly.

64
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:35.610
And that was the whole goal and
reason in terms of GRE.

65
00:03:35.610 --> 00:03:38.660
And it didn't really care about
the encapsulation as far,

66
00:03:38.660 --> 00:03:41.730
for encryption, not encapsulation.

67
00:03:41.730 --> 00:03:44.700
It didn't really care about
the encryption so much,

68
00:03:44.700 --> 00:03:48.792
as much as we need this to be [INAUDIBLE]
because of so many different types of

69
00:03:48.792 --> 00:03:52.432
networking equipment and
networking protocols that are there.

70
00:03:52.432 --> 00:03:55.968
Here's a generic one that allows
us to be able to go through and

71
00:03:55.968 --> 00:03:59.410
traverse all of them is what
it allows us to do, okay?

72
00:03:59.410 --> 00:04:03.290
So that is the figure that we're
actually working with a lot of times.

73
00:04:03.290 --> 00:04:04.720
Now is this still used?

74
00:04:04.720 --> 00:04:07.520
Yes, and it's actually making
a pretty big comeback.

75
00:04:07.520 --> 00:04:11.600
And that is because today's networks,
they are much more complicated.

76
00:04:11.600 --> 00:04:15.380
And instead of actually just kinda
doing everything that you need to,

77
00:04:15.380 --> 00:04:18.250
to not worry about any of the intervening
technology in the middle.

78
00:04:18.250 --> 00:04:21.890
Creating a GRE tunnel actually
makes it work a lot better and

79
00:04:21.890 --> 00:04:24.720
a lot more simplified for what we need.

80
00:04:24.720 --> 00:04:29.120
So we're going to show you how to
configure this particular type of tunnel

81
00:04:29.120 --> 00:04:31.970
using, of course,
the labs that we have on hand here.

82
00:04:31.970 --> 00:04:33.630
So that you can do this as well, okay?

83
00:04:33.630 --> 00:04:37.540
So let's take a look at my machine and
this is where we'll get started too, okay?

84
00:04:37.540 --> 00:04:39.140
So I'm gonna pull up that lab diagram.

85
00:04:39.140 --> 00:04:40.350
But before we do,

86
00:04:40.350 --> 00:04:44.370
make sure you remember that we do
have access to practicelabs.com.

87
00:04:44.370 --> 00:04:47.580
As a member of ITPro.TV,
you will be able to use these.

88
00:04:47.580 --> 00:04:50.430
And we'll be following our lab steps
to help us guide us through this,

89
00:04:50.430 --> 00:04:51.060
right?
>> Mm-hm, mm-hm.

90
00:04:51.060 --> 00:04:52.800
>> So interconnecting Cisco networking

91
00:04:52.800 --> 00:04:56.690
devices, make sure you choose ICND with
the one with the version three And

92
00:04:56.690 --> 00:05:00.960
we're gonna do Configure, Verify and
Troubleshoot GRE Connectivity and

93
00:05:00.960 --> 00:05:02.390
this is what we'll end up seeing.

94
00:05:02.390 --> 00:05:05.580
We're gonna create this idea
of the GRE tunnel, okay?

95
00:05:05.580 --> 00:05:09.440
So in the GRE tunnel, it says it doesn't
just have to run across the internet.

96
00:05:09.440 --> 00:05:12.030
You can use them to join networks
that wouldn't normally occur,

97
00:05:12.030 --> 00:05:14.660
enabling dynamic routing
across a firewall.

98
00:05:14.660 --> 00:05:16.630

Configure GRE, tunnel connectivity.

324
00:19:30.961 --> 00:19:33.460
Once again, Ronnie did a great job.

325
00:19:33.460 --> 00:19:34.520
Before we leave though Ronnie,

326
00:19:34.520 --> 00:19:35.970
anything else you'd like to say?
>> Well,

327
00:19:35.970 --> 00:19:39.720
the great thing is this is not such
a difficult configuration for us to know.

328
00:19:39.720 --> 00:19:43.200
So it's one of those few
topics that we have where

329
00:19:43.200 --> 00:19:46.840
the configuration seems logical,
it make sense, and

330
00:19:46.840 --> 00:19:50.480
it actually works the way that we
think it should very easily, okay.

331
00:19:50.480 --> 00:19:55.240
The hard part, once again,
is trying to remember, okay.

332
00:19:55.240 --> 00:19:56.690
That if you don't practice it,

333
00:19:56.690 --> 00:19:59.980
it's an easy detail to forget
when it comes down to the exam.

334
00:19:59.980 --> 00:20:04.250
So add this into a list of things that
you should be practicing as well.

335
00:20:04.250 --> 00:20:06.630
If this all makes sense, that's fine.

336
00:20:06.630 --> 00:20:09.600
Turn on the back burner compared
to some of the ones that really

337
00:20:09.600 --> 00:20:11.540
are more difficult for you.

338
00:20:11.540 --> 00:20:13.050
But do not forget it.

339
00:20:13.050 --> 00:20:14.680
Because this is something
you'll actually see, for

340
00:20:14.680 --> 00:20:19.590
those of you who are aspiring towards
your CCNP Routing and Switching exam, is

341
00:20:19.590 --> 00:20:24.190
something that you actually at least have
to have the fundamentals of it down first.

342
00:20:24.190 --> 00:20:27.950
But you'll see that there's actually
a lot more to GRE that we can configure.

343
00:20:27.950 --> 00:20:28.660
>> Thanks Ronnie,

344
00:20:28.660 --> 00:20:32.590
awesome, all your information is
fantastic and your advises, wonderful.

345
00:20:32.590 --> 00:20:34.360
And here's some more advice for you,

346
00:20:34.360 --> 00:20:38.632
make sure you see every single episode of
CCNA Routing and Switching exam 200-105.

347
00:20:38.632 --> 00:20:40.630
And while you're doing that,

348
00:20:40.630 --> 00:20:45.240
you're inside the course library where
there's thousands of other videos too.

349
00:20:45.240 --> 00:20:46.450
So make sure you check those out too.

350
00:20:47.480 --> 00:20:49.050
Tell everybody you know about ITProTV,

351
00:20:49.050 --> 00:20:52.410
you know a good ITProTV
person is always learning.

352
00:20:52.410 --> 00:20:53.030
Thanks for watching.

353
00:20:53.030 --> 00:20:54.550
I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

354
00:20:54.550 --> 00:20:55.243
>> And we will see you again soon.

355
00:20:55.243 --> 00:21:02.672
[MUSIC]

356
00:21:02.672 --> 00:21:04.985
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe what a WAN is and why we need them.  The guys also talk about some od the different types of WAN topologies that are configured by the service provider for the customer's need.
episodes.title: Describe WAN Topology Options
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.648
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.648 --> 00:00:06.708
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.708 --> 00:00:08.263
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.263 --> 00:00:13.069
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

5
00:00:13.069 --> 00:00:16.595
watching ITProTV, empowering
the world with engaging learning.

6
00:00:16.595 --> 00:00:20.813
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CCNA routing and

7
00:00:20.813 --> 00:00:23.140
switching, exam 200-105.

8
00:00:23.140 --> 00:00:25.990
This episode describes
WAN topology options, and

9
00:00:25.990 --> 00:00:29.910
we will be discussing those options
with the one and only Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:29.910 --> 00:00:32.920
Ronnie, great to have you here, thank you.
>> Well, Zach, thank you again for

11
00:00:32.920 --> 00:00:36.830
joining me once again on our CCNA
routing and switching journey together.

12
00:00:36.830 --> 00:00:39.342
We are now taking a look at
different WAN topologies.

13
00:00:39.342 --> 00:00:44.105
And we are about to discuss the idea here,
of course, of what that actually means,

14
00:00:44.105 --> 00:00:45.955
and why we need to know about it.

15
00:00:45.955 --> 00:00:48.307
So that is what we're
gonna be diving into.

16
00:00:48.307 --> 00:00:49.289
>> So Ronnie, what is a WAN,

17
00:00:49.289 --> 00:00:52.466
right off the bat, what is that?
>> Well, remember that there's actually

18
00:00:52.466 --> 00:00:55.620
different ways that networks were
pretty much described, okay?

19
00:00:55.620 --> 00:01:01.480
So for us, in just generic terminology, it
normally goes by geographic size, right?

20
00:01:01.480 --> 00:01:05.271
So when we start talking about the idea
of a LAN, a local area network,

21
00:01:05.271 --> 00:01:07.921
it's all of the actual
technologies combined.

22
00:01:07.921 --> 00:01:11.377
In which those devices are physically
connected together, and

23
00:01:11.377 --> 00:01:14.325
that they share that same
common media that they have.

24
00:01:14.325 --> 00:01:18.297
Well, then as you started extending that
outward, right, a little bit wider than

25
00:01:18.297 --> 00:01:21.887
that technology is what's called a MAN,
or a metropolitan area network.

26
00:01:21.887 --> 00:01:25.032
Where everybody's within that
same geographic region, but

27
00:01:25.032 --> 00:01:27.760
probably not within the same
building a lot of times.

28
00:01:27.760 --> 00:01:30.350
And that means that they might be
spread out throughout a city, but

29
00:01:30.350 --> 00:01:31.970
they're still localized to a point,

30
00:01:31.970 --> 00:01:36.120
probably within several kilometers
of each other as well, okay?

31
00:01:36.120 --> 00:01:37.954
But then you have, well, areas and

32
00:01:37.954 --> 00:01:41.455
different local area networks that
need to be connected together.

33
00:01:41.455 --> 00:01:45.503
But they're nowhere, maybe not even in
the same country or in the same state, but

34
00:01:45.503 --> 00:01:47.624
we still need connectivity between them.

35
00:01:47.624 --> 00:01:50.607
And that is what we call
a wide area network, or

36
00:01:50.607 --> 00:01:54.675
a WAN, is what we talk about in
terms of the idea of a WAN, okay?

37
00:01:54.675 --> 00:01:57.770
So for us to actually kinda
think about that, we might go,

38
00:01:57.770 --> 00:02:00.200
all right, so why do we need it, okay?

39
00:02:00.200 --> 00:02:03.927
So in that sense, right, when we start
talking about what a WAN is, okay,

40
00:02:03.927 --> 00:02:06.890
it allows us to connect,
well, LANs together.

41
00:02:06.890 --> 00:02:11.730
And the idea here is that LANs may exist
in multiple geographic locations, and

42
00:02:11.730 --> 00:02:14.670
we need that connection to come together,
okay?

43
00:02:14.670 --> 00:02:17.560
So when we start doing that,
how can we do that?

44
00:02:17.560 --> 00:02:20.210
Well, there's one way that we can do this,
Zach.

45
00:02:20.210 --> 00:02:24.594
You and I could actually run cables to all
the different places that we might have

46
00:02:24.594 --> 00:02:25.844
locations to, okay?

47
00:02:25.844 --> 00:02:29.294
So let's say, for example,
for us here at ITProTV,

48
00:02:29.294 --> 00:02:33.298
we know that we actually have
an office that's over in the UK.

49
00:02:33.298 --> 00:02:36.648
So Zach, you and I could run
a cable directly from Gainesville,

50
00:02:36.648 --> 00:02:38.406
Florida over into the UK, okay?

51
00:02:38.406 --> 00:02:41.969
Well, that seems almost impossibility,
that's a very long cable.

52
00:02:41.969 --> 00:02:42.624
>> Would be a long trip.

53
00:02:42.624 --> 00:02:44.032
>> So we can shorten that up.

54
00:02:44.032 --> 00:02:47.744
We also know that we have a couple
different employees that are spread around

55
00:02:47.744 --> 00:02:49.730
the United States as well, okay?

56
00:02:49.730 --> 00:02:52.370
So even here from Gainesville, Florida,
could we actually run it up to Raleigh,

57
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:53.430
North Carolina?

58
00:02:53.430 --> 00:02:56.356
No, even that seems like
an impossibility as well.

59
00:02:56.356 --> 00:03:01.082
And even some in Chicago,
no, we can't do that.

60
00:03:01.082 --> 00:03:02.907
And there's a lot of reasons why, okay?

61
00:03:02.907 --> 00:03:05.619
One of the reasons is, you and
I don't own enough cable, okay, so

62
00:03:05.619 --> 00:03:07.492
that's one of the reasons.
>> That's one of the reasons.

63
00:03:07.492 --> 00:03:08.215
>> Secondly,

64
00:03:08.215 --> 00:03:13.120
we'd have to actually kinda break laws,
okay, to do some of this, right?

65
00:03:13.120 --> 00:03:16.100
We'd have to actually not only run the
cable, we'd have to bury it in people's

66
00:03:16.100 --> 00:03:19.620
yards, we'd have to tear fences
down to run it through, right?

67
00:03:19.620 --> 00:03:22.244
And go over creeks and mountains,
and explode some stuff,

68
00:03:22.244 --> 00:03:23.932
whatever we might have to do, right?

69
00:03:23.932 --> 00:03:26.458
So there's things that we cannot overcome.

70
00:03:26.458 --> 00:03:31.123
Because, well, even though it sounds like
a great idea in running a cable, okay,

71
00:03:31.123 --> 00:03:33.410
it's just impossible to do.

72
00:03:33.410 --> 00:03:37.570
So a WAN is normally owned by
what we call a service provider.

73
00:03:37.570 --> 00:03:41.270
A service provider says, look, you can't
do it, but we have millions of dollars.

74
00:03:41.270 --> 00:03:43.640
And we have these different systems
that we've already bought and

75
00:03:43.640 --> 00:03:46.560
paid for that we can connect together.

76
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:50.320
That might give you that connection
between here in Gainesville and the UK.

77
00:03:50.320 --> 00:03:55.043
That might give us the connection between
here and Chicago, or here and Raleigh,

78
00:03:55.043 --> 00:03:57.994
whatever it might be,
we have those connections.

79
00:03:57.994 --> 00:03:59.744
And all you have to do, Zach,

80
00:03:59.744 --> 00:04:03.947
instead is just pay us the cost of
whatever the subscription is, okay?

81
00:04:03.947 --> 00:04:06.552
Well, that sounds a lot easier for
me to do, okay?

82
00:04:06.552 --> 00:04:10.350
Than to actually go, all right, Zach,
go and grab that gigantic spool of

83
00:04:10.350 --> 00:04:14.500
cable that's the size of an 18 wheeler
truck to be able to actually run.

84
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:17.350
And make sure you get five or
six of them along the way, and

85
00:04:17.350 --> 00:04:18.850
we'll start running this cable.

86
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:21.426
It's just about an impossibility
at that point, okay?

87
00:04:21.426 --> 00:04:24.605
So when we start seeing it,
that's what normally happens here, okay?

88
00:04:24.605 --> 00:04:28.550
So typical types of what we
call WAN providers, right?

89
00:04:28.550 --> 00:04:29.450
Would be, again,

90
00:04:29.450 --> 00:04:33.820
our our Internet service providers,
including satellite Internet providers,

91
00:04:33.820 --> 00:04:38.400
cable Internet providers, telephone
networks that are actually out there, DSL.

92
00:04:38.400 --> 00:04:42.560
These are all different types of WANs that
we can actually have that provide for

93
00:04:42.560 --> 00:04:46.640
us the ability to connect these
different sites together.

94
00:04:46.640 --> 00:04:50.664
But instead of me having to run
my own cable to do so, okay?

95
00:04:50.664 --> 00:04:54.472
I can actually just go ahead and be able
to actually say, all right, I'll pay for

96
00:04:54.472 --> 00:04:57.550
the connection if you'll
make the connection for me.

97
00:04:57.550 --> 00:05:01.267
So that's really the idea and purpose
of what we have, when we start talking

98
00:05:01.267 --> 00:05:04.646
about the purpose of a WAN.
>> So you've already touched on this,

99
00:05:04.646 --> 00:05:07.069
and it might be a little redundant here,
but

100
00:05:07.069 --> 00:05:09.796
why do we need WANs?
>> Yeah, well, we need WANs because when

101
00:05:09.796 --> 00:05:13.051
we start thinking about the idea of some
of those connections that we just talked

102
00:05:13.051 --> 00:05:16.910
about, even though it's long distance,
right, that's not the only problem.

103
00:05:16.910 --> 00:05:20.920
What about all those other people that
need those connections as well, okay?

104
00:05:20.920 --> 00:05:23.074
So when something happens,
let me show you a picture here.

105
00:05:23.074 --> 00:05:25.368
I just pulled this up as a generic
picture that we can show.

106
00:05:25.368 --> 00:05:25.881
>> [LAUGH]

107
00:05:25.881 --> 00:05:27.908
>> Here's what happens when you allow

108
00:05:27.908 --> 00:05:30.281
everybody to run their own cable, okay?

109
00:05:30.281 --> 00:05:31.484
So when you take a look,

110
00:05:31.484 --> 00:05:34.262
you can see generic of
[CROSSTALK] print on here, okay?

111
00:05:34.262 --> 00:05:37.396
So this is how you know if
somebody's actually overloading.

112
00:05:37.396 --> 00:05:40.833
Now, we can tell, well,
I say we can tell, okay?

113
00:05:40.833 --> 00:05:46.249
There definitely is this point where
this is what actually telephone poles or

114
00:05:46.249 --> 00:05:51.166
the electricity poles would have
actually looked like around the turn

115
00:05:51.166 --> 00:05:52.843
of the 20th century.

116
00:05:52.843 --> 00:05:56.819
Okay, not the 21st century,
the 20th century, as Edison and

117
00:05:56.819 --> 00:05:59.805
all that stuff started getting working,
right?

118
00:05:59.805 --> 00:06:03.594
Every apartment building
needed their own connection.

119
00:06:03.594 --> 00:06:04.673
>> So there was a line to everybody.

120
00:06:04.673 --> 00:06:06.047
>> And the weird thing is,

121
00:06:06.047 --> 00:06:08.865
people would actually climb
up on those poles and

122
00:06:08.865 --> 00:06:11.752
run their own electrical
lines from the source and

123
00:06:11.752 --> 00:06:14.728
out to their own apartments even, okay?
>> Goodness gracious.

124
00:06:14.728 --> 00:06:16.412
>> Every single one of these things like

125
00:06:16.412 --> 00:06:17.069
that, okay?

126
00:06:17.069 --> 00:06:21.141
So what I'm trying to actually show you
is that this is probably not to US code.

127
00:06:21.141 --> 00:06:22.966
That is what we'd have today, okay?

128
00:06:22.966 --> 00:06:25.810
But this is essentially what we
would be talking about if you and

129
00:06:25.810 --> 00:06:27.690
I were actually allowed to do this.

130
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:30.218
Beause we're not the only ones that
would actually need connections like

131
00:06:30.218 --> 00:06:30.755
that, right?

132
00:06:30.755 --> 00:06:34.610
Everybody that actually starts running
this, all of a sudden, you start seeing

133
00:06:34.610 --> 00:06:38.070
now where you're actually grateful
that this is a concrete pole first,

134
00:06:38.070 --> 00:06:39.560
is what you're grateful for.

135
00:06:39.560 --> 00:06:42.530
Cuz I can't imagine the actual regular old

136
00:06:42.530 --> 00:06:45.530
pole that they would've used that's
made out of wood to handle all of this.

137
00:06:45.530 --> 00:06:47.210
But when you start seeing
something like this,

138
00:06:47.210 --> 00:06:51.250
right, there's a great reason why
WAN providers are needed, okay?

139
00:06:51.250 --> 00:06:55.524
It's because they can actually
provide this infrastructure and

140
00:06:55.524 --> 00:06:58.172
remove something that looks like this.

141
00:06:58.172 --> 00:07:02.164
Just for the idea of simple
connectivity that we might have for

142
00:07:02.164 --> 00:07:03.790
our data access, okay?

143
00:07:03.790 --> 00:07:07.065
So its overwhelming ability
to do something like this,

144
00:07:07.065 --> 00:07:09.510
okay, really does help us out to do that.

145
00:07:09.510 --> 00:07:12.808
So without WANs,
we are pretty much in trouble because one,

146
00:07:12.808 --> 00:07:16.058
we may not have the technical
ability to run what we need to.

147
00:07:16.058 --> 00:07:20.271
Two, if everybody starts doing it, this
is what would actually end up happening.

148
00:07:20.271 --> 00:07:20.880
>> Chaos.

149
00:07:20.880 --> 00:07:22.636
>> And now, yeah, imagine, Zach,

150
00:07:22.636 --> 00:07:25.121
somebody's actually
climbing up there to say,

151
00:07:25.121 --> 00:07:28.649
I know I can actually make the connection
I need to through just this.

152
00:07:28.649 --> 00:07:29.305
>> [LAUGH]

153
00:07:29.305 --> 00:07:29.904
>> I mean,

154
00:07:29.904 --> 00:07:35.575
I just imagine something like this where
somebody said, I think I can do this.

155
00:07:35.575 --> 00:07:39.612
And decided to climb up this pole,
and run their own connections,

156
00:07:39.612 --> 00:07:42.220
is what you actually end up seeing, okay?

157
00:07:42.220 --> 00:07:46.133
So yeah, so that's a big no-no
when we start doing this.

158
00:07:46.133 --> 00:07:49.444
Now, the other thing that the WAN
provider allows to to do,

159
00:07:49.444 --> 00:07:52.757
because in theory, right,
the only reason why you have any

160
00:07:52.757 --> 00:07:57.477
particular privacy at all is because you
know which of these lines are yours, okay?

161
00:07:57.477 --> 00:07:59.623
But you don't know who
everybody else's line is.

162
00:07:59.623 --> 00:08:00.771
So it could be that if I ran this and

163
00:08:00.771 --> 00:08:03.660
go, I wonder if this session connects over
to where I think it's gonna connect to.

164
00:08:03.660 --> 00:08:07.520
You could be tapping in
somebody else's line instead.

165
00:08:07.520 --> 00:08:09.591
So now you have an infrastructure, and

166
00:08:09.591 --> 00:08:12.855
this is actually a picture of
an infrastructure of some sort,

167
00:08:12.855 --> 00:08:16.650
not a good infrastructure, but
it's a picture of an infrastructure.

168
00:08:16.650 --> 00:08:20.771
We could tap into any one of these lines,
hopefully not get electrocuted, but

169
00:08:20.771 --> 00:08:23.790
let's pretend like these are data lines,
right.

170
00:08:23.790 --> 00:08:26.167
So we could tap into any
one of these possibly and

171
00:08:26.167 --> 00:08:28.970
end up getting information
that we shouldn't, okay.

172
00:08:28.970 --> 00:08:31.761
The WAN provider,
what we do is when we pay them for it,

173
00:08:31.761 --> 00:08:34.880
we end up getting also what we
call a service loan agreement.

174
00:08:34.880 --> 00:08:39.200
And that may also mean, not only are we
gonna provide our own protections.

175
00:08:39.200 --> 00:08:42.650
But they're gonna also protect the network
from, well, things like this, okay,

176
00:08:42.650 --> 00:08:44.170
as is what you're actually seeing.

177
00:08:44.170 --> 00:08:48.510
So that's why I wanted to show this
particular image as we do this.

178
00:08:48.510 --> 00:08:49.845
So it can provide some security,

179
00:08:49.845 --> 00:08:52.139
it can secure our network
connections a little bit more.

180
00:08:52.139 --> 00:08:55.794
It also allows us to think
about this idea, okay,

181
00:08:55.794 --> 00:09:00.740
of doing the connections without
having to sweat a lot, okay.

182
00:09:00.740 --> 00:09:04.962
So even though we think about this,
about, hey, a service provider and

183
00:09:04.962 --> 00:09:08.230
redundancy about what it is and
why we actually need it.

184
00:09:08.230 --> 00:09:12.778
It does help us when we see this picture
to essentially describe our need for

185
00:09:12.778 --> 00:09:13.990
it, okay.

186
00:09:13.990 --> 00:09:16.447
So what we wanna talk
about now of course then,

187
00:09:16.447 --> 00:09:20.306
are well what are the different options
that we might actually run into?

188
00:09:20.306 --> 00:09:24.550
And we might have when we start taking
a look at the idea of the topology.

189
00:09:24.550 --> 00:09:26.250
This is something that you
don't want to see, okay.

190
00:09:26.250 --> 00:09:30.360
Now just when I say that, do you tend to
see this inside of a lot of circuits?

191

00:17:30.795 --> 00:17:35.551

00:17:35.551 --> 00:17:40.520

00:17:40.520 --> 00:17:45.382

00:17:45.382 --> 00:17:49.628

00:17:49.628 --> 00:17:51.459

00:17:56.824 --> 00:18:03.038

00:18:12.382 --> 00:18:15.522

00:18:21.370 --> 00:18:25.548

00:18:25.548 --> 00:18:30.486

00:18:30.486 --> 00:18:35.900

00:18:36.930 --> 00:18:40.442

00:18:53.590 --> 00:18:55.494

00:19:04.180 --> 00:19:07.634

00:19:07.634 --> 00:19:08.596

00:19:13.392 --> 00:19:17.926

00:19:26.010 --> 00:19:32.444

00:19:32.444 --> 00:19:36.090
So we can actually do that and
a lot of the, I wouldn't say a lot.

00:19:36.090 --> 00:19:40.239
Other cabling that's out there can

00:19:40.239 --> 00:19:43.386

So when we start talking about this

So if I am as a customer, and let's say

There's not a lot of different

Now, we are supposed

00:24:44.860 --> 00:24:46.830
There it is,

And now we'll kind of

00:24:50.770 --> 00:24:53.420

When you start hearing about this

00:25:13.741 --> 00:25:18.640

00:25:26.660 --> 00:25:29.380
Instead of over some type of leased line,

00:25:29.380 --> 00:25:32.170
So for us, when we started to
actually take a look at this and

00:25:32.170 --> 00:25:36.700
actually implementing it for
general customer service.

453
00:25:36.700 --> 00:25:40.700
The thing that we actually want to

454
00:25:40.700 --> 00:25:44.980
the first technologies that we

455
00:25:44.980 --> 00:25:50.130
And we do it because it allows us

456
00:25:50.130 --> 00:25:54.360
So instead of actually saying,
here is the technology and

00:25:54.360 --> 00:25:57.630
let me deal with it the way we need to,

00:25:57.630 --> 00:26:02.340
This particular technology PPPoE
was actually designed with

00:26:02.340 --> 00:26:04.330

00:26:04.330 --> 00:26:09.970
Okay, to be able to manage IP

00:26:09.970 --> 00:26:15.160
As well as to track the customer's

00:26:15.160 --> 00:26:19.820
So it has this advantage if you

00:26:19.820 --> 00:26:22.940

00:26:22.940 --> 00:26:25.950

00:26:25.950 --> 00:26:29.760
So it's a very popular technology

00:26:29.760 --> 00:26:33.700
But it does have problems just like

This is one of the few WAN technologies

00:26:38.160 --> 00:26:42.080

00:26:42.080 --> 00:26:46.440
up working for the client side

But once we get that and we get everything

00:26:50.060 --> 00:26:52.910

00:26:52.910 --> 00:26:54.740
So, when we start taking

00:26:54.740 --> 00:26:58.130

00:26:58.130 --> 00:27:01.870
So then we can set up authentication,

00:27:01.870 --> 00:27:06.680

We can also of course be able to get some

00:27:16.650 --> 00:27:19.400

00:27:19.400 --> 00:27:22.850
If you're not familiar with it,

00:27:22.850 --> 00:27:24.860
But now that we've gone

00:27:24.860 --> 00:27:26.670
you can always refer back to it and go.

00:27:26.670 --> 00:27:27.950
I know how to configure that one, or

00:27:27.950 --> 00:27:32.560

485
00:27:32.560 --> 00:27:33.620
And then of course,

486
00:27:33.620 --> 00:27:37.410
the advantage of it is that by using this
technology cuz it was designed around this

00:27:37.410 --> 00:27:41.220
idea of the business that we wanted
to accomplish with it, okay?

488
00:27:41.220 --> 00:27:45.020
We can monitor and
we can track everything that goes on.

489
00:27:45.020 --> 00:27:47.630
Now can this be defeated to a point?

490
00:27:48.700 --> 00:27:54.380
If you're using virtual private networks,
right, a VPN connection,

491
00:27:54.380 --> 00:27:58.320
you can actually end up
defeating that idea of tracking.

492
00:27:58.320 --> 00:28:02.060
And the reason why for
tracking to end up happening, right.

493
00:28:02.060 --> 00:28:05.110
That means that they have to be able
to look inside the packets to see where

494
00:28:05.110 --> 00:28:05.710
it's going to.

495
00:28:05.710 --> 00:28:09.540
So in other words, I have to see
the source, I have to see the destination.

496
00:28:09.540 --> 00:28:11.440
That layer three header that
we were talking about and

497
00:28:11.440 --> 00:28:14.400
see all that stuff,
maybe even deeper if they wanted to, okay?

498
00:28:14.400 --> 00:28:18.390
They have to be able to see all that but
if you use a VPN, a virtual private

499
00:28:18.390 --> 00:28:23.540
network, that kinda destroys the ability
to any kind of deep packet inspection.

500
00:28:23.540 --> 00:28:28.100
So that then defeats the ability
to any kind of tracking at all.

501
00:28:28.100 --> 00:28:31.300
But it's still popular if you've

502
00:28:31.300 --> 00:28:34.900
That's probably still the most

503
00:28:34.900 --> 00:28:37.640
All right, we've still got just

00:28:37.640 --> 00:28:43.450

00:28:43.450 --> 00:28:46.660
Now I know this is a little bit

506
00:28:47.690 --> 00:28:50.620
But I want us to take a look at this
little tunnel that I have created right

507
00:28:50.620 --> 00:28:53.270
here in the connections that we are doing.

508
00:28:54.480 --> 00:28:57.440
We talked about the idea of
a side to side VPN, okay?

509
00:28:57.440 --> 00:28:58.670
The two clouds that are represent,

510
00:28:58.670 --> 00:29:02.420
let's say those are regular desktop
users inside of our LANs, okay?

511
00:29:02.420 --> 00:29:04.750
They have no clue in one way or the other.

512
00:29:04.750 --> 00:29:08.510
Whether I should use the VPN connection or
not, okay?

513
00:29:08.510 --> 00:29:10.120
But they actually do,

514
00:29:10.120 --> 00:29:14.750
if they need to send from 192.168.1.0 over
192.168.2.0, they don't know that it's

515
00:29:14.750 --> 00:29:20.290
gonna be an encrypted connection all
the way through to the other side.

516
00:29:20.290 --> 00:29:23.620
Those users, they see it and
it's transparent.

517
00:29:23.620 --> 00:29:26.360
They don't have a clue that it's going on,
okay.

518
00:29:26.360 --> 00:29:29.500
So when we start doing something like
that, that's essentially what happens.

519
00:29:29.500 --> 00:29:32.710
Because the encryption happens
right here on the edge.

520
00:29:32.710 --> 00:29:38.190
Notice on this interface, it happens and
then over here on the other interface.

521
00:29:38.190 --> 00:29:42.390
So when you take a look at packets as they
flow through, it can go from a single

522
00:29:42.390 --> 00:29:46.660
source to a single destination,
from one network to the other network.

523
00:29:46.660 --> 00:29:50.500
And then,
the VPN header is also added here and

524
00:29:50.500 --> 00:29:53.300
then all of the data in between that.

525
00:29:53.300 --> 00:29:54.920
It's gonna be encrypted.

526
00:29:54.920 --> 00:29:58.110
So any time somebody tries to
actually try and peer into it,

527
00:29:58.110 --> 00:30:01.980
they will not be able to get into that

16.20.

10,000.

when we actually finish the ping here
>> Let's see, okay, this time,

it still only dropped two

that's why we talk about is near 100%

that we only drop that, that's not bad at

Configure Basic HSRP,

>> Well, the great thing is this is

But the other thing, right, is to actually

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss Cloud Resources.  They discuss how to access cloud resources and the different types of virtual services available. Lastly, they describe the virtual network infrastructure.
episodes.title: Describe Cloud Resource Impact on Enterprise

>> Right, so when we start talking about

probably forgot to say this as we were

A lot of times people get a little

So as we begin and we start talking about

what it should make you do is think about,

well we're connecting to

It doesn't belong to us, but the nice

46

>> Right.
>> So when we connect to cloud services,

the earliest rendition of what we would

And that server forum normally for

And that really is a big part of

So when we first actually

we start talking about the idea

The impact of it on an enterprise really

Over here, of course, is my example

I just put ITProTV.

So, normally when we

there's normally three different

00:03:42.800 --> 00:03:46.250
When we start talking about

The first one, of course,

74
00:03:50.010 --> 00:03:52.349
If we have access to

we can then access any of the cloud

over here on the right that's

>> [LAUGH] It is.

78

>> In terms of the different services,

79

And that particular connection as we do so
okay, well this does help us

because now we're no longer keeping really
any real big infrastructure on hand.

81

But our particular kind of bottleneck at

00:04:17.090 --> 00:04:20.850
The Internet doesn't really care

It doesn't care that you have

What that means is you also have to

particular intersection at some point
here, that can cause some disruptions.

86
00:04:33.750 --> 00:04:37.170
So for example, right, when you talk

87
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:39.900
at least here in the United States,
I'm not gonna say all over the world.

88
00:04:39.900 --> 00:04:43.640
At least here in the United States,
you essentially have backbone connections

89
00:04:43.640 --> 00:04:47.450
that actually run North and South and

90
00:04:47.450 --> 00:04:50.401
What all it takes is one of

Depending on where your traffic

00:04:59.010 --> 00:05:01.090

That's when you know you

So most of these particular cloud services

So like there's a big gigantic center,

But then there's also, of course, those

00:05:24.090 --> 00:05:26.570
So when you start doing that,

104
00:05:26.570 --> 00:05:30.150
Sometimes you also see them right smack

105
00:05:30.150 --> 00:05:35.120
But any type of that time when there's
an internet connection that's kind of

00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:36.770
overwhelmed, right.

107
00:05:36.770 --> 00:05:37.680
Anywhere along that path,

108
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:40.700
you're gonna experience that

109
00:05:40.700 --> 00:05:42.850
So all these particular services,

110
00:05:42.850 --> 00:05:46.290
as we start talking about the internet

111
00:05:46.290 --> 00:05:49.796
We don't really have to worry

00:05:49.796 --> 00:05:53.964

00:05:57.223 --> 00:06:00.190
So that's kind of the very first

115
00:06:01.620 --> 00:06:04.979
The other type of connection, this one

00:06:04.979 --> 00:06:05.661
demonstrate.

117
00:06:05.661 --> 00:06:07.935
I tried to move this out of the way so

00:06:07.935 --> 00:06:12.721
we can focus in on a little bit more
instead is that, what we don't do is we

don't get to our cloud services by trying

120
00:06:18.770 --> 00:06:21.680
Cloud services themselves,
and you can look and see what

type of services that are available to

122
00:06:25.780 --> 00:06:29.090
They may have their own private WAN

that then you would also pay

00:06:31.770 --> 00:06:36.000
So that you can make a connection to

00:06:36.000 --> 00:06:39.560
So you would connect to the nearest
node that you can, and at that point,

00:06:39.560 --> 00:06:40.500

So now notice where I actually

00:06:43.370 --> 00:06:46.790

When you do that, the enterprise

00:06:54.350 --> 00:06:57.800

00:06:57.800 --> 00:07:02.440
And that means, for example ITProTV,

00:07:02.440 --> 00:07:06.480

00:07:06.480 --> 00:07:11.580
Or, if we wanted to, we would actually
connect to Azure connection, as well.

135
00:07:11.580 --> 00:07:13.290
And then, even AWS.

136
00:07:13.290 --> 00:07:13.955
And of course,

137
00:07:13.955 --> 00:07:18.640

138
00:07:18.640 --> 00:07:22.310
So, all that is actually available for

139
00:07:22.310 --> 00:07:25.890
So not only do we have the internet,
but we also have the ability

140
00:07:25.890 --> 00:07:29.710
to have these particular private
WAN services that are available.

141
00:07:29.710 --> 00:07:32.860
This one is a dedicated connection,
which means,

142
00:07:32.860 --> 00:07:37.620
the only traffic allowed in these
private clouds is traffic going to them.

143
00:07:37.620 --> 00:07:39.415
And that means less traffic.

144
00:07:39.415 --> 00:07:44.315
You're not competing with somebody else,
watching YouTube in an apartment complex.

145
00:07:44.315 --> 00:07:45.211
>> [LAUGH]
>> You know,

146
00:07:45.211 --> 00:07:48.510
you are not having to worry
about anything like that.

147
00:07:48.510 --> 00:07:53.260
But all you're doing is you're really just
using that same particular connection and

148

all those that need those dedicated
service, they may actually,

149
00:07:56.903 --> 00:07:58.939
again purchase that subscription.

150

To be able to access theirs

151
00:08:01.906 --> 00:08:02.583
The benefit of this, right?

152
00:08:02.583 --> 00:08:07.754
Is that we're no longer sending any
traffic across an Internet connection.

153
00:08:07.754 --> 00:08:09.492
Now, is it as protected?

154
00:08:09.492 --> 00:08:13.388
It's actually better protected on
the Internet connection you and

155
00:08:13.388 --> 00:08:18.035
I would still have to a VPN, a virtual
private network connection that tunnels us

156
00:08:18.035 --> 00:08:21.605

provides encryption to help us out.

157
00:08:21.605 --> 00:08:25.393
Which is fine, it works,
a lot of us do it all the time.

158
00:08:25.393 --> 00:08:28.815
But if your particular
company though said, look,

159
00:08:28.815 --> 00:08:33.030
I wanna make sure that my traffic

00:21:01.180 --> 00:21:04.030
And might have just said, here,
we'll provide the infrastructure.

387
00:21:04.030 --> 00:21:08.134
But now, they're also into
managing the Office 365 for you.

388
00:21:08.134 --> 00:21:10.290
So they're providing a platform for
you as well.

389
00:21:10.290 --> 00:21:14.030
They're providing all the other management
things that you have to be able to do.

390
00:21:14.030 --> 00:21:18.722
But just kind realize that all these
pretty much include, of course, the IaaS,

391
00:21:18.722 --> 00:21:22.760
okay, which is the infrastructure
as a service on hand

392
00:21:22.760 --> 00:21:25.740
as we start talking about all of them,
okay?

393
00:21:25.740 --> 00:21:28.680
Now, there is a distinction
that we need to make, okay, for

394
00:21:28.680 --> 00:21:30.280
these services as well, okay?

395
00:21:30.280 --> 00:21:33.900
And I actually wanna stay on this
particular screen because I have it

396
00:21:33.900 --> 00:21:39.130
marked right here in terms of
private Cloud and public Cloud.

397
00:21:39.130 --> 00:21:41.580
So you'll hear those two different terms.

398
00:21:41.580 --> 00:21:44.158
Private Cloud is as far as it's goes,

399
00:21:44.158 --> 00:21:48.860
pretty much means that the resources
are owned by, well, your company.

400
00:21:48.860 --> 00:21:51.280
So if your company says, hey,
we're gonna create a private Cloud,

401
00:21:51.280 --> 00:21:54.830
what they're saying is they
are investing In their own data center.

402
00:21:54.830 --> 00:21:56.960
And that means that they
own all the equipment.

403
00:21:56.960 --> 00:21:59.240
They have to pay for
their own electricity.

404
00:21:59.240 --> 00:22:01.290
They have to, of course,
have their own licensing for

405
00:22:01.290 --> 00:22:03.280
all the stuff that
they're gonna run on it.

406
00:22:03.280 --> 00:22:06.640
They are gonna maintain it,
they are gonna manage it themselves.

407
00:22:06.640 --> 00:22:10.710
And that may be a very viable way for
a company to actually work.

408
00:22:10.710 --> 00:22:12.896
So does that mean,
though, a private Cloud,

409
00:22:12.896 --> 00:22:16.510
does that mean a data center
right there on-site all the time?

410
00:22:16.510 --> 00:22:17.690
Not necessarily.

411
00:22:17.690 --> 00:22:19.006
It can be, okay?

412
00:22:19.006 --> 00:22:24.500
You can build up your own data center and
it can actually run and work that way.

413
00:22:24.500 --> 00:22:28.720
But you can also end up
purchasing that IaaS,

414
00:22:28.720 --> 00:22:32.260
the infrastructure as a service,
from one of the Cloud providers, and

415
00:22:32.260 --> 00:22:34.660
say, look, I don't need all
of the rest of the services.

416
00:22:34.660 --> 00:22:36.920
I need the infrastructure here.

417
00:22:36.920 --> 00:22:40.480
And you can actually say it's
gonna be dedicated to me, okay?

418
00:22:40.480 --> 00:22:46.240
So it can be what we call a hosted Cloud
or you can put it up for yourself as well.

419
00:22:46.240 --> 00:22:50.129
Everything else that you and
I have actually talked about so far,

420
00:22:50.129 --> 00:22:53.181
these are also what we call
public Cloud services.

421
00:22:53.181 --> 00:22:56.635
And that is because, well,
they're gonna be shared resources for

422
00:22:56.635 --> 00:22:58.540
more than one particular company.

423
00:22:58.540 --> 00:23:02.430
Sometimes even governments that are out
there and all of these would be examples

424
00:23:02.430 --> 00:23:08.090
of public Cloud services that we also
have available to us, too, okay?

425
00:23:08.090 --> 00:23:12.240
So when we start taking a look at that
idea of that impact, right, so for

426
00:23:12.240 --> 00:23:14.110
your company in terms of the impact.

427
00:23:15.470 --> 00:23:20.090
If you wanted to, okay, in all reality,
your company at this point,

428
00:23:20.090 --> 00:23:24.150
the only thing it really would need
internally a lot of times, okay,

429
00:23:24.150 --> 00:23:29.380
would be a switch, and of course, desktop
computers for everybody to sit down at.

430
00:23:29.380 --> 00:23:31.630
Or laptops or whatever it might be.

431
00:23:31.630 --> 00:23:35.440
And of course,
just your basic networking to go on.

432
00:23:35.440 --> 00:23:38.060
But from that point, if you wanted
everything else in terms of your

433
00:23:38.060 --> 00:23:41.750
infrastructure to be in a cloud service,
you could.

434
00:23:41.750 --> 00:23:44.490
You could put all of your servers
into a cloud whether it's a public or

435
00:23:44.490 --> 00:23:45.930
private, okay?

436
00:23:45.930 --> 00:23:47.405
You can even have your data,

437
00:23:47.405 --> 00:23:51.530
all of your data in terms of a high-speed
storage device, up here in the Cloud.

438
00:23:51.530 --> 00:23:54.296
You and I would never know about it,
and it would be fine.

439
00:23:54.296 --> 00:23:59.314
And it has availability like crazy,
which is also a key feature for us.

440
00:23:59.314 --> 00:24:03.052
Now all that can actually be
managed in that way in particular.

441
00:24:03.052 --> 00:24:07.814
The only time that you ever really worry
about the idea of cloud services not being

442
00:24:07.814 --> 00:24:10.336
enough for you, at least in today's age,

443
00:24:10.336 --> 00:24:14.280
it depends on what you're
doing at that moment in time.

444
00:24:14.280 --> 00:24:19.210
So a great example of that right now
is when our video right here finishes,

445
00:24:19.210 --> 00:24:20.660
when we do this, right?

446
00:24:20.660 --> 00:24:23.690
It's gonna get sent to
a local server at this point,

447
00:24:23.690 --> 00:24:27.030
this is where our production
team will go in and edit it.

448
00:24:27.030 --> 00:24:31.030
Now if we had it only in the cloud service
at this point, that would mean that

449
00:24:31.030 --> 00:24:34.490
as we finished a video it would
have to get uploaded to the cloud.

450
00:24:34.490 --> 00:24:35.600
If there's any editing,

451
00:24:35.600 --> 00:24:40.240
because normally Ronnie kind of
messes up or something, right?

452
00:24:40.240 --> 00:24:43.780
Well, that means they'd have to pull
a copy of that down from the cloud to

453
00:24:43.780 --> 00:24:45.950
a local computer, then wait for

454
00:24:45.950 --> 00:24:50.790
that copy to go on, have that fixed and
put it back up in place.

455
00:24:50.790 --> 00:24:55.410
ideally, what should happen right, is as
it goes from the recording device that

456
00:24:55.410 --> 00:24:58.800
it's on, it immediately goes
either to our storage server or

457
00:24:58.800 --> 00:25:01.890
goes directly over to one
of the editing stations.

458
00:25:01.890 --> 00:25:06.370
Stays there until it's done, once it's
done, then it gets uploaded into cloud.

459
00:25:06.370 --> 00:25:10.640
So there are times when it's not
sufficient for everything, but

460
00:25:10.640 --> 00:25:14.450
you have that ability to do so
if it needs to do so.

461
00:25:14.450 --> 00:25:17.570
So that's why it's important
that we understand that, okay?

462
00:25:17.570 --> 00:25:20.230
So there are needs for everything, okay?

463
00:25:20.230 --> 00:25:23.060
But for example right here at ITProTV,

464
00:25:23.060 --> 00:25:27.521
we don't really have anything
besides the storage servers,

465
00:25:27.521 --> 00:25:32.166
okay, or the videos that we have
on hand for our library, okay?

466
00:25:32.166 --> 00:25:36.289
But everything else, we are doing through
the cloud because we have redundancies in

467
00:25:36.289 --> 00:25:38.262
the cloud that I don't think about, and

468
00:25:38.262 --> 00:25:41.590
that's another big part of
using cloud services too.

469
00:25:41.590 --> 00:25:44.510
Now we've got a few minutes left,
which is perfect because

470
00:25:44.510 --> 00:25:49.030
we need to actually talk about
the idea of how this virtual.

471
00:25:49.030 --> 00:25:53.990
We need to understand the basic
virtual network infrastructure, okay?

472
00:25:53.990 --> 00:25:56.780
So, we're doing this for
one machine, is what we're doing, so

473
00:25:56.780 --> 00:26:00.690
that we can talk about how in the world
that something like this ends up working.

474
00:26:02.300 --> 00:26:07.240
This whole thing represents one physical
machine as far as the color portion goes.

475
00:26:07.240 --> 00:26:10.245
Notice there's a switch at the bottom,
there's a router at the bottom,

476
00:26:10.245 --> 00:26:12.820
going out to whatever LAN
provider we have, okay?

477
00:26:12.820 --> 00:26:16.520
Now besides that, the only other thing we
know about the hardware at this point is

478
00:26:16.520 --> 00:26:22.800
that there are two network interface cards
that we have inside as our hardware.

479
00:26:22.800 --> 00:26:27.410
But running on top of our hardware though,
because we are virtualizing everything,

480
00:26:27.410 --> 00:26:29.710
we run a hypervisor.

481
00:26:29.710 --> 00:26:31.390
And in that hypervisor,

482
00:26:31.390 --> 00:26:36.880
okay, it allows me to essentially
create a virtual switch here.

483
00:26:36.880 --> 00:26:42.350
And then I can also create VMs or
virtual machines on top of them.

484
00:26:42.350 --> 00:26:45.610
Inside of those VMs,
I can run different operating systems or

485
00:26:45.610 --> 00:26:50.180
the same operating systems, I can run
different application in each one,

486
00:26:50.180 --> 00:26:53.380
if I choose to, all that is very possible.

487
00:26:53.380 --> 00:26:57.515
But if I want them to be networked so
that other people can access them,

488
00:26:57.515 --> 00:27:01.579
I will then also have to realize
that inside of that virtual machine,

489
00:27:01.579 --> 00:27:03.916
there is going to also be a virtual NIC.

490
00:27:03.916 --> 00:27:10.290
Or a virtual network adapter that can
connect to this virtualized switch here.

491
00:27:10.290 --> 00:27:14.250
The virtualized switch will
then be able to talk to

492
00:27:14.250 --> 00:27:19.610
these two network adapters to send
the data out into the physical world.

493
00:27:19.610 --> 00:27:24.760
So the idea of translating, or making sure
that data can get from a virtual machine

494
00:27:24.760 --> 00:27:30.170
into the physical machine here, does work
in this way where we have virtualized

495
00:27:30.170 --> 00:27:33.120
hardware, that's the easiest
way to think about it.

496
00:27:33.120 --> 00:27:37.630
>> That then gets translated by
the hypervisor, into the real hardware and

497
00:27:37.630 --> 00:27:41.830
the real hardware delivers that, of
course, out to where it needs to go, okay?

498
00:27:41.830 --> 00:27:45.600
So these types of connections
are important for us to understand.

499
00:27:45.600 --> 00:27:49.500
When we configure something, I can even
build virtual machines right here on

500
00:27:49.500 --> 00:27:53.320
my MacBook if I want to,
using some type of software.

501
00:27:53.320 --> 00:27:57.240
For me, I'm using VMware Fusion,
and it has all those functions.

502
00:27:57.240 --> 00:28:00.790
You can see right there that I can
actually create multiple network

503
00:28:00.790 --> 00:28:02.830
adaptors if I want to, okay?

504
00:28:02.830 --> 00:28:05.840
And it actually allows me to
run multiple virtual machines.

505
00:28:05.840 --> 00:28:09.380
My limitation is only the hardware
that I have available

506
00:28:09.380 --> 00:28:11.350
on my machine at that point.

507
00:28:11.350 --> 00:28:15.300
I just have to realize that it's actually
trying to work based off of the free

508
00:28:15.300 --> 00:28:18.380
hardware that I have available,
including storage space,

509
00:28:18.380 --> 00:28:22.560
including RAM,
including the CPU utilization as well.

510
00:28:22.560 --> 00:28:25.030
All that I can actually end up using, but

511
00:28:25.030 --> 00:28:27.828
in terms of the NICs,
I only have one network adapter.

512
00:28:27.828 --> 00:28:32.670
And actually on reality I don't have
any network adapters on this particular

513
00:28:32.670 --> 00:28:37.750
MacBook at all, and I only have a wireless
network adapter, okay, but can I plug in?

514
00:28:37.750 --> 00:28:40.410
Yes, I can plug in to
an external network adapter and

515
00:28:40.410 --> 00:28:43.840
I can send it out over that
wire if I choose to as well.

516
00:28:43.840 --> 00:28:47.740
But those are those types of
understanding that we wanna make sure

517
00:28:47.740 --> 00:28:49.870
that we have available to us.

518
00:28:49.870 --> 00:28:53.812
Most of the time today you and I will
never have to configure the hardware to

519
00:28:53.812 --> 00:28:55.791
make it work with a virtual machine.

520
00:28:55.791 --> 00:29:01.472
If we're configuring anything, it's gonna
be on the hypervisor side with the virtual

521
00:29:01.472 --> 00:29:06.510
machine making sure that we assign
the proper NIC to where it needs to be.

522
00:29:06.510 --> 00:29:08.285
And that will work for us, okay?

523
00:29:08.285 --> 00:29:09.750
So that is the beginning,

524
00:29:09.750 --> 00:29:14.210
when we start talking about the idea of
cloud services and its impact in network.

525
00:29:14.210 --> 00:29:17.725
It does change just a little bit
of the infrastructure for us.

526
00:29:17.725 --> 00:29:21.030
But once we understand that we're
connecting essentially to the same thing,

527
00:29:21.030 --> 00:29:25.380
we're just paying a subscription and a fee
for it, we are pretty much ready to go.

528
00:29:25.380 --> 00:29:28.290
>> Zach, that should cover just
about everything we need as we

529
00:29:28.290 --> 00:29:32.110
continue to get prepared for
our CCNA routing and switching exam.

530
00:29:32.110 --> 00:29:34.400
>> Describe cloud resource
impact on enterprise,

531
00:29:34.400 --> 00:29:36.220
wonderful episode as usual, Ronnie.

532
00:29:36.220 --> 00:29:38.930
And before we move on,
anything else you'd like to say?

533
00:29:38.930 --> 00:29:41.740
>> Well, remember, this is not
the hardest topic in the world.

534
00:29:41.740 --> 00:29:45.640
And this is one of those topics where
it just asked us to describe it, so

535
00:29:45.640 --> 00:29:47.400
take a look at it.

536
00:29:47.400 --> 00:29:52.228
Just kind of go over the verbiage, why I
can't I remember what I'm trying to say?

537
00:29:52.228 --> 00:29:53.222
The terms-
>> [LAUGH]

538
00:29:53.222 --> 00:29:55.153
>> Terminology that does actually apply

539
00:29:55.153 --> 00:29:58.890
here in this world because you'll
see that terminology again.

540
00:29:58.890 --> 00:30:03.350
So just spend a lot more time in that,
but I would take this right?

541
00:30:03.350 --> 00:30:04.640
Make sure you glance over it,

542
00:30:04.640 --> 00:30:07.450
if it's totally unfamiliar with
you make sure you study a bit.

543
00:30:07.450 --> 00:30:10.580
So if you feel confident of what
we just talked about, okay?

544
00:30:10.580 --> 00:30:14.110
Then I would skim over it by far and
make sure I put more

545
00:30:14.110 --> 00:30:17.480
effort into those areas that you're
not as confident in instead.

546
00:30:17.480 --> 00:30:18.580
>> Great job as usual, Ronnie.

547
00:30:18.580 --> 00:30:20.950
Thank you for some awesome advice,
and here's some more good advice.

548
00:30:20.950 --> 00:30:25.327
Make sure you watch everything in the CCNA
Routing and Switching exam 200-105 series.

549
00:30:25.327 --> 00:30:28.860
You'll be glad you did when

550
00:30:28.860 --> 00:30:32.410
And you'll also be in our course library,

00:30:32.410 --> 00:30:36.070
all there to help you go further,

552
00:30:36.070 --> 00:30:40.120
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
ITProTV is binge-worthy.

553
00:30:40.120 --> 00:30:41.580
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

554
00:30:41.580 --> 00:30:42.300
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

555
00:30:42.300 --> 00:30:44.426

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce the concepts of Basic QoS concepts.  Theys talk about how it works and define terminology that is used in QoS that the cisco professional should know for the exam.
episodes.title: Describe Basic QoS Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.673
Welcome to ITPro.TV, I'm your host Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.673 --> 00:00:09.916
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:09.916 --> 00:00:11.517
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.517 --> 00:00:14.191
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITPro.TV,

5
00:00:14.191 --> 00:00:16.840
helping you learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:16.840 --> 00:00:21.040
I'm your host Zach Memos with
this episode of CCNA, Routing and

7
00:00:21.040 --> 00:00:22.750
Switching, Exam 200-105.

8
00:00:22.750 --> 00:00:24.352
Great episode coming up.

9
00:00:24.352 --> 00:00:29.360
My remit is, describe basic QOS concepts,
Quality of Service.

10
00:00:29.360 --> 00:00:30.000
Sounds good.

11
00:00:30.000 --> 00:00:31.750
And Ronnie Wong's gonna
tell us all about it.

12
00:00:31.750 --> 00:00:32.900
Ronnie, good to see you, sir.

13
00:00:32.900 --> 00:00:33.510
>> Hello, Zach.

14
00:00:33.510 --> 00:00:34.200
Thank you again for

15
00:00:34.200 --> 00:00:38.950
having me back on the show as we continue
in our CCNA Routing and Switching show.

16
00:00:38.950 --> 00:00:43.000
We are taking a look now at some of the
infrastructure services, and we are going

17
00:00:43.000 --> 00:00:49.440
to dive into just a little bit of what we
call quality of service in this episode.

18
00:00:49.440 --> 00:00:56.170
This is by no means a comprehensive or
exhaustive topic that we're talking about,

19
00:00:56.170 --> 00:01:00.210
but it's an important one that every
Cisco professional should at least know

20
00:01:00.210 --> 00:01:03.030
the basics of, and that's what we're
gonna make sure that we cover today.

21
00:01:03.030 --> 00:01:06.020
>> So, in the Cisco world,
what is quality of service?

22
00:01:06.020 --> 00:01:08.970
>> Now when it comes down to it,
a lot of times, if you're new to

23
00:01:08.970 --> 00:01:13.310
the idea of networking, quality of service
doesn't mean anything to us at all.

24
00:01:13.310 --> 00:01:16.840
But when we start talking about the idea
of quality of service in terms of

25
00:01:16.840 --> 00:01:23.860
networking, this is where we are trying
to ensure and guarantee that we allow for

26
00:01:23.860 --> 00:01:28.100
well, traffic to be able to be prioritized
and take place the way they want to.

27
00:01:28.100 --> 00:01:33.390
That we can configure essentially
how our data is gonna be treated

28
00:01:33.390 --> 00:01:35.940
as it actually goes across a network.

29
00:01:35.940 --> 00:01:38.350
But this is an important part,

30
00:01:38.350 --> 00:01:42.330
when there is actually network
congestion that happens.

31
00:01:42.330 --> 00:01:47.940
So what I mean by that is that on
a regular, normal everyday pattern of your

32
00:01:47.940 --> 00:01:52.480
traffic inside of the network that you are
serving, you normally don't have to worry

33
00:01:52.480 --> 00:01:57.100
about the idea of actually ensuring that
you have proper handling of your data.

34
00:01:57.100 --> 00:02:01.461
And that is because the data will actually
flow perfectly normal as long as it's

35
00:02:01.461 --> 00:02:03.497
within the bounds of the bandwidth.

36
00:02:03.497 --> 00:02:07.865
But what if we start overwhelming
that idea of bandwidth?

37
00:02:07.865 --> 00:02:10.785
And that is what quality
of service helps us to do.

38
00:02:10.785 --> 00:02:16.825
It helps us to actually be able to ensure
this idea that, when congestion happens,

39
00:02:16.825 --> 00:02:21.690
we can still make sure that the data
arrives at the other end that it needs to.

40
00:02:21.690 --> 00:02:24.640
And also depending on the type of data,

41
00:02:24.640 --> 00:02:28.740
some data may actually get a higher
priority than what we need as well.

42
00:02:28.740 --> 00:02:32.050
So let's make sure we understand
this idea of congestion just briefly

43
00:02:32.050 --> 00:02:34.610
before we move on with this topic.

44
00:02:34.610 --> 00:02:37.740
So let's take a look at my screen here,
and this will help us out,

45
00:02:37.740 --> 00:02:42.240
cuz this is something pretty much,
just about everybody is familiar with.

46
00:02:42.240 --> 00:02:45.630
I know it doesn't seem logical a lot of
times when start talking about things,

47
00:02:45.630 --> 00:02:49.070
but this one right here
will actually seem logical.

48
00:02:49.070 --> 00:02:50.830
At least I think it will.

49
00:02:50.830 --> 00:02:55.400
So whenever we start talking about
the idea of congestion on a roadway

00:02:55.400 --> 00:03:00.015

00:03:00.015 --> 00:03:03.025
Our capacity of our roadway

So for example, if I'm running

00:03:17.455 --> 00:03:22.455
Mbs bandwidth, starts getting about 80 or

00:03:22.455 --> 00:03:26.960
But if we actually start to get

00:03:26.960 --> 00:03:29.060
then we start having more congestion.

00:03:30.280 --> 00:03:34.670
The idea of congestion then is not just

00:03:34.670 --> 00:03:39.540

00:03:39.540 --> 00:03:43.400

And then of course,

what happens to the data at that point

00:05:13.940 --> 00:05:16.600

00:07:37.140 --> 00:07:38.530

00:30:18.480 --> 00:30:21.920
So they still have to have the LAN there's
nothing you can do about it cuz of

498
00:30:21.920 --> 00:30:25.950
distance and how you have to send
the data over that distance, right?

499
00:30:25.950 --> 00:30:29.110
But they can remove as much of it
as possible, they can go ahead and

500
00:30:29.110 --> 00:30:33.810
say look, all the other stuff,
we're essentially assigning that class and

501
00:30:33.810 --> 00:30:36.140
now we're actually now
assigning this to say,

502
00:30:36.140 --> 00:30:40.210
look, make this as fast as
possible through this network.

503
00:30:40.210 --> 00:30:45.370
So that's important in terms of voice
data because a two way conversation

504
00:30:45.370 --> 00:30:49.450
on a VoIP phone where you have to wait for
my response to come back.

505
00:30:49.450 --> 00:30:53.420
Or you don't hear my complete response
is something that you're having,

506
00:30:53.420 --> 00:30:54.910
that's terrible, okay?

507
00:30:54.910 --> 00:30:58.015
Where you just have to kind of see
this backward and forward thing.

508
00:30:58.015 --> 00:31:02.750
Same thing if I'm streaming
video,just like I'm doing right now,

509
00:31:02.750 --> 00:31:06.060
it maybe something that I
want to consider as well.

510
00:31:06.060 --> 00:31:10.120
So that the message doesn't break up,
so like if you ever see us, and

511
00:31:10.120 --> 00:31:13.350
I hope, you don't see it, cuz that's
what we hope you don't see, right?

512
00:31:13.350 --> 00:31:17.700
And all of a sudden you Zach and you hear
Zach is still talking, but his screen is

513
00:31:17.700 --> 00:31:20.970
completely frozen and then you start
seeing it looks like puzzle pieces

514
00:31:20.970 --> 00:31:25.210
dropping off and certain things happening,
pixelation, all that stuff here okay?

515
00:31:25.210 --> 00:31:29.410
That again kind of lets you know that hey
look there's something else happening in

516
00:31:29.410 --> 00:31:30.400
the background.

517
00:31:30.400 --> 00:31:32.900
So we can implement quality
of service to try and

518
00:31:32.900 --> 00:31:36.540
assure as much as we can that stuff
like that doesn't happen as well.

519
00:31:36.540 --> 00:31:39.110
Now if I'm just sending you a video file,
it doesn't matter.

520
00:31:39.110 --> 00:31:41.965
Best effort is probably other
way I can go as well, but

521
00:31:41.965 --> 00:31:45.023
it depends on the need that
you have at the moment, okay?

522
00:31:45.023 --> 00:31:47.647
Now, there's one last thing that
we need to mention here and

523
00:31:47.647 --> 00:31:49.198
we don't have an actual slide for.

524
00:31:49.198 --> 00:31:53.084
But there's two concepts,
which is called congestion management.

525
00:31:53.084 --> 00:31:54.865
Okay, by default.

526
00:31:54.865 --> 00:31:59.420
And what you wanna understand is without
any quality of service at all, okay,

527
00:31:59.420 --> 00:32:02.215
a router handles things
in what they call FIFO.

528
00:32:02.215 --> 00:32:07.130
F-I-F-O, or FIFO,
however people pronounce it, okay?

529
00:32:07.130 --> 00:32:11.862
FIFO or FIFO means First In First Out,
that's exactly how it handles it.

530
00:32:11.862 --> 00:32:14.130
It doesn't care what
type of traffic it is.

531
00:32:14.130 --> 00:32:16.570
If it comes in first,
it gets to go out first, okay?

532
00:32:16.570 --> 00:32:18.880
That's pretty much it, that makes sense.

533
00:32:18.880 --> 00:32:23.570
But when we start talking about the idea
of quality of service again, okay?

534
00:32:23.570 --> 00:32:30.703
What we may actually end up doing
instead is what's called WFQ, okay?

535
00:32:30.703 --> 00:32:36.120
WFQ ironically here, right,
means Weighted Fair Queuing.

536
00:32:36.120 --> 00:32:37.520
And this will let you know something.

537
00:32:37.520 --> 00:32:41.624
It's actually saying, well, we'll put this
along the idea of actually, the buffers

538
00:32:41.624 --> 00:32:45.293
that we're talking about which shows
you how important that they really are.

539
00:32:45.293 --> 00:32:51.245
And what we can do instead of say, here's
how much bandwidth we are gonna assign to

540
00:32:51.245 --> 00:32:57.790
what different types of traffic based on
a weighted distribution we choose to do.

541
00:32:57.790 --> 00:33:00.290
So any traffic cue that we have,
we can give it so

542
00:33:00.290 --> 00:33:03.530
much of a particular type of
bandwidth that we want to.

543
00:33:03.530 --> 00:33:07.590
And allow that also to be handled
in the buffer as well, okay?

544
00:33:07.590 --> 00:33:09.730
So that is what quality of service does.

545
00:33:09.730 --> 00:33:12.000
It takes the idea of first in first out.

546
00:33:12.000 --> 00:33:16.743
So it goes no, let me now arbitrarily
decide how this is gonna be

547
00:33:16.743 --> 00:33:19.258
divided up better for us, okay?

548
00:33:19.258 --> 00:33:22.274
But Zack, overall when we
start taking a look at this,

549
00:33:22.274 --> 00:33:26.890
that really is about the basics of the QoS
that we need to think about, okay?

550
00:33:26.890 --> 00:33:31.020
So when you're getting ready for the exam,
the hard part of this one is simple.

551
00:33:31.020 --> 00:33:36.000
It's all of the actual terminology that is

552

553
00:33:39.880 --> 00:33:41.450
It's still confusing.

554

But just remember,
take a look at the terms, and try and

555
00:33:44.350 --> 00:33:46.465
understand what the terms
are helping you to do.

556
00:33:46.465 --> 00:33:47.840
>> Thanks for sharing, Ronnie.

557
00:33:47.840 --> 00:33:49.460
Awesome job, very nice.

558
00:33:49.460 --> 00:33:53.200
Describe basic QpS concepts,
the title of this episode.

559
00:33:53.200 --> 00:33:56.140
And you know before we move on, I think
you have something else you'd like to say.

560
00:33:56.140 --> 00:33:59.040
>> Well,
just go ahead at this point, right?

561
00:33:59.040 --> 00:34:02.138
This is not the biggest topic in
the world, but it is an important one.

562
00:34:02.138 --> 00:34:06.590
And it's something that you will encounter
in the field especially if you know

563
00:34:06.590 --> 00:34:10.700
that your network is gonna be supporting,
well, a lot of different types of traffic.

564
00:34:10.700 --> 00:34:14.380
It's no longer like networking of the 90s
anymore or even of the early 2000s where

565
00:34:14.380 --> 00:34:18.530
it's all about making sure that data
can arrive at one place or the other.

566
00:34:18.530 --> 00:34:22.785
Today is about arriving and making sure
that the data has the bandwidth that it

567
00:34:22.785 --> 00:34:26.857
needs to get to the other place in
the way that it's supposed to get there.

568
00:34:26.857 --> 00:34:30.383
And that's the key behind understanding
how this QoS is gonna begin to

569
00:34:30.383 --> 00:34:31.550
work for you.

570

Tell everybody you know about ITPro TV.

ITPro TV is beinge-worthy.

580

Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

581

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review the concepts of ACLs.  They discuss not only the types but also what they can be used for.  The guys describe the 2 step process: configuring ACLs correctly and placing it on the interface.  Lastly, they show how to configure and verify a standard ACL.
episodes.title: Configure Access-lists for Filtering

So when we start taking a look at

this is gonna sound funny,

I'm gonna actually sound like a Star Wars

So even though you see three different

So technically there's two types even

answers right here on the screen.

There is standard okay,
access control list.

A lot of times you'll actually see that,

And then there is an extended named,

I guess I could just call it Named,

So that's why, even though there are three

So whenever you start seeing

At the very beginning we take

the earliest notation of this, okay?

As you start doing it is that access

This one beginning with a 1, so

anything 1 through 99 is gonna be

00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:59.510
So you can, at least at the very basic

It is possible and

Now, if you compare this

If I create an access control list,

Usually, this particular verb here

And then we can decide

Now the source address doesn't have to

00:04:41.570 --> 00:04:43.610
If we want it to be that way.

86
00:04:43.610 --> 00:04:45.680
So it is possible that you can do that.

87
00:04:45.680 --> 00:04:50.240
If you do the subnet part, you also

88
00:04:50.240 --> 00:04:53.530
that subnet part,
if that's what you're gonna do.

89
00:04:53.530 --> 00:04:59.060
The term host is just an alias here for

90
00:04:59.060 --> 00:05:02.070
At the end of the standard
access control list,

91
00:05:02.070 --> 00:05:06.410
there's also gonna be what they
call an implicit deny any.

92
00:05:06.410 --> 00:05:10.550
That means if you do not put

93
00:05:10.550 --> 00:05:13.900
It will actually go ahead and

94
00:05:13.900 --> 00:05:17.660
configure an access control list properly,

95
00:05:17.660 --> 00:05:21.850
And then you also place that access
control list on an interface, it will

96
00:05:21.850 --> 00:05:27.790
still deny every bit of traffic if you do
not have at least one permit statement.

97
00:05:27.790 --> 00:05:31.250
So regardless of the access
control list that we have, right?

98
00:05:31.250 --> 00:05:36.120
That means there has to be at least one
permit statement allowed, if you don't,

99
00:05:36.120 --> 00:05:39.050
that means it's gonna be deny
all no matter what you actually

100
00:05:39.050 --> 00:05:40.120
configure on there.

101
00:05:40.120 --> 00:05:40.760
So if you see,

102
00:05:40.760 --> 00:05:44.931
all deny everything that you have here,
that's what we're gonna see, okay?

103
00:05:46.110 --> 00:05:50.050
Now the other one here, and
this is I see I forgot to change the verb.

104
00:05:51.270 --> 00:05:54.448
Let me change these two and
this will help us out here.

105
00:05:56.616 --> 00:06:01.950
All right, so when we start talking
about the idea of the extended access

106
00:06:01.950 --> 00:06:07.995
control list, the extended access list
begins with yeah 100 Through 199.

107
00:06:07.995 --> 00:06:10.744
And once again because of
all the other protocols

108
00:06:10.744 --> 00:06:13.893
that were out there at some point,
they had to jump up all

109
00:06:13.893 --> 00:06:19.290
the way to 2,000 through 2699 to give
an extension of this list as well okay?

110
00:06:19.290 --> 00:06:23.000
Now remember that even though
the standard access control list up here

111
00:06:23.000 --> 00:06:27.330
is only based off the source
address only okay?

112
00:06:27.330 --> 00:06:28.570
This one, though, down here,

113
00:06:28.570 --> 00:06:33.610
is actually gonna be based off
the idea of source and destination.

114
00:06:33.610 --> 00:06:39.015
But notice, it also issues protocol,
which is TCP, what you see right here.

115
00:06:39.015 --> 00:06:39.530
>> Mm-hm.

116
00:06:39.530 --> 00:06:43.780
>> And even the idea of, well,
the port number if we choose to, or

117
00:06:43.780 --> 00:06:46.050
the specific protocol as well.

118
00:06:46.050 --> 00:06:51.221
So when you read an access
control list like this, okay,

119
00:06:51.221 --> 00:06:57.472
you say access-list 101 permits
TCP traffic from this one host,

120
00:06:57.472 --> 00:07:02.884
192.168.16.10 172.16.16.0.

121
00:07:02.884 --> 00:07:09.280
That entire network, okay,
to that network here, it equals FTP.

122
00:07:09.280 --> 00:07:09.880
Okay?

123
00:07:09.880 --> 00:07:13.100
So that's what you can actually end
up reading it in that particular

00:07:13.100 --> 00:07:14.230

125
00:07:14.230 --> 00:07:15.360
So that's what you see.

126
00:07:15.360 --> 00:07:17.920
I'm probably actually to make

127
00:07:17.920 --> 00:07:21.490
Now that I think about it,

00:07:21.490 --> 00:07:24.959
I didn't actually hand kind of take

00:07:26.280 --> 00:07:29.710
Do not forget at the end of even

00:21:51.887 --> 00:21:55.550
IP version 6 access lists or
traffic filtering.

362
00:21:55.550 --> 00:21:56.318
>> I bet you can't say that again.
[LAUGH]

363
00:21:56.318 --> 00:21:58.079
>> Yeah, I wanted to actually try and

00:21:58.079 --> 00:22:02.610
get all that into a show title but I was

365
00:22:02.610 --> 00:22:05.906
So the actual diagram that we have is,
we're really working with NYEDGE1.

And of course,

00:22:10.753 --> 00:22:15.890
to verify that access lists

00:22:15.890 --> 00:22:20.145
There's not a lot of configuration that

00:22:20.145 --> 00:22:23.470
us it's all NYEDGE1 is
where we are going to be.

00:22:23.470 --> 00:22:28.955
All right, let's go ahead and do that one,
[INAUDIBLE] that down and hopefully

00:22:28.955 --> 00:22:34.458
be able to zoom in to NYEDGE1, which is
what I want to be able to do, all right?

372
00:22:34.458 --> 00:22:38.872
Now over on NYEDGE1, we are now
ready to configure a numbered access

373
00:22:38.872 --> 00:22:43.150
list to match a single IP address,
and that is what we want, okay?

374
00:22:43.150 --> 00:22:48.060
Our single IP address is
gonna be 192.168.16.10,

375
00:22:48.060 --> 00:22:51.600
so let's get into this
particular device here.

376
00:22:51.600 --> 00:22:53.896
We are going to,
on the router that we have,

377
00:22:53.896 --> 00:22:56.018
go into [INAUDIBLE] configuration mode.

378
00:22:56.018 --> 00:22:59.075
From this point we're gonna
configure an access list here and

00:22:59.075 --> 00:23:00.853
we're gonna give it a number 10.

380
00:23:00.853 --> 00:23:04.470
Remember, you can pick whatever
number you want to between 1 and 99.

381
00:23:04.470 --> 00:23:09.540
Now I have to give it the verb
which is gonna be, deny,

382
00:23:09.540 --> 00:23:14.744
and then I can use host 192.168.16.10.

383
00:23:14.744 --> 00:23:16.056
>> Good.

384
00:23:16.056 --> 00:23:19.511
>> All right,
now remember that if you type this in,

385
00:23:19.511 --> 00:23:24.300
that's perfectly fine,
that's probably the fastest way to do so.

386
00:23:24.300 --> 00:23:27.650
But if you didn't want to and
you wanna do the wildcard mask,

387
00:23:27.650 --> 00:23:29.420
you'd just leave out the word host.

388
00:23:29.420 --> 00:23:34.435
And then on the right-hand
side of 192.168.16.10

389
00:23:34.435 --> 00:23:40.372
you'd type in four zeros in a row to make
the idea of that 32 bit subnet mask.

390
00:23:43.230 --> 00:23:47.385
So now once we're actually there on
that side of it let's take a look and

391
00:23:47.385 --> 00:23:50.237
see if there's any access
list already on here.

392
00:23:53.354 --> 00:23:57.254
And you can see right away that
what they did is say, all right,

393
00:23:57.254 --> 00:24:00.510
we've already configured
