394
00:24:00.510 --> 00:24:03.643
So that you didn't have to worry,
or I actually just configured this,

395
00:24:03.643 --> 00:24:04.436
[INAUDIBLE] yeah.

396
00:24:04.436 --> 00:24:08.043
So, I don't know why, I said, they had

00:24:08.043 --> 00:24:11.067
a look at the second line, I was like,
I did not type that in here.

398
00:24:11.067 --> 00:24:14.022
Notice they have standard
IP access lists for NAT.

399
00:24:14.022 --> 00:24:21.168
They have a permit 192.168.16.10,
and they have a deny up here.

400
00:24:21.168 --> 00:24:23.762
And you might be wondering
why does that matter,

401
00:24:23.762 --> 00:24:25.796
because the list order is important.

402
00:24:25.796 --> 00:24:29.040
The way that access lists
are going to be processed, right,

403
00:24:29.040 --> 00:24:30.636
is from the top to the bottom.

404
00:24:30.636 --> 00:24:32.688
It doesn't process the entire list.

405
00:24:32.688 --> 00:24:37.357
Whichever it actually matches,
it should stop right there, okay?

406
00:24:37.357 --> 00:24:38.855
And if it stops right there,

407
00:24:38.855 --> 00:24:41.799
then it doesn't actually
process the rest of the list.

408
00:24:41.799 --> 00:24:44.260
So in theory,
if I get information coming in,

409
00:24:44.260 --> 00:24:46.730
I still have to configure
it on the interface.

410
00:24:46.730 --> 00:24:51.495
But if I get information coming in
from 192.168.16.10 it should hit

411
00:24:51.495 --> 00:24:56.189
this list that I've highlighted first,
stop processing the rest of the list and

412
00:24:56.189 --> 00:25:00.990
at this point, according to the verb,
I should be denied access, right?

413
00:25:00.990 --> 00:25:04.326
So everything actually does look
good when we start seeing it, okay?

414
00:25:04.326 --> 00:25:08.251
But we are going to find out,
okay, something here,

415
00:25:08.251 --> 00:25:13.250
that the list is actually missing
something for us too, okay?

416
00:25:13.250 --> 00:25:16.700
So now, if you remember, Zach,
I talked about this a little bit earlier.

417
00:25:16.700 --> 00:25:19.070
Even though we're only
seeing one line here, okay?

418
00:25:19.070 --> 00:25:22.070
>> Right.
>> Remember that there's an implicit,

419
00:25:22.070 --> 00:25:24.870
hidden, okay, invisible,
whatever you want to call it, okay?

420
00:25:24.870 --> 00:25:28.010
Other listing that's right here
called Mac List Control Entry.

421
00:25:28.010 --> 00:25:32.716
That even at the end
just deny 192.168.16.10.

422
00:25:32.716 --> 00:25:33.260
>> Right.

423
00:25:33.260 --> 00:25:36.635
>> There's also gonna
be after it a Deny Any.

424
00:25:36.635 --> 00:25:41.028
Which says, hey, don't only deny this,
but at the end of this list,

425
00:25:41.028 --> 00:25:44.242
make sure that you deny
everything as well, okay.

426
00:25:44.242 --> 00:25:47.779
So it actually is missing
something that we see but also,

427
00:25:47.779 --> 00:25:52.497
the very fact is I also talked about
a rule here that in every access list, for

428
00:25:52.497 --> 00:25:57.238
dash to be a real access list, there has
to be at least one permit statement.

429
00:25:57.238 --> 00:25:59.837
So if I don't want to
just deny everything,

430
00:25:59.837 --> 00:26:04.850
I wanna see if it's just denying this one
thing, I need a permit statement in there.

431
00:26:04.850 --> 00:26:08.060
So let's go back in and
we'll configure this thing.

432
00:26:09.890 --> 00:26:15.026
So this is going to be access-list 10.

433
00:26:15.026 --> 00:26:20.982
And for us once we do this it's
going to be permit any, all right.

434
00:26:25.702 --> 00:26:30.804
Now, notice that at the end of the
standard access list which I just created,

435
00:26:30.804 --> 00:26:33.290
we also added in a permit any.

436
00:26:33.290 --> 00:26:35.440
So this should be effectively what I want.

437
00:26:35.440 --> 00:26:37.913
Cuz I don't want to just deny everything,
okay?

438
00:26:37.913 --> 00:26:39.761
I want to just deny this one host,

439
00:26:39.761 --> 00:26:43.460
and allow everything else to go
through and notice those numbers.

440
00:26:43.460 --> 00:26:46.230
Those numbers are what we
call access control entries.

441
00:26:46.230 --> 00:26:50.780
And these numbers are actually separated
at this point by default by ten.

442
00:26:50.780 --> 00:26:54.500
This gives us room to actually put
something in the middle if we need to but

443
00:26:54.500 --> 00:26:58.730
remember that with regular access lists
I'd still have to actually take it out,

444
00:26:58.730 --> 00:26:59.870
type in a 15 in the middle, and

445
00:26:59.870 --> 00:27:04.590
then repaste it back in, removing this
access list if I were to do this.

446
00:27:04.590 --> 00:27:05.920
That's what I have to be able to do.

447
00:27:05.920 --> 00:27:06.450
>> Okay.

448
00:27:06.450 --> 00:27:07.400
>> All right,

449
00:27:07.400 --> 00:27:11.320
the second part of this of course is
then applying it to an interface.

450
00:27:11.320 --> 00:27:15.963
So a reaccess list by itself
doesn't mean anything until it is

00:27:15.963 --> 00:27:17.937
applied to an interface.

452
00:27:17.937 --> 00:27:22.228
And we are gonna apply it at interface

453
00:27:22.228 --> 00:27:27.075
gigabit 0/1 then ip access-group and

454
00:27:27.075 --> 00:27:32.720
we just tell it what
list we want to apply.

455
00:27:32.720 --> 00:27:34.740
And then I actually choose what direction.

456
00:27:35.940 --> 00:27:40.030
So notice its saying, that's for inbound
packets, that's for outbound packets here,

457
00:27:40.030 --> 00:27:46.970
well for me, this is coming in from
192.168.16.10, so this is gonna say,

458
00:27:46.970 --> 00:27:52.120
hey, take that list and apply it to
this interface inbound to the router.

459
00:27:54.100 --> 00:27:54.800
Is what we're gonna do.

460
00:27:54.800 --> 00:27:56.590
Actually, I'm telling you wrong.

461
00:27:56.590 --> 00:27:57.894
So it should be outbound.

462
00:28:00.529 --> 00:28:03.056
Group 10 outbound, no, in.

463
00:28:03.056 --> 00:28:05.480
Let me remove that.

464
00:28:05.480 --> 00:28:10.834
That should be O group,

465
00:28:10.834 --> 00:28:17.000
no ip access-group 10.

466
00:28:17.000 --> 00:28:20.521
Out, in, I need to remove that, sorry.

467
00:28:20.521 --> 00:28:24.787
I can't remember what I was doing,
ip access-group 10, and

468
00:28:24.787 --> 00:28:28.903
this should be outbound,
at least that's what the lab says.

469
00:28:28.903 --> 00:28:31.088
>> That's what the lab says, yeah.
>> We're gonna make sure that we do it

470
00:28:31.088 --> 00:28:31.885
right there.

471
00:28:31.885 --> 00:28:36.469
All right, Let me go ahead and exit out of
that, and now let's verify if this thing

00:28:36.469 --> 00:28:40.666

00:28:42.935 --> 00:28:47.495
All right so here is the actual lab

So at this point if I go ahead here and

I begin to ping Now, 192.168,

no, I actually don't even have the,

So when you take a look at it, it says

00:29:20.435 --> 00:29:23.876

any, but notice also I'm seeing

NAT, Network Address Translation,

That means that it's leaving my NY Edge-1.

This is going out to gigabit 0/1,

Show IP nat Translations,

So now, If we do the inbound.

00:31:47.376 --> 00:31:50.167

00:31:55.458 --> 00:31:59.769

00:32:14.821 --> 00:32:19.366
And let's see and

00:32:19.366 --> 00:32:22.700

00:32:27.570 --> 00:32:30.241

00:32:30.241 --> 00:32:35.730

remember that standard access control

22
00:01:00.904 --> 00:01:03.724
lists only based filtering
on the source address?

23
00:01:03.724 --> 00:01:08.722
But there's gonna be more as our traffic
and as the number of devices continue to

24
00:01:08.722 --> 00:01:12.890
become more complex and
our networks become more complex.

25
00:01:12.890 --> 00:01:16.400
The idea of actually being our filtered
traffic based off of source and

26
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:19.950
destination address, as well as protocol,

27
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:24.210
is going to be very helpful in making
our filtering very specific, okay?

28
00:01:24.210 --> 00:01:28.830
And the reason why we wanna mention that
is, remember that the processing order

29
00:01:28.830 --> 00:01:33.080
of these access lists are from the top
of the access list to the bottom?

30
00:01:33.080 --> 00:01:36.710
So a good, also additional and
general rule of thumb for

31
00:01:36.710 --> 00:01:39.780
access lists that we want from them,
regardless of what it is,

32
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:44.560
but especially for extended access lists,
is that you want the most specific

33
00:01:44.560 --> 00:01:48.740
access control lists to be
towards the top of the list.

34
00:01:48.740 --> 00:01:53.750
And then the most generic ones to be down
towards the bottom of the list, okay?

35
00:01:53.750 --> 00:01:55.695
That way, when you filter something out,

36
00:01:55.695 --> 00:01:58.950
you're actually filtering out
the most specific things first.

37
00:01:58.950 --> 00:02:00.350
And then, if it doesn't match those,

38
00:02:00.350 --> 00:02:05.450
then you move on to the more general items
in that access control list that you want,

39
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:07.690
and hit the filtering
that you need down there.

40
00:02:07.690 --> 00:02:11.051
But if you put the most specific
ones at the bottom, okay,

41
00:02:11.051 --> 00:02:13.452
you'll probably end up filtering more,

42
00:02:13.452 --> 00:02:17.443
because you have a generalized
access control list towards the top.

43
00:02:17.443 --> 00:02:20.874
And they may filter too much
out that you don't want to so

44
00:02:20.874 --> 00:02:23.504
always put them toward
the top of the list.

45
00:02:23.504 --> 00:02:28.100
The more specific that you are, okay,
the better off that it's going to be.

46
00:02:28.100 --> 00:02:31.130
And then you actually start moving
towards the more general ones.

47
00:02:31.130 --> 00:02:33.690
So if you have some that
goes only from host to host,

48
00:02:33.690 --> 00:02:35.870
that should be right up towards the top.

49
00:02:35.870 --> 00:02:36.930
Then, if you think about it,

50
00:02:36.930 --> 00:02:40.880
if you have something from a host
to a particular subnet somewhere,

51
00:02:40.880 --> 00:02:44.100
well that again might actually be right
after the host-to-host connections.

52
00:02:44.100 --> 00:02:48.325
But then what about the idea here of,
well, network-to-network, okay,

53
00:02:48.325 --> 00:02:50.600
subnet-to-subnet filtering?

54
00:02:50.600 --> 00:02:54.310
Well that would actually be after
the host to a network, right?

55
00:02:54.310 --> 00:02:58.480
And then you might have, instead,
the idea of a host to any,

56
00:02:58.480 --> 00:03:01.560
okay, one particular host
inside to any place else.

57
00:03:01.560 --> 00:03:03.340
That would be more generic.

58
00:03:03.340 --> 00:03:06.200
Or my subnet to any, okay?

59
00:03:06.200 --> 00:03:08.310
That would, again, be more generic.

60
00:03:08.310 --> 00:03:09.544
So make sure you understand that.

61
00:03:09.544 --> 00:03:12.106
And then, always,
at the end of that access list,

62
00:03:12.106 --> 00:03:16.098
regardless of how long it becomes,
that you also remember that there's always

63
00:03:16.098 --> 00:03:19.852
that implicit deny all statement,
okay, that's actually down there for

64
00:03:19.852 --> 00:03:23.960
any protocol going from any place to
any other place that's out there.

65
00:03:23.960 --> 00:03:26.350
Do not forget that that always exists.

66
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:30.567
And also remember that for an access
list it really be a valid access list,

67
00:03:30.567 --> 00:03:34.732
there has to be at least one permit
statement in there somewhere, okay?

00:03:34.732 --> 00:03:36.880

numbering but that's fine, okay.

251
00:15:39.095 --> 00:15:40.781
That will end up working for us, okay?

252
00:15:40.781 --> 00:15:45.859
So unlike what we had before where if
I actually had forgotten the FTP data,

253
00:15:45.859 --> 00:15:46.433
right.

254
00:15:46.433 --> 00:15:51.062
So how do I actually get that second
entry in there if I wanted to do this?

255
00:15:51.062 --> 00:15:56.232
Well it'd be the same exact way,
okay, that I've just removed it.

256
00:15:56.232 --> 00:16:00.826
I'd go back in ip Access-list

257
00:16:00.826 --> 00:16:06.418
extended, And then permit-ftp,

258
00:16:06.418 --> 00:16:12.005
which is the name of that access list,
and then I can actually put in a number.

259
00:16:12.005 --> 00:16:17.469
I'm gonna change this
number to 15 instead,

260
00:16:17.469 --> 00:16:23.206
to put it right in the middle,
permit this time for

261
00:16:23.206 --> 00:16:28.550
us, tcp host 192.168.16.10.

262
00:16:28.550 --> 00:16:34.738
And then host 172.15.0.10 = ftp data.

263
00:16:42.296 --> 00:16:49.668
Show ip access-list permit-ftp, no, wait.

264
00:16:54.613 --> 00:17:02.127
Permit-ftp, I forgot ftp for that.

265
00:17:02.127 --> 00:17:08.953
Show ip access, I gotta remember
how to do this, access-list,

266
00:17:12.146 --> 00:17:16.535
permit-ftp, maybe I can do that,
okay finally, okay?

267
00:17:16.535 --> 00:17:20.756
So now you can see where I could change it
very easily by comparison to what we've

268
00:17:20.756 --> 00:17:23.282
actually been able to do,
if we want to do that.

269
00:17:23.282 --> 00:17:27.146
We're gonna configure it again
onto the interface at this point,

270
00:17:27.146 --> 00:17:30.399
remember it actually has to
be applied to an interface.

271
00:17:30.399 --> 00:17:35.493
And for us,
it's not really that different,

272
00:17:35.493 --> 00:17:41.510
then instead you do
ip-access-group permit-ftp.

273
00:17:41.510 --> 00:17:44.773
So instead of a number,
you're just using the name instead.

274
00:17:44.773 --> 00:17:50.137
And now it is applied, and
let's see what we can do.

275
00:17:50.137 --> 00:17:55.106
So if we go back over into our list here,

276
00:17:58.393 --> 00:18:00.922
Let me get back out here and
let's see if we can ping.

277
00:18:00.922 --> 00:18:07.030
172.15.0.10 and
see if we actually get anything.

278
00:18:10.409 --> 00:18:13.242
So notice the request is timing out,
which is perfectly fine.

279
00:18:18.141 --> 00:18:20.801
So it is kinda slow, but
it is actually working.

280
00:18:20.801 --> 00:18:27.329
Then we'll do the ftp again, Ping,

281
00:18:27.329 --> 00:18:33.688
no not ping, ftp, ftp 172.15.0.10.

282
00:18:33.688 --> 00:18:37.879
Now if you're saying, hey why are you
typing in the IP address this time?

283
00:18:37.879 --> 00:18:41.379
It's just faster instead of
having to do name resolution,

284
00:18:41.379 --> 00:18:44.183
we can just type in the IP
address to help us out.

285
00:18:44.183 --> 00:18:47.979
And we wanna go back over and verify,

286
00:18:51.196 --> 00:18:54.819
Do show ip access-list,

287
00:18:59.068 --> 00:19:03.388
Extended permit-ftp.

288
00:19:03.388 --> 00:19:08.171
I don't think I have to do
all that extended here.

289
00:19:08.171 --> 00:19:12.061
I always forget that,

290
00:19:12.061 --> 00:19:17.598
ip access-list permit-ftp.

291
00:19:17.598 --> 00:19:21.162
I don't know why I keep
typing in extended, but I do.

292
00:19:21.162 --> 00:19:24.842
All right, so
here there we go again, okay?

293
00:19:24.842 --> 00:19:27.524
We actually did allow for
that permit in there,

294
00:19:27.524 --> 00:19:31.022
we showed you how you could
actually add in more information.

295
00:19:31.022 --> 00:19:35.201
So if you start finding that you need
more, well you can again go back in.

296
00:19:35.201 --> 00:19:40.019
Add in 20, add in 12, 13,
whatever you want to.

297
00:19:40.019 --> 00:19:44.126
And keep making sure that they fit in
the proper place that you need to without

298
00:19:44.126 --> 00:19:48.123
having to copy the whole list out and
be able to do everything else, okay?

299
00:19:48.123 --> 00:19:52.708
So that is pretty much
the key in doing this, okay?

300
00:19:52.708 --> 00:19:56.173
All right, so
now that that's actually done for us,

301
00:19:56.173 --> 00:20:00.952
that's really kind of the verification
that we need to be able to do this.

302
00:20:00.952 --> 00:20:06.329
Now I gotta go ahead and remove this one
for our next little jaunt into, well,

303
00:20:06.329 --> 00:20:11.645
our last little bit here, which is,
of course, creating an ACL for IPv6.

304
00:20:11.645 --> 00:20:14.908
So let me get back into gigabit 0.

305
00:20:14.908 --> 00:20:19.117
Then no ip access-group,

306
00:20:19.117 --> 00:20:24.243
this is gonna be permit-ftp in.

307
00:20:24.243 --> 00:20:28.678
And that will get us ready to start
creating the idea here, okay?

308
00:20:29.690 --> 00:20:33.466
So now Zach, as we go into this, we are
now ready to take a look at the idea of,

309
00:20:33.466 --> 00:20:36.074
of course, making an access list for
IP version 6.

310
00:20:36.074 --> 00:20:39.162
>> Well,
does access work any different with IPv6?

311
00:20:39.162 --> 00:20:40.985
>> Well, to a point, okay?

312
00:20:40.985 --> 00:20:43.192
So it doesn't function any differently.

313
00:20:43.192 --> 00:20:46.272
It still does the same things that we've
been talking about throughout this little

314
00:20:46.272 --> 00:20:46.976
miniseries here.

315
00:20:46.976 --> 00:20:54.200
But it does only use named access-list,
so you can't use a number system with it.

316
00:20:54.200 --> 00:20:58.306
For us here, it's actually only going
to work with a named access-list.

317
00:20:58.306 --> 00:21:01.668
You still have to create the list, you
still have to apply it to an interface,

318
00:21:01.668 --> 00:21:02.672
it's the same thing.

319
00:21:02.672 --> 00:21:05.735
But the weird thing,
of course, for you and me, for

320
00:21:05.735 --> 00:21:09.491
those of us I should say,
that have only worked in IP version 4,

321
00:21:09.491 --> 00:21:13.616
it's still typing in the unusual-looking
IP version 6 addresses.

322
00:21:13.616 --> 00:21:17.255
If you're brand new to this and you've
learned your IP version 6 addresses,

323
00:21:17.255 --> 00:21:19.141
this probably looks very normal to you.

324
00:21:19.141 --> 00:21:22.068
But if you haven't,
than it looks a little bit stranger.

325
00:21:22.068 --> 00:21:26.317
Lets go ahead and configure this thing and
make sure that we can do this.

326
00:21:26.317 --> 00:21:31.075
All right, so a big difference here,

327
00:21:31.075 --> 00:21:38.373
is instead of IP we're gonna
do ipv6 access-list here.

328
00:21:38.373 --> 00:21:44.307
And then we're gonna say let's
block NYEDGE 2, all right?

329
00:21:44.307 --> 00:21:48.591
So we're gonna block NYEDGE2 and
that's the name of it, is block NYEDGE2.

330
00:21:48.591 --> 00:21:53.821
We are going to deny
anything going to the actual

331
00:21:53.821 --> 00:21:58.807
NYEDGE2, based on IP versions 6 address.

332
00:21:58.807 --> 00:22:03.878
That's 2001:A:B

333
00:22:03.878 --> 00:22:08.711
:31::2, okay?

334
00:22:08.711 --> 00:22:12.824
That is the IPv6 address for NYEDGE2.

335
00:22:12.824 --> 00:22:19.067
And that other point I'm
going to permit any to any.

336
00:22:19.067 --> 00:22:23.549
So it actually looks like it's
even a simpler configuration for

337
00:22:23.549 --> 00:22:25.212
us to be able to do this.

338
00:22:25.212 --> 00:22:33.455
Show ipv6 access-list.

339
00:22:36.053 --> 00:22:39.914
All right, so there is our access-list and
notice at the end there they have,

340
00:22:39.914 --> 00:22:42.559
instead of sequence numbers
being at the beginning.

341
00:22:42.559 --> 00:22:45.764
They have the sequence numbers
listed at the end, okay?

342
00:22:45.764 --> 00:22:49.792
And they actually even had the word
sequence is what they have to make sure

343
00:22:49.792 --> 00:22:53.182
that we can see the way that
this ends up working, all right?

344
00:22:53.182 --> 00:22:58.582
We want to apply this to
our gigabit0/1 interface.

345
00:22:58.582 --> 00:23:03.648
So this time we're changing up because
we're no longer going into the router.

346
00:23:03.648 --> 00:23:10.262
We're actually trying to prevent this
router from communicating to NYEDGE2,

347
00:23:10.262 --> 00:23:14.162
so we are going to go
into interface gig 0/1.

348
00:23:14.162 --> 00:23:19.514
And on this one, once we get there,
this is where it's a little bit different.

349
00:23:19.514 --> 00:23:24.285
We begin with ipv6 to
allow us to configure it,

350
00:23:24.285 --> 00:23:28.342
instead of access-group or anything,

351
00:23:28.342 --> 00:23:31.937
this is gonna be traffic-filter.

352
00:23:31.937 --> 00:23:37.767
It's gonna be block, NYEDGE2,

353
00:23:37.767 --> 00:23:41.214
I'm gonna tell it to block it outbound.

354
00:23:45.974 --> 00:23:47.251
Why can't I spell exit?

355
00:23:47.251 --> 00:23:51.187
I don't know why, but whatever it is,
I can't spell it, okay?

356
00:23:51.187 --> 00:23:54.437
All right, so let's verify that we
can actually ping this thing or not.

357
00:23:54.437 --> 00:23:59.697
We're gonna go over to NYWAN1, And

358
00:23:59.697 --> 00:24:05.124
on NYWAN1, if I can get access to it,

359
00:24:05.124 --> 00:24:13.966
there we go,
let's ping ipv6 2001:A:B:31::2

360
00:24:18.108 --> 00:24:20.748
All right, so
I am actually starting to see, well,

361
00:24:20.748 --> 00:24:24.370
it looks like something here is
actually coming across here.

362
00:24:24.370 --> 00:24:28.690
But notice, it's not actually all the,
what we're expecting, okay?

363
00:24:28.690 --> 00:24:33.294
So I get one dropped ping, but
I actually get these As coming across, and

364
00:24:33.294 --> 00:24:35.700
also see the success rate of 0%-
>> That's not good.

365
00:24:35.700 --> 00:24:38.230
>> Is coming through, okay?

366
00:24:38.230 --> 00:24:40.430
So is that good or is that bad?

367
00:24:40.430 --> 00:24:44.280
Well, for us, at a success rate of 0,
that's pretty much what we said.

368
00:24:44.280 --> 00:24:46.610
We wanted to block all
traffic from getting there.

369
00:24:46.610 --> 00:24:47.620
>> So it is good.

370
00:24:47.620 --> 00:24:50.190
>> So
it could be actually good at this point.

371
00:24:50.190 --> 00:24:54.134
So let's check and verify against NYEDGE1,

372
00:24:54.134 --> 00:24:58.185
let's see if we actually
get any matches here.

373
00:25:00.222 --> 00:25:08.060
Show ipv6 access-list, and
notice that there it is.

374
00:25:08.060 --> 00:25:13.140
The deny statement did get 4
matches that came across here, and

375
00:25:13.140 --> 00:25:14.890
it said, hey look, there it is.

376
00:25:14.890 --> 00:25:19.340
So this access control list is actually
working the way that we specified

377
00:25:19.340 --> 00:25:20.610
it to work.

378
00:25:20.610 --> 00:25:24.920
Now, what if we wanted to make sure
that we also denied access to,

379
00:25:24.920 --> 00:25:27.980
well another interface too, okay?

380
00:25:27.980 --> 00:25:33.860
Instead of the 31::2 here,
we wanted to also deny to 31::1,

381
00:25:33.860 --> 00:25:38.930
we wanted to add that in to
the same access control list.

382
00:25:38.930 --> 00:25:42.040
Well the great thing about numbered
access control list is it can be done.

383
00:25:44.230 --> 00:25:50.723
So now I go back into my
global configuration mode,

384
00:25:50.723 --> 00:25:55.857
ipv6 access-list block_NYEDGE2,

385
00:25:55.857 --> 00:25:59.636
I have to spell it correctly.

386
00:26:02.738 --> 00:26:05.819
And this time,
the way that we do this right is I

387
00:26:05.819 --> 00:26:10.630
essentially need it to be in
between these two statements, okay?

388
00:26:10.630 --> 00:26:15.482
That's what I need it to be in between,
between sequence 10 and sequence 20.

389
00:26:15.482 --> 00:26:18.360
So, this is where it gets
a little bit squirrelly, okay?

390
00:26:18.360 --> 00:26:22.700
I don't know why they did it this way,
but I don't know why I did that, okay?

391
00:26:22.700 --> 00:26:24.950
So, why should that matter, okay?

392
00:26:24.950 --> 00:26:28.680
So instead you'd actually have to
type in at the beginning here,

393
00:26:28.680 --> 00:26:30.838
sequence 15 right in between.

394
00:26:30.838 --> 00:26:36.356
We are going to deny anything from

395
00:26:36.356 --> 00:26:42.468
going to 2001:A:B:31::

396
00:26:42.468 --> 00:26:47.009
actually anything, yep.

397
00:26:47.009 --> 00:26:49.035
So I actually have
the entire network here,

398
00:26:49.035 --> 00:26:52.560
even though it actually originally says,
it actually did, on line two.

399
00:26:52.560 --> 00:26:59.385
I thought we were just doing that to one
but it's actually to the whole network.

400
00:26:59.385 --> 00:27:01.552
So we're gonna do a /64 here and

401
00:27:01.552 --> 00:27:05.533
we're also gonna add in the term
log is what we're going to do.

402
00:27:10.420 --> 00:27:16.723
Now we're not actually really showing
anything except for show ipv6 access-list.

403
00:27:20.802 --> 00:27:23.130
Just to show you how you
can add that in there.

404
00:27:23.130 --> 00:27:26.070
But I did want to point out
this key word log here, and

405
00:27:26.070 --> 00:27:28.450
why that one is important too, okay?

406
00:27:28.450 --> 00:27:31.430
As we take a look at this idea, okay,

407
00:27:31.430 --> 00:27:35.550
the term log is actually very good because
it literally does allow me to keep

408
00:27:35.550 --> 00:27:40.630
a record of this entry of how many
times this entry got matched.

409
00:27:40.630 --> 00:27:42.760
Now I can do it right here,
which is fine, but

410
00:27:42.760 --> 00:27:46.180
the idea of logging it
actually says make it show up.

411
00:27:46.180 --> 00:27:48.230
So the other thing that you can also do,

412
00:27:48.230 --> 00:27:52.710
remember we had the implicit deny
statement at the end of everything.

413
00:27:52.710 --> 00:27:55.590
If you want to know how many times people

414
00:27:55.590 --> 00:28:00.870
have actually encountered an access list
that you didn't expect them to do it.

415
00:28:00.870 --> 00:28:02.910
You can put the word log at the end and

416
00:28:02.910 --> 00:28:07.550
that will count up that many times that
somebody actually ended up hitting that.

417
00:28:07.550 --> 00:28:11.170
And again log it for us,
which is actually a really good thing.

418
00:28:11.170 --> 00:28:14.680
But you can't log an entry
that's only implicit, okay?

419
00:28:14.680 --> 00:28:18.562
So if you wanted to at the end, instead
you would actually do deny any, and

420
00:28:18.562 --> 00:28:20.577
then you'd put the word log after it.

421
00:28:20.577 --> 00:28:24.575
And that way you can say, nobody else is
supposed to actually even be trying this.

422
00:28:24.575 --> 00:28:28.764
If they're blocking, that's fine, but why
are they actually still trying to get in,

423
00:28:28.764 --> 00:28:31.340
and then you would actually
know that that happened.

424
00:28:31.340 --> 00:28:35.130
For us here, that helps us
out when we start doing this.

425
00:28:35.130 --> 00:28:37.995
Zack, in this little two part
miniseries that we did, right?

426
00:28:37.995 --> 00:28:39.195
>> Mm-hm.
>> We've covered a lot of

427
00:28:39.195 --> 00:28:39.720
information,right?

428
00:28:39.720 --> 00:28:43.508
The idea of standard access control lists,
extended access control lists,

429
00:28:43.508 --> 00:28:44.683
both of them numbered.

430
00:28:44.683 --> 00:28:49.103
But then also at the end here we talked
about of course named access list as

431
00:28:49.103 --> 00:28:51.430
well as access list for IP version 6.

432
00:28:51.430 --> 00:28:54.070
There's a lot of material that we've
just covered in these two episodes.

433
00:28:54.070 --> 00:28:57.030
>> Sure did, configure access list for
filtering part two.

434
00:28:57.030 --> 00:29:00.965
Make sure you see part two and Ronnie has
one more thing he wants to say, I think.

435
00:29:00.965 --> 00:29:04.900
>> Well just remember, you want to make
sure you understand those mechanics we

436
00:29:04.900 --> 00:29:09.170
talked about over in episode one,
pretty well.

437
00:29:09.170 --> 00:29:12.640
Now, take a look also at
the IP version 6 ones,

438
00:29:12.640 --> 00:29:16.340
if you haven't configured
IP version 6 access lists.

439
00:29:16.340 --> 00:29:19.480
Make sure you go over the lab and
make sure you step through it and

440
00:29:19.480 --> 00:29:22.980
understand what you are looking at as
you step through it as well, okay?

441
00:29:22.980 --> 00:29:25.060
All of this will only help you for
the exam,

442
00:29:25.060 --> 00:29:29.050
but will get you, of course, ready for
also the production network too.

443
00:29:29.050 --> 00:29:33.000
So the lists that we generally have
made here are very simple by comparison.

444
00:29:33.000 --> 00:29:37.440
In a real production environment, these
lists can extend for hundreds of lines.

445
00:29:37.440 --> 00:29:44.292
Do not be mistaken about that, so
don't think that it can't overwhelm you.

446
00:29:44.292 --> 00:29:48.159
You can look at some of these lists,
and even if they're only 50 or 60 long,

447
00:29:48.159 --> 00:29:51.006
it does take a long time in
getting used to looking at them.

448
00:29:51.006 --> 00:29:54.630
But for you, just make sure you
understand what the list looks like,

449
00:29:54.630 --> 00:29:56.894
go over the show commands heavily, okay?

450
00:29:56.894 --> 00:29:59.851
That you understand what is actually
being blocked and what isn't, and

451
00:29:59.851 --> 00:30:01.950
don't forget about the implicit deny.

452
00:30:01.950 --> 00:30:04.260
>> Well said Ronnie and
thank you for all your hard work.

453
00:30:04.260 --> 00:30:08.490
And what you guys need to do is take
a look at every single episode of

454
00:30:08.490 --> 00:30:13.202
CCNA Routing and Switching Exam 200-105,
it's gonna help you in the exam.

455
00:30:13.202 --> 00:30:16.350
Ronnie has done a lot of hard work
putting together a lot of information for

456
00:30:16.350 --> 00:30:17.885
you and you'll be glad that you did.

457
00:30:17.885 --> 00:30:19.780
And by the way,
you'll be in the course library,

458
00:30:19.780 --> 00:30:22.070
there's thousands of other videos there.

459
00:30:22.070 --> 00:30:25.480
You could take a look at those too because
they're there to help you go further.

460
00:30:25.480 --> 00:30:29.160
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
ITProTV is binge worthy.

461
00:30:29.160 --> 00:30:30.840
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

462
00:30:30.840 --> 00:30:31.560
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

463
00:30:31.560 --> 00:30:34.054
>> And we will see you again soon.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the use of the APIC-EM Path Trace ACL tool. They show where to get access to the lab and how to configure it for use.  Lastly, the team demonstrates the steps:  discovery first, then path trace to show where to isolate the ACL.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie begin by discussing what SNMP is and what is required to make it work.  The guys also talk about the different versions and the most common version is using SNMPv2c.  They configure snmp for version 2c and version 3.
episodes.title: Configure SNMP for Device Monitoring

devices do not all support that same

492
00:29:36.605 --> 00:29:37.310
version.

493
00:29:37.310 --> 00:29:40.380
You have to pick the one that
the devices will support.

494
00:29:40.380 --> 00:29:44.188
And that pretty much means all of them
will have to be on that same level.

495
00:29:44.188 --> 00:29:47.480
So version 2c is by far the most common,
and with that one,

496
00:29:47.480 --> 00:29:49.280
you'll use community strings.

497
00:29:49.280 --> 00:29:52.328
>> Great information,
doesn't he do a great job, he really does.

498

CCNA routing and switching exam 200-105,
make sure you watch every single episode,

you're gonna be so glad you did.

They're there to help you go further,

And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,

Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie take a look at Echo-based IP SLAs and why we use them.  Using the practice labs, they demonstrate the configuration and implementation of it.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Connectivity with IP SLA
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.595
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.595 --> 00:00:06.822
[CROSSTALK] Coming at you live
from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:06.822 --> 00:00:08.385
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.385 --> 00:00:12.020
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.020 --> 00:00:12.770
>> Hello and thank you for

6
00:00:12.770 --> 00:00:17.040
watching ITPRO.TV, empowering
the world with engaging learning.

7
00:00:17.040 --> 00:00:19.450
I'm your host Zach Memos for
this episode of CCNA Running and

8
00:00:19.450 --> 00:00:21.500
Switching Exam 200-105.

9
00:00:21.500 --> 00:00:26.910
This episode,
troubleshoot connectivity with IP SLA.

10
00:00:26.910 --> 00:00:27.720
What's that?

11
00:00:27.720 --> 00:00:30.770
Well, this guy right over here knows
the answer, and his name is Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:30.770 --> 00:00:32.310
Ronnie, [LAUGH] good to have you here.

13
00:00:32.310 --> 00:00:35.690
>> Well, Zach, thank you again for joining
me as we continue on our journey here.

14
00:00:35.690 --> 00:00:38.460
Taking a look at our CCNA routing and
switching show.

15
00:00:38.460 --> 00:00:42.350
We are up to this point where we
are now talking about of course

16
00:00:42.350 --> 00:00:44.000
infrastructure maintenance.

17
00:00:44.000 --> 00:00:48.540
And this is one of those unusual places
where we begin to actually see the idea of

18
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:52.530
business need as well as the idea
of just basic connection,

19
00:00:52.530 --> 00:00:55.760
in other words networking that
we need to happen as well.

20
00:00:55.760 --> 00:01:00.520
And that begins at least for our parts
on this term SLA nad what it means,

21
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:03.360
and then we attach that
acronym IP to the front of it,

22
00:01:03.360 --> 00:01:05.860
and then we also have to ask
what that means as well.

23
00:01:05.860 --> 00:01:08.905
And we'll be discussing that as well
as showing you how to configure it.

24
00:01:08.905 --> 00:01:12.695
>> Ronnie, IMCP echo based, IP SLA.

25
00:01:12.695 --> 00:01:13.655
What is that?
>> Yeah.

26
00:01:13.655 --> 00:01:16.335
So all of a sudden, you just said
a mouthful of different things, right.

27
00:01:16.335 --> 00:01:17.215
>> I know.
>> It stopped me.

28
00:01:17.215 --> 00:01:18.345
I was stuttering a little.

29
00:01:18.345 --> 00:01:19.745
>> No, no, there's no doubt.

30
00:01:19.745 --> 00:01:23.135
So this is a little bit tough here,
because IP SLA,

31
00:01:23.135 --> 00:01:29.200
it's a large gigantic variety of
different things that we can actually do.

32
00:01:29.200 --> 00:01:31.460
So when we start off
with this idea of an SLA,

33
00:01:31.460 --> 00:01:34.320
let's kind of break
the terminology down here first.

34
00:01:34.320 --> 00:01:37.760
We'll start off with the term, SLA, cuz
that's kind of the biggest terminology,

35
00:01:37.760 --> 00:01:40.230
which means Service Level Agreement.

36
00:01:40.230 --> 00:01:44.320
Well, a Service Level Agreement, for at
least you and me in just a general sense,

37
00:01:44.320 --> 00:01:47.480
not just talking about IP based
Service Level Agreements here.

38
00:01:47.480 --> 00:01:51.710
But what we're normally talking about,
of course, is what is the expected

39
00:01:51.710 --> 00:01:56.190
level of service that you and
your customers have agreed to?

40
00:01:56.190 --> 00:02:00.520
So in that sense,
if you're providing a network,

41
00:02:01.831 --> 00:02:04.030
Administration at some sort, right?

42
00:02:04.030 --> 00:02:06.350
Then you have already
come to a contract and

43
00:02:06.350 --> 00:02:10.230
you say here is the amount of service
that I am willing to provide and

44
00:02:10.230 --> 00:02:13.050
then of course, they agree on that and
so they can expect

45
00:02:13.050 --> 00:02:17.570
that amount of performance from you to
make sure that they have that agreement.

46
00:02:17.570 --> 00:02:21.240
When there's a violation, there
normally come with penalties as well.

47
00:02:21.240 --> 00:02:23.657
But for us here,
when we start dealing with that,

48
00:02:23.657 --> 00:02:25.970
understanding that part
is really kind of key.

49
00:02:25.970 --> 00:02:31.120
Because in a business sense,
that is something we all have to agree to.

50
00:02:31.120 --> 00:02:35.390
As the world continues
towards more cloud services.

51
00:02:35.390 --> 00:02:39.970
Whether or not your company
are up to snuff on being ready to

52
00:02:39.970 --> 00:02:43.680
do everything in the cloud, well, it could
be that they hire a contractor to come in.

53
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:45.690
The contractor says, well, here's the SLA.

54
00:02:45.690 --> 00:02:48.970
Here's the Service Level Agreement
that we're willing to provide.

55
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:51.030
Some of the hoops they'll jump through,
some of them they won't.

56
00:02:51.030 --> 00:02:52.340
You'll end up agreeing to that.

57
00:02:52.340 --> 00:02:56.500
And that's what you have to actually do
is you'll stick by those terms, okay?

58
00:02:56.500 --> 00:03:00.270
But when we start taking a look at
it from the standpoint of network

59
00:03:00.270 --> 00:03:01.650
performance though.

60
00:03:01.650 --> 00:03:04.770
It doesn't matter if you and
I agree to it.

61
00:03:04.770 --> 00:03:09.600
What we want to be able to do then,
of course, is to try and be sure that we

62
00:03:09.600 --> 00:03:13.780
can find out, is our network actually
performing the way it needs to be.

63
00:03:13.780 --> 00:03:17.300
And so now, we start talking about
the type of network that we're normally

64
00:03:17.300 --> 00:03:20.660
running today which is
an IP based network.

65
00:03:20.660 --> 00:03:23.990
So that for us means, of course,
using IP based networks.

66
00:03:23.990 --> 00:03:26.570
Means that between our devices, right,

67
00:03:26.570 --> 00:03:31.020
what level of performance can
be expected from those devices.

68
00:03:31.020 --> 00:03:35.330
And that can go from just performance
levels to just regular connectivity levels

69
00:03:35.330 --> 00:03:35.990
if we choose to.

70
00:03:35.990 --> 00:03:36.880
And there's so

71
00:03:36.880 --> 00:03:40.200
many different varieties that we can
choose depending on what we need

72
00:03:40.200 --> 00:03:44.200
to verify and test whether or not this is
working the way that it should be working.

73
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:48.380
Now, Zach mentioned a specific
branch of even the IP SLA called

74
00:03:48.380 --> 00:03:52.350
the echo based IP SLA as well, okay?

75
00:03:52.350 --> 00:03:57.550
Well, this idea of the echo based or
ICMP echo based one, means that we

76
00:03:57.550 --> 00:04:03.180
are going to use as our particular way
of actually verifying and testing.

77
00:04:03.180 --> 00:04:08.290
Whether or not we're getting the expected
level of connectivity that we need to,

78
00:04:08.290 --> 00:04:13.290
inside of our network, is that we're going
to use ICMP to help us to test that.

79
00:04:13.290 --> 00:04:17.360
So in that sense, what begins to
happen then, is that we have to

80
00:04:17.360 --> 00:04:22.480
actually be able to say, here's how we're
going to say that we're going to discover.

81
00:04:22.480 --> 00:04:24.950
And whether or
not our connectivity is up and

82
00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:28.510
good, as we're going to use
ICMP to help us to do that.

83
00:04:28.510 --> 00:04:31.930
>> So we know a little about what it is,
but now what does it do?

84
00:04:31.930 --> 00:04:36.240
>> Yeah now, we begin to actually set it
all up and get everything settled down.

85
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:42.130
The base nature of using this echo based
ICMP SLA, right, when we start doing it,

86
00:04:42.130 --> 00:04:46.260
it allows us to begin to send
data across the actual network

87
00:04:46.260 --> 00:04:51.600
to measure the level of performance
that we have between our devices.

88
00:04:51.600 --> 00:04:56.340
So it's not really enforcing it and
saying you better have this amount.

89
00:04:56.340 --> 00:04:57.810
But it's essentially telling us and

90
00:04:57.810 --> 00:05:01.740
sending messages to verify
that we have the expected

91
00:05:01.740 --> 00:05:06.240
level of agreement that we're talking
about in terms of network performance.

92
00:05:06.240 --> 00:05:10.410
And at some point, if it's not working, it
should let us know that it's not working,

93
00:05:10.410 --> 00:05:13.520
and that way it might be where we
begin troubleshooting as well.

94
00:05:13.520 --> 00:05:16.610
The other thing that it also does for

95
00:05:16.610 --> 00:05:22.300
us, is that with the echo based one,
we're essentially simulating

96
00:05:22.300 --> 00:05:27.520
the amount of data that we are going to
expect to see on our network as well.

97
00:05:27.520 --> 00:05:30.930
So this means we can actually do
this with the idea of frequency.

98
00:05:30.930 --> 00:05:34.370
We can do it with the idea of
numbers of bites if we choose to.

99
00:05:34.370 --> 00:05:38.840
You name it there's different ways that we
can actually try and simulate the amount

100
00:05:38.840 --> 00:05:45.140
of expected number activity without having
to double the network activity to do so.

101
00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:49.830
So it gives us that ability to do so
using ICMP instead.

102
00:05:49.830 --> 00:05:54.570
So that is a big reason why we would do
this, because then someone that's CCNA,

103
00:05:54.570 --> 00:05:59.580
someone that's CCNP,
in other words a Cisco networking

104
00:05:59.580 --> 00:06:03.400
professional, someone that's
doing all of this, right.

105
00:06:03.400 --> 00:06:07.700
Well, they can then isolate where
they need to begin troubleshooting,

106
00:06:07.700 --> 00:06:10.080
if they're not getting what
they're expecting to see.

107
00:06:10.080 --> 00:06:13.360
>> So Ronnie, why would we use it,
why would we need to use it?

108
00:06:13.360 --> 00:06:17.020
>> Yeah, well, different companies will
use it for different reasons, okay?

109
00:06:17.020 --> 00:06:18.780
So when you start thinking about it,

110
00:06:18.780 --> 00:06:22.960
one of the primary reasons why we use
the echo based one is fairly simple.

111
00:06:22.960 --> 00:06:26.940
We're trying to verify edge
to edge connectivity and

112
00:06:26.940 --> 00:06:29.525
availability monitoring is
what we're trying to do.

113
00:06:29.525 --> 00:06:30.100
>> Mm-hm.

114
00:06:30.100 --> 00:06:34.860
>> So in something like that, the echo
based type of SLA is going to help us

115
00:06:34.860 --> 00:06:39.610
by providing us with packet loss
information or statistics that we need, so

116
00:06:39.610 --> 00:06:42.640
that we can judge and
figure out what's actually happening.

117
00:06:42.640 --> 00:06:46.450
Where are we losing the packets and
how much are we losing at one time to.

118
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:49.550
We can also of course get
network performance monitoring.

119
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:50.320
So this is different.

120
00:06:50.320 --> 00:06:52.920
We're not just testing for
end to end connectivity anymore.

121
00:06:52.920 --> 00:06:56.610
But let's say that we are expecting
a guaranteed level of service and

122
00:06:56.610 --> 00:06:59.870
you might be wondering,
why are we really worried about that?

123
00:06:59.870 --> 00:07:04.280
At one point, you weren't because
regardless of how much network bandwidth

124
00:07:04.280 --> 00:07:10.110
that you had internally in your LAN, you
never really sent that much bandwidth out.

125
00:07:10.110 --> 00:07:14.410
Well, today, because we have a mix of
different types of data, voice and video,

126
00:07:14.410 --> 00:07:19.020
in other words, Real time data, along
with just files that we normally access.

127
00:07:19.020 --> 00:07:23.320
Well, now, the combination of
those may really come close.

128
00:07:23.320 --> 00:07:25.680
Really overwhelming your network, okay?

129
00:07:25.680 --> 00:07:27.210
It doesn't mean it always will.

130
00:07:27.210 --> 00:07:31.770
You add that in with other proprietary
things that begin to happen

131
00:07:31.770 --> 00:07:32.770
on your network.

132
00:07:32.770 --> 00:07:35.720
Then it might actually come
close to that saturation

133
00:07:35.720 --> 00:07:37.740
of the level of bandwidth that you have.

134
00:07:37.740 --> 00:07:42.840
So it can help us out even in taking
a look at the idea of performance too.

135
00:07:42.840 --> 00:07:47.290
It might give us statistics on things like
latency, as well as response times or

136
00:07:47.290 --> 00:07:50.600
round trip times,
to essentially help us out in that way.

137
00:07:50.600 --> 00:07:53.860
And then of course,
just basic trouble shooting.

138
00:07:53.860 --> 00:07:55.618
Isolating like what I said before.

139
00:07:55.618 --> 00:07:58.823
Making sure that you can define
where you're going to see this.

140
00:07:58.823 --> 00:08:01.721
So all of these things for us, right?

141
00:08:01.721 --> 00:08:05.195
It really is starting to push
us towards what we need.

142
00:08:05.195 --> 00:08:10.794
At the beginning, the idea for all of us
that we were starting off studying for

143
00:08:10.794 --> 00:08:16.157
our CCENT or the CCNA routing and
switching exam or both of those, right.

144
00:08:16.157 --> 00:08:19.708
We really focused in on just
making the devices communicate and

145
00:08:19.708 --> 00:08:22.880
connect, making sure
we understood routing.

146
00:08:22.880 --> 00:08:25.410
Making sure we understood
the basic concepts of routing and

147
00:08:25.410 --> 00:08:27.010
switching doing all of that.

148
00:08:27.010 --> 00:08:31.580
All of that is great and fundamental,
but in a production network right, and

149
00:08:31.580 --> 00:08:33.580
something which people
are depending on for

150
00:08:33.580 --> 00:08:36.050
their business to do what it needs to do.

151
00:08:36.050 --> 00:08:39.690
We also now are moving and
we're starting to find out something.

152
00:08:39.690 --> 00:08:44.990
This is where the Cisco professional
is beginning to find out whether or

153
00:08:44.990 --> 00:08:48.240
not their networked in the way
that's been configured

154
00:08:48.240 --> 00:08:52.620
is meeting the performance demands
of what the business requires.

155
00:08:52.620 --> 00:08:55.595
So this is where we're seeing
the technical side and

156
00:08:55.595 --> 00:08:59.854
the business strategy side essentially
meet to make sure that we're doing

157
00:08:59.854 --> 00:09:01.833
everything that we can to do to so.

158
00:09:01.833 --> 00:09:04.518
So that is what we're
gonna be setting up today,

159
00:09:04.518 --> 00:09:07.276
is taking a look at this
idea of the echo based SLA.

160
00:09:07.276 --> 00:09:09.797
>> Perfect, well let's take a look,

All right so we're gonna of

Remember that as
an ITProTV member you have

00:09:18.390 --> 00:09:20.720
access to this with your subscription.

166
00:09:20.720 --> 00:09:24.538
As you get started make sure that once
you get in there you're gonna choose

interconnecting Cisco networking devices
ICND2 version 3 make sure you choose

version 3,
there a couple of additions in there.

169
00:09:31.455 --> 00:09:37.370
Troubleshoot network connectivity
issues using ICMP echo based IP SLAs.

Now that is a mouthful and

171
00:09:41.000 --> 00:09:45.020
that's listed there as the title of this
lab, that's what I wanted in the lower

172
00:09:45.020 --> 00:09:49.180
third that you normally saw as
the episode actually pulled up here.

But it was way too long so I just kind

But this is the lab that we will be doing,

So I'm simply gonna zoom back out and

then we're gonna be using NYEDGE1 and
also PLAB right here, okay?

At the beginning of the lab
when it first kicks on and

00:10:11.631 --> 00:10:13.681
everything is configured
the way it needs to.

This is the only device that is turned

That's the only option you should have,

So now once we do that I'm gonna

we'll go ahead and begin our IPSLA
configuration as well, okay?

187
00:10:41.671 --> 00:10:46.479
So we're gonna go ahead and configure this
on NYEDGE1 and we need to, of course,

00:10:46.479 --> 00:10:49.142
go into our global configuration terminal.

And once we're inside of our
global configuration terminal,

the syntax is relatively easy here, okay?

It's ip sla and then you give it a string

be a number that you identify this with,
and once you do that, notice

the prompt has changed config-ip-sla,

If you exit out of this and try to go back

So make sure you actually

You won't be able to get back in to

So for us, once we're actually in
here now we can begin to define

the IP SLA option that we want.

So we're gonna set up icmp-echo,
what we're doing,

00:11:38.381 --> 00:11:43.627
we're telling it what type of SLA
we're actually asking for as well.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the concept of SPAN or "port mirroring."  They discuss the reason to use it and some of the weaknesses it has.  The team then shows the simple configuration of local SPAN and verify it's operation by seeing the data from the monitored port.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Problems with SPAN

When we do something like

Where in the other term for

very hard at everything it does,

396
00:24:08.215 --> 00:24:11.678
To ensure that data can get
from one port to another.

397
00:24:11.678 --> 00:24:13.542
But whenever you enable spam,

398
00:24:13.542 --> 00:24:17.850
you're asking it to actually work alot
harder to do what it needs to do.

399
00:24:18.970 --> 00:24:21.280
So, when you actually start
examining real time data,

400
00:24:21.280 --> 00:24:25.180
you're going to see that it's not going
to give you everything that you want.

401
00:24:25.180 --> 00:24:28.970
Alot of times it's going to give you
what they call a summary of data.

402
00:24:28.970 --> 00:24:31.300
It's not trying to show
you every single packet.

403
00:24:31.300 --> 00:24:32.030
Even though it's called,

404
00:24:32.030 --> 00:24:36.220
it's port mirroring, it is only gonna
show you a summary of what might bere.

405
00:24:36.220 --> 00:24:39.540
Now, what happens to all the data
that doesn't get through?

406
00:24:39.540 --> 00:24:41.900
Well, the switch essentially drops it.

407
00:24:41.900 --> 00:24:45.070
So the data actually does that,
it drops it.

408
00:24:45.070 --> 00:24:48.610
The other thing that
also SPAN is not good for

409
00:24:48.610 --> 00:24:51.890
is the priority of how
it works on the switch.

410
00:24:51.890 --> 00:24:56.820
And what I mean by that is, if there is
traffic go in between, your device and

411
00:24:56.820 --> 00:24:58.670
through the monitoring port as well.

412
00:24:58.670 --> 00:25:01.860
Which it shouldn't be, but
happens that way, right?

413
00:25:01.860 --> 00:25:07.010
Well, the last thing that really is
a priority is the idea of monitoring.

414
00:25:07.010 --> 00:25:10.120
That means of regular traffic is,
flooding that port or

415
00:25:10.120 --> 00:25:13.190
sending to whatever
the destination port is.

416
00:25:13.190 --> 00:25:17.120
Well, it will drop all of
the span traffic before

417
00:25:17.120 --> 00:25:20.680
it drops any real time
production traffic at all, okay?

418
00:25:20.680 --> 00:25:25.260
So that is something else that
you can also see as a limitation.

419
00:25:25.260 --> 00:25:26.240
If you're trying to do this for

420
00:25:26.240 --> 00:25:30.680
some type of network troubleshooting
which involves maybe a security risk.

421
00:25:30.680 --> 00:25:33.630
It can also change time stamps on packets,

422
00:25:33.630 --> 00:25:35.210
that's never a good idea, either
>> No, No.

423
00:25:35.210 --> 00:25:36.810
>> Cause now you dont know when that can

424
00:25:36.810 --> 00:25:42.110
happen and because of the nature of how
we're sending the information,right?

425
00:25:42.110 --> 00:25:45.281
Remember that this can be a security risk,
okay?

426
00:25:45.281 --> 00:25:50.070
Because we're saying if I can copy
the data from one place to another port.

427
00:25:50.070 --> 00:25:53.260
Somebody else can do the same thing
as well and start doing that.

428
00:25:53.260 --> 00:25:55.680
So it's not the most difficult
configuration in the world.

429
00:25:55.680 --> 00:25:58.610
It's not tricky,
it's doesn't require any authentication.

430
00:25:58.610 --> 00:26:01.360
It just requires physical
access to the switch itself.

431
00:26:01.360 --> 00:26:04.150
So there's a lot of different
ways that it can help you out.

432
00:26:04.150 --> 00:26:09.260
But overall, though, it is good for just
certain things, and not for everything.

433
00:26:09.260 --> 00:26:12.830
Now what if you want to capture every
single piece of data that's coming in

434
00:26:12.830 --> 00:26:13.920
or leaving that.

435
00:26:13.920 --> 00:26:17.320
Well at that point, you have to go
to what's called a network tap.

436
00:26:17.320 --> 00:26:19.730
A network tap is a physical device, and

437
00:26:19.730 --> 00:26:23.560
it normally requires you to
have two different ports.

438
00:26:23.560 --> 00:26:26.630
One set up for instream, and
one set up for outstream data.

439
00:26:26.630 --> 00:26:30.310
And then you'll actually configure
that to go to another device itself.

440
00:26:30.310 --> 00:26:34.700
But usually at that point you're really
serious into that and it's kind of neat.

441
00:26:34.700 --> 00:26:39.460
But these devices they have been
in the past insanely expensive.

442
00:26:39.460 --> 00:26:42.290
Because you have to monitor
two different ports to do so.

443
00:26:42.290 --> 00:26:45.440
But it is worth it, the reason behind
that is even though it actually

444
00:26:45.440 --> 00:26:48.280
copies the data,
it doesn't actually do this.

445
00:26:48.280 --> 00:26:50.520
It doesn't actually stop anything.

446
00:26:50.520 --> 00:26:53.880
All it's doing is literally actually just

447
00:26:53.880 --> 00:26:58.650
putting that data out there on another
device and you're ready to go, okay?

448
00:26:58.650 --> 00:27:03.260
So if you really need to do real
time data mirroring in that sense,

449
00:27:03.260 --> 00:27:06.670
use a network tab instead.
>> Awesome, great episode,

450
00:27:06.670 --> 00:27:08.430
troubleshoot problems with span.

451
00:27:08.430 --> 00:27:10.781
I've enjoyed it, learned a lot,
I'm sure you did too.

452
00:27:10.781 --> 00:27:12.264
But Ronnie has a few
more things he'd like to

453
00:27:12.264 --> 00:27:13.210
say.
>> Well,

454
00:27:13.210 --> 00:27:15.230
this is not the most
difficult one in the world.

455
00:27:15.230 --> 00:27:17.560
So I wouldn't a spend a ton of time on it.

456
00:27:17.560 --> 00:27:21.762
I would make sure that I understand that
it is a technique that can be used for

457
00:27:21.762 --> 00:27:22.910
troubleshooting.

458
00:27:22.910 --> 00:27:26.400
Especially if you take a look at
the issues that we've talked about before.

459
00:27:26.400 --> 00:27:31.630
But remember that this is not great for
real time monitoring at all, okay?

460
00:27:31.630 --> 00:27:34.470
So take a look it, and
make sure you go with your lab.

461
00:27:34.470 --> 00:27:38.780
I wouldn't spend the majority of
time trying to figure this one out.

462
00:27:38.780 --> 00:27:42.240
But I would make sure I go okay I know
what local SPAN will help me to do.

463
00:27:42.240 --> 00:27:47.020
It's also known as port mirroring, so
if you read any question that sounds like

464
00:27:47.020 --> 00:27:50.950
it's asking me to send a copy of
the data to another, that's what it is.

465
00:27:50.950 --> 00:27:54.080
SPAN or it's port mirroring,
you'll probably be fine.

466
00:27:54.080 --> 00:27:56.290
But just make sure that
you understand that.

467
00:27:56.290 --> 00:27:59.070
And the configuration of
what might be happening.

468
00:27:59.070 --> 00:28:02.020
Most people in the misconfiguration
on this is because they either

469
00:28:02.020 --> 00:28:05.710
forgot to set the source port or
they forgot to set the destination port.

470
00:28:05.710 --> 00:28:08.970
they're talking about receiving only the
data that looks like it's coming inbound.

471
00:28:08.970 --> 00:28:13.580
You need both you just change
the word RX to both, okay?

472
00:28:13.580 --> 00:28:17.980
Or TX to both, whatever it might be, just
make sure you pay attention to some of

473
00:28:17.980 --> 00:28:20.400
those simple things out there.
>> Thanks Ronnie and thanks for

474
00:28:20.400 --> 00:28:22.860
being so thorough and
speaking of thorough.

475

You'll be thorough if you take a look at
every single episode of CCNA Routing and

Switching Exam 200-105.

Ronnie has done a marvelous job putting
together a lot of information for

00:28:32.780 --> 00:28:34.720
you in all of these great episodes.

479
00:28:34.720 --> 00:28:36.460
And by the way you'll be

there's thousands of
other videos there too.

00:28:38.810 --> 00:28:42.880
Also and they're there to help you go

00:28:42.880 --> 00:28:46.420
And tell everybody you know about

Thanks for watching I'm Zach Memos.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe using AAA for device management.  They explain the difference between TACACS+ and RADIUS.  They demonstrate the router configuration necessary to connect to the AAA server.
episodes.title: Describe Device Mgmt Using AAA

3
00:00:06.574 --> 00:00:08.254

5

6
00:00:16.830 --> 00:00:21.740
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with the CCNA Routing and

7
00:00:21.740 --> 00:00:23.790
Switching Exam 200-105.

8
00:00:23.790 --> 00:00:28.065
This episode describe device
management using AAA.

9
00:00:28.065 --> 00:00:32.170
I don't know, [LAUGH] so let's ask Ronnie.

10
00:00:32.170 --> 00:00:33.900
Ronnie Wong, good to see you, sir.

11
00:00:33.900 --> 00:00:35.355
>> Good to see you too,
yes, we're not sure.

12
00:00:35.355 --> 00:00:40.217
It's some type of car maintenance service,
is what we're not doing here.

13
00:00:40.217 --> 00:00:43.774
Yes, as we continue on our CCNA
routing and switching show,

14
00:00:43.774 --> 00:00:48.140
we're gonna be taking a look at
the idea of, well, like Zach said, AAA.

15
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:52.500
Most of the time you here people call it
triple A, is what you hear about here,

16
00:00:52.500 --> 00:00:54.750
so what in the world is that about?

17
00:00:54.750 --> 00:00:59.230
Okay, well like Zach actually said, for
us, when we start talking about the idea

18
00:00:59.230 --> 00:01:04.210
of triple A we are talking about
authentication, authorization, and

19
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:08.010
accounting, is all in one package.

20
00:01:08.010 --> 00:01:10.430
Now why is that important?

21
00:01:10.430 --> 00:01:14.800
The problem that we have with
the earliest Cisco devices is simple.

22
00:01:14.800 --> 00:01:20.460
Okay, for us to be able to get access in,
it only had what we call basic security.

23
00:01:20.460 --> 00:01:25.890
Now the unusual thing right,
as we're now at almost yeah,

24
00:01:25.890 --> 00:01:29.290
actually after the first quarter of
2018 as of the recording of this show.

25
00:01:29.290 --> 00:01:30.427
>> This is April 2018
as of this recording.

26
00:01:30.427 --> 00:01:32.751
>> So as we take a look at that right,

27
00:01:32.751 --> 00:01:37.831
the idea of basic authentication date
really is kind of unusual, okay.

28
00:01:37.831 --> 00:01:42.360
Because we've actually dealt with so
much even over the past year, year and

29
00:01:42.360 --> 00:01:44.342
a half, that authentication and

30
00:01:44.342 --> 00:01:47.761
the idea of security has kind
of jumped up tremendously.

31
00:01:47.761 --> 00:01:49.489
But at the very beginning, okay,

32
00:01:49.489 --> 00:01:52.236
when you start taking a look
at networking equipment.

33
00:01:52.236 --> 00:01:57.245
The idea of protecting your particular
equipment came down to one thing,

34
00:01:57.245 --> 00:01:59.780
and that was basic security.

35
00:01:59.780 --> 00:02:02.030
Well what is basic security?

36
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:05.250
Basic security is just putting
a password on something.

37
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:06.130
>> Right.
>> So for

38
00:02:06.130 --> 00:02:10.940
us that meant that if we actually set
a password to get access to the router,

39
00:02:10.940 --> 00:02:13.010
it was really that,
it was just a password.

40
00:02:13.010 --> 00:02:16.710
That didn't matter whether Zach used
the password, or I used the password, or

41
00:02:16.710 --> 00:02:18.540
you used the password, that was it.

42
00:02:18.540 --> 00:02:20.440
That was basic security.

43
00:02:20.440 --> 00:02:26.050
So in other words, one password ended up
giving you access to that one device.

44
00:02:26.050 --> 00:02:29.230
Well the problem that we found out
very quickly, I shouldn't say quickly,

45
00:02:29.230 --> 00:02:31.620
we found out after time, is simple.

46
00:02:31.620 --> 00:02:33.990
Not only do we have the problem
of it being one password, but

47
00:02:33.990 --> 00:02:38.190
it's probably the password that we
ended up using on a lot of our devices.

48
00:02:38.190 --> 00:02:42.006
And now because everybody realized that,
like Zach, and myself, and

49
00:02:42.006 --> 00:02:45.577
other people ended up realizing that,
that also meant that what?

50
00:02:45.577 --> 00:02:49.161
The scope of that one password was
not only on every single device, but

51
00:02:49.161 --> 00:02:52.710
everybody in my organization seemed
to know what that password was.

52
00:02:52.710 --> 00:02:56.921
And that meant that they could also
gain access into those devices, and

53
00:02:56.921 --> 00:03:01.370
be able to mess around with
the configuration fairly easily.

54
00:03:01.370 --> 00:03:04.670
Okay, so at the very beginning,
where was that password kept?

55
00:03:04.670 --> 00:03:08.660
Well it was stored locally right
there on the router or on the switch.

56
00:03:08.660 --> 00:03:12.510
So that meant that when you created
the router or the switch configuration,

57
00:03:12.510 --> 00:03:15.230
you added that right in and
that went into your running config,

58
00:03:15.230 --> 00:03:19.340
which of course then when you saved it,
it enter into your startup config.

59
00:03:19.340 --> 00:03:22.880
And we've shown you this in the past,
especially in the CCent series,

60
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:28.030
where you could actually see passwords
right there in the actual configuration.

61
00:03:28.030 --> 00:03:32.530
So that meant that when the device booted
up, it also made those passwords actually

62
00:03:32.530 --> 00:03:35.373
appear that the way they
were actually right there.

63
00:03:35.373 --> 00:03:38.859
So in that sense they realized
that what we had to come up with

64
00:03:38.859 --> 00:03:40.480
something better, okay.

65
00:03:40.480 --> 00:03:45.096
Which you can call advanced security,
but as far as advancement goes today we

66
00:03:45.096 --> 00:03:49.890
would kind of laugh at it and go it's
not really advanced security at all.

67
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:52.535
It's what we would call basic security.

68
00:03:52.535 --> 00:03:56.350
>> Okay, so the funny thing
is that when Cisco came up,

69
00:03:56.350 --> 00:04:00.160
I shouldn't say they came up with,
when they decided to actually do

70
00:04:00.160 --> 00:04:03.620
advanced security they didn't
actually call it advanced security.

71
00:04:03.620 --> 00:04:04.270
They said, hey,

72
00:04:04.270 --> 00:04:08.530
we're actually implementing
a new model of security, okay?

73
00:04:08.530 --> 00:04:12.330
The idea of the new model of security,
well, what the heck did that mean?

74
00:04:12.330 --> 00:04:14.860
It meant a username and a password.

75
00:04:14.860 --> 00:04:17.520
So that meant that we could configure
a different username password for

76
00:04:17.520 --> 00:04:22.770
Zach, a different one for me, username for
my particular account as well.

77
00:04:22.770 --> 00:04:24.790
And of course one for you and
a different one for you.

78
00:04:24.790 --> 00:04:30.990
Well that meant that we limited then
the scope and the actual password access.

79
00:04:30.990 --> 00:04:33.940
If I didn't want you to access
a router that I was managing,

80
00:04:33.940 --> 00:04:35.340
I wouldn't create a user account for you.

81
00:04:35.340 --> 00:04:39.007
That made it easier and I only have to
keep my password, same thing with Zach.

82
00:04:39.007 --> 00:04:42.385
If he didn't want me getting in,
he wouldn't actually make an account for

83
00:04:42.385 --> 00:04:45.671
me and that would, again,
kind of settle and solve everything, okay.

84
00:04:45.671 --> 00:04:49.860
So this idea of the new model
itself was kind of the beginning.

85
00:04:49.860 --> 00:04:55.899
And still at the same time, the weakness
then became not so much the individuals.

86
00:04:55.899 --> 00:04:58.743
Cuz Zach maybe I would get us into
the ones that he managed, but

87
00:04:58.743 --> 00:05:02.039
not all the ones that I manage,
not all the ones that you manage, okay.

88
00:05:02.039 --> 00:05:06.876
But at the same time, though because
we are storing everything locally on

89
00:05:06.876 --> 00:05:11.713
that particular device, it also meant for
anybody that could go ahead and

90
00:05:11.713 --> 00:05:14.470
be able to do some type of password reset.

91
00:05:14.470 --> 00:05:17.704
Well we showed you how to do
that in the CCENT series, okay.

92
00:05:17.704 --> 00:05:19.664
For anybody that was able to do that,

93
00:05:19.664 --> 00:05:22.708
well that was actually easy
to bypass even at that point.

94
00:05:22.708 --> 00:05:26.950
So when it boils down to it, it's not
exactly the newest model in the world,

95
00:05:26.950 --> 00:05:31.600
but that's what they started configuring
as what we call a new model.

96
00:05:31.600 --> 00:05:34.663
Now the idea,
the truest sense of the new model then,

97
00:05:34.663 --> 00:05:36.650
is kind of a mix of things, right?

98
00:05:36.650 --> 00:05:40.312
We require something a little bit more
complex than just a basic password.

99
00:05:40.312 --> 00:05:44.239
Username and of course passwords
still kind of the main crux of

100
00:05:44.239 --> 00:05:48.660
where most businesses have all
their users logging in, right?

101
00:05:48.660 --> 00:05:53.320
If you think about it right, and if you've
got even like Office 365 as where your

102
00:05:53.320 --> 00:05:59.160
email goes, you're probably using username
in terms of an email address of some sort,

103
00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:02.080
and some password that you're typing
in to get access to your email.

104
00:06:02.080 --> 00:06:04.800
So username and
passwords are still being used everywhere.

105
00:06:04.800 --> 00:06:09.514
But the key now though, is to protect
where that information is stored, and

106
00:06:09.514 --> 00:06:11.560
to make sure that it remains secret.

107
00:06:11.560 --> 00:06:18.040
So the way that we do that in the world of
Cisco, of course, is to remove the load of

108
00:06:18.040 --> 00:06:22.830
where that information is stored, which is
not on the router or the switch anymore.

109
00:06:22.830 --> 00:06:26.290
But to off load that to something else,
that we call,

110
00:06:26.290 --> 00:06:30.550
in most generic terms,
a triple A server, okay.

111
00:06:30.550 --> 00:06:32.120
And there's two different types, and so

112
00:06:32.120 --> 00:06:34.880
let's take a look at how this
actually forms out for us.

113
00:06:34.880 --> 00:06:37.820
Okay, so on my screen I have
made a simple diagram for us.

114
00:06:38.950 --> 00:06:44.200
So in terms of triple A here, okay,
it actually does cover the scope

115
00:06:44.200 --> 00:06:50.230
from the very fact of the client beginning
to need access into the network somewhere.

116
00:06:50.230 --> 00:06:53.450
And when we actually type how
we're gonna get access in,

117
00:06:53.450 --> 00:06:56.630
the router itself acts as what
we call an authenticator.

118
00:06:56.630 --> 00:07:00.390
So the client is a supplicant that says,
hey, I need to get access in,

119
00:07:00.390 --> 00:07:05.080
and he normally presents or
he supplies some type of credentials for

120
00:07:05.080 --> 00:07:07.120
us it's gonna be username and password.

121
00:07:07.120 --> 00:07:10.850
The authenticator here verifies or
actually says,

122
00:07:10.850 --> 00:07:14.800
all right, can you get in or not?

123
00:07:14.800 --> 00:07:18.434
Okay, if it believes you can actually
do so, it will then pass it on to

124
00:07:18.434 --> 00:07:23.370
the authentication server to validate
whatever credentials you've presented.

125
00:07:23.370 --> 00:07:26.511
Okay, the nice thing about this is
that means that the router itself,

126
00:07:26.511 --> 00:07:29.226
sitting on the edge of your
network exposed to the internet or

127
00:07:29.226 --> 00:07:31.950
some other network that
you don't know about.

128
00:07:31.950 --> 00:07:34.800
It also means that at this point,

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe network programmability.  The guys begin by describing how networking devices function now with the control plane and data plan.  Next they discuss the use of the network controller and APIs used with SDNs
