hopefully that's a good introduction.

475
00:28:03.530 --> 00:28:06.190
That we can have because we're
not asked to configure anything,

476
00:28:06.190 --> 00:28:07.640
we're not asked to show you anything.

477
00:28:07.640 --> 00:28:10.570
We're asked to just describe why
would we actually do this and

478
00:28:10.570 --> 00:28:12.140
hopefully we've covered that.

479
00:28:12.140 --> 00:28:16.470
>> Some episode, describe network
programmability with Ronnie Wong and me.

480
00:28:16.470 --> 00:28:19.040
And before we leave,
anything else you'd like to say Ronnie?

481
00:28:19.040 --> 00:28:24.000
>> Well this is one of those things
that you're going to probably need to

482
00:28:24.000 --> 00:28:27.750
read up on as a Cisco professional
continues to develop.

483
00:28:27.750 --> 00:28:31.220
Do not think that you won't
encounter this in the future,

484
00:28:31.220 --> 00:28:33.950
that's all you're gonna be
encountering in the future.

485
00:28:33.950 --> 00:28:38.280
So at least now you have good solid
foundation in terms of networking

486
00:28:38.280 --> 00:28:39.420
fundamentals.

487
00:28:39.420 --> 00:28:43.410
You understand how the networking
devices work which is great okay?

488
00:28:43.410 --> 00:28:47.050
But now as the networking
continues to evolve and

489
00:28:47.050 --> 00:28:53.040
change you too are going to need to pick
up more and new skills along your way.

490
00:28:53.040 --> 00:28:56.290
A CCNA is great achievement,
don't get me wrong.

491
00:28:56.290 --> 00:28:58.280
But at the same time,

492
00:28:58.280 --> 00:29:02.120
you actually have to understand that
all of networking is changing again.

493
00:29:02.120 --> 00:29:05.520
And so that means you too will
also have to adapt and overcome.

494
00:29:05.520 --> 00:29:06.490
>> Great advice Ronnie.

495
00:29:06.490 --> 00:29:07.170
Great show.

496
00:29:07.170 --> 00:29:08.560
Thank you so very much.

497
00:29:08.560 --> 00:29:10.590
And you know,
a good IT pro is always learning and

498
00:29:10.590 --> 00:29:13.650
that's what Ronnie's telling us, we're
always learning, we're always evolving.

499
00:29:13.650 --> 00:29:17.150
Make sure you watch every single
episode of CCNA routing and

500
00:29:17.150 --> 00:29:21.240
switching exam 200-105 you're
gonna be glad that you did.

501
00:29:21.240 --> 00:29:24.850
And in the course library where you're
gonna be there's thousands of other videos

502
00:29:24.850 --> 00:29:27.940
that will help you continue to grow,
and learn, and go further.

503
00:29:27.940 --> 00:29:29.050
Check them out as well.

504
00:29:29.050 --> 00:29:33.340
And tell everybody you know about IT Pro
TV, you know IT Pro TV is binge worthy.

505
00:29:33.340 --> 00:29:34.970
Thanks for watching I'm Zach Memos.

506
00:29:34.970 --> 00:29:35.670
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

507
00:29:35.670 --> 00:29:37.401
>> And we will see you soon.

508
00:29:37.401 --> 00:29:43.265
[MUSIC].

509
00:29:43.265 --> 00:29:46.100
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review of the basic tools used to troubleshoot end-to-end connectivity.  The guys demonstrate the use of ping, extended ping and traceroute to demonstrate their purpose and use.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot End-to-End Connectivity
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.197 --> 00:00:02.774
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.774 --> 00:00:05.990
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.990 --> 00:00:11.621
[SOUND] You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.621 --> 00:00:16.760
Hello and thank you for watching ITProTV,
helping you learn everywhere you go.

5
00:00:16.760 --> 00:00:20.852
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue
on to CCNA Routing and Switching,

6
00:00:20.852 --> 00:00:26.080
Exam 200-105, we're gonna troubleshoot
end-to-end connectivity, yes we are.

7
00:00:26.080 --> 00:00:28.790
And the person who's gonna help us do
that is the one and only Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:28.790 --> 00:00:30.010
Ronnie, good to see you sir.

9
00:00:30.010 --> 00:00:34.160
Good to see you too Zach, as we continue
on in our CCNA Routing and Switching Show,

10
00:00:34.160 --> 00:00:37.950
we are now taking a look at that
idea of end-to-end connectivity and

11
00:00:37.950 --> 00:00:40.220
troubleshooting on layer three.

12
00:00:40.220 --> 00:00:44.232
Now we've gone through a lot of this
already during our entire series where

13
00:00:44.232 --> 00:00:46.971
we've been using ping a lot
of times to make sure and

14
00:00:46.971 --> 00:00:48.901
verify that we have connectivity.

15
00:00:48.901 --> 00:00:51.804
It's probably the tool that I run
most often than anything else.

16
00:00:51.804 --> 00:00:53.726
When I start configuring devices and

17
00:00:53.726 --> 00:00:57.580
verifying their connectivity
that is what we're trying to do.

18
00:00:57.580 --> 00:01:00.540
But the goal is not just to make
sure that the devices are actually

19
00:01:00.540 --> 00:01:01.610
talking to one another.

20
00:01:01.610 --> 00:01:05.130
But it is to also get the idea
of end to end connectivity.

21
00:01:05.130 --> 00:01:09.380
So if you break down the idea of
troubleshooting end-to-end connectivity,

22
00:01:09.380 --> 00:01:13.070
one it means every device along
that path has to be connected.

23
00:01:13.070 --> 00:01:14.676
And that's what ping helps us to do.

24
00:01:14.676 --> 00:01:19.591
Ping also verifies for us the very fact
that if I can ping from the source all

25
00:01:19.591 --> 00:01:24.207
the way through the destination,
then the path is also okay as well.

26
00:01:24.207 --> 00:01:28.931
The only thing that ping really doesn't
show me then is where it goes along

27
00:01:28.931 --> 00:01:31.080
that particular path.

28
00:01:31.080 --> 00:01:34.160
So we're also gonna end up taking,
we've got trace route.

29
00:01:34.160 --> 00:01:38.980
Trace route will actually tell me the path
that those pings will end up taking on

30
00:01:38.980 --> 00:01:43.350
this journey from the source to the
ultimate destination that it needs to go.

31
00:01:44.410 --> 00:01:50.040
So those are pretty much the two different
protocols that we're looking at as well.

32
00:01:50.040 --> 00:01:54.210
Now when you start thinking about going,
haven't we ran these utilities before?

33
00:01:54.210 --> 00:01:56.180
We did.
We've run them through all the shows, so

34
00:01:56.180 --> 00:02:02.180
this particular episode is more of
just a basic review of those commands,

35
00:02:02.180 --> 00:02:04.650
and just trying to show you some of
the options you may not have run before.

36
00:02:04.650 --> 00:02:07.430
So that's what we want to
jump into as we get started.

37
00:02:08.540 --> 00:02:09.720
So let's go ahead and do so.

38
00:02:09.720 --> 00:02:12.920
Let's take a look at lab and
this will help us out as we get started.

39
00:02:12.920 --> 00:02:16.900
So make sure that you get into your own
practice labs there, once you do that

40
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:21.720
you are going to get into Interconnecting
Cisco Networking Devices ICND@ version 3.

41
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:25.410
Troubleshoot Basic Layer 3
End-to-End Connectivity Issues.

42
00:02:25.410 --> 00:02:28.300
Now on this lab, I've actually
had a couple of different times,

43
00:02:28.300 --> 00:02:30.480
where it's been a little bit trying.

44
00:02:30.480 --> 00:02:34.030
Because the lab did not load
the way that it needed to.

45
00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:38.430
So if you are finding out where the lab
stuff are not lining up, it's not that

46
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:42.070
they're designing it to make sure that
you can, that everything is perfect.

47
00:02:42.070 --> 00:02:45.340
But they normally want to make sure
that you can get through the lab.

48
00:02:45.340 --> 00:02:48.210
Sometimes you'll come to a stop and
it's like there's nothing that I'm

49
00:02:48.210 --> 00:02:50.640
trouble shooting that's helping
me to get through the lab.

50
00:02:50.640 --> 00:02:53.860
It might mean that one of
the configurations didn't load correctly.

51
00:02:53.860 --> 00:02:58.180
And when that happens you don't
have the ability at that point,

52
00:02:58.180 --> 00:02:59.700
maybe to go behind the scenes and

53
00:02:59.700 --> 00:03:03.800
actually kind of realize what should
actually be there, but you may.

54
00:03:03.800 --> 00:03:07.510
But even at that point, there may be other
things that have actually been configured

55
00:03:07.510 --> 00:03:08.650
that may be wrong.

56
00:03:08.650 --> 00:03:10.510
So what I do is I normally
just go ahead and

57
00:03:10.510 --> 00:03:14.480
I reboot the entire lab,
bring it back up and it should work.

58
00:03:14.480 --> 00:03:17.830
So one of the first things we want to do
when we start taking a look at the idea of

59
00:03:17.830 --> 00:03:23.740
troubleshooting, well I'm gonna actually
ping from NYEDGE1 over to my server.

60
00:03:23.740 --> 00:03:27.230
I've gotta verify that,
that lab server is up and running.

61
00:03:27.230 --> 00:03:30.630
And according to the green
lights they are up and running.

62
00:03:30.630 --> 00:03:31.970
And you can see right here on the screen,
and

63
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:33.830
I've already done this just to make sure.

64
00:03:33.830 --> 00:03:37.775
Because I've actually had it
kinda fail a couple of times too.

65
00:03:37.775 --> 00:03:42.080
192.168.16.10, verify that
we have connectivity, okay.

66
00:03:42.080 --> 00:03:45.750
When we get the five pings in a row,
that's what we normally see.

67
00:03:45.750 --> 00:03:50.480
So remember that in Windows land, you'll
normally see four replies that come back.

68
00:03:50.480 --> 00:03:52.930
In Cisco, they send you five.

69
00:03:52.930 --> 00:03:55.280
Not a big difference,
but at the same time,

70
00:03:55.280 --> 00:03:58.530
you might be wondering why
is this what we want to see.

71
00:03:58.530 --> 00:04:01.140
Because remember that as we see this,
right?

72
00:04:01.140 --> 00:04:04.880
It actually is kind of a percentage
gauge for us at this point.

73
00:04:04.880 --> 00:04:07.085
So if we are missing one ping,

74
00:04:07.085 --> 00:04:10.280
well we know that 80% of
traffic is getting through.

75
00:04:10.280 --> 00:04:11.700
It kind of divided it up nice and easily.

76
00:04:11.700 --> 00:04:13.557
Windows just said,
we'll do it in quarters.

77
00:04:13.557 --> 00:04:17.098
You know, 25% getting through, 50%, 75%.

78
00:04:17.098 --> 00:04:20.529
Ciso again, actually does it
a little bit more where they say,

79
00:04:20.529 --> 00:04:25.322
let's do this by 20% because they realize
something, normally a lot of time that you

80
00:04:25.322 --> 00:04:29.728
haven't been issuing pings before,
the first time that it actually connects,

81
00:04:29.728 --> 00:04:32.953
you might see it drop,
which turns into a period instead.

82
00:04:32.953 --> 00:04:35.577
And that's because it's having to do ARP.

83
00:04:35.577 --> 00:04:39.225
If you see something else that's
stranger in its response,

84
00:04:39.225 --> 00:04:43.871
such as the idea of the letter U or A also
coming up with periods in-between and

85
00:04:43.871 --> 00:04:48.808
exclamation points too, it means that
there's something that's absolutely,

86
00:04:48.808 --> 00:04:51.551
100% not configured correctly, okay?

87
00:04:51.551 --> 00:04:54.353
When you see a combination of letters,
specially U,

88
00:04:54.353 --> 00:04:58.584
it's probably not a good thing, and that
means something else needs to be done,

89
00:04:58.584 --> 00:05:01.031
before you can verify and
test successfully.

90
00:05:01.031 --> 00:05:04.108
What we always wanna see of
course is just pings, okay?

91
00:05:04.108 --> 00:05:07.220
Never this combination,
never intermittently.

92
00:05:07.220 --> 00:05:09.089
We all wanna make sure that we see these.

93
00:05:09.089 --> 00:05:12.600
The more drops that you're getting
in between with periods in between,

94
00:05:12.600 --> 00:05:15.030
it tends to show you that
something else is wrong.

95
00:05:15.030 --> 00:05:17.620
A lot of times it's
you're dropping packets.

96
00:05:17.620 --> 00:05:20.158
And that could be
indicating a flopping NIC.

97
00:05:20.158 --> 00:05:22.898
It might be happening
somewhere along the line, or

98
00:05:22.898 --> 00:05:25.780
device is actually acting intermittently.

99
00:05:25.780 --> 00:05:28.210
You may be able to also
trace that as well.

100
00:05:28.210 --> 00:05:31.820
Now you not always do it
with just five pings, okay?

101
00:05:31.820 --> 00:05:35.150
So sometimes you actually need
to issue more than five pings.

102
00:05:35.150 --> 00:05:38.540
Most of the time when we start doing that
we don't know exactly how to do that so

103
00:05:38.540 --> 00:05:40.689
we'll take a look at how
we get that done as well.

104
00:05:40.689 --> 00:05:44.717
All right so let's verify that we
know the difference between this and

105
00:05:44.717 --> 00:05:46.773
when the device is not responding.

106
00:05:46.773 --> 00:05:49.841
So I'm gonna go to NYACCESS1 and

107
00:05:49.841 --> 00:05:54.560
in my NYACCESS1 I'm going
to simulate a failure.

108
00:05:56.840 --> 00:05:58.502
By simply turning off an interface.

109
00:05:58.502 --> 00:06:02.408
So if I go into interface at a 0/1 and

110
00:06:02.408 --> 00:06:07.300
I shut down the actual
interface at this point.

111
00:06:08.450 --> 00:06:12.564
Now that should be good, I'm waiting for
the syslog messages to tell me that

112
00:06:12.564 --> 00:06:15.025
everything is actually
what we want it to be.

113
00:06:15.025 --> 00:06:21.671
Which is that it's shut down then
I scroll back up here and NYEDGE1.

114
00:06:24.062 --> 00:06:30.123
And inside NYEDGE1,
I again ping 192.168.16.10.

115
00:06:30.123 --> 00:06:33.951
I know that's the device in between me and
16.10,

116
00:06:33.951 --> 00:06:38.090
now notice that I'm getting
this result instead.

117
00:06:38.090 --> 00:06:44.760
Dropping one or two like I said right at
the beginning, it may indicate something.

118
00:06:44.760 --> 00:06:46.120
One normally not so much.

119
00:06:46.120 --> 00:06:48.410
You don't really care too much
about that at the beginning.

120
00:06:48.410 --> 00:06:52.442
But if you drop two that begins to
get a little more disconcerting.

121
00:06:52.442 --> 00:06:56.143
Drop three, something else is delaying
something else is happening, and

122
00:06:56.143 --> 00:06:59.743
you drop all of them it absolutely
means that something is wrong, okay?

123
00:06:59.743 --> 00:07:03.376
So for us we just simulated that failure,
let's go ahead and turn that back on.

124
00:07:03.376 --> 00:07:06.303
So that we know that we're
actually doing okay.

125
00:07:06.303 --> 00:07:11.933
So a no shut down there, and
we are back and ready to go.

126
00:07:11.933 --> 00:07:17.169
All right, so now that we've got that us
verify once again that everything is good,

127
00:07:17.169 --> 00:07:22.108
so this is what you end up doing right, is
that you verify if something is wrong or

128
00:07:22.108 --> 00:07:23.471
it's right, okay?

129
00:07:23.471 --> 00:07:25.908
Then if it's wrong you have to go and
try and

130
00:07:25.908 --> 00:07:29.648
figure out where along that path
something did end up happening.

131
00:07:29.648 --> 00:07:34.308
And so for us, let's say it was
on NYACCESS1, we fixed, and

132
00:07:34.308 --> 00:07:35.930
then we try it again.

133
00:07:38.470 --> 00:07:42.582
So it's always this constant state
between the idea of actually fixing or

134
00:07:42.582 --> 00:07:44.920
coming back up, and there you go, okay?

135
00:07:44.920 --> 00:07:49.134
So you can see that this time it was
a little bit slower in responding,

136
00:07:49.134 --> 00:07:52.870
because I brought it back up and
had to do the ARP again.

137
00:07:52.870 --> 00:07:56.340
And in that second one, a little bit slow,
but it picked up on the other three.

138
00:07:56.340 --> 00:07:58.842
If you're ever not sure Just run it again,
hit the Up arrow,

139
00:07:58.842 --> 00:08:00.180
you'll be able to run it again.

140
00:08:00.180 --> 00:08:02.845
Not in our lab interface here,
we can't do that.

141
00:08:02.845 --> 00:08:05.640
We just have to type it in again,
is what we'd have to do, okay?

142
00:08:05.640 --> 00:08:08.892
All right, so
now that we've actually enabled that,

143
00:08:08.892 --> 00:08:12.579
what if I actually needed to verify
this for a bit of time more?

144
00:08:12.579 --> 00:08:14.847
Well, you can always go ahead and

145
00:08:14.847 --> 00:08:18.330
issue more pings than just
the standard five here.

146
00:08:18.330 --> 00:08:24.267
If I do 19216816.10 I can tell it
how many pings I want it to repeat.

147
00:08:24.267 --> 00:08:27.249
Now, if you're ever not
sure what you can you do,

148
00:08:27.249 --> 00:08:29.890
you can do a question mark like this.

149
00:08:29.890 --> 00:08:32.050
And now notice that after the ping,

150
00:08:32.050 --> 00:08:37.034
and of course the destination that I
want to ping here, there it goes, okay?

151
00:08:37.034 --> 00:08:39.661
So when you take a look here,

152
00:08:39.661 --> 00:08:45.352
you can actually see that I can
choose data, df-bit as well,

153
00:08:45.352 --> 00:08:51.050
repeat size source too, time out,
toss as well as validate.

154
00:08:52.080 --> 00:08:55.865
This point here, let's go ahead and
do ping 19216816.10.

155
00:08:55.865 --> 00:09:00.980
We'll tell it that I
want to send 100 of them.

156
00:09:03.030 --> 00:09:06.123
We'll do something like that, and
there you go, there's 100 pings.

157
00:09:06.123 --> 00:09:08.350
Notice it actually took 100 out of 100.

158
00:09:08.350 --> 00:09:12.980
For those of you that are now watching
this as maybe towards the very

159
00:09:12.980 --> 00:09:16.628
end of the entire series,
when we did HSRP, right?

160
00:09:16.628 --> 00:09:19.340
The hot desk standby router protocol,

161
00:09:19.340 --> 00:09:24.942
we issued 10,000 pings shutting one
of the routers down on the interface.

162
00:09:24.942 --> 00:09:28.400
Showed where the other one picked back
up and it just dropped like one or

163
00:09:28.400 --> 00:09:31.560
two pings out of 1,000 is what
we actually ended up doing.

164
00:09:31.560 --> 00:09:35.508
So that's pretty good cuz that's less
than 1% or so, or right around 1%.

165
00:09:35.508 --> 00:09:39.750
So you got to actually kind of think about
that when you start seeing that, okay?

166
00:09:39.750 --> 00:09:42.557
So that's something else
that can also be done.

167
00:09:42.557 --> 00:09:46.690
Now that's not our only option,
though, in terms of pings.

168
00:09:46.690 --> 00:09:49.079
The one that we like using sometimes,
right?

169
00:09:49.079 --> 00:09:53.810
Let's say that we wanted to verify and
see what else could we do.

170
00:09:53.810 --> 00:09:58.252
Well, on this router, right,
on NYEDGE1 there's two interfaces.

171
00:09:58.252 --> 00:10:00.810
Show ip interface brief.

172
00:10:02.990 --> 00:10:07.879
And what I want to do is I want
to actually be able to ping

173
00:10:07.879 --> 00:10:12.784
16.10, but
I want to ping it from this address.

174
00:10:12.784 --> 00:10:16.160
Now go okay, no big deal.

175
00:10:16.160 --> 00:10:21.260
Well, it is a big deal cuz if you just
type in ping and the destination address,

176
00:10:21.260 --> 00:10:26.621
it's gonna ping it off of whatever address
is closest to the destination, okay?

177
00:10:26.621 --> 00:10:28.620
So that is gonna be this address.

178
00:10:28.620 --> 00:10:33.873
So by default,
when I did the ping 19216816.10,

179
00:10:33.873 --> 00:10:39.032
the source address on
that ping was 19216816.1.

180
00:10:39.032 --> 00:10:45.350
So how do I get that change to 17214.1
as being the source instead, okay?

181
00:10:45.350 --> 00:10:49.003
And you can see that right here
once again if you take a look.

182
00:10:49.003 --> 00:10:53.030
Notice it says echoes right
here as it's doing it.

183
00:10:53.030 --> 00:10:57.210
It is actually pinging it from
the first address is what we see.

184
00:10:57.210 --> 00:10:58.600
So how do we change that?

185
00:11:00.933 --> 00:11:02.423
Let me see if I can scroll that down so

00:11:02.423 --> 00:11:05.450
I don't get too much
information on the screen here.

00:11:05.450 --> 00:11:08.212
Well, at this point you can type in ping,
and

this ends up in what

The protocol that we're gonna

00:11:28.214 --> 00:11:30.872
Data gram size,
we again can pick the size.

Timeout in two seconds,

And now notice I can change

Now it doesn't mean you can actually

00:11:51.799 --> 00:11:55.930

00:11:55.930 --> 00:11:59.410
So from here I could do 17216,
14, excuse me, 14.0.1.

00:11:59.410 --> 00:12:07.170
Type of service we're gonna leave alone.

00:12:07.170 --> 00:12:11.662
Everything else we're gonna leave alone,

00:12:11.662 --> 00:12:16.606
And now you can see that the packet

00:12:16.606 --> 00:12:20.325
address instead of 17214.0.1.

00:12:20.325 --> 00:12:24.202
That means it left,

00:12:24.202 --> 00:12:28.694
actually from the interface of 172140.1,

00:12:28.694 --> 00:12:35.430
going out 19216816.1,
all the way to 16.10 from this point,

00:12:35.430 --> 00:12:39.840
and it showed us that

00:12:39.840 --> 00:12:44.210
This is a good way to verify that your

00:12:44.210 --> 00:12:45.140

00:12:45.140 --> 00:12:48.788
Because on your router,

00:12:48.788 --> 00:12:52.884

00:12:52.884 --> 00:12:55.452
you should be able to ping

00:12:55.452 --> 00:12:57.911
From any other connected interfaces

218
00:12:57.911 --> 00:13:01.140
instead of you going well, let me go

00:13:01.140 --> 00:13:02.858
You can just do it from right here,

00:13:02.858 --> 00:13:06.950
ping from that other interface to be able
to verify that you have good connectivity

221
00:13:06.950 --> 00:13:11.164
from every other network that's actually

00:13:11.164 --> 00:13:13.632

223
00:13:13.632 --> 00:13:17.260
So that's the idea of using

224
00:13:17.260 --> 00:13:20.610
Now, you can take a look and
do some of the other things but for

225
00:13:20.610 --> 00:13:25.279
us that's normally we end up using it for,
the test for something like connectivity

226
00:13:25.279 --> 00:13:29.252
there, at least even in layer three or
the routing table of two, okay?

00:13:29.252 --> 00:13:32.800
So we're left with one
thing at this point, okay?

00:13:32.800 --> 00:13:36.443
We know now that we can test for

00:13:36.443 --> 00:13:40.431

00:13:40.431 --> 00:13:43.349
So this is where it becomes

00:13:43.349 --> 00:13:47.260
even in our lab it's not that big

00:13:47.260 --> 00:13:48.979
But for us across the Internet,

00:13:52.234 --> 00:13:55.550
So let's go ahead and

00:13:55.550 --> 00:14:01.061
We're gonna gonna go to NYWAN1, NYWAN1,

00:14:02.844 --> 00:14:07.349
And from NYWAN1, I'm going to use

00:14:07.349 --> 00:14:12.790

00:14:12.790 --> 00:14:14.882
Now, before I issue that command,

I'm gonna make sure you actually

00:14:18.732 --> 00:14:22.034
So that means it's actually

00:14:22.034 --> 00:14:27.814
So from NYWAN1, and I'm gonna actually

00:14:27.814 --> 00:14:33.714
other interfaces over where somewhere,

00:14:33.714 --> 00:14:36.803
There it is, 172140.3,

I was like I know I saw it but

00:14:40.800 --> 00:14:43.597
So in theory it should

00:14:46.098 --> 00:14:48.905
Now remember that when we talk about

00:14:48.905 --> 00:14:49.820

00:14:49.820 --> 00:14:52.096
In other words it hops along the path.

So for us it's actually only one hop, even

this is not acting as

00:15:01.430 --> 00:15:06.197

00:15:06.197 --> 00:15:09.874

00:15:09.874 --> 00:15:13.935
Let me go back over to NYLAN1.

00:15:18.138 --> 00:15:22.570
Now let's issue our trace route, and

00:15:22.570 --> 00:15:25.461
Now this can take a bit of time,

00:15:27.680 --> 00:15:31.410

So here notice that it

00:15:34.012 --> 00:15:37.639
we're seeing a number 1 over

00:15:37.639 --> 00:15:42.174
it's giving me this asterisk which means

00:15:42.174 --> 00:15:45.752

00:15:45.752 --> 00:15:53.063
I know that that's actually the,
Interface on NYEDGE1, is what it's doing.

00:15:53.063 --> 00:15:55.385
And then it showed me the second hop,

00:15:55.385 --> 00:15:58.650
17214.0.3.

00:15:58.650 --> 00:15:59.370
Is what it's showing me.

So it's actually showing

I guess I had to hit that

00:16:05.020 --> 00:16:09.000
So this is where I can see

00:16:09.000 --> 00:16:11.130
where I might experience issues.

00:16:11.130 --> 00:16:14.666
Notice it left NYWAN1 here,

00:16:14.666 --> 00:16:18.939
it hit this interface on NYEDGE1,

00:16:18.939 --> 00:16:22.624
Then the next hop along

00:16:22.624 --> 00:16:28.140
which was this interface right here,

275
00:16:28.140 --> 00:16:32.844
What you're generally looking for, right,
is that as you start seeing these,

00:16:32.844 --> 00:16:37.356
wherever you stop receiving information,

277
00:16:37.356 --> 00:16:42.640
You're gonna look into the device before

00:16:42.640 --> 00:16:45.451
And you're gonna begin your

00:16:45.451 --> 00:16:47.650
is what you're gonna end

00:16:47.650 --> 00:16:54.040
All right, now let's set up one other
thing for us as we also do this too, okay?

00:16:54.040 --> 00:16:58.370
Now, why did it end up going through 16.1?

00:16:58.370 --> 00:17:02.486
We have two routers that are actually

00:17:02.486 --> 00:17:07.908
Let's take a look, show ip route, And

00:17:07.908 --> 00:17:12.045
if I take a look at the id

00:17:12.045 --> 00:17:15.897
you can see right here
where it says gateway of,

00:17:15.897 --> 00:17:20.839
oops let mes scroll up a little bit,
Enter a couple of times.

00:17:23.369 --> 00:17:28.605
There we go, okay, so
the gateway of last resort

00:17:28.605 --> 00:17:36.780
is 172.16.1 to any network

00:17:36.780 --> 00:17:38.990
So what if I wanted to change that?

00:17:38.990 --> 00:17:41.870
Well, that's actually fairly simple for

00:17:43.300 --> 00:17:47.510
So first thing I want to do is get

And then let's get rid of

ip route.

Let's get rid off the default route and

00:18:03.640 --> 00:18:09.387
192.168.16.1, and

00:18:09.387 --> 00:18:15.132
then let's change this to ip route

00:18:15.132 --> 00:18:20.300
192.168.16.2.

298
00:18:20.300 --> 00:18:25.080
So that should make it hit instead
NYEDGE2 to be able to do this.

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:35.186
So now if we do a traceroute,
all as one word,

00:18:35.186 --> 00:18:41.115
172.16 14, I'll just do 16.0.3.

00:18:43.170 --> 00:18:46.940
And we should just give

00:18:46.940 --> 00:18:49.970
And if it actually takes too long,

But the goal is the same thing,

00:18:52.505 --> 00:18:54.490
did this actually go

00:18:54.490 --> 00:18:59.648
So in other words, if I modify the routing

00:18:59.648 --> 00:19:05.160
I say that I want it to take, and I can

00:19:05.160 --> 00:19:09.530
So me manipulating it,

00:19:24.141 --> 00:19:28.948
And that is because more than likely, the

00:19:28.948 --> 00:19:31.830

00:19:31.830 --> 00:19:34.430
So that's why we're actually

00:19:34.430 --> 00:19:38.512
If this happens where you are not

You should be able to do a Shift+Ctrl+6

[LAUGH] If your command actually works,

00:19:57.601 --> 00:20:04.183
Okay, so for us here, Ctrl+Shift+6 is

00:20:13.150 --> 00:20:16.380
Okay, so when you start taking a look

Now, are there not any others,

00:20:22.620 --> 00:20:25.965
But these are by far the most

00:20:25.965 --> 00:20:27.604
You would also do it differently,

Well, you might say,

Well, what if you wanted

00:20:37.270 --> 00:20:42.760
So you don't have to actually verify that

00:20:42.760 --> 00:20:45.010
But if you want to do Telnet or SSH,

that verifies connectivity as

00:20:50.075 --> 00:20:52.833
Wanna to verify the idea of UDP,

00:20:52.833 --> 00:20:57.348
you find a protocol that works with UDP,

00:20:57.348 --> 00:20:59.868
And remember that if you're

00:20:59.868 --> 00:21:03.210
not every device accepts the idea

00:21:03.210 --> 00:21:05.535
So you may have to use

00:21:05.535 --> 00:21:06.960
Normally, the best verification and

00:21:06.960 --> 00:21:11.550
especially going across the Internet is

00:21:11.550 --> 00:21:14.520

00:21:14.520 --> 00:21:18.320
If it works, then you know that you have,

00:21:18.320 --> 00:21:19.010
If it doesn't,

you may wanna begin troubleshooting

And determine whether or not it's actually

If it's your router,

00:21:35.440 --> 00:21:37.839
